Full_Mask_comment: This line is preceded in some MSS. by the following verses, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” They are not found in Med., Rom., Gud., or the Verona fragments (Pal. and the fragments of Vat. and St. Gall seem to fail here), and the only MS. in Ribbeck's list which contains them (the Berne MS. No. 172) has them written in the margin by a later hand. They appear to have existed in the time of Servius and of the Pseudo-Donatus, who say that Nisus the grammarian had heard a story of their having been expunged by Tueca and Varius; on which Heyne remarks, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The external evidence of such a story it is impossible to estimate, but its existence suspiciously indicates that the lines were felt to require apology. Those who speak of them as an introduction to the poem, forget that if genuine they are an integral part of the first sentence; and that it is, to say the least, remarkable that the exordium should be so constructed as to be at once interwoven with the context, and yet capable of removal without detriment to the construction, just at the point which forms a much better commencement. The words ‘MASK MASK’ are quoted by Martial, 8. 56., 19. 14., 185. 2, and Auson. Epig. 137. 1, evidently as a real commencement of the Aeneid; while Ovid, Trist. 2. 533, and Persius, 1. 96, quote ‘MASK MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as important and independent words, which they cease to be the moment ‘MASK’ is viewed in connexion with the words supposed to precede it. Virg. himself, 9. 777, has (of the poet Clytins) “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Comp. also MASK , Prop. 3. 26. 63, which point the same way. Macrob. Sat. 5. 2. quotes ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as part of the first verse of the Aeneid. On the other hand Priscian 910 P cites ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as Virg.'s. Henry's view that ‘MASK MASK’ is happily contrasted with ‘MASK MASK’ (comp. MASK ) seems to be favoured by the structure of the sentence, and may very possibly have been present to the mind of the author of these lines; but it clearly was not present to the minds of those who quoted ‘MASK’ by itself as war . Tastes may differ as to the rival commencements, on which see Henry in loco, and on 2. 247; but it may be suggested that Virg. would scarcely in his first sentence have divided the attention of the reader between himself and his hero by saying, in effect, that the poet who wrote the Eclogues and the Georgics, sings the hero who founded Rome . Wagn. and Forb., however, as well as Henry, consider the lines as genuine; and they have been imitated by Spenser in the opening of the Faery Queene, and Milton in the opening of Paradise Regained.

this is an imitation of the opening of the Odyssey, MASK MASK MASK MASK . MASK . MASK . It may also be taken from the first line of the Cyclic poem of the Epigoni, preserved by the Schol. on MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK . It is followed by all the other Roman writers of epic poetry, Lucan, Flaccus, Statius, and, above all, Silius, the most faithful copier of Virg., with a unanimity which strongly supports the view taken in the preceding note. The words are not a hendiadys, but give first the character of the subject and then the subject itself. ‘MASK’ may have been intended to suggest, though it does not express, a contrast between this and Virg.'s previous poems.—In commencing with ‘MASK’ he has followed his own example in the Georgics, rather than that of Homer, who at once invokes the Muse; and the Latin Epic writers have followed Virg. The earlier commentators have found a difficulty in reconciling ‘MASK’ with Antenor's previous migration (below, vv. 242 foll.), and suggest that Aeneas had first reached Italy proper, though Antenor had previously reached Venetia. On the other hand, Heyne and Wagn. make ‘MASK’ equivalent to ‘MASK MASK’ thus weakening a word which from its position and its occurrence in the first line of the poem must be emphatic. The more obvious sense is that Aeneas is so called without reference to Antenor, as the founder of the great Trojan empire in Italy.

a mixture of modal and instrum. abl., as in 4. 696., 6. 449, 466, &c. Here it seems to go with ‘MASK MASK’ though it might go with ‘MASK MASK’ comp. 10. 67. Perhaps the force may be “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” a glorious and heaven-sent fugitive. So MASK , comp. by Weidner, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” For the poetic accus. ‘MASK MASK’ without the preposition, see Madv. § 232, obs. 4. The MSS. are divided between ‘MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ and perhaps ‘MASK MASK’ The last, however, though adopted by Burm. and Heyne, and approved by Heins., seems to rest solely on the authority of Med., which has ‘MASK’ (corrected into ‘MASK’), with a mark of erasure after the word. ‘MASK’ is found in the Verona fragm., and is supported by quotations in Terentianus Maurus and Diomedes, and in single MSS. of Priscian, Censorinus, and Servius in artem Donati. ‘MASK’ is found in Rom., Gud., and probably most other MSS., and is supported by quotations in Macrobius, Gellius, Marius Victorinus, Pompeius, the Schol. on Lucan, most MSS. of Priscian, and one of Censorinus. Servius mentions both readings, saying, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is supported by 4. 236: but the synizesis, though not unexampled (comp. 5. 269., 6. 33, and see on MASK ), is perhaps awkward, especially in the second line of the poem, and the imitation in Prop. 3. 26. 64, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” is in favour of the form ‘MASK’ Juv. 12. 71 has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though there as in Prop. the quadrisyllabic form might be introduced and explained by synizesis. On the whole, I have preferred ‘MASK’ believing the form to be possible in itself (comp. “MASK MASK” “MASK MASK” “MASK” &c.), and more probable in this instance; the modern editors however are generally for ‘MASK MASK’ Lachmann on MASK speaks doubtfully. The epithet which belonged to the place after the foundation of the city by Aeneas is given to it here, as in 4. 236, by a natural anticipation at the time of his landing.

The imitation of the exordium of the Odyssey continues, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ being modelled on MASK MASK . . MASK MASK MASK . . MASK : ‘MASK MASK’ as so often in Virg., standing for the Homeric MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ &c., used to be pointed as a separate sentence; it is however evidently constructed with ‘MASK MASK’ so that ‘MASK’ is virtually pleonastic. Comp. 5. 457., 6. 593., 9. 479. Here it appears rhetorically to be equal to ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is naturally transferred from wanderings by sea to wanderings by land. In such passages as vv. 332, 668, we see the point of transition. So 5. 627, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

“MASK MASK MASK MASK” 8. 11. ‘MASK’ may be taken either as “MASK MASK MASK MASK” or as “MASK MASK” as in v. 568., 6. 766, &c. The latter seems more probable. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ denote the three ascending stages of the empire which sprang from Aeneas, Lavinium, Alba, and Rome . Comp. 12. 823, foll., which is a good commentary on the present passage. ‘MASK MASK’ probably means not ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but the senate, or rather the noble houses of Alba, of which the Julii were one.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

is not unfrequently used where we should be content with the sing., e. g. v. 414., 2. 105., 3. 32., 6. 710, the last of which will illustrate the epexegetical clause ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is appropriate, as the Muses were connected with memory: comp. 7. 645, and see note on MASK .—There are various ways of taking ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Some think there is a change of construction, and that “MASK MASK MASK” or something like it, should have followed; so that Virgil should have imitated Homer, Il. 1. 8, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK ; But this, as Heyne remarks, though not unexampled, would be a singular piece of loose writing so early in the poem, and would moreover involve the inconsistency of first saying that it was Juno, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ and then asking the Muse what god it was. Others make ‘MASK’ nearly equivalent to ‘MASK MASK’ citing 2. 123, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but even supposing that ‘MASK’ in this sense might be taken distributively, which the passage above quoted does not prove, ‘MASK’ would scarcely be appropriate to ‘MASK’ in this sense, while the words frequently occur in conjunction in the sense of outraged majesty. Comp. 2. 183, Hor. Epod. 15. 3, and Macleane's note. Heyne accepts Serv.'s proposal of separating ‘MASK’ from ‘MASK MASK’ and taking it in the sense of “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK” which would be extremely harsh. It remains then, with Wagn., to regard the expression as equivalent to “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” referring it to the cases already noticed on MASK , where the pronoun or pronominal adjective stands for its corresponding adverb. Thus the negative answer to ‘MASK MASK MASK’ would be “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Or we may say that ‘MASK MASK’ alone would stand for “MASK MASK” (see Madv. § 426), and that in such a construction the question could hardly be asked otherwise than by making the interrogative pronoun agree with the noun. No charge of impiety strictly could be brought against Aeneas, but there might be ‘MASK MASK’ such as are mentioned vv. 23—28, which impelled Juno to persecute even one renowned for piety.
see on MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The misfortunes are regarded as a destined circle which Aeneas goes through.

(6. 403) characterizes the hero, as MASK does Ulysses in the commencement of the Odyssey. The contrast, however, between piety and sufferings is made in the case of Ulysses himself, Od. 1. 60 foll., 66 foll. ‘MASK’ includes the performance of all duties to gods, parents, kinsmen, friends, and country. “MASK MASK” is not uncommon in Cicero; see Forc.
It is difficult to say whether ‘MASK MASK’ is a dat. with an ellipsis of the verb substantive or the ablative.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ instead of Rome . The dative, as in 8. 65., 10. 203. For the pronoun taking the gender of the following substantive, see Madv. § 313.

is similarly used 6. 882. “MASK MASK MASK” 4. 652., 11. 701. Med. 2 m. p. has ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ in that early age, long before it became the actual rival of Rome . ‘MASK’ determines the construction, the infinitive being the object of both verbs. ‘MASK’ is often followed by an infinitive, the subject being the same as the nominative to the verb, as “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Hor. 1 Ep. 10. 20, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Pers. 5. 139. ‘MASK MASK’ on the other hand, takes an accusative, as “MASK MASK MASK” These two constructions are united, the sentence ‘MASK MASK MASK’ standing in the relation of an ordinary infinitive to ‘MASK MASK’ and of an accusative to ‘MASK MASK’ Three MSS. give ‘MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK’ has been conjectured. Some have thought ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ spurious, on the strength of a notice of Serv., which really refers to v. 534 beiow.

2. 164, &c., MASK MASK , ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK’ The present infinitive, ‘MASK MASK’ denotes the event as existing in the designs of fate. ‘MASK MASK’ as in 10. 145. Gossrau, following a suggestion of Serv., thinks the ‘MASK’ is Scipio, which is very improbable, and besides makes ‘MASK MASK’ v. 21, inexplicable; and the same objection applies to Ladewig's more plausible explanation of ‘MASK’ as the great Trojan families among the Romans.
‘MASK MASK’ See on 7. 99. ‘MASK MASK’ as in 2. 652, &c. As might be expected, some MSS. have ‘MASK MASK’

In v. 235, where the expression is somewhat parallel, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” seems epexegetical of “MASK MASK” Serv. mentions that Probus marked this and the next line as doubtful; but it seems to have been merely a critical opinion. ‘MASK’ here seems to be equivalent to ‘MASK MASK’ as in Sil. 10. 573, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

like “MASK MASK” and “MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ being probably the dative, as ‘MASK’ seems to be 2. 325. But there is room for doubt in both instances. It is hard to fix the precise meaning of ‘MASK MASK’ The passage 3. 375, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” is equally obscure; and we are left to choose between the ideas of a cycle of events (which is recommended by “MASK MASK MASK” in the passage in A. 3), an urn in which lots are shaken, the threads of a spindle (which is the view of Serv.), and a book. I have returned to the common orthography ‘MASK MASK’ as being apparently the only one known to the MSS. of Virg.: but the word must be derived from “MASK” as “MASK” from “MASK” unless, deriving it from “MASK” we pronounce it as a trisyllable by synizesis. “MASK” on the other hand seems clearly to come from “MASK” like “MASK” from “MASK MASK” so that we must suppose a synizesis in MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

and ‘MASK’ are applied to the Trojan war, as contrasted with this new antipathy of Juno to the Trojans, caused by her anxiety for Carthage, as the former had been caused by her love for Argos. ‘MASK MASK’ adverbially, as in MASK .

The words from ‘MASK’ to ‘MASK’ are parenthetical. These ‘MASK MASK’ are distinguished from the ‘MASK MASK MASK’ in other words, from the ‘MASK’ themselves, the bitterness displayed in or produced by the war. Virg. had already, v. 24, suggested one cause in her love for Argos; but though this supplies a parallel to her present feeling, it scarcely accounts for its existence; so he goes back to show that her old quarrel with Troy had other grounds. ‘MASK’ is the pang, put for the affront. It is only in the sense of the affront that it can properly be joined with ‘MASK MASK MASK’ understood of being forgotten. So “MASK MASK” v. 9. Or if ‘MASK’ is taken in its ordinary sense, ‘MASK MASK’ will shift its meaning, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

‘MASK MASK MASK’ referring to the birth of Dardanus, who was the son of Jupiter by Electra, daughter of Atlas. The carrying off of Ganymede, who belonged to a later generation of the royal house of Troy , was a further provocation.

Virg. plunges “MASK MASK MASK MASK” as the commentators remark. See Introduction to this Book. The departure from Sicily closes Aeneas's narrative, 3. 715. Forb. takes ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ to mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ or of those who were MASK Sicily, comparing 11. 903, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but there the sense is determined by the context: and the common rendering, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is more natural, and equally good Latin. Comp. MASK. g. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Cic. Sull. 9. Generally, though not universally, where the noun MASK the gen. is a thing, the gen. is that of the object; and, MASK the present case, we more naturally think of the Trojans looking towards Sicily, than of Sicily looking towards the Trojans.

Heyne puts a comma after ‘MASK MASK’ which is the punctuation of Med., but MS. authority on such points is of little value. Wagn. omits the comma altogether, on the ground that ‘MASK’ belongs to both verbs; which of course it does, in sense; but in construction it must be taken with the one or the other, and it is obviously better taken with the former. Virg., in fact, is imitating Od. 5. 269, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , Ulysses's voyage there answering to Aeneas's here. ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ see note on MASK . “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 10. 214. “MASK MASK” (“MASK” neut. nom.) occurs Enn. A. 14. 1.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ with a derivative notion of secrecy. Comp. Aesch. Eum. 156, MASK — MASK MASK MASK MASK . On a comparison of MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” it is perhaps better to take ‘MASK’ closely with ‘MASK’ than, as the order might warrant, with ‘MASK MASK’

“MASK MASK MASK” says Serv., comparing v. 225 below and 2. 93. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as opposed to ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is to soliloquize, if the person is alone; to think or mutter, if the person is in company. It is the MASK MASK MASK MASK of Od. 5. 285, where Poseidon takes the part taken by Juno here. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ for this use of the accus. and infin. to denote indignation or surprise, see Madv. § 399. In Greek the article is not unfrequently prefixed to the infin. in this construction. ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ For one aspect of the word we may comp. 7. 310, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” for another, Hor. 1 Ep. 13. 11, “MASK MASK MASK”
MASK . As Henry remarks, it means not merely to turn way, but to turn back. Rom. originally and Gud. have ‘MASK MASK’

generally gives a reason (comp. vv. 59, 661 below, MASK , MASK , MASK ), sometimes with irony, and here with indignation.—The use of ‘MASK MASK’ which implies a negative answer, expresses incredulity that Pallas should have done what Juno cannot. Hom., Od. 1. 326, makes the minstrel sing to the suitors of the MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . But in Od. 3 and 4, where the return of the Greeks is described in detail, he says nothing of a general storm. Ajax, in Od. 4. 499, is shipwrecked, but saved on a rock, in spite of the enmity of Pallas, by Poseidon, who afterwards, provoked by his impious boast that he would escape in spite of the gods, cleaves the rock on which he is sitting, and drowns him. Aeschylus, like Virg., mentions a general storm, and implies (through the forebodings of Clytaemnestra) that it was the punishment of some impiety. The crime of Ajax is fixed by Lycophron and others to be insolence offered to Cassandra in the temple of Pallas. Virg. however merely mentions him among others in 2. 403, where Cassandra is dragged from sanctuary.
‘MASK MASK’ the crews, as distinguished from the ships. Forb. comp. Il. 14. 47, MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK .

So Tryphiodorus v. 650, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . I have placed a comma at ‘MASK MASK’ to show that ‘MASK’ is not to be taken with ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but that the second clause is distinct from and epexegetic of the first. Comp. v. 251 below, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” But it is hard to judge in cases like this, where it is a question of minute considerations. See on 3. 162. ‘MASK’ expresses the Homeric MASK , the infatuation which impels to crime. MASK MASK is twice used of the provocation which Ajax gives to Poseidon, Od. 4. 503, 509. ‘MASK’ is not an adjective, but a patronymic genitive, like MASK MASK MASK . In Cic. de Orat. 2. 66, and MASK , ‘MASK’ is probably the Greek genitive. Hyginus and Dictys Cretensis however are cited by Freund for an adjective, ‘MASK’ For the orthography ‘MASK MASK’ not ‘MASK’ (which is however the reading of Med., supported by some grammarians, and adopted by Ribbeck), see Wagn. on v. 30 above, who decides that where the nominative terminates only in ‘MASK’ the genitive must terminate, not in ‘MASK’ but in ‘MASK MASK’ Rom. and Gud. have ‘MASK MASK’

So Aesch. Eum. 827, she says of herself, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . Juno, in Book 4, raises a thunder-storm, but does not herself (‘MASK’) hurl the thunderbolt. “MASK MASK” and the owl grasping a thunderbolt, are found on coins. ‘MASK MASK’ is of course merely a periphrasis for the lightning. See the passage from Attius cited on v. 44. Comp. Eur. Tro. 80, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK (spoken by Pallas).

Eurip. l.c. makes Zeus send the storm and Poseidon raise the sea, Pallas being merely charged with the lightning. Quinct. Smyrn. 14. 444 foll. follows Virg., making Zeus give all his artillery to Athena for the occasion, and delight in seeing the storm which she raises. He imitates Virg. in the speech which Athena addresses to Zeus, vv. 427 foll., and also in the visit Iris is represented as paying on Athena's account to Aeolia, for the special purpose of making the tempest worse about the headland of Caphareus, vv. 474 foll., though in the latter case his narrative is more summary.
Comp. MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”; and Attius, Clyt. fr. 5 (quoted by Serv. on this passage), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” For ‘MASK’ Probus read ‘MASK MASK’

Comp. MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is the wind or force of the thunderbolt, as in 6. 594. See also on 2. 649. Forb. is right in placing a semicolon only after ‘MASK MASK’ to show that ‘MASK MASK MASK’ &c. is connected with the lines preceding. One or two MSS. have ‘MASK MASK’ which Cornutus ap. Serv. preferred “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is a little awkward after ‘MASK MASK’ and the construction “MASK MASK MASK MASK” to impale a person upon a thing, is, as Henry has pointed out, unusual, if not unexampled. ‘MASK’ however is supported by Sen. Ag. 571, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” quoted by Gossrau. Henry's interpretation, making ‘MASK’ abl., and supposing Ajax to be pierced by a fragment of rock hurled at him (‘MASK’ being paralleled with “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 12. 531), agrees to a certain extent with Quinct. Smyrn. 14. 567 foll. (not with Sen. Ag. 552 foll., who follows Hom.); nothing however is there said about piercing Ajax, who is merely said to be overwhelmed by the rock as Enceladus was overwhelmed by Aetna; so that the parallel is hardly made out. W. Ribbeck cites Seneca's poem to Corduba, vv. 13, 14 (Wernsdorf's Poet. Lat. Min. vol. 5, p. 1367), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” which is in favour of the common interpretation, as the writer evidently means to speak of his banishment to a rocky island as an impalement.

Apparently from Il. 18. 364 foll., where Here pleads her dignity as greatest of the goddesses and consort of Zeus, as a reason why she should work her will on the Trojans. ‘MASK MASK’ poetically substituted for the simple copula “MASK MASK” with an allusion, of course, to the majesty of Juno's gait. The word itself, as Henry remarks, does not necessarily imply majestic movement; but this notion is gained by attention being directed to the movement at all, in a context like this; at the same time, of course, that it is enforced by the qualifying words ‘MASK MASK MASK’ &c. Comp. Prop. 2. 2. 6, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” It is probable that Prop. had seen Virg.: see on v. 2 above.

MASK MASK MASK , Il. 16. 432. ‘MASK MASK’ Juno thinks it strange that she should take so long to subdue a single nation; Venus, on the other hand (v. 251 below), complains that she and her son are persecuted to gratify a single individual, Juno.

The old reading, unsupported apparently by the better MSS., though one or two have ‘MASK MASK’ was ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Heins. and Heyne recommended, and later editors have restored, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ from Med., Rom., and other MSS. Some MSS. however, including Gud. originally, have ‘MASK MASK’ and this would appear to be the true reading, both from the instances quoted by Wagn. in support of the indicative against the subjunctive ( MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and Consolatio ad Liviam Incerti Auctoris, 7, 8), and from the nature of the case. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ would be, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ If then the subjunctive is less forcible than the indicative, it is precisely because the future is less forcible than the present. Those who read ‘MASK’ explain the change of tense by saying that ‘MASK MASK’ = “MASK MASK”—‘MASK’ couples the presents ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK’—‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ then will express, not so much sequence in time, as a logical relation, like MASK . We may still however comp. “MASK MASK MASK” MASK . ‘MASK’ MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ of offerings, 4. 453., 6. 246, 253, MASK . appears from 8. 417 to be Lipara. The Aeolia of Hom. (Od. 10) has been supposed to unite the characteristics of Lipara and Strongyle, the latter of which appears to be assigned by Virg. (l. c) to Vulcan. Comp. also Val. F. 1. 579 foll. The Aeolus of Hom. is not a demigod, but the king of a sort of magic isle, entrusted by Zeus with the control of the winds, but passing his life in continually feasting with his queen and children.

Hom.'s winds are not represented as struggling, or the object of anxious custody. When Aeolus wishes to waft Ulysses to his country, he lets the west wind blow, and ties up all the rest in a skin. Val. F., on the contrary, with questionable judgment, makes Aeolus let loose the winds whenever he finds them ungovernable. Gud. originally had ‘MASK’

Henry (on v. 86) considers the whole picture of the winds to have been suggested by the Ludi Circenses, referring particularly to the words ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ and citing the imitation by Val. F. 1. 611, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and the description of a chariot-race in Sidon. Apoll. 1. ad Consentium, opening with “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Against this may be urged the collocation of two of the most important words, ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ inasmuch as ‘MASK MASK’ must mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ not ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ also appears to fix the sense of ‘MASK’ as a prison-house, and not a barrier in a race-course. Again, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is not the same thing as “MASK MASK MASK MASK” The more reasonable thing seems to be to say that Virg. uses imagery principally taken from the race-horse and the prison, but without intending any one connected or uniform series of metaphors. Lucr., in a passage from which this is partly imitated ( MASK ), compares the winds pent in a thunder-cloud to wild beasts in a cage, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK .

Here we are reminded of an earlier part of the passage just cited from Lucr., where the storm-clouds in which the winds are confined are compared to mountains (vv. 189, 190) and caverns (v. 195), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” It is possible that the Lucretian image may have suggested to Virg. his deviation from the account in Hom. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ comp. such phrases as “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Cic. 2 Verr. 1. 24. See also Hand, Tursell. 2. p. 152, foll. ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ as v. 245 shows, in spite of the passage in Lucr. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

It is not easy to say what or where this ‘MASK’ of MASK is intended to be. The common notion is that it is the top of the mountain in which the winds are confined. Henry once thought it was an eminence within the cave; now he takes it of a fortress or palace in the neighbourhood. This last certainly seems the most natural meaning of the word. The citadel is the natural dwelling of a despotic governor (comp. Juv. 10. 307); in Greek history, tyrants seize it when they assume supreme power; and so here, as Aeolia is under a strong government, it is supposed to be furnished with an ‘MASK MASK’ though the government consists in keeping the key of the prison. So in the description of the shades, Stat. Theb. 8. 21, Pluto is described as “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” words apparently imitated from Virg., and doubtless to be understood simply as bringing out the notion of sovereignty, without any particular reference to the appropriateness of the image. It is in this ‘MASK’ that Juno has her interview with MASK, who goes from it (though this is not directly asserted) to the dungeon, and opens the door. ‘MASK’ expresses actual sitting, not, as Henry thinks, merely dwelling; but it has no further appropriateness than as carrying out the image of ‘MASK MASK’ and so ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the Homeric MASK .

MASK in Greek appears to signify generally the symbols of supreme authority rather than the actual sceptre. Virg. however uses it simply for ‘MASK MASK’ 7. 252, and probably this is the meaning here, though there is no special appropriateness in the image; see previous note. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” MASK (note), is half physical, half mental. ‘MASK MASK’ &c., as Henry observes, expresses the general effect of Aeolus' sway.

The present tense here, as in 6. 292., 11. 912, is substituted for the imperfect to give greater vividness, and express the greater imminence of that which is prevented or averted. ‘MASK MASK’ MASK , note. Med. has ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK , note.

In MASK , Aphrodite tells Here she cannot refuse one who is the partner of Zeus' bed.

Virg. possibly, as Heyne suggests, had in his mind Here's first offer to Sleep, Il. 14. 238, of a banqueting throne and a footstool; though this need not have been at the feast of the gods. Aeneas is nearly killed by Diomede, from whom he is rescued by Aphrodite, Il. 5. 297 foll. Diomede is characterized as the bravest of the Greeks by Helenus, Il. 6. 98, Achilles being specially not excepted.

But Pliny may have quoted from memory, confusing ‘MASK’ with “MASK MASK” and it is perhaps a little hazardous to desert all the MSS. Heins., who illustrates this form of the gen. largely, says that in 5. 301 an ancient MS. gives ‘MASK’ for “MASK MASK” This may show that the transcriber remembered having seen ‘MASK’ somewhere: but it may also remind us that Virg. made “MASK” the gen. of “MASK MASK” “MASK” however is read by one MS. in the passage from Book 5.

‘MASK’ There is a similar syncope in 4. 606, “MASK” 4. 682, “MASK” 5. 786, “MASK” 11. 118, “MASK” Forb. has collected similar instances on MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ they did not actually enter the cave of the Cyclops, but they landed on the shore, and so may be said to have known it. Heyne inquires how Aeneas came to know the name of MASK, when elsewhere he exhibits so much ignorance about his destination, and answers that he must have been told it by Anchises MASK the shades,—meaning probably by Helenus MASK Epirus, as Aeneas does not visit the shades till afterwards. But the proportions of Aeneas' knowledge and ignorance at various times even Virg. himself would probably have found it difficult to adjust (compare e. g. his knowledge of Italy from Creusa 2. 781 with his ignorance afterwards, 3. 100 foll.), so that we need hardly invent an explanation where the poet most likely had none. “MASK MASK” MASK of the abodes of the gods.

It is not necessary to limit the meaning of ‘MASK’ actually to the crisis of death, (which would seem to be the sense of the phrase ‘MASK MASK’ in Tac. H. 4. 54, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”) as in that case “MASK MASK” would be required here. The expression rather implies death as a continuing state: ‘MASK MASK MASK’—‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Wund. distinguishes between the “MASK” which took place at the moment of death, and the “MASK” or “MASK” which took place after the burial, and of which we have instances 3. 68., 6. 231, 506; and he thinks that the first is referred to here, on the ground that the Manes were supposed to hear the “MASK” Henry may be right in going farther, and supposing the words to mean that the “MASK MASK” which, as he observes, was originally a means of ascertaining whether a person was really dead, actually takes place.

Wagn. (after Heyne) supposes an anacoluthon, as if “MASK MASK MASK” should have followed; but this would be very harsh, resembling rather the licences of the Greek poets than those of Virg. The omission of the verb subst. with the second person is paralleled by 5. 687., 10. 827. Ribbeck, who has attacked the omission of the verb subst. in various passages where it is acknowledged to be right in Wagn.'s elaborate essay on the whole subject, Q. The meaning of ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is clearly, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ (of reaching Italy). “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Gell. 1. 3. ‘MASK’ expresses the opposition between destiny and destiny as in 7. 293, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Strictly then the epithet would agree with ‘MASK MASK’ as the latter of the two correlatives, but by a poetical variety it is joined with ‘MASK MASK’ the former.

Comp. 6. 62, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” No MS. appears to give ‘MASK MASK’ which might have been expected as a variety, as in the parallel passages “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” v. 591, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 3. 708, the abl. is found in some of the best MSS.

Jupiter is addressed not merely as the interpreter of fate, but as identified with it, and answers accordingly “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” v. 279. So “MASK” v. 237. Comp. 3. 375. Otherwise ‘MASK’ would bear the modified signification of announcing; see on 3. 85.

The legend of MASK is given by Livy, 1. 1, where it is said that he led a colony of Trojans and of Heneti from Paphlagonia to the head of the Adriatic, whence he expelled the Euganei; and that the place where he and his followers first landed was called Troja. His story was variously told, Pindar, Pyth. 5. 19, taking the Antenoridae to Cyrene: the Romans however cherished naturally the legend of a migration to Italy, and one Largus, a contemporary of Ovid, wrote a poem on it. See Heyne's Excursus on this passage. ‘MASK MASK’ others, such as Sophocles, made him escape by collusion with the conquerors.

is contrasted with ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as Forb. remarks. ‘MASK’ is not so much to penetrate into, as to make his way through or past; Illyricum, the Liburni, and the Tergestinus Sinus, in which is the ‘MASK MASK MASK’ being all left on Antenor's right as he sailed to Venetia. The expression seems to denote the difficulty of a coasting voyage, such as Antenor would make up the east of the Adriatic, whether arising from the dangerous nature of the coast itself, or from the barbarity of the inhabitants. ‘MASK MASK’ may be either the Adriatic, as washing the shore of Illyricum, or the indentations in the Illyrican coast. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is not so much the interior of the Liburnian territory, which Antenor coming by sea would not penetrate, as the kingdom lying far inward in the Adriatic. ‘MASK’ is said to be a nautical word by Serv., who quotes from Lucilius “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Here and MASK , where it is also applied to the Timavus, it probably denotes difficulty. It is just possible, however, that Virg. may intend to represent Antenor as sailing up the stream of the Timavus, in which case we may comp. 8. 58, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

is rightly explained by Henry of the fountain or source of the Timavus. Between this and the sea (a distance of about a mile) there are subterranean communications, through which the salt water forces its way, breaking out at the fountain through seven mouths or holes in the limestone rock, and overflowing the channel of the river. See the account quoted by Henry from Cluverius, Ital. Antiq. 1. 20, and more recent descriptions cited in the same note from Wittmann and Schlözer. It appears from Serv. that this view was received by many in his time; but the subsequent commentators, including Heyne, Wagn., and Forb., understand ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ of the volume of the waters of the river, so that ‘MASK MASK’ has to stand for the river itself.

the general account, as intimated above, appears to be that there were seven of these ‘MASK MASK’ or sources. Cluverius however l. c. speaks of the whole of the country to the sea as “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and it seems from Wittmann's account that the ‘MASK’ are constantly overflowed, so that their number is not easy to ascertain. Polybius asserts that the water in all but one of these ‘MASK’ is salt, which Strabo denies. The two are reconciled by Cluverius, who reports from actual observation that the sea occasionally bursts up through six of the sources, and renders the water undrinkable. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ refers to the sound of the water re-echoing through the limestone rock as it bursts up; ‘MASK MASK MASK’ to its sound after bursting up. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” v. 55 note. ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ comp. 7. 459, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Gud. originally and fragm. Veron. corrected have ‘MASK MASK’ which is mentioned but disapproved by Serv. This description of the Timavus has been censured as out of place in the speech of Venus; it however expresses the portentous character of the region into which Antenor is allowed to penetrate with safety.
in spite of all these dangers.

probably Veneti, which was identified with Heneti. &c.: Wagn., Forb., and Jahn understand these words of the death of Antenor; but in spite of the special pleading of the former that a peaceful death would naturally be mentioned as the climax of the wanderer's happiness, and that Antenor, even during the Trojan war, must have been near the grave, it is evident that the sense required is rather that of a tranquil settlement following on labours. The language undoubtedly is such as is more generally applied to death or sleep, but the occurrence of such expressions as “MASK MASK” (7. 339., 12. 822), or “MASK” (10. 15), “MASK MASK MASK” (12. 109), and “MASK MASK MASK MASK” (3. 387), proves abundantly that the words ‘MASK MASK’ may well have been used of the repose of a peaceful life. Possibly too Virg. may have thought of Ennius' celebrated lines (A. 18. 7), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where of course peaceful old age, not death, is meant. The antithesis between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ merely implies that, after having founded his city, named his nation, and hung up his arms for ever, he entered on a prosperous reign.

The legend was that the first settlement (represented in Virg. by the camp) endured for three years, Lavinium for thirty, after which the kingdom was transferred to Alba, which lasted for three hundred. For the form of expression comp. v. 755 below.

The propriety of ‘MASK MASK’ as denoting that he was still in the camp, has not been noticed. ‘MASK MASK’ may very well be the abl. absol.; but it is more probably the dative, an idiom common in Greek, and found also in Juv. 14. 10, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” It is a variety of the ethical or personal dative. See on v. 102 above.

Heyne without reason suspects this line. It is a natural attempt to strengthen a weak point of the legend, the absence of any connexion between Iulus and any character in the Trojan story. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ may either be rendered with Wagn., ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ (‘MASK MASK’ = “MASK MASK”), or, which seems better, while the Trojan state (‘MASK MASK MASK’ like ‘MASK MASK’) stood with power unbroken (‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’). In the latter case we may compare 2. 88, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” With the perfect after ‘MASK MASK’ in the sense of duration, comp. 3. 15, “MASK MASK MASK MASK”

here and in “MASK MASK MASK” 9. 7, Virg. has followed the usage of Enn. A. inc. 69, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and of MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Both in this passage and in 9. 7, however, the ordinary sense of the gerundive would have force, as in each case it is a god who may be speaking of destiny, so that we may doubt whether Virg. would have used the word in a connexion where he could not have availed himself of common as well as of archaic associations. ‘MASK’ may be either dative, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ or modal abl. = ‘MASK’ Heins. restored ‘MASK MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ from Med., Rom., &c.

‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ not, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Virg. doubtless followed MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK”, where however population seems meant. Serv. mentions a reading ‘MASK MASK’ supported by a correction in one of Ribbeck's cursives. Wagn. and Forb. explain ‘MASK’ as “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” referring to 4. 566., 6. 676., 8. 42., 11. 708, Tibull. 2. 5. 56, in all of which passages ‘MASK’ means ‘MASK MASK’ a sense inapplicable here. We must rather take it therefore as contrasting Alba and its long-lived dynasty with the preceding members of the series. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ then will mean, at this point of the series of events. It is difficult to say whether ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK’ is to be taken as the adjective. With the combination Weidner comp. v. 382 below, “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ 6. 28, note, as Antigone is termed MASK MASK in MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ a Vestal.

For the construction ‘MASK MASK MASK’ and the meaning represented by it, see note on MASK . “MASK MASK MASK” is used by Ter. Hec. 3. 3. 32, and Ovid (Met. 3. 260) has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ = “MASK MASK” Comp. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 7. 660.

comp. Hor. 3 Od. 4. 34, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and the similar use of “MASK MASK” Prop. 5. 10. 20 describes Romulus with a helmet of wolf-skin; but Virg., as Henry remarks, doubtless meant the ‘MASK’ to cover the whole person.

Comp. note on MASK . The notion here is that of succession. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ There is nothing to warrant the notion of Thiel and Forb. that ‘MASK’ = “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ may point at once to the birth of MASK, the worship of Mars at Rome , and the martial character of the nation.

‘MASK’ as opposed to their predecessors, whose date was limited. ‘MASK’ probably refers to the bounds of the empire (‘MASK’), ‘MASK’ to its duration. ‘MASK’ however may be transferred from space to time, 10. 472. With ‘MASK MASK MASK’ we may compare “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 10. 467.

is commonly taken with ‘MASK’ (like “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 11. 400), expressing the terror which Juno spreads through the universe. It may however, and perhaps better, be taken, as Serv. suggests, for the alarm which Juno feels at the course of destiny, if we compare v. 23, “MASK MASK MASK” and 10. 9. ‘MASK’ will then mean, keeps earth, air, and sea astir, by constantly traversing them and exciting their powers; so “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 8. 92. Thus Virg. may have had in his eye Il. 4. 26, where Here complains of the toil which she and her horses have undergone in persecuting the Trojans: comp. also Il. 8. 478 foll.

The phrase ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is twice used MASK Virg. (here and 11. 425) for ‘MASK MASK’ Serv. refers to Ennius (A. 289) as saying that Juno became reconciled to the Romans MASK the second Punic war. There would naturally be different opinions about the time when her sentiments changed: Horace has his own, 3 Od. 3. 16 foll.: Virg. seems to put the date earlier, 12. 841, though elsewhere, as MASK 10. 11 foll., he intimates that the gods take part MASK the struggle between Rome and Carthage.

Macrobius (Sat. 6. 5) says that Laberius was the author of this line; and Suetonius (Aug. 40) tells a story of Augustus' quoting it. It had probably become a stock line to express the grandeur of imperial Rome . ‘MASK MASK’ is not a tame addition, being sufficiently characteristic; so that there is no need with Heyne to seek a point in any antithesis between “MASK” and “MASK MASK” Hor. 3 Od. 5. 10, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

MASK MASK . Jupiter is speaking destiny. It will be observed that ‘MASK’ being a strictly Roman measure of time, Jupiter is thus made to speak the language of the great nation. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

Assaracus is the ancestor through whom Aeneas was related to the royal house of Troy . Comp. Augustus (Julius MASK by adoption); not, as Serv. thinks, Julius, who could hardly be said to be laden with the spoils of the East, and who was not the primary object of a Roman's homage. We may observe that he is not distinctly spoken of here as Julius MASK, which would have been ambiguous, but is called MASK, the gentile name Julius being mentioned as connecting him with Iulus. It may seem against this that his apotheosis is spoken of v. 289; but we may be meant to understand the deification as taking place during his life, as we know it to have done, MASK note, Hor. 2 Ep. . 15. Henry takes ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as equivalent to “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and interprets ‘MASK’ as ‘MASK’ He objects to the ordinary sense ‘MASK’ (making the spear curl or quiver), on the ground that it is unsupported and inappropriate, when, as here and in 12. 165, where the line recurs, the person is peacefully engaged. While however it may be granted that ‘MASK’ is a strong expression for the motion of the spear merely as carried in the hand in walking, it must be remembered that it is hazardous to assume that one expression is put for another, which itself has no example in the Latin language. Hom.'s heroes carry two spears. “MASK MASK MASK” 4. 131.

There the co-operation of the country in the crime of its king might be assumed naturally; here it is uncertain whether the Penates are those of Pygmalion, and so concerned in the murder, or those of Sychaeus, and so merely witnesses of it. Perhaps 4. 21, MASK , point rather to the latter, which is also more probable if we suppose that Dido is made actually to see the altar and the treasure (see on next line). On the other hand, we should more naturally think of the crime as perpetrated, like that of Atreus, in the house of the murderer, and the concealment would then have been more easy. But where the data are so few conjecture degenerates into licence.

Whether the poet intended a vision strictly speaking or a dream, is not quite clear; if the former, ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ must be taken of words spoken by the apparition; if the latter, Dido was actually made to see the altar and the cavern where the treasure lay. The former seems more consistent with analogy; but the latter is supported by 2. 297, where Hector, after appearing in much the same way as Sychaeus here, brings out the sacred things from the penetralia. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as perpetrated by her brother, not as perpetrated before the Penates.

Macrob. Sat. 3. 2 fancies that ‘MASK’ is used with singular propriety, the “MASK MASK” at Rome being made by the Pontifex Maxumus, with which character Virg. is supposed to imply that Aeneas is invested. Virg.'s love of recondite half-allusions to traditions which he does not expressly adopt is unquestionable; but where, as here, there is no more than a possibility of such a reference, we may perhaps make the question one of poetical taste, which here would certainly seem to exclude anything of the sort. The word doubtless has a propriety of its own, but it is merely as suggesting the notion of a minute and rather tedious narrative.

‘MASK’ The MSS. authority is divided between ‘MASK’ (Med., Gud.) and ‘MASK’ (Rom., Pal., the latter however altered into ‘MASK’), ‘MASK’ being further supported by quotations in Macrob., Priscian, Nonius, and other early writers. The question is argued in favour of the future indicative by Forb. against Wagn., who in his large edition supports ‘MASK’ but in his smaller edition tacitly admits ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ implying that the condition will not happen, separates this passage from such as “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (Hor. 3. Od. 3. 7), where it is implied that the condition may very conceivably happen, as Wagn. remarks. In the only strictly parallel passage quoted, Cic. Tusc. 5. 35. 102, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” there is the same variety of reading as here. Being thus left to decide between the authority of MSS., which in a case like this proves little, and what would seem to be the propriety of language, I have preferred ‘MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ closing the gates of heaven through which the day issues. Serv. considers ‘MASK MASK’ to be said of physically climbing the sea,—“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” It would be more natural to suppose that the poet referred to some commoner appearance or sensation such as the elevation of the horizon or the rising of the wave; “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (Tennyson). ‘MASK’ however is so completely appropriated as a technical term for embarking, being used in that sense even without an accusative, that we can hardly avoid giving it such a meaning in a connexion like this. Here as elsewhere (see on MASK ) it seems that Virg. while he secured the sense ‘MASK’ by the use of ‘MASK MASK’ arranged his words so as to give him the advantage at the same time of some other ideas, of which that of climbing the wave just mentioned may have been one, and the notion opposed to “MASK” (“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 5. 29), whether of actual ascent or of effort, may have been another. ‘MASK’ constructed as in 10. 213, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

This line seems to answer in structure and therefore probably in sense to v. 400. Its meaning has been the subject of much controversy; the word ‘MASK’ being variously understood either as to settle on or to mark out for settling (“MASK MASK”), which latter would agree with the military sense of “MASK MASK MASK” The difficulty in each case consists in the words ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which could not very naturally, as Henry thinks, stand for the action of the swans rising again and hovering over the place where they had settled, while Wagn.'s view (in his smaller edition), that some mark their ground, others look down on it after having marked it, is open to the obvious objection that such a distinction could not possibly be observed or pointed out by a spectator. It seems best then, with Burm., to take ‘MASK’ in the sense of “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” so that the sense would be, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ expresses that they are just looking down on their companions and already preparing to follow them. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is no objection to this interpretation, as Henry thinks, those words being evidently ornamental and only vaguely descriptive. Ribbeck's ‘MASK MASK’ (‘MASK’ Pal.) is a sufficiently unhappy conjecture, introducing a most un-Virgilian word. ‘MASK’ however is read by Pal. (corrected) and Gud.

probably to be contrasted with “MASK” v. 228. Heyne and Wagn. take it as having reference to her love for Paphos. Serv. suggests that ‘MASK’ is the fixed epithet of Venus; and MASK actually occurs in the passage quoted immediately below, from which this is verbally imitated. Virg. however cannot have meant ‘MASK’ for a fixed epithet, though it is possible that he may have mistaken the character of the fixed epithet, and supposed that it was meant to have a special reference to the context, like some of the critics on Homer. Henry (Class. Mus.) once thought it more poetical to make ‘MASK’ the verb to ‘MASK’ as well as ‘MASK’ than to understand ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ But the words are clearly imitated from Od. 8. 362, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK : MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK , where MASK answers to ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ here. How Virg. came to develope the single altar of Hom. into a hundred does not appear: probably it arose from his turn for amplifying, as in MASK , A. 4. 199. The commentators observe that sacrifices of blood were not offered to Venus, citing Tac. H. 2. 3 (in Catull. 64 (66). 90 foll. the reading and interpretation are doubtful). Horace however, 1 Od. 19. 16, and 4 Od. 11. 7, refers to a different practice. ‘MASK MASK’ festoons.

A semicolon is commonly placed at ‘MASK MASK’ but ‘MASK’ is found with an infin. 2. 627, MASK . ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ part are at work on the fortifications, part on the houses. ‘MASK MASK’ as in 3. 132, Hor. A. P. 399. ‘MASK MASK’ the citadel proper, as distinguished from the ‘MASK MASK’ v. 420. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ to roll them up to the eminence on which the citadel was being built.

‘MASK MASK’ as in 3. 119, 132. There is a reading ‘MASK MASK’ found in some MSS., including Rom. as originally written, and rather preferred by Henry, seemingly without reason. ‘MASK’ is generally taken as the trench for the foundations. Lersch however (Antiqq. Vergg. § 19) understands ‘MASK’ of choosing with auspices, and ‘MASK MASK’ of drawing a trench of demarcation round the houses, supposing that Virg. has transferred the solemnity of founding a city to the foundation of private dwellings. Henry makes ‘MASK’ general, so as to include citadel as well as private houses, supposing the distinction marked by ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ to be between actual building and laying out.

Heyne and Ribbeck think this line spurious, as interrupting the enumeration of buildings; but legislation (“MASK MASK”) is mentioned in nearly the same connexion 3. 137., 5. 758. Virg. was probably thinking of the republican institutions of Rome and her colonies, without considering how this action of the people was to be reconciled with the authority of Dido (comp. v. 507). ‘MASK’ is the regular epithet of the Roman senate. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is a zeugma, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” as Forb. gives it.

appears to be strictly correct, as the harbour of Carthage, which Serv. calls Cothon, was artificial. ‘MASK’ is the reading of Med., ‘MASK’ of Rom., Pal. (originally), and fragm. Ribbeck follows fragm. Vat. in reading ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ apparently regarding the latter as introduced from 4. 266; but such a thing is hardly probable in the face of authorities so independent as Med., Pal., and Rom. Vat. apparently has ‘MASK MASK’ so that not much can be made out of this coincidence. The temporary wooden theatre of M. Aemilius Scaurus had a ‘MASK’ of three stories, supported by 360 columns, Pliny 36. 15.

These lines are repeated with slight variations from MASK —169; a reference to which passage proves that the divisions here introduced by ‘MASK’ imply, not different times, but different parties, and so are parallel to the different occupations of the Carthaginians. The variations are ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ the first necessitated the second, and was natural in a passage where bees and honey are not the main subject celebrated, but only an illustration.

is commonly taken as “MASK” or “MASK MASK MASK” which would not agree with the pluperfect tense, or with the dependent words ‘MASK MASK MASK’ &c., which follow. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Justin (18. 5) has a story that the Carthaginians on first digging found an ox's head, which seemed to portend servitude; that they then dug again, and found a horse's head; and that the two were then taken to portend plenty and success in war combined. Caelius Rhodius (referred to by Taubmann) says that Cacabe, the old name of Carthage, meant a horse's head, which, if true, would account for the legend. A horse's head is common on Punic coins. ‘MASK MASK’ is paraphrased by Silius (2. 411), “MASK MASK” In 3. 539 (“MASK MASK MASK”) horses are taken as an omen of war.

in its strict sense. The threshold was of brass, with steps leading up to it. The latter particular is an ornamental one, and need not be understood as if the steps were of brass also. Brazen thresholds are Homeric, e. g. Od. 7. 89, of the palace of Alcinous, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , a passage which may have been in Virg.'s mind. The next clause presents a greater difficulty. All the first-class MSS. seem to have ‘MASK’ (Wagn. excepts fragm. Vat., but Ribbeck is silent); ‘MASK’ is mentioned by Serv., found in some MSS., and adopted by Wagn. (ed. mi.), Forb., Henry, Ladewig, and Haupt. The external authority is quite sufficient to support the change, which is itself a very natural one (see on 4. 217., 5. 279, MASK ); but its advocates are not agreed on the sense. Henry and Forb. take ‘MASK’ of the beams of the roof, which rest on brazen columns. Wagn. makes ‘MASK’ the doorposts, and understands ‘MASK MASK’ in the sense of “MASK MASK MASK MASK” simply a periphrasis for ‘MASK’ Ladewig makes ‘MASK’ the architrave, which rests on pillars or jambs of brass. Of these the third seems the only one that can stand, the first being objectionable as introducing a particular about the rest of the building between two particulars about the door; the second as giving a forced and unnatural sense to ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Understanding ‘MASK’ with Wagn. of the doorposts, I believe ‘MASK MASK’ stands for “MASK” as “MASK” or “MASK” might have done, the word being employed, not only to express the coherence of the plating with the thing plated, but to indicate the coherence of the posts with the threshold and the lintel, much as in MASK (which Wund. comp.) MASK MASK is used of the necklace of Eriphyle, in the sense of ‘MASK’ rather than in that of ‘MASK’ Perhaps Claud. Rapt. Pros. 1. 237 (cited by Heyne) means the same thing when he says “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is probably to be supplied to ‘MASK MASK’ but ‘MASK MASK’ will still be a predicate.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ We hear both of brazen and of brass-bound doors. The conjunction of brazen doors with brassplated jambs seems merely a variety. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 6. 573.

There seems no reason for separating ‘MASK’ from ‘MASK MASK MASK’ and taking the latter as “MASK MASK MASK MASK” as the commentators propose. The sense appears to be, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

These representations are probably on the doors or external walls of the temple. Comp. the sculptures mentioned MASK , A. 6. 20. ‘MASK’ then will express that Aeneas is looking up. Heyne discusses in an excursus the question whether these were sculptures or paintings, observing that the former was the only mode of representation known in the Homeric times, and that other poets, such as Val. Fl. 5. 411 foll., Sil. 3. 32 foll., describe similar temples with sculptures; but that the latter is more suited to the language of the present passage, and would be a natural anachronism, paintings on temple-walls or in porticoes being common in later times. There is a similar question about the description of the temple of Delphi in the Ion of Euripides.

It has been asked how Aeneas knew that Dido was coming. Probably the idea is that he sees the senate assembled and the crowd waiting. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ for “MASK MASK MASK MASK” marvels at the prosperity of the city, shown in the splendour of its temple. Aeneas sees everything in the light of his own great enterprise; so his thoughts would naturally pass from the temple to the city, of whose greatness it is an evidence. For ‘MASK MASK’ see on MASK .

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which he compares together. This line gives the reason why the battles have been painted, and prepares us for the thoughts that follow.

The two Atridæ are first mentioned in the enumeration of the heroes, then Priam; after which Achilles is naturally introduced as ‘MASK MASK’ i. e. to the Atridae no less than to Priam. This seems a sufficient explanation of the loose use of ‘MASK’ with which MASK in Od. 4. 339 has been aptly compared. The other objection that Achilles' quarrel was with Agamemnon alone, is of little weight, as the brothers were united in interest, and Menelaus as the husband of Helen suffered most. Achilles includes both in his taunts Il. 1. 159., 9. 340. Sen. Ep. 104 quotes the passage with ‘MASK’

For the story of Rhesus see Il. 10, and the play of that name ascribed to Euripides. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is an anachronism. The Homeric MASK , as appears from Il. 24. 448, were huts of planks thatched with grass.

is proved by a number of instances (2. 268., 5. 857) to mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ not, as Wagn. thinks, the first time they slept at Troy . ‘MASK MASK’ betrayed to him, and so surprised. Possibly Henry may be right in making ‘MASK’ instrumental, ‘MASK MASK MASK’
was spreading havoc through them. Perhaps it is more forcible to take ‘MASK MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ not with ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ But the point is very doubtful.

is the Homeric MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ 7. 781. One MS. has ‘MASK’ which was the colour of the horses of Rhesus, Il. 10. 437. But the mention of the colour as exactly represented here might be thought rather jejune, especially after ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ as “MASK MASK” 10. 78.

The subj. denotes the intention of Diomede. Homer and the Pseudo-Euripides know nothing of this intention, which Eustathius on Il. 10. 435, and the Scholiast, followed by Serv. on this passage, say was to prevent the accomplishment of an oracle that if the horses of Rhesus tasted the grass or water of Troy , Troy should not be taken.

MASK is mentioned by Priam, Il. 24. 257, with the epithet of MASK , as having been killed in battle (before the time of the Iliad). The tradition that he was killed by Achilles must have been drawn by Virg. from other sources, such as those represented by Quintus Smyrnaeus, Tzetzes, Dictys, and Dares, who however differ about the period in the Trojan war when his death occurred. Heyne conjectures from a Schol. on Hom. l. c. that Soph. in his lost tragedy of MASK represented the youth as surprised by Achilles while exercising his chariot, and killed. See his Excursus on this passage. MASK , speaks of the death of MASK as one of the three fatal events in the siege of Troy , the other two being the loss of the Palladium and the fall of the top of the Scaean gate. Ribbeck transposes this passage so as to make it follow the next scene; but this would be to bind Virg. to follow servilely the Homeric order, with which indeed there would still be a disagreement, as in Hom. the mission to the temple of Athene precedes the Dolonea. The intention of Virg. doubtless is to mention first two fatal blows to Troy , and then the despairing effort of the Trojan women to propitiate the angry goddess.
couples ‘MASK MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’

is run away with. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” He has fallen backwards from the car (which of course had no back), but hangs by the reins, which were passed round the body, and which he still grasps with his hand. ‘MASK’ is the spear of Troilus. Virg., as Heyne remarks, has departed from the Homeric custom, in which two warriors ride in the same car, one to drive and the other to fight.
Heyne justly wonders that Quinct. (7. 9) should raise a question whether ‘MASK’ goes with what precedes or with what follows.
like “MASK MASK” MASK .

Hom. Il. 6. 311 has MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK . The contrary attitude is described in Ovid, Trist. 1. 3. 45, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Here there is of course a confusion between the goddess and her statue.

This line suggests the mangled and pitiable state of the body as shown in the picture,—a condition such as is described 2. 272. The tense of ‘MASK’ shows that this is not a separate picture. Comp. 8. 642—4, where the tense of “MASK” similarly shows that the tearing of the limbs asunder had taken place before the action represented on the shield, which is similarly marked by the imperfect. In Hom. Hector is chased round the walls and dragged round the tomb of Patroclus. Heyne supposes Virg. to have followed the Cyclic poets or one of the tragedians, as Eur. Androm. 105 has MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . The word ‘MASK’ is apparently from Ennius, Androm. fr. 12, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The scene is from Il. 24. 478 foll.
perhaps = “MASK MASK MASK” by the dragging: see on 2. 273. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ 6. 621. See Madv. § 258.

has been differently taken as the chariot of Hector or that of Achilles. It might also be taken of that of Priam, described Il. 24. 266. The chariot of Achilles however would be a more important object in such a picture; and its presence seems to be indicated in v. 483. Statius has a parallel passage (Silv. 2. 7. 55) “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
unarmed, and so suppliant. The expression ‘MASK MASK MASK’ occurs (with a variation of reading) 10. 595., 11. 414, 672. For the thing see Il. 24. 478.

It is perhaps a little remarkable that Aeneas' features should have been transmitted by fame to Carthage, so as to be at once recognized by himself. In the other cases we may suppose that the event described told its own story. But names are found written over or under figures in old sculpture or painting, and Virg. may have had this practice in his mind, so that he would not seem to himself to be making a violent assumption. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ MASK MASK . When Poseidon rescues Aeneas from Achilles, he tells him to keep in the background during Achilles' lifetime, but afterwards MASK MASK MASK Il. 20. 338. Whether this time of more extended action is referred to here we cannot say, as we do not know how far the order of the pictures is chronological. Fragm. Vat. and Rom. give ‘MASK MASK’ which Jahn adopts. This and the next line do not seem to represent any particular scene, though Weidner (see on v. 466) thinks otherwise. Were it so, we should probably have had a more definite description, as Aeneas himself figures in the action. The lines appear rather to be a summing up of various scenes not described in detail.

The ‘MASK MASK’ are the Indian Aethiopians. Hom. says nothing of them in the Iliad, but Memnon is mentioned Od. 4. 187., 11. 521. Memnon had arms made by Vulcan, A. 8. 384. He was probably the hero of the Aethiopis of Arctinus, which is said to have followed immediately on the action of the Iliad (Mure, Hist. vol. ii. p. 282). He is called ‘MASK’ as an Aethiopian, but the legend made him eminently beautiful, Od. 11. 521. On the whole subject see Heyne's Excursus.

Penthesilea and her Amazons are again post-Homeric personages, who also seem to have figured in the Aethiopis, another title of the poem being probably Amazonia. Priam speaks of himself as having fought against Amazons invading Phrygia, Il. 3. 188. For ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which were part of the national armour of various parts of Asia, and therefore attributed to the Amazons, see Dict. A. ‘MASK’
for “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ as in 11. 649 note (of Camilla), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” See Dict. Myth. ‘MASK’ With the construction comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK”
placed as in 7. 805: comp. v. 319 above. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is supposed to be a reminiscence of the epithet MASK , applied by Hom. l. c. to the Amazons.

The simplest way of reconciling ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ is to suppose that Dido sat in the centre of the entrance; the ‘MASK’ (vaulted roof) extending over the whole building. The idea is probably taken from meetings of the senate held in temples. But Henry (anticipated by Turneb. Adv. 10. 11) may be right in taking ‘MASK MASK’ of the ‘MASK’ within the temple, and supposing that Dido was seated on the landing-place of the flight of steps by which the ‘MASK’ was commonly approached. He also remarks the general similarity between the reception of the Trojans here by Dido in the temple of Juno and by Latinus in the temple of Faunus 7. 170 foll. My lamented friend, Professor Shirley, suggested to me that the temple may have been a hypaethral one, which would have the ‘MASK’ over the door. Ribbeck reads ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ from a doubtful variety in Pal.

is the common expression of the whole Roman law, and the words are not to be pressed here. Comp. Hor. 1 Sat. 1. 9, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” with Macleane's note, and Dict. A. ‘MASK MASK’ For ‘MASK MASK’ see on v. 293 above, 5. 758. ‘MASK MASK’ foll. may be taken in two ways; either, that she divided by equity and, where that failed, by lot, which is the common way, or, that she first divided equally and then distributed the parts by lot. There is some resemblance between the scene here and that described Od. 11. 568 foll., though there the notion of administering justice is the prominent one, here that of giving laws and apportioning work.

Med., Pal. corrected, ‘MASK’ fragm. Vat., Rom., Gud., Pal. originally. The latter has generally been adopted since Heins. The words are frequently confounded in MSS., and it is not easy to establish the distinction for which Forb. and others contend, as though ‘MASK’ were too strong to be applied to any pleasurable emotion. Here however ‘MASK’ is used in a sense peculiar to itself as a synonym of ‘MASK’ (was struck dumb), the ablatives referring to both words as if it had been ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The words ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ are similarly joined in Hor. Med., Rom., Gud. corrected, Serv., Donatus. ‘MASK MASK’ Pal., Gud. originally. The MSS. however have less positive weight here, as it is evident that there has been a confusion between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ some giving ‘MASK MASK’ (Rom.), others ‘MASK MASK’ (Gud. originally, Pal. corrected). The sense is strongly against ‘MASK MASK’ whether we couple it with what follows, or, as Wagn., with what precedes. The appearance of deputies from all the ships informs Aeneas that the whole fleet is there (‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’); whereas it is difficult to see the meaning of making him wonder why all the deputies came together. Strictly, no doubt, “MASK” means all, distributively, and “MASK” the whole, as Jahn contends against the reading ‘MASK MASK’ but there are repeated instances in which “MASK” might be replaced by “MASK MASK” and even by “MASK” MASK , A. 3. 398.

The appeal is to one, to whom heaven has granted what they are seeking, to pity those whose case resembles her own, and to one who has founded civilization in the midst of barbarism, to put a stop to barbarous outrage. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ see on v. 298.

i. e. the Africans, not the Carthaginians, to whom ‘MASK’ would not be applicable. See 4. 41 (where possibly “MASK” may illustrate ‘MASK’ here), 320. It must be admitted, however, that so far as ‘MASK’ goes, it would point rather to Dido's government of her own people. Henry thinks Ilioneus speaks of the two operations in which he has seen Dido engaged, directing the building of the city and legislating (vv. 507, 508).

the nation, for the land. Comp. the Homeric MASK MASK MASK , Od. 8. 220. There were many accounts of the eponymous Italus, for which see Serv. Thuc. 6. 2 makes him a king of the Sicels. One legend made Oenotrus his brother.

The reading ‘MASK’ is supported against ‘MASK’ apparently by all the best MSS., and Serv. The sense is of course the same with either reading, while ‘MASK’ is the more difficult, ‘MASK’ the simpler. See on 4. 46, where there is a similar variety, and comp. 4. 237, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” One inferior MS. fills up the line “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

rising with a sudden swell. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is another of those artifices noticed on vv. 381, 508, the word ‘MASK’ being intended to combine the rising of the star and the rising of the wave. For ‘MASK MASK’ in the latter sense comp. MASK and note; for the former comp. Val. Fl. 5. 566, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” We are reminded here rather of the follower of Hesiod and Aratus than of the imitator of Homer. The inconsistency was felt in Serv.'s time, many, as he says, putting the superfluous question why the rising of Orion is mentioned when the tempest was raised by Juno; to which he replies that Ilioneus was not aware of the facts which the poet learned from the Muse. Elsewhere storms are connected with the setting of Orion (7. 719, Hor. 1 Od. 28. 21., 3. 27. 17, Epod. 10. 10), as here with the rising. The rising of Orion is about midsummer (Pliny 18. 68), which agrees with the time here, v. 756.
boisterous. Eupolis, quoted by Julius Pollux ap. Cerdam, calls the winds MASK . MASK has “MASK MASK” and Hor. 1 Od. 26. 2, “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ above v. 512.

either, the sea overpowering us (“MASK MASK” v. 122) or the waves rising high. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Lachm. on MASK objects to the combination “MASK” or “MASK MASK” or “MASK MASK” on the ground that “MASK” belong to the “MASK MASK” not to the “MASK MASK” accordingly, wherever the words occur, he would alter “MASK” into “MASK MASK” as here and 6. 762, or “MASK” into “MASK MASK” as in 4. 445., 7. 557, MASK . Both changes are natural enough; “MASK” and “MASK” are confused in the MSS. 5. 518, 520., 8. 221; in MASK Med. has “MASK” for “MASK MASK” But whatever may be the case with Lucr. (and I am glad to see that Prof. Munro rejects his predecessor's view), there seems on the one hand no reason why Virg. may not have used “MASK” loosely in this connexion, as equivalent to “MASK” (a word with which “MASK” is not unfrequently joined, 6. 363., 7. 543, 768., 11. 595), while on the other “MASK” at any rate is found in Virg. in a sense in which it is peculiarly appropriate to “MASK MASK” if not actually synonymous with it, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 6. 747. This is probably its sense here, as Henry suggests,—the same mixture of the notions of light and air which we find MASK , “MASK MASK MASK” Henry comp. Stat. Theb. 1. 237 (of the blind Oedipus), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” on which Lachm. merely remarks, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Elsewhere Virg. connects “MASK” with life, 6. 436., 11. 104. the cruel darkness of death. Heyne and Wagn. take ‘MASK’ as the dative and ‘MASK MASK’ as a synonym for “MASK MASK MASK” But “MASK” means to fall, ‘MASK’ to lie dead, so that Forb. is doubtless right in making ‘MASK’ abl., unless we suppose that ‘MASK MASK’ can be i. q. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” lies among the spectres.

is the reading of all the MSS., except the Hamburg corrected, and of Serv., and is supported by the occurrence of the expression “MASK MASK MASK” MASK ., 10. 17, where it is nearly equivalent to “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ was recommended by Heins. and introduced by Heyne, and has been followed by most subsequent critics. But the expression is a harsh one, though it may perhaps be palliated by such phrases as “MASK MASK MASK” There should, I think, be a semicolon or colon after ‘MASK MASK’ not a period, as Ribbeck punctuates, as if a new thought began here and were carried on to the end of v. 550. It is difficult to determine the exact point of this sentence, as ‘MASK’ may mean, besides Aeneas, i. q. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” or, besides Carthage, i. q. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” or lastly, besides Italy, i. q. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The last would accord with the remainder of the speech, which dwells on the two courses open to them, that of fulfilling their Italian destiny should Aeneas be alive, or that of settling in Sicily should he and his heir be dead.

Rom., Pal., Gud., ‘MASK’ Med. The great majority of MSS. would seem to be in favour of the former: the latter is found in at least one of the Oxford MSS., that of Ball. Coll. In internal probability the two words seem to be as nearly balanced as possible. ‘MASK’ brings out further the notion of a settlement, and is used repeatedly in connexion with the Trojan settlement in Italy (see among many other passages v. 569 below, 4. 311, 355, and comp. 3. 136). ‘MASK’ adds a new thought, and one which is natural enough in the mouth of Ilioneus. Arms are a natural addition to a city: comp. v. 347 foll. above, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 12. 192 foll., “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The Trojans have arms of their own (comp. 4. 48, where observe “MASK” and “MASK” in the immediate context); but in the absence of Aeneas they must seek armed assistance elsewhere. Such being the balance of probabilities, I have decided, after much hesitation, by external evidence, adopting ‘MASK’ with Henry and Ribbeck, against most modern critics. ‘MASK’ was first introduced by Heyne. Oddly enough, there are traces of a similar variety in Pal. and another MS. below, v. 569, where, though ‘MASK’ would be out of the question, there is a certain parallelism. ‘MASK MASK’ without a participle or word indicating origin, 5. 299.

Both this and the preceding line are intended to rebut the supposition of ignorance respecting the history of Troy , not of want of feeling; so that the references of the older commentators to the recoil of the sun from the banquet of Thyestes are quite out of place. The notion seems to be ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Comp. 6. 796, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” It would add great force to the passage if we could suppose Virg. to have conceived of the sun as the actual bearer of news to the nations of the earth, as in the well-known passage in the dying speech of Ajax, MASK , and in Od. 8. 270, 302, Aesch. Ag. 632—676. But it is to be observed that in these passages the sun is the only possible witness; and though such a thought may possibly have crossed the mind of Statius when imitating this passage in Theb. 1. 683 (“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”), it would be hazardous to assume this to have been Virg.'s meaning when the passage can be explained without it, and the simpler view is confirmed by the language of the parallel 7. 225—227. Silius (15. 334) has imitated these words in a way which seems to show that he understood them, like the old commentators, as having reference to the recoil of the sun at a dreadful occurrence. ‘MASK MASK’ seems to imply that the people disclaimed by Dido lie beyond the sun-rising.

Wagn. and others, following Serv. (“MASK MASK MASK”), strike out the interrogation at the end of this line, understanding it as a hypothesis without ‘MASK MASK’ on the ground that Dido is simply giving them their choice, not pressing an invitation. They do not however attempt to prove either that the invitation conveyed by the interrogative form is a pressing one, or that an invitation would be inappropriate here. On the contrary the whole tenor of Dido's language to the end of the speech seems to show that she hopes they will settle. For the expression comp. Hom. has simply MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , which answers to MASK MASK MASK MASK ( MASK ) MASK , the point being that the beauty of Ulysses is, as it were, gilded with diviner grace, as silver is gilded with more precious gold. Virg. has taken the idea of beauty superadded by art, and expressed it in two ways, neither of them exactly the same as Homer's. The first (‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’) is the mere superaddition of art to a beautiful material (‘MASK MASK’ in the technical sense of the artist's hand, v. 455 above); the second, the adornment of silver or marble with gold, a practice similar to that referred to 10. 135, and illustrated in Heyne's Excursus. ‘MASK MASK’ elsewhere gold is called “MASK MASK” 7. 279, &c.

while the shadows move in the hollows of the hills. ‘MASK MASK’ not, as Heyne thinks, the shadows of the woods, but those cast by the hills themselves, MASK . ‘MASK’ Heyne explains rightly of the shadow moving with the sun. With ‘MASK’ comp. “MASK MASK MASK” v. 310, and the word “MASK MASK” Many critics, from the time of Serv., have taken ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK’ (comparing Ov. 4. ex Pont. 9. 129), supposing ‘MASK’ to be corrupt (‘MASK MASK MASK’ Heins., ‘MASK MASK’ Burm.; Ribbeck thinks the passage imperfect). The use of a word in one sense in a context which would seem to suggest another, is not unVirgilian, even where, as here, that other sense is not meant to be in any way recognized. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is from MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK” (comp. Id. 5. 523 foll.). Teucer, being refused admission in Salamis by his father on his return from Troy, founded a new Salamis in Cyprus. Virg. supposes him to have sought the assistance of Belus, king of Tyre, whom he represents to have conquered the Cyprians shortly before. See Heyne's Excursus.
