is the reading of almost all the existing MSS., including Rom. and Med., which has the final ‘MASK’ added in red ink. Gellius, 9. 14, asserts that ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK’ is the true reading, the other having been introduced by ignorant correctors. ‘MASK’ seems to be the reading of Pal. and at least one other MS., from Ribbeck's silence. It is obvious that Gell.'s is merely a critical opinion, and proves nothing as to the superior antiquity of either reading. All that we know is that both readings existed from an early time, and that while ‘MASK’ was supported by several authorities after Gellius, such as Julius Romanus, ‘MASK’ was maintained by others, such as Rufius Apronianus and Donatus, whose explanation is “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. mentions both readings, and a third, ‘MASK’ (see on MASK ), which is found in one copy. Two others appear to have ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ evidently refers to wine, which would naturally form a part of Dido's presents; the expression being resolvable into “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (comp. v. 734, “MASK MASK MASK MASK”). Bacchus, as henry remarks, is called simply ‘MASK’ 9. 337, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” according to one interpretation of the words. On the other hand, it would be difficult to affix any precise sense to the line if ‘MASK’ were read. Heyne's explanation is “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ has been adopted however by most of the later editors. If any awkwardness is felt from the asyndeton, we may impute it to the imperfect state of the passage.

It is difficult to extract a consistent view from the two articles “MASK” and “MASK” in the Dict. Ant., the former of which makes “MASK” a poetical synonym for “MASK MASK” the outer garment worn by both sexes, while the latter makes “MASK” as characteristic of women as “MASK” of men. The common opinion (comp. Forc. “MASK” and Forb. on this verse) seems to be that “MASK” was a long garment (probably a pall without sleeves) worn by women and by persons of dignity, especially by the gods. For ‘MASK MASK MASK’ (which is probably a hendiadys) comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where “MASK” has been plausibly conjectured.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Serv., on 7. 188, mentions the veil of Ilione as one of the seven national heirlooms which preserved the Roman empire. The ‘MASK’ seems to have been specially appropriated to borders of this kind, so that Hesychius actually defines the word MASK MASK . ‘MASK’ seems to have been used as a subst., equivalent to the Greek MASK , by which Serv. renders it here: comp. Varro L. L. 5. 132, Isidor. 19. 24. 10, cited by Lersch, A. V. § 79. The more ordinary colour of the ‘MASK’ was white, but later poets (Calp. 4. 68, Stat. 3 Silv. 1. 37, quoted by Heyne) speak of it as red or purple.
MASK MASK , Il. 2. 161. ‘MASK MASK’ 2. 577 note. Contrast Aesch. Ag. 690, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . Helen took away with her MASK which the Greeks sought to recover, Il. 3. 285 &c.

MASK, according to one story, was married to Polymestor, the treacherous king of Thrace. She is unknown to Hom. Juno bears a sceptre Ov. F. 6. 38, and Hecuba speaks of herself as supported by Priam's sceptre Eur. Tro. 150, but no instance has been adduced where it is carried by a woman who is not even a queen, but only a princess royal.

for the neck, a construction generally found where there is a verb or verbal notion, as in 10. 135, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Such a notion we may borrow here if we please from “MASK MASK” above v. 647. probably a double circlet of gold and gems, whether formed by one circlet of each is difficult to say. The commentators evidently are at a loss, as their explanations are mere conjecture; some suggesting that ‘MASK’ refers to the combination of gems and gold, while others think that the double crown means a bridal crown as distinguished from the crown worn by virgins, which may have been single.

Virg. seems to have had in his mind MASK foll., where Aphrodite, MASK the instance of Here and Athene, prevails on Love to inflame Medea with a passion for Jason: but there is no similarity in the details. ‘MASK MASK’ carries the reader back to v. 417. Virg. however may have intended to represent the Homeric MASK MASK MASK MASK , which he has translated 12. 843.
shape. Comp. MASK , A. 3. 310., 5. 222, quoted by Forb.

carries us back to his father's feelings v. 646, and forward to his probable attractions for the queen. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ inflame the queen to madness by his gifts. Comp. v. 714, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” There is possibly an allusion to the scene in the Medea of Euripides, where Medea's children carry to Creusa a crown and a robe which actually consume her. The parallel may serve as an answer to Schrader's wonder, mentioned by Heyne, that a wealthy queen like Dido should be captivated with presents.
Comp. Cic. Div. 1. 36, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is put for the seat of feeling, like “MASK MASK” Comp. MASK .

is to be explained by “MASK MASK” v. 671; and so 4. 96, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ is of course an anticipation of the Roman feeling against Carthage. ‘MASK’ occurs as a reproach more than once in Plautus (see Freund), where it represents the forked tongue of a serpent, and has apparently no connexion with the notion of speaking two languages.

There is no occasion to separate this line from what precedes with Wagn. and Forb., as vv. 670, 671 prove. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK , where the anxiety is that of love.—‘MASK MASK’ may be explained by observing that the action has arrived at evening. Having set her son on the way to Carthage, Venus is not at rest. She is alarmed at the warmth of his reception, and knowing that Ascanius has been sent for to the banquet, at the last moment she proposes to substitute Cupid for him. But there seems also a reference to the common thought that night aggravates rather than soothes anxiety, for which Henry comp. 4. 522 foll. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ 12. 802.

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The punctuation of Med., followed by many editors, which connects ‘MASK’ with what follows, is harsh and opposed by similar expressions, such as 8. 574, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Catull. 62 (64). 215, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Comp. 10. 507, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” With the nom. ‘MASK’ Forb. comp. For Typhoeus or Typhon struck by lightning comp. MASK The bolts are called from the giant they slew, as Serv. remarks, like Roman generals from the nations they conquered. A more far-fetched explanation is that of Pomponius Sabinus, who makes ‘MASK’ = “MASK MASK” Aetna being called ‘MASK’ MASK , as resting, according to one story, on Typhoeus. The orthography ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK” (v. 201), is adopted by Heyne for the sake of the metre, contrary to all the extant MSS., which have ‘MASK MASK’ Serv. however says that many in his time had ‘MASK MASK’ The device of Cupid breaking or trampling on the thunderbolt is common in gems.
the acc. of the person of whom the request is made, not of the thing requested. Comp. 8. 382, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 3. 543 “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Serv., in commenting on the adroitness of the whole address, notices ‘MASK MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ elsewhere MASK is said to wander over all lands (v. 756., 5. 627 &c.); here for the sake of variety he is said to wander about them, tossed from one to another and resting on none. So ‘MASK’ is used rather than ‘MASK MASK’ Comp. 3. 75, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” of Delos. See on v. 32 above. ‘MASK MASK’ on or over the sea, not the instr. abl. Comp. v. 3.

fragm. Vat. originally, Pal., ‘MASK’ Med., Rom., Gud., and most MSS., including fragm. Vat. corrected, and Serv., who says “MASK MASK MASK” It seems hopeless to explain ‘MASK’ as Wagn. inclines to do (Q. V. 12. 13), either by making ‘MASK’ couple ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK MASK’ or by supposing a corruption in ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ or again, as might be just possible, by supposing ‘MASK’ to be coupled with ‘MASK’ (comp. 2. 179, where two dissimilar ablatives are joined by ‘MASK’); while the insertion of ‘MASK’ is sufficiently accounted for by an anxiety to mend the metre. With the lengthening of the final syll. here Weidner comp. 4. 222., 5. 284, MASK , in all which places there is a kind of pause after the word, so that here probably we should take ‘MASK’ in a loose connexion with ‘MASK’ as an abl. of circumstance, rather than as an instr. abl. Comp. 8. 292, quoted just below. ‘MASK’ fragm. Vat., Pal., Gud., all originally, ‘MASK’ Med., Rom., and apparently the great bulk of MSS. Internal evidence is strongly for ‘MASK MASK’ as its insertion cannot easily be explained, while ‘MASK’ doubtless came from a recollection of 8. 292, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” where there seems to be no various reading. It is curious that in 11. 587, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” some inferior MSS. give “MASK MASK” apparently from a recollection of 2. 257.

Pal., fragm. Vat. originally, and some others. ‘MASK’ Med., Rom., Gud., &c., which Wagn. ingeniously explains as = “MASK MASK MASK” On the whole I have preferred ‘MASK MASK’ with Wakef. and Ribbeck, as the repetition of ‘MASK’ v. 680 would be rather formal. what may be their issue. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Enn. Alex. fr. 1. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” for the more usual “MASK MASK MASK MASK” is found Enn. A. 1. fr. 69. The nom. to ‘MASK’ is “MASK MASK” contained in ‘MASK MASK’ Comp. Livy 2. 53, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (quoted by Forb.). Serv. says that there is a proverb “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” A similar use of ‘MASK’ is found in imitators of Virg., as Statius and Val. Flaccus, and twice in Quinctilian: see Forc. Here it may conceivably have been chosen with reference to ‘MASK MASK’ which would agree with Serv.'s explanation, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Both terms are taken from strategy, though they are clearly not meant to be harmonized. The sense is, I mean to make a complete conquest of her, so as to preclude all other intervention. With ‘MASK MASK MASK’ comp. 10. 119, “MASK MASK MASK MASK”

that Dido's friendly feelings may not be changed by Juno. ‘MASK MASK’ may either be rendered generally, by any power but mine, or by Juno's power in any way, like “MASK MASK MASK MASK” v. 8. The abl. however is rather that of circumstance than of the instrument.

“MASK MASK MASK” is the common interpretation, adopted by Heyne, Wagn., and Forb. Comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” According to this interpretation Venus would wish that Dido's affection should not be hollow (“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”), but as sincere as her own. It might also be proposed to connect ‘MASK’ closely with ‘MASK MASK’ kept on my side, or, in my power, which would accord with the general metaphor of the previous lines. Comp. 4. 115, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ is a common expression; and if the latter interpretation be adopted, Virg. has blended this with other notions, perhaps that of a town invested (“MASK MASK MASK” 10. 109). Serv, who objects to the common view, on the ground that Dido could not love Aeneas like a mother, has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” which would not be so natural.

For ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is read by Gud., ‘MASK’ by some other MSS. ‘MASK MASK’ of hearing, 2. 65, like “MASK MASK” of telling, MASK . “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 8. 400, though there the notion is rather of purpose than of opinion.
“MASK MASK MASK” 5. 252, of Ganymede. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK” 2. 247.

so Ascanius 10. 132 is called “MASK MASK MASK MASK” as also “MASK MASK MASK” Wagn. not unnaturally complains of the words as otiose here, the plot not being intended to benefit Ascanius in any way, except so far as he is served by anything which serves Aeneas. It is possible however that the removal of Ascanius to Idalia may be meant to present itself to Venus as a natural outlet for her own affection, as well as in pursuance of the plot: comp. 10. 46—53, where the general thought is parallel. The very obscurity with which this is indicated may be an intentional stroke, in a speech from which everything is excluded which does not bear on the one object of persuading Cupid. But on such matters it is easy to be over-subtle.
is probably the dat. (‘MASK’ being construed like ‘MASK’), not the abl., as Forb. thinks.

A similar pleonasm occurs in MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (quoted by Forb.). ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Venus, like other gods, had her temples in high places. Cythera is called high here, and in 10. 86. “MASK MASK MASK” are mentioned just below, v. 692, and “MASK MASK MASK” 10. 51. Comp. also “MASK MASK MASK” v. 415. Wagn. appears right in remarking that “MASK” is frequently used for entering a high place, as “MASK” for entering a low place, and “MASK” for entering a large place.
in my temple or grove. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 2. 742. As might be expected, two MSS. have “MASK MASK”

There is something inartificial in the arrangement here, as Cupid has not yet been told that he is to personate Ascanius, and the only way in which Ascanius could spoil the plot would be by appearing along with Cupid. Venus however has had the details in her mind from the first, v. 658, and she naturally dismisses the subject of Ascanius first, so as to conclude her speech with instructions to Cupid. Henry distinguishes between knowledge of the plot (‘MASK MASK’） and accidental intervention (‘MASK MASK’). “MASK MASK MASK” 10. 402.

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK . See Madv. § 306. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is to be explained like “MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK (note), the case, which here is the acc. of duration, not being altered by the construction with the comparative, any more than if “MASK” had been used. See Madv. § § 305, 306.

personate. Gossrau comp. MASK MASK , MASK where however MASK merely means to disguise. Comp. rather the use of ‘MASK MASK’ and see note on v. 407. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ it will not be difficult for you to put on the expression of a boy as you are a boy yourself. Venus removes an objection by anticipation. The notions of actual transformation and of imitation are blended and perhaps confused throughout. ‘MASK MASK’ not known to Cupid, but i. q. “MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 12. 911. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ comp. 5. 569.
when Dido, at the height of her pleasure as a queen exercising splendid hospitality, and rejoicing herself in the feast, opens her heart and takes thee to her bosom.

at the table. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Hor. 2 S. 2. 4. ‘MASK’ seems strictly to mean while the feast is going on, like “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ of wine, MASK . the correlative of “MASK MASK MASK” 8. 615. ‘MASK MASK’ 2. 490 note.

sc. “MASK MASK” as is proved by the parallel passage 7. 350, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Comp. also 9. 572, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” The mixture of the images of fire and poison reminds us again of the details of the catastrophe in Euripides' Medea, referred to on v. 659.

refers to his change of nature from a winged god to a boy, not to his change of gait from that of a god (vv. 46, 405., 5. 649) to that of Iulus. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK” in v. 696, expresses the sly pleasure with which he enters into his part.
see note on v. 412.

MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Furius Antias ap. Macrob. Sat. 6. 1, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The expression seems to be a translation of the Homeric MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , but the notions expressed by the two are MASK all probability quite different; the Homeric image being apparently that of sleep enveloping a man (the reader of Don Quixote will recall Sancho Panza's “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”), while MASK ‘MASK’ the conception would seem to be of dew or rain coming down. Comp. the image MASK 5. 854, where Sleep shakes a bough dripping with the dews of Lethe over the temples of Palinurus, and its imitation MASK Val. Fl. 4. 15. Whether the dews are the dews of night or of the body MASK sleep, is not clear. Pers. 5. 56 would prove the latter, if he does not mean satirically to pervert the image.
implies that he was cradled among the flowers and leaves. Catull. 59 (61). 8, calls upon Hymen to wreath himself “MASK MASK MASK”
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’
meanwhile Cupid had set out on his way.
If ‘MASK’ is to be connected with ‘MASK MASK’ it means that he shows signs of pleasure as he goes along.

On his arrival the feast begins. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ the perfect coupled with the historic present ‘MASK MASK’ as the pluperfect would have been coupled with the past. ‘MASK’ are doubtless the awning or curtain that hung from a Roman ceiling to catch the dust, and under which the couches would be arranged. Comp. Hor. 2 S. 8. 54, and the Schol. there. So also Serv. and the older commentators interpreted it, and so Henry. It is difficult however to account for the abl., which may be either in or under a curtain, or settled herself (‘MASK MASK’） with a curtain, as contributing to the ease of the banquet. Heyne, followed by the later editors, takes ‘MASK’ for the tapestry on the couch; but there seems to be no authority for this use of the term. Horace's “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (3 Od. 29. 15) might support such a meaning if established, but cannot be quoted to prove it.

dissyllable, 7. 190. Serv. thought it might be nom. ‘MASK MASK’ the open side of the bed or couch. Dict. A. ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ in the centre of the triclinium. This seems to have been the host's place (Hor. 2 S. 8. 23). Gossrau thinks the meaning is, that Dido occupied a couch by herself in the middle of the banqueting-hall. The narrative seems to afford little or no help in determining the question: see however on v. 718. An imitation in Val. F. 2. 346 is perhaps in favour of Gossrau's view, as both Hypsipyle and Jason are represented as taking the middle place; but the passage is too rapid and summary to throw much light on Virg.

does not begin a new paragraph, as the early editors thought; but there is no occasion to connect this line, as Wagn. and Forb. have done, with the lines before, as though it were intended to mark still farther the time of the arrival of Ascanius.
may be taken either as a preposition (comp. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK ) or adverbially—on purple spread over the couch, a view supported by v. 708, and Stat. Ach. 2. 82, “MASK MASK MASK MASK”

This is the order of the words in Med., Rom., Pal., the St. Gall palimpsest, Gud., and other good MSS. The common reading, supported by the MSS. of Priscian (De fig. num. ed. Kr. 2. 389), is “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Med., Pal., and Gud. have ‘MASK MASK’ which seems to have been introduced from v. 703. For the details comp. Od. 1. 144 foll. &c., and see MASK foll. notes. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ serve out the bread promptly from the baskets, “MASK MASK” says Serv. In Hom. heralds serve the water, maids the bread, boys the wine.
see on MASK . Here Med. a m. p. and Gud. originally have the spelling ‘MASK’

All the MSS. appear to give “MASK MASK MASK” which is the common reading. But ‘MASK’ has the authority of Charisius, the oldest extant grammarian, and was current as well as ‘MASK’ in the time of Gellius (4. 1). It also seems to have been read by Ausonius, who (Idyll. 3. 27) has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” This passage of Ausonius seems also to give the explanation of ‘MASK’—a store that will last for a long time. Serv., in explaining the difference between ‘MASK’ and “MASK MASK” says that “MASK” is “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” which probably shows that he read ‘MASK’ here, especially as he goes on to speak of the gender of ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ will then have nothing to do with the office of “MASK MASK” the arranger of the dishes, as Taubmann supposes, but will be i. q. “MASK MASK” to furnish or replenish; these ‘MASK’ being evidently distinguished from the two hundred who serve the banquet. ‘MASK’ may be a translation of Hom.'s MASK MASK in the parallel passage, Od. 7. 104; but it more probably has reference to the “MASK MASK MASK” as opposed to the hall in which the guests were served. ‘MASK’ refers not to ‘MASK MASK’ but to the division or course of labour among the servants, as in MASK , A. 5. 102. ‘MASK’ was retained by Heinsius and Heyne, and is still preferred by Gossrau and Henry; but ‘MASK’ was restored by Wagn., and is generally read by the later editors. ‘MASK MASK’ is of course common enough in Virg.; but this would be the very reason for its introduction here by a transcriber. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ seems to express merely the keeping up of the fire for cooking. Comp. MASK MASK , Aesch. Ag. 1038, MASK MASK , ib. 1056. For ‘MASK’ see note on MASK , and comp. MASK . ‘MASK’ seems to be etymologically connected with ‘MASK MASK’ and therefore the two are appropriately joined. For the construction ‘MASK MASK’ see on MASK .

Henry remarks, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ iubetque praevenire conatus consulis : occupare velut arcem eius : opprimere delectam iuventutem : quia Vestinus inminentis foro aedes decoraque servitia et pari MASK habebat . ’”

Most of the MSS., including Med., Gud., and partially Pal., have ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ which Wagn. rightly recalled as agreeing better with ‘MASK MASK’ before. Heyne had introduced ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ from Rom.: it is found too in the St. Gall palimpsest. Virg. follows Hom. in setting on the cups at once. The Romans were apt to reserve drinking to the second course, as Serv. remarks on v. 723 below.
does not equal “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” as Wagn. thinks. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is merely a poetical phrase for, bidden to the banquet. ‘MASK’ for “MASK MASK”
expressive of the glowing looks of lovers, and therefore appropriate to the god of love. Catull. 62 (64). 91, “MASK MASK MASK MASK”
with its border embroidered. Comp. v. 649. Some have wished to omit the line; but it draws out ‘MASK’ into detail, as v. 710 draws out ‘MASK MASK’
is equivalent to “MASK MASK” Comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK” and A. 4. 497, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” So “MASK MASK MASK” 4. 90. Not unlike is its use of material fire 5. 683, 699.
She is moved by the bearer as much as by the gifts. An old reading was ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but this order is only found in inferior MSS.
“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK .
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ For ‘MASK’ see note on v. 684, and comp. 3. 302, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv.'s explanation, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” is improbable.

&c., hangs on him with her eyes and with her whole heart. Val. Fl. 6. 658, imitates the construction: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” There is something of the same image in Tennyson's “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
he was probably reclining next her at table. This explains ‘MASK MASK’ Henry rightly remarks on the force of ‘MASK’ after ‘MASK MASK’ as tending to concentrate our thoughts on her.

Med., Gud. corrected, supported also by the MSS. of Non. 311. 29; ‘MASK MASK’ Rom., St. Gall palimps. Gud. originally has ‘MASK’ which probably points the same way. The word is lost in Pal. Serv. recognizes both readings, and on 6. 708 quotes “MASK MASK” On the whole it seems best, with Heyne and Ribbeck, to adopt the rarer word. The difference is between resting on the bosom and settling or sinking down into it.

The only account of the epithet ‘MASK’ is given by Serv., who after narrating an absurd etymology from MASK , cares, explains the word from the Acidalian spring near Orchomenus in Boeotia, where the Graces, Venus' attendants, bathed. The one other author who has used the word is Martial, who speaks, 6. 13. 5, of Venus' zone as “MASK MASK” and 9. 14. 3, of “MASK MASK MASK” as a pen with which Venus would write, apparently a reed growing by the spring.

Serv. (who is followed by Wund.) explains ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Comp. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” v. 673. But the meaning more probably is, to surprise her unguarded heart—her long devotion to the dead having made her cease to regard love as anything but a thing of the past. So ‘MASK MASK’ is love for a living object, and consequently itself living and real.
is coupled with ‘MASK’ in the only other passages in Virg. where it occurs, 6. 813., 7. 693.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

when they first paused from the feast. Comp. Livy 21. 5. 9, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (quoted by Wagn.). ‘MASK MASK’ is equivalent to “MASK MASK MASK” There may be a notion of the actual noise of the banquet, which is succeeded by a pause, and then by the sound of conversation (“MASK MASK MASK MASK” &c.). ‘MASK MASK MASK’ see on v. 216 above. The cups came in with the “MASK MASK” at a Roman meal. Comp. MASK ; Hor. 4 Od. 5. 31. For ‘MASK’ Pal. originally has “MASK MASK”

as Henry remarks, is appropriate to the size of the bowls. A man could hide himself behind a crater, 9. 346. Comp. Il. 6. 526, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . For ‘MASK MASK’ see note on MASK . The line is repeated 7. 147, with the change of “MASK” for ‘MASK MASK’

For ‘MASK’ some inferior MSS. have ‘MASK’ which is supported by several passages in Virg., especially 4. 665, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 5. 451, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” acknowledged by Serv., and adopted by Ribbeck. ‘MASK’ then would = “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ however is paralleled by “MASK MASK” 2. 209, “MASK MASK” 6. 220, and agrees exactly with “MASK MASK MASK” just below, v. 730. This would seem to show that the noise begins after the pause made by clearing away the food, as suggested on v. 723. Thus ‘MASK’ will have the sense ‘MASK MASK MASK’ The Longobardic MS. and a few others read ‘MASK’ here for ‘MASK MASK’ probably from 4. 665. ‘MASK MASK’ of the talkers, as “MASK MASK” of the winds 10. 98. “MASK MASK” is said 5. 149 of the shores that echo the sound, a sense which some have wished to impart here, making ‘MASK’ one word. The commentators comp. Od. 1. 365, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .
The mention of the lamps here seems to show that they are now first lighted, so that ‘MASK’ is emphatic.

Lucretius (5. 295) has “MASK MASK MASK” which he distinguishes from “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ appear to be tapers formed of a twist of some fibrous plant covered with wax. Varro ap. Servium. The form ‘MASK’ is preferred by Ribbeck from some MSS., and is supported by Lucr. l. c., where the MS. reading is ‘MASK’ Ribbeck refers to Ritschl, Mus. Phil. 10. 450.

sc. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Comp. 9. 300, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” It is doubtful whether ‘MASK MASK’ means descended from Belus, or from the time of Belus; but analogy seems rather in favour of the latter. Belus here is not Dido's father (v. 621), but the supposed founder of the Tyrian dynasty. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 11. 241. The silence is natural enough when the queen is going to speak (comp. Alcinous' address to the herald Od. 7. 178). From this he argues that the table MASK 8. 279 had doubtless been dedicated along with the “MASK MASK MASK” MASK the present case he thinks the libation was less formal, being practised by Dido alone (contrast “MASK” 8. 278), who as a queen had certain immunities. MASK Hom. at any rate there are libations where there is no mention of altars (Il. 16. 230 foll.). ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the offering which consists of wine. Bitias is a Carthaginian name. Comp. Sil. 2. 409. Serv. refers to Livy for the fact that a Bitias commanded the Carthaginian fleet. The cup seems to be passed to the Carthaginians, because it was chiefly from them that the pledge of hospitality was required. ‘MASK MASK’ bidding him be quick (‘MASK’). “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK . ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ are opposed to ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ There is playful humour in the contrast, which is too lightly touched to be undignified, as some have thought, even if Virg. could not appeal to the example of Hom. in speaking of the Phaeacian court.

The bard is introduced at the feast in imitation of Hom., Od. 1. 325 foll. and 8. 499 foll. fills the hall. Comp. Tac. A. 16. 4, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is the reading of Med., Rom., Pal., and other MSS. adopted by the later editors. Were the change worth making, the MSS. would scarcely stand in the way, as ‘MASK’ is often written for ‘MASK’ and QVEMAXVMVS might be interpreted either way (see on MASK ). Atlas in Hom. Od. 1. 52 knows the depths of the sea, and supports the pillars of earth and heaven, the epithet given to him being MASK . He seems also to have been a sort of mythical representative or progenitor of physical philosophers, among whom he is recorded by Diogenes Laertius. Being identified with the African mountain, he is naturally chosen by Virg. here as the instructor of a Carthaginian bard. For the conception of Iopas see note on MASK , and comp. the song of Orpheus MASK foll., and that of Virg.'s own Silenus, which is imitated from it, MASK foll.

like “MASK MASK MASK” 9. 811. Some inferior MSS. give ‘MASK MASK’ with the Schol. on Lucan 1. 133. The natives are naturally made to set the fashion, the strangers to follow it, as Serv. remarks.

“MASK MASK MASK MASK” 6. 537 note. See also on MASK , where I have explained “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK” of speeding along. But it is very difficult to say, as the more usual sense of “MASK” when applied to time is to protract (see the Lexicons), and the reference here may be to the length to which the conversation continued into the night. Perhaps Virg. intended to blend the two notions, in spite of their apparent inconsistency, meaning no more than that the conversation lasted the whole night long.

She drank in love with the words of Aeneas. ‘MASK’ probably refers to the notion of length contained in ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK” 3. 487 note. Serv. says “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but this can hardly be meant.

No especial praise is given to the horses of Diomede in the Iliad, though high praise is given to those which he takes from Aeneas (Il. 5. 263 foll.), and with which he wins the chariot-race (Il. 23. 377 foll.), as also to those which he takes from Rhesus (Il. 10. 567). Serv. thinks that these are meant to be the descendants of the flesh-eating horses of Diomedes of Thrace, MASK . It is possible that there may be some confusion between the names; it is possible too that Virg. may have remembered the prowess of Diomede's horses in the chariotrace without recollecting that they were once Aeneas' own. Generally too he may have remembered that Diomede was in a chariot when he encountered Aeneas. That he refers to this encounter and also to that of Achilles with Aeneas is almost certain from 10. 581, where Liger says to Aeneas, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”—‘MASK MASK’ how terrible in war. Comp. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 11. 283, said by Diomede himself of Aeneas. The notion of bulk is prominent, but not, as Henry thinks, the only one.
nay rather, instead of answering more questions in detail, tell us the whole story from the first.

Henry seems right in taking the latter part of the sentence as simply explanatory of the former, the ‘MASK MASK’ being identical with the ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but it is not so certain that these are summed up in the nine who come out of the horse in v. 260, as vv. 328, 401, would lead us to suppose that the number was larger, even if we do not suppose Virg. to be in agreement with Hom., who in Od. 4. 287, mentions one, Anticlus, not included in Virg.'s list. ‘MASK’ goes with ‘MASK MASK’

Wagn. is hardly right in explaining ‘MASK MASK’ here and v. 180 to mean no more than “MASK MASK MASK” In 1. 307., 4. 46, 381, where similar expressions are used, the meaning evidently is that the person is supposed to be driven by the winds: here the notion seems to be that of dependence on the winds, though we are meant to infer that the winds are favourable. The ships, as Henry remarks, were drawn up on the shore, and the tents pitched among them. The opposition is between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ was restored by Heins. from Med., Rom., and other MSS. ‘MASK’ is however supported by Gud. corrected, Canon., and others, and given as an alternative by Serv.

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv., rightly, as is shown by the parallel v. 189, and by the passage from Attius quoted on v. 17, from which Virg. doubtless took the words. The epithet ‘MASK MASK’ which is rather in the Homeric style than appropriate to anything in the context, makes it likely that he was referring also to Eur. Tro. 536, MASK MASK MASK , which according to the ordinary interpretation is understood in precisely the same way, though Hermann questions the applicability of MASK to the goddess, and supposes MASK MASK to be the horse. The offering was made to Minerva as one of the tutelary deities of Troy, whom the Greeks had outraged, and as such it was virtually an offering to Troy and the Trojans—a consideration which reconciles the present passage with those where it is spoken of as a gift to the Trojans (vv. 36, 44, 49), and accounts for the epithet ‘MASK MASK’ That some such object was pretended before Sinon came forward to develope the story we have seen in v. 17. ‘MASK’ seems still to be the gen., as in Cic. Verr. 2. 3. 80, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” presents made to Roman citizens (referred to by Gossrau).
v. 150 below. Thymoetes is one of the old men sitting on the wall, Il. 3. 146. Diodorus Siculus, 3. 87, makes him son of Laomedon.

In Hom. (Od. 8. 504) the Trojans first drag the horse to the citadel (which in Virg. does not happen till v. 245), and then deliberate as here what to do with it, the party of Thymoetes being represented by the words MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .

because, according to the legend mentioned by Serv., and a scholiast on Lycophron, Thymoetes had a grudge against Priam, who in consequence of an oracle that a child born on a certain day would be the ruin of Troy , put to death an illegitimate son of his own by Cilla, wife of Thymoetes, not Paris, who had the same birthday. ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as Henry takes it. ‘MASK MASK’ seems to mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ see on 11. 345. for the horse itself, like “MASK” v. 264. Od. 8. 494, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , unless MASK be an adverbial or cognate acc. So Eur. Tro. 530, MASK MASK , also of the horse. ‘MASK MASK’ see on v. 31.

It may be doubted from the word ‘MASK’ whether Virg. meant to translate Od. 8. 508, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . ‘MASK’ is the reading of the MSS. V. 34. 1) adduces other instances where ‘MASK’ couples notions which though not strictly compatible with each other have some point in common,—as here burning and sinking are two modes of destroying the horse, and so are distinguished from any plan of examining it.

Od. 8. 507, where the three propositions debated are breaking open the horse ( MASK , stronger than ‘MASK’), casting it from a precipice, and accepting it as a peace-offering to the gods. ‘MASK’ here is simply to search, with no notion of danger, as Forb. thinks, whatever it may have clsewhere. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ a translation of MASK MASK , Od. 4. 277., 8. 515.

implies that they take opposite sides, apparently those of Thymoetes and Capys, with warmth, ‘MASK’ being almost an anticipation of Tacitus' use of the word MASK the sense of factions, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Hist. 4. 6. The line is doubtless meant, as it is generally quoted, to characterize a mob contemptuously; but it points as much to party spirit as to giddiness.

Pergamus, which overlooked the shore. Heyne.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ who is mentioned not as actually having been a principal in the scheme, which the Trojans could not have known, but as the natural author of fraud, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 6. 529.

The two cases put in this and the two following lines are that the horse is a receptacle of soldiers, and that it is a means of scaling the walls. In the former case it would be fatal if admitted within the city, in the latter even if left outside. There is not the slightest reason to suppose with Ribbeck that v. 45 and vv. 46, 47 were left as alternatives by Virg., who would have omitted the one or the other in revising his work.

Heyne, after Vegetius, 4. 19, points out an allusion to the “MASK MASK” a military engine with several stories, run on wheels alongside the walls, which it approached by throwing out a bridge. See Dict. A. sub voce .

for “MASK MASK” like MASK . Hand, Tursell. 2. 520. Mr. Munro, who apparently takes Lachm.'s objection as applying to Latin of the golden and earlier ages, does not, I am glad to see, defer to it.
This verse may remind us that it is not always safe to argue from the position of words to their construction, as ‘MASK MASK’ clearly goes with ‘MASK MASK’ not with ‘MASK MASK’ Comp. 5. 500.

Some ingenuity has been wasted (see Wagn., Forb., Henry) MASK explaining ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Generally where the preposition is repeated there is no copula, as MASK v. 358, the former, as Forb. remarks, supplying the place of the latter. Here we have both, as MASK v. 337. All that can be said grammatically is that two notions are coupled: how they are coupled depends on the context. The reading of this line is doubtful. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is attested by Pomponius Sabinus to have been read by Apronianus, and is the second reading of Med. Serv. recommends ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ to avoid the jingle. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is the first reading of Med., found also apparently in both Pal. and Rom. Wagn. adopts it, comparing 7. 684, and is followed by later editors, rightly it would seem. Weidner cites an imitation in Sil. 7. 561 foll. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where it is quite in keeping with the practice of an imitator to borrow the words from one part of his original, the rhetorical use of the second person from another. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is the reading of Heyne, but it appears to have no first-class authority, though Pierius speaks of it as found in ancient MSS. The occurrence of the imperf. subj. in conjunction with the pluperf. ind. is noticeable.

The story of Sinon was the subject of a lost tragedy by Sophocles, and is variously told by Quinct. Smyrnaeus, Tryphiodorus, Dictys, Dares, and Tzetzes. See Introduction to this Book. In one of the versions he is made to mutilate himself like Ulysses in Od. 4. 244, a source from which, as Heyne suggests, the whole story may have originated. He is represented as the son of Aesimus the brother of Anticleia, and thus a first cousin to Ulysses.

Virg. however probably used ‘MASK’ as a “MASK MASK MASK” according to his usual custom, so as to secure the associations connected with the term, though the real analogy to his expression is to be found in such phrases as “MASK MASK MASK” and in the use of “MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is rightly understood by Henry not of actually opening the gates, which Sinon is not said to have done, but of his effecting an entrance for the Greeks by the story he tells, and by letting them out of the horse.

This line is repeated 3. 612, while here it is omitted in Med. (where it is added by another hand in the margin), Pal., and Gud., and not noticed by Serv. Heyne infers from Pomponius Sabinus that it was erased on critical grounds by Apronianus, whose recension Med. represents. Rom. unfortunately fails us here, having an extensive lacuna after v. 72, down to 3. 684. It is certain that Virg. frequently repeats himself (probably with the notion of imitating Hom.), and equally certain that the inferior MSS. frequently introduce lines from other parts of the poem into places where they have no business, so that it seems safest to print the verse in brackets. In itself it is sufficiently appropriate, in spite of a slight verbal inconsistency with v. 107, though not necessary, as with ‘MASK’ the beginning of Sinon's speech is not very abrupt.

For Palamedes see Heyne's Excursus, where it is shown that Virg. made a confusion in connecting him with Belus. The quantity of the penultimate of the patronymic is contrary to rule, but mentioned as an exception by Priscian, p. 584. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Palamedes appears to have figured in the tragedians (see the fragments of Aesch., Soph., Eur.) as a kind of human Prometheus, some of the inventions of the latter being actually attributed to him. He was a favourite subject with the Sophists, some of whom exercised their ingenuity in dressing up a case for him or for Ulysses, while others fixed on him as the true type of a hero, not violent, like Achilles, but wise after the Stoic pattern, and even insinuated that Homer's silence about him was owing to jealousy of his supposed poetical power.

The apodosis begins here. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ i. e. I may designate myself as such; an ellipsis, as Trapp remarks, as good in English as in Latin. ‘MASK’ then is the emphatic word. ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ are not strictly co-ordinate, as the meaning evidently is that Sinon was sent to be Palamedes' comrade, being already his kinsman; but writers are not always conscious grammarians, and instances may be found even in prose where the ordinary epithet is confounded with the epithet used predicatively.

Of the various explanations devised by the commentators to account for the mention of the poverty of Sinon's father, the most natural seem to be that some specification was to be expected MASK a plausible tale, and that poverty, while increasing the pathos of the story, would account for Sinon's dependence on a superior. So MASK the case of Achemenides, 3. 615. ‘MASK MASK’ to war, Lucan 3. 292. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ can only mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as MASK 8. 517, MASK spite of the difficulty to be noticed v. 138. Heyne altered the pointing, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ but the order of the words and the rhythm of the line are so strongly against him, that the poet would in that case have been guilty of an inexcusable ambiguity. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ to give them time to set sail, the subj. being used to show the logical relation of the clause to the verb preceding it. See note on MASK . ‘MASK MASK MASK’ cannot stand, as Wagn. supposes, for “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The explanation of other passages to which he applies his hypothesis has been given on v. 94. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ v. 756, suggests a better interpretation, in the hope, or on the peradventure that they would have sailed, of which of course there would be a doubt, as the necessary condition had not been fulfilled. An inconsistency will still remain between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ the one implying that Sinon waited while they were getting off, the other that he trusted to their having got off before his waiting was over; but this is hardly an objection, if indeed the confusion might not be said to have a dramatic propriety. Virg. probably thought of Il. 2. 794, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .
an epithet of affection, not used, as in 4. 633, to distinguish the country of his birth from that of his sojourn. Comp. MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”.

Serv. mentions a reading ‘MASK MASK’ which is found in Pal. originally and Ribbeck adopts it. But the enumeration would be jejune, and the epithet ‘MASK’ is tender and natural. Comp. 4. 33, MASK . ‘MASK’ presents a difficulty from the age of Sinon, who is said to have been sent to the war “MASK MASK MASK MASK” v. 87 (note). The notion that Virg. intentionally makes Sinon contradict himself is not to be thought of; while Henry's interpretation ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ i. e. my father and his sons, is equally impossible, and not to be defended from 4. 605., 6. 116, where the context at once fixes the sense. Had there been any object in reading ‘MASK’ we might have explained ‘MASK’ with reference to ‘MASK MASK’ but the reverse process in a context like this is not so easy. Either we must suppose an oversight, or say that Sinon, though sent out early (the time, as remarked in note on v. 87, being probably fixed with reference to the Roman age for service), may yet have been married.

is the reading of Med., Pal., and Gud., supported by Serv., who explains it “MASK MASK MASK MASK” and says that others join ‘MASK’ as ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ a variety which of course offers a further confirmation. Heyne supposes ‘MASK’ to have arisen from “MASK” the old way of writing the common reading ‘MASK MASK’ which is recognized by Pomponius; but in the absence of a more ancient authority it seems more probable that ‘MASK’ was introduced from the parallel passage 8. 495, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” to avoid the difficulty of the original text. But “MASK” and “MASK” are confused elsewhere, as in v. 781 below, and perhaps in Catull. 11. 11, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (so MS. Dresd.; the oldest copies omit “MASK”), where all perplexity would be removed by reading “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Wagn. and Forb., who read ‘MASK MASK’ take ‘MASK’ in apposition with ‘MASK MASK’ comp. 6. 20; there however the structure of the sentence gives more scope for such a construction, which here could only be explained by reference to the use of MASK in Greek. Had Virg. intended a Grecism, we should probably have other instances of the kind in his imitators, such as Silius, who in 1. 677 has “MASK MASK MASK MASK” There seems no objection to the double acc. after ‘MASK MASK’ which is found 7. 606, for Burm.'s remark, adopted by Heyne, that the demand was one not from, but of the family of Sinon, is equally good against the expression ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which it is needless to say is used where the person's own life is the satisfaction demanded. ‘MASK MASK’ is found 11. 50, Hor. 1 Od. 28. 31 &c., and is doubtless to be explained as an archaic expression, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ = ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ see below on v. 692.

But though his appeal to the sacrifice which he had escaped was a sham oath, the same cannot be said of the address to heaven; and so we need not fancy that anything is intended here by the use of ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ being plainly futures. 6. 583. The story of the Palladium was variously told; the main points however seem to be that its importance as one of the charms which rendered Troy impregnable became known to the Greeks through Helenus, and that Diomede and Ulysses made their way to the citadel by a secret passage and took the image, quarrelling about it on their road home. Its supposed possession by the Romans was accounted for in different ways, some saying that Diomede restored it to Aeneas in Italy (see on 3. 407), others that it was never taken by the Greeks, but hidden by the Trojans, and discovered by the Romans during the Mithridatic war. But it forms no part of Virg.'s story, being merely alluded to again 9. 151. See Serv.'s note on the present passage, and Heyne's Excursus, which treats chiefly of the capture of the Palladium as represented on gems.

See MASK , from which part of this line is repeated. The general notion is that of flowing away, as opposed to permanence, “MASK” v. 163 (and so Donatus). So Cic. Orator 3, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” So too the philosophical use of ‘MASK’ in Lucr. e. MASK . The particular image it is difficult to fix, if indeed any definite image was present to the poet's mind. Perhaps that of a man carried off from his standing-ground “MASK MASK” (11. 427) by the reflux of a wave (“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 10. 307), and so borne back to sea, would come nearest to it: but as the same words in the passage from the Georgics introduce a different image, though one excluded here by the context, it is safer not to speak confidently.

The story of Laocoon appears to have been variously related. See Introduction to this book. Euphorion apud Serv. agrees mainly with Virg., except that Laocoon's real offence is said to have been a forbidden marriage; and so Hyginus, who treats the notion of any other crime as a delusion of the Trojans. Heyne thinks it probable that Virg. may expressly have copied Euphorion, whom he is known to have admired (see MASK ., 10. 50). Of Sophocles' tragedy of Laocoon but very few fragments have been preserved: from one of them however (fr. 343, Nauck) it appears that his story must have differed from Virg.'s, as the flight of Aeneas with his father and a body of Trojan emigrants is distinctly mentioned, so that the hero of the play can hardly have died before the taking of the city. Serv. has a strange notice of Bacchylides, who, he says, speaks of Laocoon and his wife, or the serpents which came from the Calydnae islands and were turned into men (“MASK MASK MASK” might conceivably mean ‘MASK MASK’); but the passage may be corrupt. For fuller details of these legends see Heyne's Excursus. An interest of a different kind is given to the story by Lessing's celebrated treatise.

‘MASK’ refers generally to the blindness of the Trojans, not to their inability to foresee this portent (Heyne); nor proleptically to its effect in making them rush on their doom (Wagn. ed. mi., Forb. &c.). Comp. v. 54. ‘MASK MASK’ the intellect, as 1. 567.

a variety for “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Comp. 1. 508, “MASK MASK MASK” and note. So in English a man is said to be drawn for the militia. MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”, a thoroughly Sophoclean expression, altered, like others of the sort, by some later critics. Serv. quotes a fragment of Sallust, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and the phrase is also found Tac. A. 1. 54., 13. 29. According to Euphorion, Laocoon was already the priest of the Thymbraean Apollo, and was chosen by lot on this occasion to sacrifice to Neptune, in place of the former priest, who had been put to death. Herder (referred to by Heyne) thought this description partly suggested by Il. 2. 305 foll.; but the resemblance is very slight.

the altars where the customary sacrifices took place; Heyne, who comp. “MASK MASK” Ov. F. 5. 597, “MASK MASK MASK” A. A. 1. 133, “MASK MASK” Claud. 6 Cons. Hon. 5. Hyginus makes him sacrifice on the shore according to the Homeric practice, and this is probably Virg.'s meaning (comp. 3. 21, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”), as the subsequent description suggests.

‘MASK MASK’ Quinctus Smyrnaeus and Lycophron make them come from the Calydnae, two islands near Tenedos, mentioned Il. 2. 677 with Cos. Donatusis doubtless right in saying that this symbolized the appearance of the enemy from Tenedos; but there seems no occasion, in default of any intimation from the poet, to draw out the parallel into detail, as Henry does, not only making the destruction of Laocoon's sons and their father stand for the slaughter of the Trojans and the overthrow of their religion, but supposing that the movement of the serpents abreast represents the sailing of the ships together, the erection of their flaming crests the signal from the royal galley, the floating of their hinder parts on the surface the motion of the vessels in the rear, and lastly, their taking refuge under Pallas' feet the hostile settlement of Pallas herself on the citadel, v. 615. ‘MASK MASK’ the names of the serpents were actually given in the legend, among others by Sophocles. Tzetzes on Lycophron calls them Porces and Chariboea, Lysimachus ap. Serv. Curiffis (?) and Periboea.
with a notion of movement supplied from the context.

‘MASK MASK MASK’ is not precisely parallel to 3. 127, 706, Ov. F. 4, 289, 566, where the notion is really that of picking the way among islands or sunk rocks, so that perhaps it had better be compared to ‘MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ the motion of the serpents along the surface of the water resembling that of a ship skirting the land. ‘MASK MASK’ the common reading, supported by Pal., Med., and other MSS., and by Serv. is restored by Wagn. instead of ‘MASK’ the reading of Heins. and Heyne, which Pierius found in some very old copies. As Wagn. remarks, the nom. ‘MASK MASK’ is emphatic, opposing the second part of the sentence to the first. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

‘MASK’ these serpents, as being portentous, combine the noxious powers of several varieties, devouring, strangling, and poisoning. ‘MASK’ of blood tainted by the venom, Lucan 9. 770, 783, 794. ‘MASK MASK’ to show completely the inefficiency of his priestly character to protect him. It seems better, on a comparison of MASK , to understand “MASK” after ‘MASK’ than to supply “MASK MASK” with Wagn. and Forb.; but the point is very doubtful. It signifies little whether we make ‘MASK’ nom. sing. or pl.; but ‘MASK’ is said to be better supported by MSS. and grammarians, so the sing. seems the more probable, though in these matters the weight of external evidence must be very slight. The early commentators rightly remark on the propriety of the simile of the bull, as suggesting the sacrifice in which Laocoon was engaged by a kind of tragic MASK . The simile is partially imitated from Il. 20. 403, where the bull is being offered to Poseidon. For a victim to escape from the altar, or to bellow when struck, was a bad omen, as we learn from Paulus Diaconus (ap. Cerdam). Cerda refers to Ov. M. 7. 597, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and Livy 21. 63, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” See also v. 134, note.

to be joined with ‘MASK MASK’ i. q. “MASK” ‘MASK’ is the reading of Med. and another MS., but the word probably came from v. 212, and has no place here, as it could only mean, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ whereas the story of the serpents seems to imply that they moved together from first to last, and the repetition of the word ‘MASK MASK’ and the fact that they fly to the same spot, confirm the presumption. ‘MASK MASK’ comp. 1. 479, “MASK MASK MASK MASK”

placed as in MASK , MASK . There seems to have been a statue of Pallas in the arx besides the Palladium, or possibly one was introduced in its place, as the worship of the goddess of course was still kept up. That the mention of it here is not a mere oversight of Virg.'s, appears from the legend that Cassandra was clinging to Pallas' statue when dragged away by the lesser Ajax. See Heyne's Excursus on Vesta, the Palladium, and the Penates. Pallas' statues, as Heyne remarks, had sometimes a serpent coiled at the feet, so that this part of the legend is in keeping. In Q. Smyrnaeus the serpents vanish into the earth near the temple of Apollo.

A.), which were escorted by senators and boys (“MASK” and “MASK”) laying hold of the traces, to let go which was profanation. Mr. Keightley, in a communication to me, remarks a further propriety in the fact that the “MASK” proceeded from and returned to the Capitol, which would answer to the “MASK” here. Copied, according to Serv., from Ennius. Heyne thinks the reference is to Enn. Andr. fr. 9, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK’ see v. 351. The fleet was on its way when the royal ship hoisted the signal to Sinon. ‘MASK’ seems to mean the army, which ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ sailed in order. “MASK MASK” 12. 544. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 10. 213. So Wund. But there may also be a comparison implied between the naval array and the array of a MASK.

has been understood in two opposite ways—the moon quietly shining, or there being no moon as yet; for that the moon did rise appears from .v. 340—in the one case the silence, in the other the darkness, being assumed as favourable to the undertaking. The latter view, which seems to have originated with Politian, Miscell. 100, is apparently supported by the phrase “MASK MASK” (explained by Milton, Samson Agonistes, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”), for instances of which see Forc.; the words however must then be understood improperly, to signify the temporary absence of the moon, unless we suppose that Virg. forgot himself in v. 340, and argue from vv. 335, 360, that the night was meant to be a dark one. On the other hand the former view is supported by all the traditions of the taking of Troy , which is expressly stated to have happened on the full moon of the seventh month, and the expression may well be a variety, as Heyne says, for “MASK MASK” (as Hor. Ep. 5. 51, quoted by Cerda, has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”), even if we do not go farther, and suppose Virg. to have intended the cloudless tranquillity of the moonlight, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” (Pliny, 18. 28), to be the circumstance which befriended the Greeks. The old punctuation, which Wagn. altered, placed a comma after ‘MASK MASK’

‘MASK’ ‘MASK’ was the old reading, supported by some inferior MSS. The Greek form is MASK . Most of the less known names here and elsewhere are greatly varied in the different MSS. Thessander, unknown to Homer, is supposed to be identical with a son of Polynices of that name, whom other legends represented as slain by Telephus at the beginning of the war. ‘MASK MASK’ Il. 2. 564, &c. ‘MASK MASK’ as coming out first. For ‘MASK’ Macrob. read ‘MASK MASK’ which he quotes Sat. 5. 17 as a proof of Virg.'s addiction to Greek words; and so fragm. Vat. originally ‘MASK MASK’ Others give ‘MASK MASK’ as in v. 7 above. But it is evident that in a context like this ‘MASK’ (with which comp. “MASK MASK” 3. 211) is far superior.

refers of course to all mentioned, like “MASK MASK MASK MASK” v. 340, which, as Forb. remarks, is similarly introduced. ‘MASK’ also unknown to Homer, son of Theseus, and brother of Demophoon. The early edd. and Charisius p. 351 have ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ Med. ‘MASK’ Il. 2. 638, &c.

has not yet been satisfactorily explained, as it is weak to take it “MASK MASK” with Heyne; and to suppose with Henry that the man who was actually meant to come out first would be named seventh in a company of nine, is to suppose an abuse of language, though Val. Fl. 4. 224 is quoted as applying the epithet “MASK” to the person mentioned last in order. If it be thought that ‘MASK’ in the present connexion (which Henry compares with v. 32) can bear no other meaning than first in order, it might perhaps be better to place a colon after ‘MASK MASK’ and connect ‘MASK MASK’ &c. with ‘MASK MASK’ at the risk of seeming to make a distinction without a difference between those who come out of the horse and those who rush on the city. On the other hand, it can hardly be an epithet proper to Machaon independently of the present passage, unless it be conceivable that Virg. misunderstood something in his authorities, e. g. Il. 11. 505, MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK . Possibly the word may be corrupt, though the MSS. do not appear to vary.

1. 474. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ MASK (note), where “MASK MASK” answers to ‘MASK MASK’ here, mortals being characterized in their relation to the gods. The epithet here is general, but it is meant to excite sympathy for the Trojans, betrayed while enjoying the relief which kind nature gives to overtoiled mortality. So v. 253, and 6. 520. Contrast Aesch. Ag. 336, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , of the first tranquil sleep enjoyed by the victors after a ten years' siege, unbroken by watchings, and unmolested by the cold airs of heaven.

is appropriate, signifying that Hector assumed the same appearance which he exhibited at the time of his death. Comp. 1. 315, note. In construction it seems to be in apposition with ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ v. 274. ‘MASK’ are probably the wounds which he received while being dragged round the walls, which is the natural sense of ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ In Hom. the body is dragged not round the walls but through the plain to the ships (Il. 22. 392 foll.), and afterwards round the tomb of Patroclus (ib. 24. 14 foll.). We hear of no wounds during the former process, and we are expressly told that they are averted during the latter by Aphrodite (ib. 23. 187) and Apollo. On the other hand we do hear of wounds inflicted by the Greeks on the body before it is tied to the chariot (ib. 22. 371: comp. ib. 24. 420, MASK . . . MASK MASK : MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK ), though these are said to have been closed by divine agency (l. c.). Virg., treating the subject in a different way from Hom., has availed himself of his predecessor where he could: ‘MASK MASK MASK’ here is from Il. 22. 403, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , while ‘MASK’ is from ib. 24. 420 just quoted. What the Penates were was an unsolved problem among the ancients themselves: nor is it easy to say what Virg. supposed them to be. He classes them here and 9. 258 foll. with Vesta (comp. 5. 744), and elsewhere (3. 12., 8. 679) with the “MASK MASK MASK” but it is not clear in either case whether the association implies distinction or identification. All that can be said is that they were supposed to be in a peculiar sense the national gods of Troy (comp. 5. 63, where Acestes has other Penates of his own), and that, as their name imports, they were connected with the home and the hearth. Their images were easily carried, as appears from v. 717 below. On the whole subject see Dict. B. s. v., Heyne's Excursus on this Book, and Lersch § 57. 13.

The words ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which are frequently found together in Virg. ( MASK ., 4. 329 &c.), seem always intended to call attention to the agent, sometimes with direct reference to others, sometimes merely as coming forward prominently, e. g. where the act is one requiring exertion. ‘MASK MASK’ the door of Aeneas, who is just rushing out when he is met by Panthus on the threshold, and sallies forth accordingly, v. 336, after their conversation. ‘MASK MASK’ the old reading in the time of Pierius, supported also by Burmann, is perhaps found only in one MS., the first Hamburg. Panthus evidently flies to Aeneas as the bravest surviving warrior in Troy , supposing too that he may not be aware of the capture of the city.

or “MASK MASK” is frequently used, especially by Livy, in a political sense, for the point on which all depends: and so in 11. 302, where it is equivalent to “MASK MASK” In this way most of the commentators understand it here, taking ‘MASK MASK’ for “MASK MASK MASK” as in Hor. 1 Ep. 12. 25, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and A. 9. 723, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” There is however much to be said for supposing the reference to be military, as suggested by Trapp and enforced by Henry (who has since changed his mind), comparing Livy 23. 49, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Virg. himself twice uses ‘MASK MASK’ in this sense, 10. 70., 12. 572, in the latter place speaking of Latium, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The question then would be, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ taken literally, a natural inquiry for Aeneas, who had just expressed his ardour ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ and according with the rest of the verse. On the whole however it seems more likely that Aeneas, who has as yet seen no one, should ask first a general question about the safety of the city, and then a special one about the citadel, so that after much hesitation I follow Henry in returning to the common view. “MASK” is used in its proper sense, a citadel, or point of defence, though ‘MASK’ seems to show that the word is not meant to be restricted to the citadel MASK MASK , Pergamus, as Wagn.'s interpretation of ‘MASK’ for “MASK” would not yield an appropriate sense. Aeneas sees Panthus hurrying away from the citadel with his gods and his grandson, and so naturally asks, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK MASK’ suspecting already that Pergamus is no longer tenable. Henry well remarks that Panthus answers in effect, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ and that Aeneas, hearing this, rushes out with no definite object in the direction of the shouting. ‘MASK MASK’ 6. 61.

There seems no occasion to assert with Wagn. that ‘MASK MASK MASK’ are not used in their ordinary sense. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The expression in the next verse is not much more hyperbolical if used of a part than if extended to the whole. The great mass was thronging the gateway, and Panthus describes them with the natural exaggeration of terror. ‘MASK’ occurs again 10. 5, where Serv. says it is borrowed from Ennius. Here it probably means folding gates, not a gate opening both ways. Serv. notes it as an instance of a compound adjective made out of a participle, like “MASK MASK” “MASK” &c., a class of words belonging mostly to the earlier Roman literature. Heyne is so far right in saying that the word is used here for “MASK MASK” that it expresses not merely the quality of the gates, but the fact that they are actually open, and so retains its participial force.

the single ‘MASK’ is the orthography of the best MSS. here and elsewhere, though Med. here has another ‘MASK’ added after wards, and, like Pal., has the two last vowels interchanged; it is also supported by the best editions of Greek authors. The reference here is not to the Fury within, as Heyne thinks, but to the Fury without, as Wund. explains it, the demon of battle. So “MASK MASK” Lucan. 4. 187.

is the reading of some inferior MSS., introduced, as Heyne observes, from v. 435 (where the mention of age is appropriate) by those who supposed Epytus to be the same as Iphitus. Weidner comp. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 1. 545.

(‘MASK’ Med.) is found in the best MSS., and is supported by “MASK” 5. 547, where see note. Others have ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK’ who is mentioned v. 435 in connexion with the rest of those who are named here; so that there is some reason for identifying the two. On the other hand, in v. 435 Iphitus is named along with Pelias, who does not appear here. In both places the names have been indefinitely corrupted by the inferior MSS. Heyne first suggested the removal of the semicolon after ‘MASK MASK’ so as to refer ‘MASK MASK MASK’ to all alike. See v. 262. These names are unknown except in the sequel.

It is best to supply ‘MASK’ from ‘MASK’ to ‘MASK MASK’ See 1. 440 note. MASK, son of Mydon (Il. 3. 184), king of Phrygia, and Anaximene, is a postHomeric personage. The legend seems to have agreed about his history, but not about his death, which was generally ascribed to Neoptolemus, by Lesches to Diomedes, and by Virg., or the authority whom he followed (v. 425), to Peneleus. He is mentioned by Euripides (?), Rhes. 539. Euphorion (see on v. 199) represented him as a fool, probably to give individuality to the character, as later writers perverted the Homeric conceptions of Menelaus, Ulysses, &c.; and this view became traditional, Zenobius making him a sort of gigantic idiot who would stand counting the waves of the sea, Aristides (Platon. 2) contrasting him and Palamades as the two extremes, and Aelian (Var. Hist. 13. 15) enumerating him among extraordinary fools. Cerda, who has collected these authorities, also mentions a proverb, MASK MASK . In Virg.'s conception there is merely impetuosity and light-heartedness. The story of the love for Cassandra is evidently borrowed from Hom.'s Othryoneus, Il. 13. 363 foll.

The MSS. of Macrob. Sat. 5. 5 and some inferior MSS. of Virg. insert ‘MASK’ after ‘MASK MASK’ and this was the reading before Heins.; but the omission of the relative is distinctly recognized by Serv., and suits the less strict style of poetical narrative. One MS., the Parrhasian, substitutes ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ which would be plausible if better supported, as the corruption could be accounted for on critical grounds: but the MS. itself has been much interpolated, and the variety need only prove that the copyists were anxious to introduce the relative somewhere: thus in the Balliol MS. it is introduced after ‘MASK’ in spite of the metre. Comp. 1. 12, 530, though here the sentence is not strictly speaking parenthetical, as it interrupts the narrative, but not the construction. The late arrival of Coroebus is borrowed from Hom. 1. c., MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .

It would seem from v. 385 that ‘MASK’ is meant to be taken more or less strictly, the encounter with Androgeos having been the first of any importance engaged in by Aeneas and his friends. We must suppose then that Aeneas is speaking specifically here, having spoken generally v. 367. A former pointing was ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which is supported by the fact that in other passages of the kind where ‘MASK’ is constructed with a gen., the gen. comes after ‘MASK’ (comp. 1. 497., 11. 478): but ‘MASK’ with the gen. elsewhere in Virg. appears to mean ‘MASK MASK MASK’

‘MASK’ was restored by Heins. from Med.; Pal., Gud. originally, &c. however give ‘MASK’ which has also the authority of Serv. The difficulty is that the same spelling is not preserved throughout, as almost all the MSS. read ‘MASK’ v. 392, and Charisius (1. 15, p. 92, Keil) agrees with them, though in 6. 20 he declares that Virg. wrote ‘MASK’ which seems now to be found only in some cursive MSS. In v. 425 the great majority and Charisius have “MASK” not “MASK” In 5. 265 Med. has “MASK” Rom. and Pal. “MASK MASK” which is recognized by Quinctilian 8. 4. 24. The MSS. are constantly varying in the spelling of proper names, and it does not seem probable that Virg. would designedly have alternated between two forms of the same word within a few lines of each other, nor yet that a bonâ fide tradition of his variety of practice in this respect can have come down to the grammarians. Reason would seem in favour of ‘MASK’ ‘MASK’ as the Greek form would be MASK or MASK , like MASK or MASK , and the Romans do not turn MASK into ‘MASK’ while if they had preferred the latter form they would have had to lengthen the penultimate by adopting the diphthong. If ‘MASK’ is to be defended, we must suppose that Virg., wishing to avoid the Greek form, especially in an oblique case, chose to Latinize an imaginary third form, MASK . Meanwhile it seems safest to decide for ‘MASK’ here on the analogy of ‘MASK MASK’ which will also avoid the necessity of supposing a caesura, and in vv. 392, 425 to follow the great multitude of MSS. “MASK MASK” v. 613 below.

is a familiar Grecism, probably to be explained not by attraction, but by the help of the fuller expression, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though in sense of course the participle stands instead of the object of the verb. The principle is the same as that of prolepsis, and is exemplified also in such expressions as “MASK MASK MASK MASK” v. 388. Or we may say that the participle qualifies the verb, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” &c. In some cases the difference between the nom. and the acc. with ‘MASK’ scarcely affects the sense at all, e. g. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK , where the use of the nom. appears quite natural, and the object of the verb is supplied without any difficulty. The use of the nom. with “MASK MASK” as in Hor. 3 Od. 27. 73, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” is not to be confounded with it, as there an attraction does take place, or rather perhaps a confusion between the two modes of expression. It is right also to remember that “MASK” is sometimes used absolutely (see on 7. 434), which may have been an additional reason for Virg. to employ the expression here.

Med. has ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is commonly explained, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The context however seems decidedly to recommend a different sense, as the narrative down to v. 401 is evidently meant to describe the apparent success of the stratagem, and any words suggesting the real truth would not only interfere with the feeling of triumph, but spoil the effect of the next paragraph, which is ushered in by a sudden change of tone, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The words must then refer to the Trojans as marching under a protection not their own, whether we suppose with Serv. that the Grecian arms actually carried with them the favour of the Grecian deities, or understand Virg. simply to express in theological language the advantage derived from the disguise as Aeneas in v. 735 ascribes to some deity the confusion of mind which led him to lose Creusa. In prose we might have had “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Comp. v. 387, where Coroebus suggests that they should treat the opportunity as an interposition of fortune in their favour.

The argument there drawn from this place rests on the assumption that the cowardice described here is not likely to have been shown by any of the leaders of the Greeks: Virg. however may have chosen to disparage them here as he has done 6. 489 foll.

the dat., not the abl. The sense is not ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ but ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ may not rely on Fortune when she has really declared against him. ‘MASK’ seems to express that the gods are not willing to be trusted, as if by taking advantage of a turn of fortune and improving it by a stratagem Aeneas and his companions were exhibiting a trust in Heaven which they were not entitled to feel. This agrees with ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as explained above, and gives a force to the whole context which it would not otherwise possess, the fate of the disguised Trojans being treated as a visitation from the gods for presuming on their aid, or attempting to gain it when it was not to be given. If Serv.'s explanation of v. 396 could be substantiated, the meaning would be more definite; but the passage does not require such a hypothesis. We should bear in mind the prominence given throughout this book to the agency of the gods; the Trojans are blinded by the gods so as to take in the horse: Aeneas rushes out in desperation on hearing that the gods have declared against Troy , v. 336; his very words to his companions, vv. 350 foll., contrast ominously with those of Coroebus, v. 387, the one bidding them accept the doom of the vanquished, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” the other urging them to avail themselves of the first omen of safety and convert it into a certainty. They are punished; and Aeneas, after witnessing the fate of Priam, is caused by Venus to see the gods visibly arrayed against his country. With the language of this line comp. 5. 800, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” which might perhaps be quoted to show that ‘MASK’ here agrees with ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK”

The Cyclic poets, as appears from the argument of the MASK MASK of Arctinus, preserved by Proclus, described Cassandra as dragged from the temple of Pallas by Ajax, the son of Oileus, who dragged away also the statue of the goddess to which she was clinging; for this the Greeks would have stoned him had not he himself taken sanctuary, and his trial before the kings for the crime was the subject of paintings in the Poecile at Athens and at Delphi. The story is also referred to by Eur. Tro. 69 foll., where it is said that the Greeks took no notice of the crime. His death on the voyage home was represented as Pallas' revenge for the sacrilege, as mentioned on 1. 39. The MASK , or dragging away of prisoners into captivity, is mentioned by Hom. (Il. 6. 465, &c.) The suppliant Danaides in Aeschylus (Supp. 428 foll., 909) are in danger of being dragged by the hair from the statues to which they are clinging; and so Eur. Iph. A. 1366, Tro. 881, &c.
the temple of Minerva in the citadel; Aeneas and his comrades had made their way to the heart of the city, v. 359. Heyne.

MASK , of which it may be a translation. The attributing of horses to the winds, like the converse belief that certain horses were the offspring of the winds ( MASK , note), is sufficiently common. Phoen. 219), and a fragment quoted by Orelli, on Hor. l. c., “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The plural ‘MASK’ proves nothing, as Virg. evidently intends ‘MASK MASK’ to be a perpetual epithet.

seemingly implying that Ajax and the Greeks with him had not detected the fraud, their one feeling being revenge for the rescue of Cassandra. Ribbeck, following an indication in Pal., where there is a gap after the first three letters of ‘MASK MASK’ reads ‘MASK MASK’ supposing the sense to be that the Greeks discover that the arms of Aeneas and his friends are really not Greek, but Trojan. But the Trojans are not commonly spoken of as Priam's men; and it is a considerable step even from this to speak of the assumed arms as Priam's arms. ‘MASK MASK’ to be understood in its usual sense with Serv. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ not with Heyne and others as if it were passive. The weapons were actually Greek, and so were not counterfeited, but counterfeiting.

= “MASK MASK MASK MASK” as Jahn explains it, a person who is concerned with a thing when done being said poetically to do it, as in MASK , and elsewhere. ‘MASK MASK’ to be taken closely with ‘MASK MASK’ the discordance being the “MASK MASK” Wund remarks that Hom. assumes that the Greeks and Trojans spoke the same language, but Virg., following the later Greek poets, makes them differ. Forb. says that the difference must be understood to be confined to dialect, as they are always represented in the Aeneid as intelligible to each other. The probability seems to be that Virg. followed Hom. without thought, or from the necessity of the case, in other passages, and that he is here inconsistent with himself. In Aesch. Choeph. 563, Orestes says that Pylades and he will speak in a peculiar dialect; when however they appear again they talk Attic like the rest, the poet not scrupling to be inconsistent where consistency would have produced awkwardness.
