It is not altogether easy to fix the sense of ‘MASK MASK’ That Serv. is right generally in explaining it of battle is clear, so that Forb. has good reason to compare “MASK MASK” in Stat. Theb. 10. 754, and elsewhere. ‘MASK’ however in this connexion may refer either to the casualties of war (that which happens to each in turn), or to actual encounters between two persons, the ‘MASK MASK MASK’ of combat. The former is evidently the prominent notion in Sil. 3. 13, Claudian 6 Cons. Honor. 282, where fortune is spoken of in the context; the latter is perhaps what is intended in Stat. l. c., where the words are “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” On the whole, I can scarcely doubt that Thiel is right in distinguishing ‘MASK’ from ‘MASK MASK’ as hand-to-hand encounters, “MASK MASK” MASK , from missiles; comp. below, v. 726, where the expression is very parallel, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and above v. 358, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ will then = “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” In any case the expression ‘MASK MASK’ is perhaps a little harsh; but there can be no doubt that the punctuation is right, as against an attempt, mentioned by Heyne, and revived by Peerlkamp, Ladewig, Haupt, and Ribbeck, to connect ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ which they join with ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Scaliger seems to have had some notion of the true reference of ‘MASK MASK’ his words being “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ apparently goes with ‘MASK MASK’ as well as ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK” v. 54. One MS. gives ‘MASK MASK’ one or two others ‘MASK MASK’ which Burm. groundlessly prefers.

Whether ‘MASK MASK’ depends on ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ or on ‘MASK MASK’ is hard to say, as either construction would be admissible in itself, and either would suit the passage. ‘MASK MASK’ is aptly explained by Serv., “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Gossrau comp. “MASK MASK MASK” Tac. Germ. 14, and a similar passage in Val. F. 1. 196, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ = “MASK MASK” as in MASK , and elsewhere. ‘MASK MASK’ probably of time, though it might denote place, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The subject of ‘MASK’ is doubtless “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” or as it is less regularly expressed, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

MASK and MASK are unknown to Hom., and do not appear elsewhere in Virg., unless ‘MASK’ is rightly read in v. 340, note. Here, as there, the name is variously spelt, though the form ‘MASK’ does not seem to occur. Virg. would naturally coin such names as he required to make his epic narrative circumstantial. The age of one of Aeneas' comrades, and the disabled state of the other, show how desperate the fortunes of Troy had become, and so contrast with the description vv. 339 foll. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK” 2. 246.

Wund. remarks that two struggles were going on between the assailants and defenders, one about scaling the walls of the palace, the other about forcing an entrance through the doors (vv. 449, 450). The progress of the one is described vv. 452—468, that of the other vv. 469 foll. The ‘MASK’ here intended is probably not the machine so called, but the MASK . Quinct. Smyrnaeus, following, it is supposed, the early Cyclic writers, represents the Greeks as attacking Troy in this manner, in a passage, part of which may be worth quoting (11. 358 foll.): “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Comp. also Virg.'s own description 9. 505 foll., which in some respects is fuller than the present, and Livy 34. 39, cited by Weidner. ‘MASK MASK’ is repeated 9. 505. “MASK MASK” like “MASK MASK” is used of drawing a line, as in MASK , A. 10. 514 (comp. MASK in MASK MASK ); and this seems to be the notion here, the formation of a column of shields, which is driven up to the wall.

in prose “MASK MASK MASK” Heyne. Scaling ladders are part of the Roman (as of the later Greek) apparatus for an assault, which Virg. has transferred to epic times. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ the ladders are planted at the very posts of the doors, ‘MASK’ perhaps pointing to the daring which approaches where the defence would naturally be strongest.

of the ladders, not, as Cerda thought, of the doors. ‘MASK MASK’ describes the ‘MASK MASK’ For ‘MASK MASK’ Med., Gud., and others give ‘MASK MASK MASK’ a reading mentioned by Serv., but rightly rejected by him, and evidently due to ‘MASK MASK’ v. 445. A different error, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ has crept into some copies.

Wund. remarks that ‘MASK’ is added ex abundanti , as participles are sometimes added by the Greek poets, e. g. Soph. Ant. 23. Whether ‘MASK’ means the actual roof, or is used loosely for the projecting battlements, is not easy to say, and perhaps does not much signify.

Serv. mentions a reading ‘MASK MASK’ which is found also in some MSS. ‘MASK MASK’ may serve to illustrate the use of ‘MASK’ as a substantive. Some have suggested ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ so as to leave ‘MASK MASK’ by itself, as in 8. 98., 12. 132 (see on MASK ).

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. The meaning may be not merely that their darts were unavailing, but that they felt them to be so, and accordingly launched them weakly; but this would perhaps be a refinement.

Virg. does not tell us how many ‘MASK’ there were: he merely says that they applied their leverage to the flooring, as affording a point in which implements might be inserted; and he may very well call this flooring ‘MASK’ merely as being above or on the roof of the palace. ‘MASK MASK’ is not a very strict expression, as the joining would not totter itself, though it would make the wall totter. ‘MASK’ is generally taken ‘MASK’ but it may equally well mean ‘MASK’ the tower being overthrown from the bottom. ‘MASK’ then will be the foundation.

The following simile is modelled, MASK parts almost verbally, on one MASK Il. 22. 93 foll., where Hector is compared to a deadly serpent stirring itself up for battle. The point however is not the same: Hector is waiting for an attack, while Pyrrhus is himself the assailant, and the bodily motion of the serpent, which MASK the Homeric image merely implies readiness for conflict, is combined by Virg. with its having renewed its youth, so as to make it a fit symbol of the ‘MASK MASK’ ( MASK ), who, as Henry remarks, appears on the scene at the end of the siege and fleshes his maiden sword during the last days of Troy . Henry refers to a similar comparison MASK Sil. 12. 6 foll. of Hannibal breaking his winter quarters to a serpent emerging from its winter sleep. ‘MASK MASK’ has rather perplexed the commentators, some of whom wish to alter it, while others, rightly constructing it with ‘MASK MASK’ complain of the awkwardness of the separation of the words and of the tautology with ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Virg. however is fond of throwing MASK a word at the beginning of a simile to indicate as it were the main point and apply generally to what follows (comp. 1. 148 “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 6. 707 “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 12. 908 “MASK MASK MASK MASK”), and we may say here that ‘MASK MASK’ does the duty of a verb, which is consequently not needed till v. 474. On the alleged tautology Forb. well remarks that ‘MASK MASK’ includes the light as opposed to underground darkness as well as the actual sunshine. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is Homer's MASK MASK MASK . ‘MASK’ as MASK “MASK MASK” MASK . Henry quotes Pliny 8. 59 to show that the ancients thought the serpent was poisonless during the winter (contrast however Seneca, Epist. 42), and acquired its venom from the food it ate on reviving MASK spring. Statius, Theb. 4. 95 (also quoted by Henry), seems to speak as if there were something peculiarly deadly MASK its first venom.

is not uncommonly applied to serpents (Forb. refers to Ov. M. 1. 460., 10. 313), but it seems scarcely to agree with the state of torpor here mentioned, so that if we do not suppose Virg. to have written loosely, we must assume either that he wishes us to think of the natural violence of the serpent as scarcely subdued by its winter seclusion, or that, unlike Pliny, he holds that the poison is brewing during the winter.

MASK is a Greek warrior, the bravest of the Aetolians, in Hom. (Il. 5. 842), where however he is killed by Ares. He is called MASK , which answers to ‘MASK’ here. Automedon is mentioned repeatedly in the Iliad as Achilles' charioteer. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ MASK . ‘MASK’ alone is a common word for a charioteer: see Forcell. ‘MASK MASK’ note on MASK .

Serv. thinks that MASK had changed his function, and become Pyrrhus' armour-bearer; but he may have been both: see on 6. 485. Elsewhere (9. 648., 11. 32) the armour-bearer of one generation becomes the companion, “MASK MASK” of another. ‘MASK MASK’ Pyrrhus had come from Scyros, the kingdom of his maternal grandfather Lycomedes.

“‘ MASK MASK : ’MASK MASK‘ fores adoriuntur ’” Heyne. It would seem rather as if ‘MASK’ were to be taken strictly of the roof, Pyrrhus' comrades attempting to scale the walls while Pyrrhus himself is making an impression on the door. In other passages, such as 1. 627, ‘MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK’ is used of entering the house.

of Pyrrhus as distinguished from his comrades. ‘MASK’ are the doors, as ‘MASK’ shows. Pyrrhus is battering and hewing the doors with his axe, bursting them through and making them start from their hinges, till at last he cuts out a plank or panel. The presents, ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ describing the general effect of the blows, a process still going on, contrast with ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ which express a single completed act. This seems a truer view of the passage than to say with Henry that the successful forcing of the door is first mentioned all at once, and then its various stages (vv. 480, 481, 491—493) and its consequences (vv. 483—490) enumerated more at leisure. We must remember that Aeneas describes what he saw, and that Pyrrhus would appear to him from the first to be breaking the door through, even before any actual impression had been made.

Non. p. 202 quotes this line to show that ‘MASK’ is masc., so that he must have read ‘MASK’ Gerlach and Roth however print ‘MASK’ with no various reading.

The repetition of sound in ‘MASK MASK’ adds energy to the line. Such jingles are common in early Roman poetry, both tragic and comic, being apparently regarded in the case of the former as pieces of artistic symmetry, in the case of the latter as jokes. The present passage seems to be imitated by Livy 4. 38 (comp. by Taubm.), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK’ a sufficiently common use of “MASK MASK” the accusative expressing not what is burst, but what is produced by bursting—having in short a kind of cognate force. So “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK” &c.

Wagn. questions whether Virg. ought to have represented Aeneas as an eye-witness of all this. The words are doubtless more natural in the mouth of one who, like Andromache, could only look on without any power of resisting; but Aeneas has told us that he bore his part in all the struggles during the last act of the tragedy (vv. 6, 431 foll.), and so he may fairly speak of what he was compelled to witness in spite of himself, as in fact he has already done v. 5. For ‘MASK’ one copy has ‘MASK MASK’ which Heyne prefers, on account of ‘MASK’ so closely preceding; but ‘MASK’ is the better word here, and if the repetition is not intentional, as Jahn thinks, at any rate it may be excused in a passage where the feeling is so highly wrought, as showing a ‘MASK MASK’

‘MASK MASK’ perplexes Serv., who proposes five solutions—that a definite number is used hyperbolically for an indefinite—that Priam's fifty sons, being barbarians, would have more than one wife each—that ‘MASK’ merely means women —that it means brides, the daughters-inlaw of some one, but not necessarily of Hecuba—and that ‘MASK’ is to be taken with ‘MASK MASK’ though he admits that a single person could hardly be slain over a hundred altars. Later commentators have seen that the number one hundred is made up by adding Priam's fifty daughters to his fifty daughters-in-law. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ referring probably to the manner in which he was put to death, being dragged to the altar, as it were from altar to altar, v. 550.
is the ‘MASK’ of Ennius.

A bay-tree grows similarly in the middle of Latinus' palace, 7. 59. Priam's bay seems to have been a favourite object in exaggerating legends, which represented it as having a stem of gold, and blossoms, branches, and leaves partly of gold, partly of silver (Taubm.). For ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ we should probably have had subjunctives in prose. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ has nothing to do with sprinkling blood, but simply denotes the contamination which a father must necessarily receive from the very sight of his son's murder.

The legitimacy of Neoptolemus seems never to have been questioned in any way, so that Priam means no more than that his nature belies his lineage, as Dido 4. 365 (comp. by Serv.) says, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” So Pyrrhus understands it, “MASK MASK” v. 549.

Tro. 481 foll., Hec. 23. Lesches represented him as torn from the altar and slain at the palace door (a story from which Virg. may have borrowed the fact of his being seized by the hair: see above on v. 403): others, alluded to by Serv., said that he was dragged to the tomb of Achilles and killed there. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Like the four lines prefixed to the Aeneid, this passage is traditionally said to have been written by Virg., but omitted by Tucca and Varius. The external evidence against its genuineness is strong, stronger than against the genuineness of the former passage, the MSS. which contain the lines now in question being very few, and apparently none of them of great importance. The early interpreters do not comment on them, though their existence is recognized by a doubtful notice in Serv., which is the chief authority for the Tucca and Varius story. But when we come to internal considerations, the case is altered. The lines, though possibly disfigured by a few harshnesses, are vigorous and elaborate, and in general worthy of Virg. They are perhaps not required by the context, as v. 601 might be explained without them, and the appearance of Venus could be accounted for by supposing with Donatus that Aeneas was meditating suicide; but the context is improved by their presence, and v. 589, as Wagn. has pointed out, coheres rather awkwardly with v. 566. The aesthetical or ethical objection that has been taken to them, as if Virg. would not have made his hero think of killing a woman in a temple, seems to belong to a later age (see on v. 583), nor need the discrepancy between the present account of Helen and what we read 6. 510 foll. about her introducing the Greeks to the chamber of Deiphobus disturb us much, at the same time that one or both reasons may have led to their exclusion on critical grounds, whether by Tucca and Varius, or by some less authorized regulator of Virg.'s text. The external evidence however seems to me too formidably strong to be summarily ignored, so that I have followed the earlier editors, who enclose the passage in brackets, rather than the bulk of the later, who print it as an unquestioned part of the text. Where possibilities are so many and facts so few, an attitude of doubt seems the only one which can be safely assumed, except by those, who, like Jahn and Peerlkamp, condemn the lines unreservedly, on internal as well as external grounds.

This line has been condemned by those who, like Wagn., defend the rest of the passage; but there is no fresh external evidence against it, and the internal grounds for separating it from its fellows do not appear conclusive. ‘MASK’ for “MASK” is in Virg.'s manner, and occurs again 11. 270 (comp. “MASK MASK” 3. 471): it is not said that she will see Menelaus for the first time on her return, but merely that she will return and be re-united to her family, husband, children, and parents: ‘MASK’ may very well stand for “MASK MASK” like “MASK MASK” v. 457, for father and mother-in-law, and is in fact so used in some inscriptions referred to by Forcell., if not in Ov. M. 4. 61: Tyndareus and Leda are represented by Eur. Or. 473 as alive even after the death of Clytaemnestra, though Hom. Od. 11. 298 introduces Leda in the shades: and the picture of Helen attended by a retinue of Trojan dames may refer at least as well to her daily life, which is the more Homeric conception, as to her procession in triumph, which would be a Roman image. ‘MASK MASK’ Hom. The expression ‘MASK MASK’ (i. q. “MASK MASK MASK MASK”) is apparently Virg.'s own; Ovid however imitates it M. 3. 2., 11. 264., 12. 601. It is not clear whether ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK’ should be read; in other words, whether ‘MASK’ goes with ‘MASK’ or with ‘MASK MASK’ The latter is supported by Med., the former by the editors generally. In the one case ‘MASK’ has to be applied to three people; in the other three people are said to be surrounded by the whole Grecian army, when the meaning merely is that enemies are swarming round them.

‘MASK’ denotes that the enemy is constantly passing backwards and forwards, and suggests that they may at last by mere chance light upon their victims. ‘MASK’ expresses that the danger and consequently the guardianship are not over. ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ on the other hand, for the sake of liveliness, speak of the destruction as already a thing of the past.

v. 4. We must remember that Aeneas had just witnessed the destruction of Priam's palace. ‘MASK MASK’ v. 290 note.

Aeneas knew that the tutelary gods of Troy had left their temples (v. 351): he now learns that there are heavenly powers actually arrayed against Troy. How far the two views of the relations of the gods to Troy harmonize it would be hard to say: in Homer certain gods are the avowed friends, certain other gods the avowed enemies of Troy , and though the Trojans try to propitiate the latter (comp. the procession to the temple of Pallas Il. 6. 269 foll.), their hostility seems to be unabated. The opening of Aeneas' eyes that he may see the gods is from Il. 5. 127, where Pallas performs the same office to Diomedes, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .

is a clause which has given some trouble to the commentators. Heyne thinks Virg. would have altered it had he lived to revise the poem: Wagn. vindicates it as giving the reason why the cloud is to be removed, that Aeneas, seeing the desperate state of Troy, may not hesitate to abandon it. Perhaps it would be better to say that Venus fears lest Aeneas, seeing the gods banded against Troy , should become desperate, or too timid to make an attempt to save his family,—a view which will agree with ‘MASK’ here, and with the language of v. 620.

The picture of Neptune overthrowing the walls with his trident is taken from a curious passage, Il. 12. 27 foll., speaking of the destruction of the unblessed rampart of the Greeks by Poseidon, in connexion with Apollo and Zeus, after the fall of Troy . There however his functions as the earth-shaking god of the sea are more distinctly marked: the rampart had been made to protect the ships as they stood drawn up on the shore, and the foundation is accordingly undermined by the waves, and the beach restored as it was before. Here there may be a hint of Neptune's marine agency on a maritime town, but all that is expressed is the leverage of the trident in overturning the walls of the city. Comp. also the descent of the gods to battle Il. 20. 47 foll.
“‘ Pulvis ’MASK MASK MASK MASK” Heyne.

Serv. reminds us that the walls of Troy were originally built by Neptune and Apollo, Cerda that MASK was one of the names of Poseidon. If Virg. remembered the one fact and was aware of the other, he might naturally feel that there was a philosophical propriety in representing the same power as the maker and the destroyer. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ of course belongs really to ‘MASK’ as well as to ‘MASK MASK’ though grammatically only to the latter.

Like Neptune (v. 610), MASK presides over the destruction of that which she ordinarily (see note on MASK ) protects. In Il. 5. 460 Apollo takes his seat on the height of Pergamos, to defend it.

The ‘MASK’ naturally goes with the ‘MASK’ as the “MASK” is really the whirlwind that drives the storm-cloud, whence the double meaning of the word in Greek. Comp. 8. 353 foll., Sil. 12. 720 foll. So Apollo Il. 15. 308 appears MASK MASK MASK (Horace's “MASK MASK MASK MASK”), MASK MASK MASK MASK , a line which Virg. doubtless meant to translate. The brightness of the storm-cloud, to which Henry objects, may be accounted for, if not, with Wagn., by the lurid glare of the conflagration, at any rate by the lightning which it would naturally emit—a view agreeing well with the historical picture of a captured town quoted by Henry himself from Tac. A. 13. 41, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” So Pallas, who carries the “MASK” of Zeus, wields also Zeus' lightning, as we have seen on 1. 42. Her descent here then will be parallel to Juno's 10. 634, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though there we hear only of the darkness of the cloud, not of the lightning. So explained, ‘MASK’ seems to give a finer because a more real and less conventional picture than Henry and Ladewig's substitute ‘MASK’ (recognized by Serv. as a various reading, and still found as an alternative in one MS.), though the robe reaching down to the feet was a characteristic of Pallas, and the border would naturally be of peculiar splendour, as it appears frequently to have been in more ordinary human costume.— ‘MASK’ might conceivably, as Serv. remarks, be taken with ‘MASK MASK’ but it is apparently a translation of MASK quoted above. Both Hesiod and Hom., as Henry observes, call the Gorgon MASK .
MASK note. ‘MASK’ seems to mean ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK’

is a variety for “MASK MASK MASK MASK” with a glance, after Virg's manner, at other possible aspects of the word, the notion of rescuing flight from those who would rob one of it (Gossrau), and the use of “MASK MASK” (Ov. F. 3. 867) in the sense of flying hastily. See on 1. 381, MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ the struggle, as Homer's heroes talk of battle as MASK : see on v. 11. For ‘MASK MASK’ in the sense of putting an end to, which Weidner seems to question, comp. 5. 463.

doubtless suggested the ‘MASK MASK’ that throng the gate of Milton's Paradise: but Virg. probably meant ‘MASK’ It has been asked why ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ are not joined by a copula: the answer is that the two epithets are not co-ordinate, ‘MASK MASK’ being in fact part of the predicate, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

as we might say ‘MASK MASK’ more emphatic here than ‘MASK MASK’ as it is the exertion of a superhuman power on which we are meant to dwell. The effect of the hemistich here is very grand, and it is not easy to see how Virg. could have improved the line by completing it. At any rate the effective brevity with which he dismisses in a line and a half what an inferior poet would have taken a paragraph to express is a memorable testimony of his judgment. Serv. has a curious note: “MASK MASK” (astrology), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ( MASK , seemingly an astrological term) “MASK MASK”
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

after his eyes have been opened to see Heaven fighting against Troy. ‘MASK’ is emphatic. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ occurs 9. 145, and Tac. H. 3. 33, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” perhaps an imitation of Virg. Troy is undermined by the flame, and so cannot stand against it, but sinks down into it. The word is also applied to the collapse or subsidence of flame itself.
as if god-built towers might have been expected to resist.

Hom. Il. 4. 482 foll. compares the death of Simoisius to the falling of a poplar which the woodman cuts down; but the circumstances of the felling are not dwelt on. MASK foll. has a simile more like Virg.'s, comparing the overthrow of Talus under Medea's enchantments to a tree half cut down and left, which first moves gently to the wind and afterwards comes down with a crash. But Virg.'s simile is sufficiently original, as regards both the details and the thing to which the tree is compared. Heyne complains of its grammatical structure, from the omission of the apodosis: but ‘MASK MASK’ means not ‘MASK MASK’ but ‘MASK MASK’
note on MASK .

bears its ordinary sense of threatening to fall. Henry fancies the point of the comparison is between a tree dangerous in its fall and Troy threatening injury to its captors: but the only danger the tree can cause is by falling, and we hear nothing of injury when the fall actually takes place v. 631. It seems equally needless to suppose that in the next line there is any allusion to a warrior nodding his plumes threateningly. Aeneas has ceased to look upon Troy as having any power for offence or defence, and regards its destruction as simply a question of time. ‘MASK MASK’ it keeps threatening.

M. 8. 776. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ will then mean that the tree fell heavily, and lay at length along the mountain, not, as has been supposed, that part of the mountain gave way with the tree.

as Gossrau remarks, receives some light from a story told by Serv. from Varro's work “MASK MASK MASK” to the effect that the Greeks allowed Aeneas and others to take with them what they valued most: that while others chose their treasures, he chose his father: that his filial piety was rewarded by the permission to make a second choice, when he selected the Penates; and that after this second proof of unselfishness the conquerors left him free to take with him what he liked. This story was not likely to be adopted by Virg., who would feel that it in some sort compromised the prowess of his hero; but it may very well have influenced his language here. ‘MASK’ then will mean that Aeneas thought of saving his father before saving any other person or thing, so that it had best be made to agree with ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ Ida, vv. 801 foll. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ whom I first addressed, or, to whom I first made my way.

Guellius and Cerda are, I suspect, right in conjecturing ‘MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK” &c. occur repeatedly in Virg., and “MASK” too is common; but “MASK” is never used by him in this sense except here and in 12. 762, where one MS., the Parrhasian, gives “MASK” unless we are to follow fragm. Vat. in reading “MASK” 5. 785. It is at least singular that the only two instances in which this use of the word is supported by the weight of the MSS. should be instances of participles, where the difference amounts to little more than a difference of spelling. The spelling “MASK MASK” which seems to have taken general possession of the MSS., may have arisen from a false etymology: see on 1. 22. Comp. also the fluctuations between “MASK” and “MASK”
9. 255. So “MASK MASK” 5. 73.

This line was omitted in Med., doubtless by accident, and had to be added in the margin. See on MASK . ‘MASK’ is probably to be taken with ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ we may however comp. the emphatic ‘MASK MASK MASK’ with which Dido apparently stabs herself 4. 660, as well as “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ib. 681. Comp. also MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” of the slain calf. ‘MASK’ of the dead, like MASK : see Forc.: and so ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ seems to refer to the “MASK” rather than to the “MASK” (see on 1. 219); but it is difficult to say. They are to treat him as if he were already dead, and leave him.

The words ‘MASK MASK’ are so frequently connected by Virg. in the sense of doing a thing with one's own hand, that it seems impossible to give them any other sense here. ‘MASK MASK’ on the other hand is more naturally understood of death from an enemy than of an enemy's abstaining from maltreating the dead; and the words of Aeneas v. 661 rather favour the same view. Forb. therefore seems right in supposing that Anchises means to follow Priam's example, mingling in the battle and provoking his death. Comp. “MASK MASK” above v. 434. Anchises is infirm, but we need not suppose that the blast of the thunder had actually incapacitated him from motion, as he is able to accompany Aeneas on his seven years' voyage. For ‘MASK MASK’ Serv. aptly comp. 9. 495., 10. 676.

indicates that the enemy might kill him for other reasons than pity. ‘MASK MASK’ was the reading before Pierius. In calling the loss of a tomb a light one, Anchises is speaking as a world-wearied old man, not as one who consciously realized the belief of the heroic time.

The story was that Anchises was struck (some said killed) by lightning for divulging his intercourse with Venus. See Hom. Hymn to Aphrodite, vv. 287 foll. ‘MASK MASK’ as Achilles Il. 18. 104 calls himself in his inaction MASK MASK MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ seems rightly explained by Serv. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though there is still room for question whether the notion is that of deferring the day of doom or of acting as it were as a clog upon time by passing a feeble spiritless dead-alive existence. Comp. 3. 481 “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and Horace's “MASK MASK MASK” 3 Od. 27. 50.

seems to be an extension of the notion of ‘MASK MASK’ which expresses the effect of the “MASK” or heat of the thunderbolt. So MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” of fire; and again 6. 221 he speaks of things struck by lightning as “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though he immediately afterwards adds “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Virg. too may have thought of the wind of the thunderbolt's motion: see on 1. 35. Any distinct doctrine, like that of the wind's being the cause of the thunder or lightning, on which Lucr. enlarges 6. 96 foll., is less likely to have been in his mind, though in A. 8. 430 he makes wind one of the component parts of lightning, that which gives it speed. ‘MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK” MASK note.

here, as in other passages (v. 75, 1. 327 &c.) seems to be simply = “MASK MASK” a use which may be accounted for perhaps by Virg.'s artificial style, which probably led him, as similar causes led our post-Restoration poets, to give a conventional and poetical sense to certain words. The Greek MASK is used rather loosely, though not with the same latitude. ‘MASK MASK’ seems to be on the analogy of MASK MASK . The more usual Latin construction is with an infinitive, or with “MASK” and an ablative. ‘MASK’ seems better taken with Donatus “MASK MASK” than with Heyne “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Serv. seems right (in spite of Wagn.'s denial) in explaining ‘MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK” It was Pyrrhus' only act of the kind; but it agreed so thoroughly with his nature that it would stamp him ever afterwards. He is the butcher of son and father, says Aeneas: therefore doubt not that he will butcher us. ‘MASK’ the original reading of the Mentelian MS. which Heins. thinks more Virgilian, would give a different sense. ‘MASK MASK’ is meant to deepen the horror as well as ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ For ‘MASK MASK’ Med. and others give ‘MASK MASK’ clearly a false reading, though supported by Jahn. Med. also gives the spelling ‘MASK MASK’ which I have followed Wagn. in restoring, though with some hesitation, as I have no confidence in his notion that Virg. used the archaic form in grander and more solemn passages, the modern in an ordinary context.

For ‘MASK’ Med., Pal., and others have ‘MASK MASK’ as also in 5. 522. Here however ‘MASK’ is found in fragm. Vat. and recognized by Serv., and seems almost required by the grammar, as ‘MASK’ could not in strictness be united by ‘MASK’ to ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the latter constituting an ordinary epithet, not an adverbial part of the sentence; though such a coupling of two not strictly co-ordinate expressions might perhaps be paralleled on the one hand by passages like v. 86 (note), on the other by those of which 5. 447, MASK may be taken as specimens. ‘MASK’ too seems to be the universal reading of the MSS. in the two very similar passages 8. 81, MASK .

So in 5. 525 the description of the prodigy is introduced by ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ 9. 502. Creusa had Ascanius in her arms and was pressing him upon Aeneas. ‘MASK MASK’ seems a kind of zeugma, as we should rather have expected “MASK MASK” but the meaning may be ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

It is not easy to say whether ‘MASK’ is to be taken with Cerda and most of the later commentators of a pointed tongue of flame, or with Henry of the crown or topmost point (a tuft of hair, as he suggests with reference to ‘MASK’) of Ascanius' head. The latter would be supported by 10. 270, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” the ‘MASK’ there being the crest of the helmet which Aeneas happened to be wearing: the former has the authority of Ovid, who three times (F. 6. 636, M. 10. 279, Pont. 4. 9. 54) uses ‘MASK’ of a point or spire of flame, and agrees with Val. Fl. 3. 188, where “MASK MASK” seems to mean a luminous halo or star on the brow of Castor. This evidence in favour of a special use is to a certain extent confirmed by the language of the present passage, by the epithet ‘MASK’ and the words ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which do not agree equally well with Henry's view, as in that case ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ could hardly be separated. The tautology between ‘MASK MASK MASK’ (as explained of the flame) and ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ of which he complains, is not unVirgilian. It is singular that there should be two passages in later poets, one (Claud. 4 Cons. Hon. 192 foll.) alluding to, the other (Sil. 16. 119 foll.) modelled on, the present, in both of which the same doubt might be raised as here. A third interpretation, dating from Serv. and adopted by Burm., and more recently by Schirach, supposes the ‘MASK’ to be the Phrygian cap or mitre which Ascanius may have worn, as it is specially used of the cap worn by the “MASK” and “MASK” at Rome (see 8. 664, and Dict. A. ‘MASK’), which Serv. says Ascanius himself was the first to introduce at Alba: but the whole description seems to show that at this time at least his head was bare. The parallel instance in Roman legend, which doubtless was in Virg.'s mind, is the blazing of the hair of Servius Tullius when a boy, for which see Livy 1. 39. The appearance, wherever it was seen, was supposed to be an omen of future greatness, perhaps of royal dignity, so that here it points out Ascanius as a future king, and shows that the house of Aeneas is destined to survive. Virg. also had in view MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”. — ‘MASK MASK’ seems to be a variety for “MASK MASK MASK” a form of expression of which Persius is particularly fond. “MASK MASK MASK” MASK , which Wund. and Jahn comp., is not parallel, as ‘MASK’ there is the passive supine. ‘MASK’ was adopted by Burm. from a few MSS.; but Virg. is not now thinking of a trail of light. ‘MASK’ is the reading of the great majority of MSS., and is doubtless right, though ‘MASK MASK’ the reading before Heyne, has some plausibility. It has been questioned whether ‘MASK’ belongs to ‘MASK’ or to ‘MASK MASK’ The imitation in Sil. l. c., where “MASK MASK” occurs, may seem to point to the former, and so perhaps MASK in Apoll. l. c.: but the concurrence of the two epithets ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ is a decided objection to it. The wavy, curling appearance of Ascanius' locks forms a natural object in the picture, and is in keeping with the character of the flames which play among them.
must not be pressed, as the harmlessness of the flame would of course require that it should burn without nutriment.

seems to be used after ‘MASK MASK’ like MASK after MASK , to mark the consequence. See Hand Turs. ‘MASK’ § 4, where however the instances given are of the use of ‘MASK’ in independent sentences. Probus 14. 10 K. quotes the line with ‘MASK MASK’ a reading the existence of which had been inferred from a note of Pomponius Sabinus: “MASK MASK‘ atque haecomina firma , ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ auxilium ’MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ Da MASK auxilium , pater , et firma omina . ’” ‘MASK’ is adopted by Peerlkamp, Ladewig, and Ribbeck; but its origin is easily accounted for by 3. 89, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is found in all extant MSS., and is supported by Boethius de interpret. ed. sec. p. 291 (ed. Basil. 1546). With ‘MASK MASK’ comp. 8. 78, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” It is singular that both “MASK” and “MASK” are also used by Virg. as instrumental ablatives with “MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK , “MASK MASK MASK” A. 12. 188. Serv. says that it was usual for the Romans to ask for a second omen confirming the first, as, if a second omen appeared of a different kind, the first was neutralized: but the fact is scarcely supported by the instance he gives, “MASK MASK MASK‘ quantum Chaonias aquila veniente columbas ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

and similar expressions are followed in Virg. by “MASK MASK” by ‘MASK’ or “MASK MASK” as here, and by a clause without any connecting particle. The two latter modes of construction may be regarded as remnants of a less artificial style, a sort of MASK MASK , preserved in poetry partly for variety's sake, partly as a relief from the more formal and logical structure of prose.

Thunder on the left was a good omen in Roman augury, as lightning on the right was in Greek. See note on MASK , and comp. Cic. Div. 2. 39. The same sign occurs again A. 9. 630, with an additional circumstance.

Shooting stars are mentioned 5. 527. In the present passage Virg. may have thought of MASK , where a similar appearance is sent to sanction a journey. Henry extracts from Saunders' News-letter of July 25, 1844, an account of a meteor seen one evening at Constantinople: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Heyne seems right in connecting ‘MASK MASK MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ and explaining “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

It can hardly be doubted that, as Henry expresses it, ‘MASK’ is connected by ‘MASK MASK’ not with its unlike ‘MASK MASK’ but with its like ‘MASK MASK’ though there is some slight awkwardness, scarcely removed by the parallels he cites, in the separation of the two participles. The sense of ‘MASK MASK’ seems to be fixed by the parallel 5. 526, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” to the imprinting of the meteor's path along the sky, ‘MASK’ being for obvious reasons substituted for “MASK MASK” otherwise it might be proposed to understand the words of the meteor symbolizing the path which Aeneas was to take (comp. Claudian De Laud. Stil. 2. 291, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”), an interpretation which would remove a certain appearance of tautology in what follows, and agree well with MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”, ‘MASK MASK’ being in that case virtually equivalent to “MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ Wagn. remarks that after the disappearance of the meteor any trail that it left would be more perceptible. For ‘MASK’ following ‘MASK’ see on MASK . The early editions read ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ seemingly on very slender authority. Heins. comp. Ov. M. 15. 849, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and Burm. Sen. Thy. 698, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ like its cognate, MASK ( MASK ) in Apoll. R. l. c., as if the trail of the star ploughed up the heaven. The word is similarly used Lucan 5. 562, Val. F. 1. 568.—Serv. applies the different parts of the portent to the destiny of Aeneas, the direction of the meteor showing that the Trojans were to rally at Mount Ida, the light signifying that under Aeneas they would become illustrious, the trail of scattered sparks denoting that some would remain behind, the length of the path prefiguring the length of the journey, the furrow its maritime character, and the smoke either the death of Anchises or the war in Italy.

seems = “MASK MASK MASK” Comp. 5. 659, where “MASK MASK” expresses the effect of a portent exactly as here. But it is just conceivable, though scarcely likely, that ‘MASK MASK’ are to be constructed together, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ by the will of heaven thus convincingly manifested. Comp. Hor. 2 S. 3. 305, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ we may presume from v. 644 and the context geuerally that Anchises was stretched on his bed.

as elsewhere, is ‘MASK’ and the repetition strengthens it. We may render ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is stronger than “MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’
Ascanius, the hope of the family, as he had just been designated by the first prodigy.

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Hor. 2 S. 5. 16.

nom., ‘MASK’ acc. As Weidner remarks, not only is the fire seen and heard, but the heat is beginning to be felt.

Aeneas' haste is expressed partly by the rapid movement of this and the next line, partly by the omission of any intimation that he has begun to speak. ‘MASK’ is the imperative passive in a middle sense, like “MASK” 3. 405.
It has been supposed from Donatus' note that he read ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but the variety seems more naturally accounted for as an oversight.

may be intended, as Serv. remarks, to prepare us for Creusa's loss, at the same time that it agrees with the directions to the servants immediately following, Aeneas' object doubtless being to facilitate the escape of the whole party by making the members of it travel separately.

is rightly explained by Wagn. of Ceres' temple standing in an unfrequented spot, which appears to have been the custom at Rome from Vitruvius 1. 7 (cited by Dorville and Henry), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Henry comp. Parallel expressions to parts of this line occur 7. 60, 172., 8. 598. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as we talk of religious observance. The latter half may have been taken as Germ. suggests, from Lucr. 1. 1029, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

We have seen v. 167 that part of the crime of Diomedes and Ulysses was that they touched the Palladium with their blood-stained hands. Wagn. inclines to read ‘MASK MASK’ from some of Pierius' MSS., as Virg. generally uses ‘MASK’ when the preposition has to be inserted between a substantive and an adjective.

is used of handling sacred things Livy 5. 32. Some copies, both here and there, have ‘MASK MASK’ for which see on MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ because it was an essential part of the purification that it should be made in running water.

Donatus on Ter. Adelph. 1. 2. 47 says that ‘MASK’ is for “MASK MASK” as “MASK” there for “MASK MASK” He is so far right that there appears to be no notion of purpose conveyed by this use of the subj., which is really equivalent to what some grammarians suppose it to be, a future perf. indicative. See on MASK .

at which some of the old critics appear to have cavilled as a piece of self-praise, is merely the MASK MASK of Hom., though Serv. may be right in his last explanation, “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is used as if he had already taken his father on his back, the object of his robing himself being that he might do so. Perhaps the use of ‘MASK MASK’ MASK , is the nearest parallel we have had, though in neither case can it be said that the past part. passive is used in the sense of the gerundive.

is rightly taken by Wagn. as a hendiadys. Agamemnon accoutres himself similarly Il. 10. 23, the lion's skin being thrown over the MASK , which Aeneas would of course be wearing already. It matters little whether ‘MASK’ be taken adverbially or as separated by tmesis from ‘MASK MASK’

“‘ Inplicuit : ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is doubtless rightly understood ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ (comp. 6. 263): but it might also be explained of the uneven steps of hurry, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ like Aesch. Theb. 374, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , if the reading there is certain.

“‘ MASK : ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ Cubicula obductis velis MASK , nec tamen obscura , facio . ’” Henry. Aeneas of course means to say that he purposely kept out of the light. “MASK MASK” MASK . See on 1. 422.

It seems too much to say with Wagn. that ‘MASK’ here introduces something unexpected and surprising. The mention of his walking in the shade is naturally followed by the mention of his alarm. ‘MASK’ is contrasted with ‘MASK MASK’ and so has the sense of ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as in 5. 650, not, as Gossrau thinks, of ‘MASK MASK’ implying that he had long lost all personal fear of the Greeks, an interpretation which would agree neither with the context nor with the tense of ‘MASK MASK’

Wund. is right in interpreting ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ = “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and comparing the use of MASK in Greek. There is a slight opposition, as Forb. has seen, between darts and hand-to-hand fighting. Comp. note on v. 432.

The commentators compare MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”, where however the subject is Medea's expectation of Jason. A better parallel would be Juv. 10. 21, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (which I see Cerda cites). Forb. also comp. Sil. 6. 58.
of course is Ascanius, not, as Emm. explains it, Creusa.

Markland conj. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which Heyne adopts; but the later editors rightly defend ‘MASK MASK’ Aeneas seemed to himself to have got over the whole of the journey, as having accomplished the most dangerous part of it. like “MASK MASK” v. 23.

seems, as Heyne observes, to be a mixture of two Homeric expressions, MASK MASK and MASK MASK MASK MASK (Il. 6. 234., 24. 358). Still, though the verb and the participle convey different notions, their combination is doubtless to be referred to the class of which we have had specimens 1. 29, 69.

is used like “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK” &c., as Forb. remarks. “MASK MASK” or “MASK” is found again 7. 215., 9. 385., 11. 530, and in MASK ., 2. 249, the primary sense of “MASK” (“MASK”) apparently being a line. So Cic. 2 Verr. 5. 68, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The word was an augurial one. See Forc.

seems to refer to Aeneas, as it is commonly taken, not, as Henry thinks, to agree with ‘MASK MASK’ There would be no point in saying that Creusa died a violent death, even if we could conclude that to have been the case, or if it could be established that “MASK MASK” was the regular expression for such an end. Heyne is right in following the obvious order of the words, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” &c. ‘MASK MASK’ (which Henry illustrates from Livy 3. 50, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”) applies really to all three cases, ‘MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK’ the meaning being that she was separated finally from Aeneas, whatever was the cause: grammatically it belongs only to ‘MASK’ Perhaps there may be something rhetorical in the confusion. At any rate Peerlkamp's ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which Ladewig adopts, would only render the passage more prosaic, and Ribbeck's ‘MASK MASK’ is sufficiently un-Virgilian. The indicatives are used instead of subjunctives, which we should naturally have expected after ‘MASK MASK’ on the principle illustrated on MASK , ‘MASK’ &c. being regarded as the principal verbs in the sentence, and ‘MASK’ merely as a sort of qualifying adverb, so that we need not follow Gossrau in putting a note of interrogation after ‘MASK’

is used co-ordinately with ‘MASK MASK’ as Tacitus uses “MASK” co-ordinately with “MASK” see Forc. We have already had “MASK MASK MASK” after “MASK” 1. 218. The three cases are put, that she stood still, that she lost her way, that she sat down, just as they may be conceived to have occurred to the mind of Aeneas, though strictly, of course, there is no great difference between the first and the third. For ‘MASK’ Med. and others have ‘MASK MASK’ which Burm. injudiciously approves. See on MASK .
Some MSS. give ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as in 8. 352.

comp. 9. 387. ‘MASK MASK’ = “MASK MASK” as in our verb ‘MASK MASK’ a sense which occurs in one or two other passages, though “MASK MASK” is more commonly used of a change of feeling: see Forc. Heins. restored ‘MASK’ from the majority of MSS. for ‘MASK MASK’ which is said to have the authority of Med., though Ribbeck's silence makes this more than doubtful.
The temple stood on a ‘MASK MASK’ where there were one or more trees, v. 713. ‘MASK’ refers rather to the temple than to the goddess.

is rightly explained by Wagn. MASK MASK MASK , though he does not mention that the notion which stands for the Greek participle is contained in ‘MASK MASK’ She played them false, or escaped their notice—how?—as her companions. The sense would have been clearer had Virg. written “MASK MASK” but he has chosen to vary the expression by fixing the appellation on the less prominent of the two correlative parties. Comp. v. 99 above (note), where the variety is of an opposite kind. The meaning of course is that she was then first found to have disappeared.

occurs Tac. H. 2. 47, quoted by Wund., where Otho says that the dying do not indulge in upbraidings of gods or men. Some MSS. give ‘MASK MASK’ as in 1. 229. Virg., as Serv. suggests, probably wished to avoid the jingle ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’
Serv. remarks “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

has the force of “MASK” and something more. So “MASK MASK” 3. 674. Comp. 11. 522, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and see on 5. 287.

We do not know where Aeneas left his armour; probably not at home, though it would have been natural that he should do so before starting with his father, as he does not return thither till v. 756, and then seems not to enter. ‘MASK’ may have some force, as showing that he no longer thought of avoiding danger. Ribbeck, after Peerlkamp, brackets the line.
like ‘MASK MASK’ with an infintive, of a fixed resolution, 12. 678. For ‘MASK’ a few MSS. have ‘MASK MASK’ With the line generally comp. 9. 389.

Aeneas had made his journey through the dark for safety's sake (v. 725): he now mentions the shade as a thing which might have led to the loss of his wife, and which consequently formed a reason for careful search, while it enhanced the difficulty of it.
“MASK MASK MASK MASK” 9. 393 (note). The ‘MASK’ of course are his son, as Serv. says.
The sense of ‘MASK MASK’ which might else conceivably have been questioned, is fixed by 8. 153, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

is adopted by Ladewig and Ribbeck from some MSS., including Pal. and Med., where however the corruption is easily accounted for by the way in which the words are written, ‘MASK’ (see on MASK ). We have already had ‘MASK’ nearly in the sense of “MASK” 1. 722; here it might be possible, if need were, to assume the more ordinary sense of courage or martial spirit. With ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Cerda and Henry comp. the description of Vitellius Tac. H. 3. 84, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ comp. v. 136 above, and see on MASK . Wagn.'s attempt to separate the second ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as if it = MASK MASK , is unnatural here, however applicable to other passages. Serv. says well “MASK MASK MASK MASK”

The old reading before Heins. was ‘MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the latter doubtless a recollection of v. 437 above. ‘MASK MASK’ is supported, not only by the oldest MSS., “MASK MASK MASK” but by 3. 349.

is merely a poetical return to the less artificial way of connecting sentences. See on MASK . In prose we should probably have had “MASK MASK MASK” Juno, like Pallas, Apollo, Vesta , &c., is supposed to have had a temple in the citadel, and the Greeks would naturally choose the dwelling of their patroness. The word ‘MASK’ may be intended to suggest further, that they placed themselves under a protection which they had not respected in the case of their enemies. The language of vv. 761, 762 favours, if it does not invite, such an interpretation.
MASK is associated with Ulysses here, as by Homer in the embassy to Achilles in Il. 9.

1. 119. The form ‘MASK’ is supported by Med. here and in 5. 40, and is not absolutely condemned by Wagn., who remarks that the name “MASK” is written with a double z in the great majority of passages by Med., and twice by Rom.
may perhaps include tripods, as Cerda and others think. The gods, however, had tables proper in their temples, as Wagn. shows from Pausanias 5. 20, where a table is spoken of in a temple of Hera.

for “MASK MASK MASK MASK” So “MASK MASK MASK” 3. 464. ‘MASK MASK’ like MASK , is applied to things as well as to persons in prose as well as in poetry. Comp. 7. 184., 11. 779, and also the use of ‘MASK’ MASK . The bowls, if not the vestments, probably come from the temples.

The captives formed a prominent feature in the representations, pictorial or narrative, of the sack of Troy . They figured in a painting of Polygnotus described by Pausanias 10. 25, 26, and they give the name to the Troades of Euripides. With the scene here portrayed we may comp. Aesch. Ag. 326 foll.: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The structure of the line reminds us, as it was possibly intended to do, of v. 238.
Some inferior MSS. fill up what Virg. left imperfect with such lines as “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” or “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Scaliger, Poet. 3. 11, expresses himself thus: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK’ to call at random, in the vague hope of reaching her ear.
here, as in v. 759, does duty for a verb of motion.

with reference to Aeneas' feeling, not to Creusa's actual condition. Contrasted with the living form, the apparition was wretched. Virg.'s characteristic love of iteration leads him to employ three words to designate the spectre.

The forms of the shades, like those of the gods, were supposed to be larger than human, apparently as being no longer ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ by the body. Contrast Il. 23. 66, where it is expressly said that the shade of Patroclus was MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK . Emm. comp. Juv. 13. 221, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where the apparition is of a living person in a dream. ‘MASK MASK’ i. q. “MASK MASK” as in 1. 684., 6. 689.
‘MASK’ like “MASK” MASK .

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

and ‘MASK’ are historical infinitives, not, as Wund. thinks, dependent on ‘MASK’ v. 773. The line, which occurs again 3. 153, is said by Serv. to have been omitted in many copies: it appears however to be found in all now extant. Ribbeck relegates it to the margin.

Two of Ribbeck's cursives and several quotations in other parts of Serv. give ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’—a recollection apparently of 6. 135. Creusa would then be denouncing Aeneas' search for her, not his grief.
5. 56. It is the Homeric MASK MASK or MASK MASK . See on 1. 133, “MASK MASK MASK MASK”

The reading of the latter part of this line is extremely doubtful. Serv. says that as it stands it cannot be scanned, but that it may be set right by changing the order of the words, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ though others prefer to read ‘MASK MASK’ From this it seems that the authentic text in his time was supposed to be ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which is still found in Pal. and some other copies. The existing MSS. vary much: two of Ribbeck's cursives follow Serv.'s regulated text: Med. gives ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ while others have ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The last of these varieties is preferred by Wagn., Forb., and Gossrau, as probably representing the parent text from which the others were corrupted. But it may be doubted whether the fact that ‘MASK’ is found in different places in the different copies proves that it originally had no place at all, and doubted too whether the less common ‘MASK’ is likely to have been substituted by transcribers for the more common ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is used by Cicero, Nepos, Plautus, and Terence (see Forc.); and though it may not be found elsewhere in poetry, it is a peculiarly appropriate word. Comp. Ter. Phorm. 3. 3. 18, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” On the whole, then, while admitting the difficulty of the question, I have restored, as Ribbeck has done, the reformed Servian text, which Heyne and most of his predecessors adopted.

probably goes with ‘MASK MASK’ as Heins. remarks. Comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK’ 7. 558. ‘MASK’ is peculiarly used of Jupiter, as a title of reverence: comp. 7. 110. 558., 10. 875, &c. Before Heins. the reading was ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which is found in Gud. corrected, Canon. corrected &c., and apparently supported by Ausonius, Mosell. 80, though there ‘MASK’ would suit the sentence rather better, as ‘MASK’ precedes. But in such matters MS. testimony is of no value.

in the plural has some rhetorical force here, as multiplying the troubles of Aeneas. In 3. 4 it is used distributively. ‘MASK’ is used strictly with ‘MASK MASK’ loosely with ‘MASK MASK’ Virg. seems as if he might have imitated Aesch. Supp. 1006, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . The resemblance would be still closer if we might follow the margin of Gud. in substituting ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’

Some inferior MSS. have ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which is supported by Serv. on 3. 5: see on v. 139 above. ‘MASK’ seems to have the force of ‘MASK’ (see on v. 761) —‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ &c.; so that it seems better to change the period usually placed after ‘MASK’ into a comma or semicolon. This definite prophecy of a home in Italy is inconsistent, as the editors remark, with what follows in the next book, where the Trojans first hear that they have to seek out their mother country, and only after a mistaken settlement in Crete, learn that Italy is to be their destination. See Introduction to Book 3. ‘MASK’ refers to the traditional origin of the Etruscans from Lydia, alluded to again 8. 479.

goes not with ‘MASK MASK’ as Burm. and Forc. think, but with ‘MASK MASK’ which has its strict sense of tilled land. It is a sort of unconscious reminiscence of the enthusiasm for labour, which, as we saw, animated the Georgies, the expression itself being perhaps modelled, as the commentators suggest, on MASK MASK . Comp. 1. 532, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ as Henry remarks, denotes prime condition rather than fruitfulness. ‘MASK MASK’ is from Enn. A. 177, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” quoted by Macrob. Sat. 6. 4. We have already had “MASK MASK” MASK .

For ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which occurs Ov. Trist. 5. 14. 32, Pont. 4. 4. 15, Lucan 1. 81, Sil. 11. 23, Med. has a curious reading ‘MASK MASK’ supported by a correction in Pal, which Wagn. attributes to a recollection of 8. 626.

is peculiarly used of things that are virtually, though not actually realized: comp. 3. 495., 6. 89., 7. 598, MASK . Henry seems to go too far when he comments on ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ dilectae Creusae ’MASK‘ regia coniunx parta . ’” The clause seems to refer rather to what follows than to what precedes. Aeneas is bidden to dry his tears, not because another marriage awaits him, but because the lost wife of his heart is destined not to degrading servitude, but to a noble ministry.
v. 7. The fate which Creusa disclaims for herself is the same which Hector dreads for Andromache Il. 6. 454 foll.

Serv. says that some one filled up the remainder of the verse with the words ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The supplement is more happy than most of those which have been invented by transcribers or critics, and may naturally enough be supposed to have occurred to Virg. himself, though without quite satisfying him.

Cybele was one of the patronesses of Troy , being a Phrygian goddess, and worshipped on Ida. Comp. 3. 111., 9. 618., 10. 252. Virg. means evidently that Creusa is to become one of her attendants, passing from ordinary humanity into a half-deified state, which agrees with v. 773. Pausanias 10. 26 says that one legend represented her as rescued from captivity by Cybele and Venus, though in the painting of Polygnotus she appeared among the prisoners. Two reasons are given why Aeneas effected his retreat, the approach of morning, which made it necessary to avoid the enemy, and the fact that the Greeks were keeping their hold on the city. Wagn rightly removes the period after v. 803, regarding vv. 801—803 as the protasis, v. 804 as the apodosis, which here as in many other places is expressed without any logically connecting particle. The building of this fleet is mentioned again 9. 80 foll., in connexion with Cybele's interposition. ‘MASK’ of building, 1. 424. ‘MASK MASK’ is a sort of pleonasm, perhaps expressing a feeling of tenderness. Serv.'s explanation, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” is very jejune.

The general tradition was that Troy was taken in the early summer (see Heyne's 2nd Excursus to this book), so that Virg. may mean that they sailed as soon as they could get their ships ready. Anchises' injunction was evidently given with reference to the favourable state of the weather for sailing. See Introduction to this book. Wagn. is apparently right in making the apodosis to ‘MASK MASK’ not ‘MASK MASK’ but ‘MASK’ (see on 2. 692), ‘MASK’ being virtually equivalent to “MASK MASK MASK”

The order seems sufficiently to show that ‘MASK’ is the dative, not, as Heyne thought, the ablative.

Thrace was separated from the Troad only by the Hellespont, so that ‘MASK’ is used, as it sometimes is, without any notion of great distance, expressing local separation, and no more. Donatus reminds us that Aeneas enters into detail for Dido's information. The mythological connexion of Mars with Thrace is as old as Hom. (Il. 13. 301). ‘MASK’ v. 73 note.

There was a place called Aenos (now Enos) at the mouth of the Hebrus, with a tomb of Polydorus (Pliny 4. 11. 18); but as it is mentioned by Hom. (Il. 4. 520) as existing during the Trojan war, the tradition can hardly have been that it was founded by Aeneas. On the other hand there was another town Aenea in Chalcidice on the Thermaic gulf, the inhabitants of which regarded Aeneas as their founder (Livy 44. 10), so that it is supposed that Virg., intentionally or unintentionally, has confounded the two. The name ‘MASK’ was probably given to the people, not to the place, though there are instances where the town bore the name of the inhabitants, as Locri. ‘MASK’ is put in apposition with ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK MASK” v. 693 below.

In Hom. MASK, Priam's youngest son, is killed by Achilles when he returns to the battle after the death of Patroclus (Il. 20. 407 foll.). Other traditions represented him as entrusted to Polymestor, king of Thrace, who broke the ties of hospitality and practised on his life; but the details of the story differed considerably, Euripides in the Hecuba agreeing in the main with Virg. (see on v. 22), Hyginus (fab. 109, 240) making Polymestor instead kill his own son by mistake, while Dictys (2. 18, 22, 27) speaks of Polymestor giving up MASK to the Greeks, who, after in vain endeavouring to exchange him with Helen, stone him to death under the walls of Troy . ‘MASK MASK’ occurs again 12. 663. Here the image is particularly appropriate, as the spears had taken root, and were growing. Comp. MASK .

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Here as in the former clause Virg. expresses himself as if the spears were the result of the vegetation instead of being that out of which the vegetation grew, an inversion not unnatural in the mouth of Polydorus, who may be supposed to have felt the spear points more keenly as the shafts grew into a wood, and the whole became incorporated with his body. Euripides makes no mention of this portent in his version of the story of Polydorus. We cannot tell whether it is Virg.'s own invention or no. Serv. thinks he had in his mind the story of Romulus' spear, which, when fixed in the Aventine, took root and vegetated.

expresses the doubt of Aeneas whether he ought to remain in the country or leave it, as it is rightly explained by Henry, who remarks also that ‘MASK MASK’ denotes a further stage of horror than that described in 29, 30.
Repeated from 2. 774.

The tale is told of course for Dido's information; but, standing where it does, it is evidently meant to express what passed through Aeneas' mind at the time. There is a difficulty however in determining whether Aeneas is reflecting on a story which he knew already, or receiving a new communication, doubtless from Polydorus himself. The language would rather be in favour of the former; but if Aeneas had known the story, he would hardly have landed in Thrace, and v. 60 seems to show that it was not until informed by him that Anchises and the Trojans knew of Polymestor's treachery.

is understood by Wagn. as referring not to Priam's end or to his ill-fortune generally, but to the misfortune about to be related, the treacherous murder of his son. Surely however an interpretation so restricted impairs the nature and poetical truth of the passage. Aeneas has just finished his narrative of the sack of Troy ; and neither he nor Dido could associate the name of Priam with any other thought than that of unhappiness, while this new horror would come in to show that as ill-fortune had followed him persistently through his later years, it was now making itself felt after his death. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ MASK , Eur. Hec. 6.

Virg.'s meaning evidently is that as the Greeks grew stronger the siege was converted into a blockade—an unseasonable introduction of the military tactics of his own time into the heroic age, and not very consistent with his own account of the ultimate capture of the city. The language in Eur. Hec. 4 is more general, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .
Fortune is said to retire, as in v. 615 to remain.

as we should say, the fortunes of Agamemnon. ‘MASK MASK’ is rather a strange grammatical combination, “MASK” being treated as a neuter adjective, apparently on the analogy of “MASK” &c. It seems to be confined to the poets and later prose authors (see Forc.), and in general only found in the plural, though Claud. 6 Cons. Hon. 21 has “MASK MASK MASK MASK”

is a term for sacrificial and other solemnities, so that we need not bring in the notion of a new interment, distinguished from the fortuitous one which Polydorus had already received. ‘MASK MASK’ &c., as Wagn. remarks, expresses in detail what has been said generally in the earlier part of the verse.

Gossrau remarks that there was a distinction between the Greek and the original Roman belief, the former placing the spirit of the buried body in the infernal regions, the latter in the tomb along with the body. Virg., in that case, must be supposed to have held himself free to adopt either view: here he is a Roman, in Book 6 a Greek. Gossrau comp. a similar expression from Ov. Doris. The affection of the powers of the sea for Delos is not clearly explained. Strabo 8. p. 574 A says the island was sacred to Poseidon before it was given to Leto. The second syllable of ‘MASK’ is common in Latin poetry, the form MASK being adopted as well as MASK . The open vowels as usual are an imitation of Greek rhythm. ‘MASK MASK’ Neptune seems to have been specially connected with the Aegaean, his palace being fixed at a place Aegae (Il. 13. 21), which some identified with Aegae in Euboea, associated with the worship of Poseidon, and supposed to have given its name to the sea (Strabo, C. 386). Soph. fr. Laocoon 341 has MASK MASK MASK MASK (quoted by Aristophanes, Frogs 664).

grateful to his own birthplace and to the island which had sheltered his mother. Med., Pal., &c. have the spelling ‘MASK MASK’ which Ladewig and Ribbeck adopt. The word is as old as Naevius: comp. Macrob. Sat. 6. 5. Another reading ‘MASK MASK’ which would go with ‘MASK MASK’ is mentioned by Serv. and found in some MSS.

The reading of this line is involved in some doubt. Med., and, as would appear from Ribbeck's silence, Pal. and Gud., besides others, have ‘MASK MASK’ which Wagn., Gossrau, Forb., and Ribbeck adopt. Ladewig and Haupt read ‘MASK’ without ‘MASK’ a reading which Heins. seems to have found in some copies, and which might be preferable if better supported, as avoiding a harsh elision. The old reading was ‘MASK’ which is clearly wrong, as Pierius remarks, the name of the island being MASK . MASK was a mythical person, whose story was differently told: see Dict. Biog. One account was that Lavinia, the wife of Aeneas, was his daughter, and like him, a prophetess. He was himself represented by some as the son of Creusa. His friendship with Anchises is explained by the legend that Anchises had consulted him in former years whether he should go with Priam to Salamis to recover Hesione. We may perhaps wonder that Virg. should have mentioned him so slightly. Ovid, in the resumé of Aeneas' voyage which occupies parts of Books 13 and 14 of the Metamorphoses, introduces him more at length (13. 631—703), giving a conversation between him and Anchises, and describing in detail the presents which he and his guests exchanged at parting. ‘MASK MASK’ is the Homeric MASK MASK . The ancient combination of the royal and priestly functions may have been introduced by Virg., as Gossrau remarks, here and elsewhere, out of compliment to Augustus.
is the reading of most MSS., including Pal. and fragm. Vat., and is adopted by Ladewig and Ribbeck; but ‘MASK’ (Med.) suits ‘MASK’ better. Med. has ‘MASK MASK’
“MASK MASK MASK” 11. 165. ‘MASK’ is the abl. ‘MASK MASK’ not the dat. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as the tie had already been contracted.

merely means “MASK MASK” though Macrob. Sat. 3. 6 and Serv. find in it an allusion to the freedom of the island from earthquakes, so that the old building was still preserved. Here and in 12. 363 ‘MASK’ is lengthened before a single consonant. Gossrau (Excursus on the Virgilian Hexameter) cites other instances, from Ov. M. 1. 193., 4. 10., 5. 484., 10. 262. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ i. e. the land where your ancestral stock first grew, the birthplace of your ancestors. ‘MASK MASK’ expresses the quality of Italy (comp. 1. 531., 2. 782), perhaps with a reference to the image of a mother immediately following. They are told not merely that they shall find a home, but that the home shall be a fruitful one.

sums up what had been said in the previous two lines and a half. The enigmatic character of the Greek oracles would perhaps have been better preserved if it had been allowed to stand alone; but Virg. is going to demand our attention for the thing said, not for the manner of saying it. With the image comp. MASK , and the oracle given to the Tarquins and Brutus that he should be king who first kissed his mother.

This and the next line are translated from Poseidon's prophecy Il. 20. 307, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK . We may observe however the verbal changes, ‘MASK MASK’ for MASK MASK , which involves making the second line epexegetical of the first, not, as in Homer, an addition to it, and the separation of ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ from ‘MASK MASK MASK’ and the real change of converting a prediction of the supremacy of Aeneas and his family in a revived Phrygian Troy into a promise of the Roman empire. V. 98 is an answer to Aeneas' prayer v. 86. Serv. has a curious statement, borrowed, Heyne suggests, from some Alexandrian poem, such as the Chiliad of Euphorion, that Homer took the words from Orpheus, as Orpheus had taken them from the oracle of Apollo.

The story as told by Serv. and others is that Idomeneus in a storm vowed to the gods of the sea that he would sacrifice the first thing that met him on landing, that this proved to be his son, that he fulfilled his vow, that a plague visited Crete, and that the inhabitants consequently expelled him, when he settled in Calabria, as mentioned v. 400 below.

Virg. expresses himself as if the Cretans had vacated the country as well as Idomeneus; but he may only mean that now that the chief was gone, the people would not be unwilling to receive the Trojans. ‘MASK’ is rightly explained by Henry, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’
the ancient name of Delos.

With Henry, following Heins., I prefer ‘MASK MASK’ the reading of at least two copies, the ‘MASK MASK’ and one at Munich, to ‘MASK MASK’ which is found in the great majority of MSS., attested by Serv., and alluded to by Paullinus, Epist. 34. The latter would make sufficiently good sense, as the number of the islands would affect the character of the sea and the safety of the sailing; but the former is much more natural in this context, referring unmistakably to the name of the Sporades, some of which the poet has mentioned already, as he has also mentioned some of the Cyclades individually before summing them up in the general clause ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ There is no force in the supposed geographical objection, as Virg. need not be supposed to be enumerating the countries in the precise order in which Aeneas sailed by them. Wagn. makes a distinction between “MASK MASK MASK” and “MASK MASK MASK MASK” the first being used strictly of apotheosis, the second also of mere metaphorical immortality or exaltation. See on MASK . When we come however to look at the principle of the distinction, it appears to fail. “MASK MASK MASK” may differ from “MASK MASK MASK MASK” the one meaning rising towards the air, the other elevation into it: but here the elevation is the same, the difference being that MASK the one case it is literal, MASK the other rhetorical. There seems then no reason why we should not with Heyne understand these words generally of the superhuman glory of Aeneas' descendants, not with Serv. specially of the apotheosis of Caesar or Augustus, which would harmonize less well with the following clause, and be further objectionable, as merging Aeneas' own deification MASK that of his posterity.

not, as is generally understood, the “MASK MASK” but the “MASK MASK” (9. 258) or “MASK MASK” who are speaking, the authors and impersonations of this national greatness. Comp. 2. 295, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and the remark of Donatus quoted there. The ‘MASK’ are the city of Lavinium, the Italian settlement, regarded however doubtless as the cradle of the eternal city itself. The attempt of Heyne and others to press ‘MASK MASK’ as if in founding Lavinium Aeneas were preparing for Rome , is altogether needless, ‘MASK’ being obviously equivalent to “MASK” in the parallel passage from Book 2.
