illustrates ‘MASK’ v. 159. They identify themselves with the Trojans, or rather the Trojans with themselves. ‘MASK’ v. 85, to which it perhaps refers, as if it had been said, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK’ 7. 240.

The natural meaning of the words would seem to be that Iasius was the father of Dardanus, and the ultimate progenitor of the Trojan race. No tradition however appears to favour this view: and Virg. himself in 7. 219 apparently follows the Homeric story (Il. 20. 215), which makes Dardanus the son of Zeus. The legends vary (see Dict. Biog. Dardanus, Iasion): but those which assert MASK connexion between Dardanus and Iasion or Iasius make them brothers. This also might be reconciled with the text, which would then mean that the brothers sprung from Italy, and that Iasius, one of them, was the father of the Trojans. Here again however we should be at issue with the legends, and with Virg.'s language elsewhere, which speak of Dardanus as the author of the race, Iasius having settled, not in Phrygia, but in Samothrace. If then we wish to make Virgil consistent with himself, and with the line of tradition which he seems to have followed, we must suppose him to use ‘MASK’ rather vaguely, and to intend ‘MASK MASK’ to refer to Dardanus. But the language is certainly against this; and those who prefer to consider that he has attributed to Iasius what is elsewhere attributed to Dardanus may perhaps fortify themselves by appealing to 7. 208, where not Iasius but Dardanus is said to have penetrated into Samothrace.

is probably the place, Corythus or Cortona, not its founder, Corythus, who according to one story was the father of Dardanus. Comp. 7. 209., 9. 10, where it appears to stand for the country. At the same time the legendary connexion with Dardanus would be a reason for Virg. using the word, without committing himself to the story. ‘MASK’ Med., fragm. Vat. Others have ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ The two latter readings might be supported from ‘MASK’ in the next line; but the former, besides being less obvious, is confirmed by the parallel passage 12. 75 foll. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
MASK . ‘MASK’ is addressed to Aeneas by the Penates, not by him to Anchises.

The sentence is interrupted by a parenthesis, which produces an anacoluthon, v. 175 introducing another sentence. With Ribbeck I have restored ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ on external grounds, though the exact state of the evidence is not clear. Wagn. admits that ‘MASK’ is found in Med. and fragm. Vat., but says that the other MSS. supporting it are few and modern: Ribbeck quotes only two Berne MSS. for ‘MASK MASK’ leaving it to be inferred that ‘MASK’ is the reading of the rest of his copies, including not only Pal., but Gud.
See on v. 151. The words seem intended to represent Homer's MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK (Od. 19. 547). Henry comp. Stat. Theb. 5. 135., 10. 205, Sil. 3. 198.
‘MASK’ crowned with fillets. Comp. 5. 134, 366., 7. 154., 11. 101. Two representations of the Penates of different Roman families so crowned are mentioned by Lersch, Antiqq. p. 149.

The sweat shows the powerful impression made by fear or otherwise upon the mind. Gossrau and Forb. comp. 7. 459, Sil. 8. 187, though they go too far when they speak of sweat as a sign of the reality of the vision. Macrob. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK .
Comp. 2. 688. As in 5. 743., 8. 70, Aeneas offers up a prayer or sacrifice after the vision. ‘MASK’ of wine 1. 636.

seems to include the two notions which have been assigned to the word by Wagn. and Wund., the wine being both unmixed and choice (unblemished, as victims are called ‘MASK’ &c.). The hearth was the altar of the Penates. ‘MASK’ v. 118. ‘MASK MASK’ the performance of the sacrifice had apparently given him time to recover himself, so that he could tell his father with pleasure (v. 169). ‘MASK MASK’ see on 4. 639.
is the more common expression in prose; but the positive is used by MASK , MASK , MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” MASK , 537.

“‘ MASK : ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv., an interpretation which would agree with Horace's “MASK MASK MASK” a second Salamis (1 Od. 7. 29, quoted by Emmenessius). The word however seems rather to mean capable of being referred to either source, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” as Forcell. quotes from Cic. Orat. 34. The ‘MASK’ here would lie in the possibility of tracing the line either to the king of the country or to the settler who married his daughter, though, as we have seen on v. 107, there is a further ambiguity which presses on us, if it did not press on Anchises or on Virg., the difficulty of determining which was the father-in-law and which the son-in-law.

seems best explained by Gossrau of the surprise of Anchises when informed of his mistake (see on MASK ), the word being used to produce an apparent antithesis with ‘MASK MASK’ as Serv. long ago remarked. Other instances of mere verbal antithesis are given in my note on Aesch. Cho. 272. Or we may say that there is a touch of humour in the word, expressing the contrast between old places and new mistakes, as it strikes the mind of Anchises, a meaning which I have endeavoured to bring out in my verse translation. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Henry's interpretation, referring ‘MASK’ to the previous mistake about settling in Thrace, which he assumes, plausibly enough, to have been advised by Anchises, is less likely, as that mistake was of a different kind, unconnected with ancient tradition, and so could hardly be called an ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” 7. 199.
is repeated 5. 725, where Anchises consoles Aeneas for the burning of the ships, as Henry remarks, as here for the unfortunate settlement in Crete.

is one of those constructions found in Greek as well as in Latin, which it is difficult to unravel satisfactorily. We may call it an extension of the construction “MASK MASK MASK” which is found 5. 862, and say that from being used with a cognate accusative, the intransitive verb comes to be used with an ordinary accusative of the object, which happens to give nearly the same sense as the cognate; or we may account for it as an accusative of the object put loosely with a verb which is generally intransitive. The expression occurs again 5. 235, and is used by Ov. ex Ponto 1. 3. 76.

The episode which follows is imitated partly from Od. 10. 260 foll., where the companions of Ulysses devour the herds of the sun, partly from MASK foll., where Zetes and Calais deliver Phineus from the Harpies. For ‘MASK’ Med. and Gud. have ‘MASK MASK’ which seems to be a corruption from the preceding word.

is obviously a variety for “MASK” ( MASK ): but whether the additional notion is that of the position of the island, or, as Wagn. thinks, the permanence of the name, is not clear. MASK foll. makes Zetes and Calais chase the Harpies to the MASK MASK , where they would have killed them, had not Iris interposed. The assailants turn back from the islands, which are thence called MASK : the Harpies fly to Crete. Other writers expanded the story (see Dict. Biog. ‘MASK’), but it does not appear whether any but Virg., whom Ov. M. 13. 709 obviously follows, made the Strophades the regular habitation of the Harpies.
For the Greek rhythm comp. MASK .

The Homeric conception of the Harpies is of personified storm-winds, which agrees not only with their general designation and with the name Podarge, given to one of them Il. 16. 149, but with the names given to them in later legends, Aello, Ocypete, and Celaeno. In the story of Phineus they appear in the loathsome character in which they are represented here. Aeschylus, one of whose lost plays was on that subject, makes the priestess in the Eumenides name them along with the Gorgous as the most frightful monsters with which her memory supplies her for comparison with the Erinnyes.
for fear of Zetes and Calais.
7. 203 note.
is a bold expression for the effect of divine anger. Val. Fl. 1. 683 has adopted it from Virg., applying it to Sirius.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ they are birds with maidens' countenances. The expression somewhat resembles MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK” Id. 2. 702.
The Harpies are the goddesses of eternal famine, carrying off and spoiling the food of others, yet ever hungering themselves, which gives point to Celaeno's denunciation v. 256.
Virg. Follows Od. 12. 353 foll., though not very closely.

‘MASK MASK’ is from Pacuvius and Attius, according to Macrob. Sat. 6. 5. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” is Serv.'s criticism. ‘MASK’ is neuter sing., not, as some have thought, gen. pl., as Cic. Progn. fr. 6. p. 556 (Orelli) has “MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ was read before Heins.
was read before Heins. The expression seems a fair instance of hendiadys (note on MASK ), standing for ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’

Partly repeated from 1. 310, 311. Here, as in 1. 311, ‘MASK’ is read by Pal., and originally by Med., Gud., and two other of Ribbeck's cursives, Rom., we may remember, being deficient through the greater part of this book and the last. ‘MASK’ is the corrected reading of Med., Gud., and another cursive, and seems on the whole safest to adopt. ‘MASK MASK’ the common reading, would be neater, but it is only found in two of Ribbeck's cursives corrected, and in inferior copies. Ribbeck goes further, and omits v. 230, which seems unnecessary, though it may be allowed that the variation of the text is a ground for suspicion.

MASK receives his revelations from Zeus, whose MASK he is, Aesch. Eum. 19. In his turn he has the power of imparting inspiration, as to Cassandra, Ag. 1202. Whether Celaeno is to be regarded as a prophetess, or merely as possessed of this single communication of the future, is not clear.

6. 605. The later mythology, which limited the number of the Erinnyes, introduced gradations of age among them. Virg. identifies or confuses the Harpies with the Furies, as Aesch. Eum. 50 does with the Gorgons.

of a speedy journey 1. 157., 2. 399, MASK . ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ As Donatus remarks, Celaeno shows them that she knows the present, that they may believe her prophecy of the future. ‘MASK’ is understood by Wagn. ‘MASK MASK’ and therefore favourable. see on 1. 29. ‘MASK’ goes with ‘MASK’ as in MASK . So “MASK MASK” 4. 601., 9. 494. This prophecy formed part of the traditional account of Aeneas' landing in Italy (Heyne, Excursus 8), so that Virg had no choice about introducing it. The notion of putting it into the mouth of Celaeno, so far as we know, is his own; others having represented it as given by Jupiter at Dodona, or by the Erythrean sibyl to Aeneas, or by Venus to Anchises. In 7. 122 foll., where the prophecy is fulfilled, it is said to have been delivered by Anchises to Aeneas, no mention being made of Celaeno, though she is expressly named as its author later in this book, v. 365. See Introduction to this Book, and also note on 7. 123. ‘MASK MASK’ the subj. is used as if the Trojans would be anxious to anticipate the visitation by establishing themselves in their city. For ‘MASK’ Heins. restored ‘MASK MASK’ from Pal. a m. s., Gud., and a few other MSS.; but the authority is not sufficient to recommend the word, though it may have a slight rhythmical advantage. Wagn. thinks it may have arisen from 5. 33, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but the resemblance is hardly great enough, and the parallel might be turned into an argument on the other side.
Imitated from Od. 11. 10, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . ‘MASK’ Med., ‘MASK’ inferior MSS., which Heyne retained.

Again from Homer (Od. 9. 24), MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . Mr. Long says of ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK’ note on v. 73.

MASK in Hom. (Od. 9. 22., 13. 351) is a mountain in Ithaca. Some have thought that Virg. considers it so here; but the subsecuent mention of Ithaca in the next line is against this, and all the other names here are names of islands. Mela 2. 7 mentions MASK among the islands in the Ionian sea, and the same is evidently the meaning of Ov. M. 13. 712, Sil. 15. 305, who however as evidently have merely copied the present passage. Perhaps Virg. was thinking of Il. 2. 633, where MASK is mentioned separately from Ithaca among the places from which Ulysses' followers came, Zacynthos and Samos following two lines afterwards.

Serv. may be right in supposing that something of a taunt may be intended in ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ with which he comp. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 1. 139. Taubm. appositely cites Cic. De Orat. 1. 44, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Here and in the next line Virg. is evidently glancing at Ulysses' own description of his country, Od. 9. 27, as MASK MASK MASK MASK , and perhaps also, as Heyne thinks, at Il. 3. 201, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK .
Leucata or Leucates is the promontory of Leucas, or Leucadia, celebrated as the scene of the Lover's Leap.

plainly indicates a temple of MASK built on a dangerous rock. Such a temple existed on Leucata (Dict. G. Leucas). Heyne however objects that they are not likely to have landed there, as the ‘MASK MASK’ in that case must be Leucas, which was besides in a different part of the island, not, as the next sentence seems to prove, Actium; he accordingly thinks that the temple of MASK at Actium is meant, thus separating v. 275 from v. 274. The following lines certainly seem to show that they landed in Actium: the present line naturally points to Leucata. Can Virg. have confused the two temples? ‘MASK MASK’ comes into sight, like “MASK” v. 206.

middle. The purification was doubtless required by their recent adventure with the Harpies. ‘MASK MASK’ in honour of Jupiter. The expression is imitated by Gratius Cyn. 492, “MASK MASK” It is asked why Jove is singled out rather than Apollo, the tutelary god of the place. Jove had doubtless been invoked foremost among the “MASK MASK MASK” v. 264, and he would be specially propitiated here for the same reason, as aggrieved in the matter of the Harpies, partly perhaps by the inauspicious sacrifice, v. 223, partly by the attempt to injure his ministers, which the prophecy v. 251 seems to show that he resents. ‘MASK’ here stand for votive offerings. Wagn. well comp. Aesch. Ag. 91, MASK MASK MASK . “MASK MASK” occurs 8. 285. The vows are explained partly by what follows, v. 282, partly by what precedes, v. 264.

The celebration of games at Actium by Aeneas is a compliment to Augustus, who instituted a quinquennial celebration at Actium in honour of his victory, Dion 51. 1. The adjective ‘MASK’ occurs again 8. 675, 704, and elsewhere in the Latin poets, the prose form being “MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is a variety for “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” “MASK” having its strict sense of ‘MASK MASK MASK’

The ‘MASK’ is given as a specimen of other games, whicl may perhaps be the force of the plural. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” 1. 499, “MASK MASK” Prop. 4. 14. 3. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the oil is said to slip, probably from its effect on the bodies of those who use it.

The sun is said to roll round the year, as it is said to roll round the sky, the year being equivalent to what is traversed in the year. In a Greek author we should at once pronounce ‘MASK’ to be a cognate accusative; here it is evidently an ordinary accusative of the object, though the acc. of the duration of time may help us to understand the expression. The epithet ‘MASK’ is merely an ornamental one, just as Hom. Il. 2. 134 speaks of MASK MASK MASK (comp. MASK note), not, as Wakefield thinks, used with the feeling of an exile. For the date which this point marks in Aeneas' wanderings see Introduction to the present Book.

The inference to be drawn from this line apparently is that they remained on shore during the winter, though prima facie it would seem from v. 289 that they started immediately. Here as elsewhere the narrative is touched very lightly.

The name of Abas, an early king of Argos, son of Lynceus and Hypermnestra, is connected in legends with a shield, which obtained victory even after his death (Dict. Biog., following Serv. on this passage). This shield appears to have been fastened up in the temple of Here at Argos, that the conqueror in the games celebrated there might bear it in procession. Another story, also mentioned by Serv., made Abas the inventor of the shield. Virg. can hardly be thinking of this mythical person, whose date would involve an anachronism here, though it is singular that the words ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ v. 289, coincide with the pedigree of the shield, which is said originally to have belonged to his grandfather Danaus, while the story about the games again seems as if it might be glanced at in the Actian games just mentioned, as if Aeneas were bearding the old hero on his own ground. But for these coincidences, the Abas of the present passage would be to us merely the name of some unknown Grecian warrior whom Aeneas had slain at some time or other, and whose shield he hangs up on Grecian soil as a crowning act of triumphant joy after an unmolested sojourn there. Ov. M. 15. 664 talks of the shield of Euphorbus, which Pythagoras recognized as his own, as hanging up “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ 7. 246.

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 7. 183. ‘MASK MASK’ as Heyne says, is merely ornamental, on the door as it faces you. It is not said where the door was; indeed, we are left to imagine for ourselves how Aeneas contrived to inhabit the town unmolested.

of passing a place, or seeing it vanish, like MASK Plato Protag. 338 A. Not unlike is the use of “MASK” MASK . The ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ( MASK ) are the mountains of Corcyra, MASK MASK MASK MASK , Od. 5. 279.

may be either dat. or local abl. “MASK MASK” 7. 161, “MASK MASK” 8. 125, seem in favour of the former. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is the reading of many MSS., including Med. a m. sec., the text having originally been ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which Valerius Probus actually explained as a genitive, comparing ‘MASK’ with “MASK” Serv. notices the plural as unmetrical.

‘MASK’ the reading before Heins., is favoured by ‘MASK MASK’ but hardly agrees with what follows, vv. 300, 345, which shows that Aeneas did not reach the city till afterwards. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Dict. G. Perhaps it is only meant to be a perpetual epithet of a city.

for “MASK” 2. 579. The story of Aeneas' meeting with Helenus seems to have been told by Varro in his 2nd book “MASK MASK” (Serv. on vv. 256 above, 349 below), as it is told by Dionys. Hal. 1. 51. For ‘MASK’ a few MSS. give ‘MASK MASK MASK’ a few others ‘MASK MASK’ which Jahn prefers, coupling ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ In any case the infinitives seem to depend on ‘MASK MASK’ as 2. 10 shows, though 8. 163 might be pleaded for connecting them with ‘MASK MASK’

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. Wagn. examines this dictum in an excursus on 12. 609—613, ending by accepting it in a very limited sense, as applying to the supposed case of a bona fide participle in the nominative terminating a paragraph, of which he finds no example in Virg., and which he thinks objectionable on account of the weakness of such a termination. The question is one of some interest, but belongs perhaps more properly to a treatise on Latin composition than to a commentary on a Latin poet. Serv. is evidently wrong at the outset in the distinction which he takes between Latin and Greek poetry, as if the offending participle were more to be condemned in the case of the latter than in that of the former. The present participle at any rate is known to be much more idiomatic in Greek than in Latin. Hom. says in one of his most wonderful passages (Il. 6. 201) MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK . Cicero renders it nearly verbally (Tusc. 3. 26) “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and we at once feel the difference. As a matter of fact, one book of the Iliad (the 18th), and two of the Odyssey (the 5th and the 15th) end with the obnoxious participle.

which Heyne preferred, is the reading of two of Ribbeck's cursives. Ladewig rightly observes against Wagn., that if we adopt ‘MASK’ we must understand it not in the sense of MASK MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” a sense which would not suit the imperfect, but in the sense of ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ so that the semicolon which Wagn. and others put after ‘MASK’ should be changed into a comma. ‘MASK MASK’ would be supported by 9. 3, 638. ‘MASK MASK’ may refer merely to the libations which formed the staple of the offerings to the dead (see on v. 66 above), as ‘MASK’ would seem to show; but there may very well be a zeugma. ‘MASK’ are distinguished from libations in the funeral offerings to Misenus 6. 225, where see note. In 5. 92 the meaning is doubtful.

R. 1. 7. ‘MASK’ does not refer, as Thiel and perhaps Serv. suppose, to the actual interruption of Aeneas' speech by Andromache's shrieks and sobs, but to the effect produced on his mind by the whole scene. ‘MASK’ of opening the mouth without full articulation, like “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 6. 493.

Ladewig and Henry are apparently right in restoring ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK’ from fragm. Vat. (Bottari: but Ribbeck is silent) and some other MSS., supported by the testimony of Serv., who mentions both readings. The external authority for the accusative is perhaps not great: in v. 303 above ‘MASK’ is corrupted into ‘MASK’ by fragm. Vat., and the ‘MASK’ here may have arisen from ‘MASK’ which in fragm. Vat., as in some other copies, was originally ‘MASK MASK’ But the common reading is objectionable as conveying an unfeeling reproach to Andromache, understood as it must be with Wagn., “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”—a reproach, too, which would be unmeaning in itself, as Aeneas well knew that Andromache had become Pyrrhus' captive, and therefore, according to the Homeric usage, his concubine, and inconsistent with the previous context, as though Aeneas finds the rumour of Helenus' good fortune incredible, he nevertheless assumes its truth in action (v. 299). The force of these objections might be to a certain extent abated; but enough would remain to make the passage as commonly read difficult and awkward. If we accept the accusative, all is clear: Aeneas asks, as Henry remarks, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ the second clause going beyond the first, and referring to the report of her new prosperity, while in the third he inquires whether she is still united to Pyrrhus, in other words, whether the report is a false one. ‘MASK MASK’ will then balance ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ For the genitive ‘MASK MASK’ which, as Gossrau observes, is not elliptical but an ordinary possessive, see Madv. § 280, obs. 4. ‘MASK’ like “MASK” 10. 668, 12. 503, “MASK” 12. 797, the final ‘MASK’ being elided before a consonant no less than before a vowel. Wagn. prefers writing these and similar words without an apostrophe.
For the story of Polyxena see the Hecuba of Euripides.

is used loosely in any case, as Polyxena's death happened after the sack of Troy . Euripides makes Polyxena's death take place in the Thracian Chersonese; Virg. followed a different story, placing the tomb of Achilles on the Sigean promontory.

The captives were divided by lot, Eur. Tro. 240 foll., where however it is said of Andromache, v. 274, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . Andromache's feeling is like that of Creusa 2. 785 foll. For the indicative where we might have expected the subjunctive see on MASK .
like MASK MASK .
1. 376, a comparison of which will show that ‘MASK MASK’ here may be the local abl., though the abl. abs. seems more natural. ‘MASK’ of the city Troy , as in 5. 624.

defines ‘MASK MASK’ Andromache was the slave of her master's passion, and had offspring by him. The name of Andromache's son was Molossus, who is one of the dramatis personae in Eur. Andr. It is strange that Jahn should have attempted to fix another sense on ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though he appears right in saying that this absolute use of ‘MASK’ for bringing forth is not common. It would be possible to explain ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ of the insolence of Pyrrhus in leaving Andromache after making her his concubine; but ‘MASK’ is in favour of the other interpretation, which is also perhaps more in keeping with ancient feeling.

Wagn. appears rightly to explain ‘MASK’ as coupling two clauses which are co-ordinate in sense, though not grammatically, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ (to be the wife of his captive) ‘MASK’ (and to be a captive wife). Of the parallel instances which he quotes from Virg. the most apposite seem to be “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 5. 447, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ib. 498, “MASK MASK MASK” 10. 734. See also on 2. 87, MASK . The old reading ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ supported by a few inferior MSS., looks like a correction.

‘MASK’ fragm. Vat., Pal., Gud. a m. p., ‘MASK’ Med. External evidence seems in favour of the simple word, which I have preferred with Ribbeck. On internal grounds there seems little to say: the dictionaries would lead us to suppose that the simple word was more common in poetry, the compound in prose. See on 4. 54. Henry remarks that Orestes is represented as impelled to kill Pyrrhus by two causes—he is not himself, and he has sustained a personal injury. With the sense so produced he compares Ausonius' epitaph on Pyrrhus (Epitaph. Heroum 9), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
9. 138 note. ‘MASK MASK’ combines the two senses, which in the old belief would be undistinguishable, of the Furies that punished the matricide and the madness arising from it.

MASK . With the language of this line Henry comp. 1. 349, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” observing that ‘MASK MASK MASK’ explains ‘MASK MASK’ Pyrrhus being attacked at home in his own penetralia. There is however a doubt about the reference of ‘MASK MASK MASK’ here, which is generally explained of an altar raised in honour of Achilles at Delphi (a fact apparently resting only on a doubtful statement of Serv.), Delphi being the place where Pyrrhus was said to have met his death (Dict. B. ‘MASK’). Virg.'s brevity will hardly allow us to decide definitely. In any case, as the language shows (comp. 2. 663), we are meant to think of Pyrrhus' death at the altar as a retribution for his murder of Priam. Heyne refers to Tryphiodorus v. 640— “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Comp. also Eur. Andr. 1117 foll., where Pyrrhus is killed at the altar of Apollo by the Delphians under Orestes. But the parallel would be better if we suppose him to have been killed in his own house.

Different stories were told of the connexion of Pyrrhus with Epirus: see Dict. B. ‘MASK MASK’ The names Neoptolemus and Pyrrhus were both given to kings of Epirus in historical times. The sense of ‘MASK’ is disputed. Forb. explains it, not improbably, with reference to Helenus' position at Troy , to which he was now in some sort restored. But it may be suggested that the word may have the sense of giving in succession, giving to one person after another, though I know of no other instance which would support it. Mr. Long suggests that ‘MASK’ here simply expresses a result from an antecedent. ‘MASK’ above v. 297.

The name ‘MASK’ was one of greater antiquity than that which is here ascribed to it, the Chaonians being connected by tradition with the Pelasgians (Dict. Geogr. ‘MASK’). Various stories of this Chaon are mentioned by Serv., the general result being that he was Helenus' brother or comrade, who was either killed by him accidentally or died for him voluntarily.
There is an unmetrical reading ‘MASK’ in Med. (supported by a correction in Pal.), which Serv. mentions as the usual one in his time, though he condemns it. With ‘MASK MASK MASK’ comp. 6. 774.

Andromache means, as Heyne remarks, to ask Aeneas how he has come to Epirus—by stress of weather, or by destiny, or divine intervention, ‘MASK’ having virtually the force of ‘MASK’ ( MASK note). The alternatives are scarcely meant to exclude each other, being rather different ways of stating the same thing. With ‘MASK MASK MASK’ comp. 4. 225, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

is explained by ‘MASK MASK’ a divine intervention having brought Aeneas to a country which he did not know to be a friendly one. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is repeated below v. 715. Before Heins. ‘MASK MASK’ was read for ‘MASK MASK’

see on MASK . ‘MASK’ as in MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ 1. 546. Here some MSS. give ‘MASK MASK’ which is supported by a reading in fragm. Vat., and approved by Jahn; but the construction is not found elsewhere in Virg.

A solitary instance in Virg. of a hemistich where the sense is incomplete. The copyists of the inferior MSS. have attempted to supply the deficiency in different ways—“MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Later critics, as Heyne Gossrau, and Ladewing, have fancied that the passage has been interpolated. Wagn. and Forb. complain that, as the text stands, Andromache makes no mention of Creusa, whom she could not know to be lost, and accordingly adopt, as does Ribbeck, ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK’ from the ‘MASK MASK’ separating ‘MASK MASK MASK’ from ‘MASK MASK’ (Ribbeck cites Med. for ‘MASK MASK’ but a friend who consulted the MS. for me assures me that it distinctly reads ‘MASK MASK’) They account for ‘MASK’ v. 341 by supposing that Aeneas gives some sign which shows that his wife is no more— an expedient which would scarcely be natural in an ancient drama, but is ridiculous in an epic. (Ribbeck supposes a lacuna.) The words of the next line clearly show that Andromache—how, we know not, but may imagine for ourselves— was aware of Creusa's fate. They are not such as would occur to her on the moment of hearing a piece of news like this: they are precisely what might be spoken under other circumstances by a mother possessed with the image of her own lost boy, and wondering whether the separation had really entailed a breach in their love of each other. On the whole, there seems no good reason to doubt that we have the passage as Virg. left it. If we cannot complete the hemistich satisfactorily, we may console ourselves with thinking that be could not either.

Germanus attempts to show that the features of this river are intended not to be contrasted but to be paralleled with those of the real Xanthus, which was itself comparatively a small stream, as Horace Epod. 13. 13 talks of “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” But this is obviously contrary to Virg.'s meaning, which is evidently to contrast Hom.'s MASK MASK with its miniature, which “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

of entertaining guests, as in Ter. Eun. 5. 8. 52, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The “MASK” seem to have surrounded the “MASK MASK” which appears to be used by Virg. in the case of a palace as equivalent to “MASK MASK” See Lersch, § 72. “MASK” and “MASK” are connected 2. 528., 12. 474 foll. The banquet probably extended to both, as all Aeneas' companions appear to have been entertained. Symmons finds a difficulty here: but the circumstance doubtless did not count for much with Virg., who is apt to exaggerate in such matters (comp. 1. 634, 635 &c.), and merely wished to convey a notion of Helenus' hospitality.

‘MASK’ is one of the archaisms which Virg. admits into the Aeneid: see on 1. 254. ‘MASK MASK’ the reading of some MSS., is supported by citations in several grammarians: but the preposition is omitted by Med., Pal., and others.

as we should say, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ These supernatural facts were as open to Helenus as the common facts of sense to ordinary men. The enumeration ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ may remind us of v. 91 above, as the passage generally resembles 10. 174 foll. Here, as there, astrology is made part of divination —a notion much later than the Homeric times. Apollo is called “MASK” from his temple at Claros near Colophon, where oracles were given as late as the time of Germanicus, who is said to have received there an ambiguous presage of the fate awaiting him (Tac. A. 2. 54). ‘MASK MASK’ the reading of Pal., Med. a m. pr., &c., would be unmetrical. ‘MASK’ Med. a m. pr., Pal., ‘MASK’ Med. a m. s. &c. See on MASK .

‘MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK MASK’ refer to the two modes of divination, from the note and from the flight of birds. ‘MASK’ is an augurial term, variously explained (see Forc.), though authorities seem agreed that the appearance designated by it was a favourable one.

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. There is another reading ‘MASK MASK’ found in Pal. and Gud. a m. pr., and adopted by Ribbeck; but Virg. probably chose to vary the expression in the two clauses, saying in the first that there were favourable prognostics of the whole of Aeneas' voyage, in the second that the divine voices were unanimous in favour of his journeying to Italy.
is used of a divine presence or utterance Phaedrus 4. 11. 4, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ of the expression of the divine will 2. 123 note.
i. q. ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 6. 59.

must be understood as = “MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ being coupled with ‘MASK’ as an epithet of ‘MASK MASK’ though no instance is quoted of this adjectival use. like ‘MASK’ (from which the grammarians attempted to distinguish it: see Serv.), seems to be used of anything contrary to ordinary experience, and consequently attributable to supernatural interposition. So here it is applied to an event which seemed as if it could not happen under ordinary conditions.

‘MASK’ is used of revolting food Pliny 10. 29. For the present indicative ‘MASK’ see on v. 88. ‘MASK’ in fact is explained by ‘MASK MASK’ He puts the question directly instead of making it depend on ‘MASK MASK MASK’ perhaps on account of the length of the intervening parenthesis.

“MASK MASK MASK” Serv. It seems better to take it ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ From the encouragement of the gods he inferred that the difficulties could be surmounted in some way or other. ‘MASK’ might be explained as a return to the indirect question (comp. Pers. 3. 67 foll.): but it seems better to regard it as depending on ‘MASK MASK’ which may be resolved into ‘MASK MASK MASK’

I have removed the commas which are generally placed after ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ as “MASK” v. 373 shows that ‘MASK’ is not confined to ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but belongs to the whole sentence down to the end of v. 372. ‘MASK’ of time 1. 728, ‘MASK MASK’ v. 65. Victims are sacrificed before consulting the oracle, as in 6. 38.

above v. 261. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ this action of Helenus is apparently to be paralleled by such passages as Tibull. 2. 5. 66, Ov. F. 1. 503, the unbinding of the hair being in keeping with the abnormal physical condition of those who are about to be made subjects of the divine afflatus. Thus we may comp. the Sibyl 6. 48, and even the frantic action of Cassandra Aesch. Ag. 1264 foll. Helenus however seems to have performed the action gravely and deliberately. Serv. has a mystical interpretation to the effect that unbinding the head is supposed to free the mind, and so make it susceptible of divine communications.
The sacrifice seems to have been made elsewhere, not in the temple itself, unless we take ‘MASK’ of the adytum, or suppose a MASK MASK .

Jupiter MASK supposed to draw the decrees of fate like lots out of the urn, being apparently the regulator, if not the actual author of destiny. So 4. 614 we hear of “MASK MASK MASK” In ‘MASK MASK’ the notion seems to be that of ordaining the succession of events, being further explained by “MASK MASK MASK MASK” We have already had the word used in connexion with fate 1. 22, 262 (notes): but in the latter passage, and perhaps in the former too, the precise reference seems to be different.

Henry seems right in giving ‘MASK’ here and v. 539 a medium sense, like that of MASK , between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ To press the latter aspect of the word would be inconsistent with ‘MASK MASK’ as if the seas were absolutely friendly. Helenus' directions would scarcely be needed: to merge it entirely in the former would make the epithet less poetical. Comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and the application of MASK , MASK , MASK to seas.
as Henry remarks, signifies to settle finally and completely.

Serv., followed by Heyne and others, separates ‘MASK’ from ‘MASK MASK’ understanding the words to mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ it being supposed that an admission of Helenus' ignorance would be derogatory to his prophetic dignity. Forb. makes ‘MASK’ the subject of ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ of ‘MASK MASK’—‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ But it is simpler with Wagn. and Ladewig to make ‘MASK’ the subject of both infinitives, Helenus saying in effect that the future is partly unknown to him, partly incommunicable by him. With ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ we may comp. Aesch. Ag. 1025, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . Whether the restraining power exercised by Juno is owing simply to her enmity to Troy is not clear. Helenus' respect for her appears afterwards vv. 437 foll. In Sil. 1. 137, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” comp. by Wagn., there is a propriety in her intervention, as it is a Carthaginian priest who is speaking of the future. What the ‘MASK’ specifically are we need not inquire, though the context seems to point rather to the events of the voyage (Serv., Heyne) than to the future greatness of the Trojan empire in Italy (Forb.). seems best taken with Forb. as the abl. after ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ the “MASK” spoken of being Epirus, where they now were, and ‘MASK’ being introduced to give a rhetorical balance, like “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 4. 83, in spite of the logical confusion created by its insertion. Other interpretations are ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ divides by a long stretch of country, referring to the length of Italy that has to be sailed along before the Trojans reach the proper spot for landing (Heyne), and ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ a way by long tracts of country, like “MASK MASK MASK” v. 507 below (Wund.), an expression which would be applicable to a land-journey, not to a voyage. ‘MASK MASK’ is another jingle, an imitation of such Greek combinations as MASK MASK , &c., ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Helenus' meaning is that though Italy looks near, the way which Aeneas must go to reach the part assigned him by the fates is long and beset with dangers.

Henry seems to be refining too much when he understands ‘MASK’ of supplying rather than of bending the oar, and accordingly refuses to admit the parallel of Catull. 62 (64). 183, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” It is true doubtless that ‘MASK’ = ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but there is nothing to show that it may not be applied to the simple drawing of an oar against the water or to the simple bending of a bow (which surely must be its sense MASK Stat. Theb. 1. 703, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”). The imitation of Sen. Ag. 435, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” seems to show that he understood it MASK that sense. Comp. also 7. 28, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where the meaning is the water pulls against the oars as well as the oars against the water. At the same time there is nothing to prevent our supposing that Virg. chose the word here to indicate that the voyage was to be a long one, the oars growing more tough and flexible by exercise.

They pass by Circe's island after leaving Cumae and Caieta, 7. 10 foll. ‘MASK’ was the old reading: but ‘MASK MASK’ which Heins. restored from the older MSS., is in keeping with Virg.'s practice elsewhere of preferring the Roman to the Greek form of the genitive. Hom. calls Circe's island MASK MASK , Od. 10. 135, Circe being so called from her connexion with Aea in Colchis.

MASK note. Virg. follows a story which represented some of the companions of the younger Ajax as driven on shore on the coast of Bruttii by the storm which attacked the Grecian fleet on its return, and settling there. Others were driven still farther, to Africa, as Virg. tells us himself, 11. 265.
See on v. 122. “MASK” is the orthography of Med., Pal., &c., preferred by Heins. and the later editors to ‘MASK’ One MS. has ‘MASK’ which is supported by a coin.
MASK . ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Meliboea in Thessaly had been part of the dominious of Philoctetes (Il. 2. 717), who, like Idomeneus, was forced to leave his kingdom and settle in Italy.

supported by its wall, like “MASK MASK” 1. 506. Henry thinks a compliment is intended to the strength of the little Bruttian town, which made a gallant resistance in the second Punic War, Livy 23. 30. ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ The spelling ‘MASK’ is found in Med. and supported by coins: but ‘MASK MASK’ the orthography of Pal., Gud., &c., has also some confirmation from inscriptions. Turnebus derives the name from “MASK” a word apparently signifying thin or shrunk, occurring in fragments of Plautus and Lucilius (see Forc.): and Henry, who connects this dubious adjective with the French “MASK MASK” thinks we have here an instance of a practice not uncommon with Virg. (see on 1. 298), of adding to the name of a place an epithet explanatory of its meaning.

Wagn. would take ‘MASK’ here, like “MASK” above v. 110, as a perf. subj. from “MASK MASK” such a form being vouched for by Charisius and Diomedes, so that ‘MASK’ here will = “MASK MASK” We may accept his remark as to the use of the word in these two passages without committing ourselves to his grammatical position, as Gell. 2. 14 apparently speaks of “MASK” as the only perfect of “MASK MASK” The utmost that could be said would be, that as “MASK” seems to be confined to the transitive sense of “MASK MASK” and even then only to be used in legal formularies, the perfect of ‘MASK’ is sometimes employed with a certain latitude, so as to include the meaning of “MASK” intransitive. For the union of “MASK” and “MASK MASK” as for that of “MASK” and “MASK MASK” vv. 410, 411, see on MASK . Gossrau apparently connects “MASK MASK” with “MASK MASK” not with “MASK MASK” but the order seems against this. Helenus' direction refers to their landing on the nearest coast of Italy for the purpose of sacrificing, as is evident from vv. 543 foll., where they fulfil his injunction, so that perhaps we may say that this and the next verse contain an indirect precept, Helenus assuming that they will do what otherwise they would not have thought of doing.

imperative passive: see on 2. 707, and comp. v. 545 below. To explain ‘MASK’ as infinitive for imperative is to introduce a construction unexampled in Latin, except in one very doubtful passage, Val. Fl. 3. 412, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” See Wagn. Lect. Verg. p. 377. The covering of the head during sacrifice was a distinctively Roman custom, the Greeks sacrificing with the head uncovered. There is a representation of Aeneas sacrificing with his head covered in the Royal Gallery at Florence: see Lersch, p. 176. Lucr. has not omitted the trait in his wellknown lines on the inutility of sacrifice (5. 1196 foll.), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
MASK . ‘MASK MASK MASK’ expresses the same thing more picturesquely.

The reason given for the precept seems to be that the appearance of an enemy, if seen by the worshipper, would be an evil omen. It is not said that such an appearance would be an evil omen in itself; nor is anything intimated about the danger to the sacrificer; though perhaps the meaning may be that he would become confused or break off the sacrifice. The prohibition “MASK MASK” is supposed to be connected with the same observance. If we may trust Serv., Virg. is not only accounting for a Roman custom, but glancing at a Trojan legend, to the effect that Diomede, being ordered by an oracle to restore the Palladium, came upon Aeneas while sacrificing, that Aeneas did not interrupt his worship, and that the restoration was consequently made not to him, but to Nautes. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” 9. 120. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the omens would have been taken before the sacrifice, and anything occurring during the sacrifice might spoil them. explains ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ are varieties found in the MSS. here or elsewhere. The question seems to lie between the two first, both of which seem to have been forms used in classical Latin, Cic. Arat. v. 152 having “MASK MASK” while “MASK” occurs 10. 211. On internal grounds it might seem more probable that Virg. should have written ‘MASK MASK’ as there is no passage in the Aeneid which requires the form in ‘MASK’ while there are several (5. 116, 156., 10. 211) which do not admit it. The external authority however is strongly for ‘MASK MASK’ only inferior MSS. being cited for ‘MASK MASK’ and as the question seems not to be one of mere orthography, it is better to adopt the better attested word. The notion that Virg. was likely to have given the more colloquial name to the ship, the less colloquial to the actual fish, is refuted by the passage in Book 10. The ‘MASK’ was a great fish, which Pliny (9. 3) says was found sometimes of 200 cubits' length.

This line is a further description of the “MASK” part of Scylla, which was not entirely fish, but fish and wolf or dog mixed. ‘MASK’ probably means little more than “MASK MASK” Virg. calls the fishy part ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ indifferently, aiming in each case at being poetically graphic, not prosaically general, as he speaks of the material of the Trojan horse as fir, maple, and oak indifferently. ‘MASK MASK’ would naturally signify a belly like a wolf's (comp. 11. 813): but it is evident from v. 432 and from the story as told elsewhere, that he means there were wolves' or dogs' heads (another instance of two discordant specifications) about her belly. ‘MASK’ of junction. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Juv. 14. 310. A consideration of the structure of the passage, and a comparison of the parallel 6. 76, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” will, I think, show that Wakef., Bothe, and Jahn are right against the majority of editors in removing the stop after ‘MASK MASK’ so that the words will run ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ On the other side comp. “MASK MASK” 6. 45, where however the oracles are demanded not of the Sibyl but of the god. The objection that the manner in which the oracles were to be given has nothing to do with the delay, might be met by saying that the Sibyl might require greater pressure to make her speak than to make her write, the latter being her usual mode of prophesying: but it is more satisfactory to say that Virg., like every other poet, chooses occasionally to include more in a sentence than the exactness of logical simplicity would require. ‘MASK’ is applied to the Sibyl with the same feeling with which it is used of the gods in such phrases as “MASK MASK MASK” as Serv. remarks. Compare MASK . We should say ‘MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ will then = “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ MASK .

This line is substantially repeated 6. 892, where it is Anchises that expounds to Aeneas his future in Italy. He would hear all about the means of avoidance and endurance, according as either might be applicable.

Of Serv.'s two interpretations of ‘MASK MASK’ grooms or drivers for the horses, and guides for the voyage, Wagn. seems right in preferring the latter. ‘MASK MASK’ as he remarks, would have little force with the former interpretation: 10. 574, which Heyne quotes, only proves that a warrior in a car could be called “MASK” in relation to his horses: and Dion. Hal. 1. 32 speaks of guides as having sailed with Aeneas from Epirus.

It is doubtful whether ‘MASK’ is to be taken in its ordinary sense or i. q. “MASK MASK” It would be no objection to the latter, as Wagn. remarks, that the Homeric warriors are themselves rowers, as Virg. constantly blends the customs of his own time with those of the heroic ages. ‘MASK’ would refer equally well to refitting the vessels and recruiting the crews. The parallel 8. 80 would be in favour of the ordinary sense of ‘MASK MASK’ but such considerations cannot be pressed. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ will refer in any case to armour given by Helenus to Aencas' companions, not to the equipment of the vessels. The present of arms to the Trojans generally as well as to Aeneas is parallel to the entertainments vv. 352 foll.

see on MASK . “MASK MASK MASK” for delaying a person has already occurred E. 10. 11, 12, so that the expression here is parallel to that in v. 481 below (note).
“MASK MASK” occurs Tac. H. 4. 4. Agric. 40.

The MSS. are divided between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ as are the early grammarians. Reason would seem to be in favour of the former, the Greek vocative, as against the latter, the Latin vocative, which would naturally have the ‘MASK’ short, like ‘MASK’ Hor. 2 S. 3. 187. Those who support ‘MASK’ here explain it as the Doric form of the Greek vocative, which seems arbitrary. Where however there is so much external authority for a form, it would be hazardous to assume on internal grounds that Virg. could not have used it, though I still think it safer to read ‘MASK MASK’ In 6. 126, 348 the preponderance of MS. authority is very decidedly for “MASK MASK”

Helenus points to the coast of Italy in the direction of Epirus: in this verse however he is thinking of Italy generally: in the next ‘MASK’ is used specially of that particular part which lies nearest. “MASK MASK” occurs again 10. 298 of gaining the shore. Comp. also 9. 13., 11. 531.
as if he were correcting himself. For the sense see above vv. 396 foll.

of course belongs to this as well as to the next clause. ‘MASK’ properly means the woof, while ‘MASK MASK’ is an embroidered mantle (Forc. s. v. ‘MASK’), so that a doubt has been raised whether the ‘MASK’ and the ‘MASK’ are meant to be distinguished as tapestry and needlework, or to be classed together as embroidery, ‘MASK’ being used vaguely of thread. Wagn. thinks the latter the more probable view, referring to Sil. 7. 39, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ i. q. ‘MASK MASK’ MASK has “MASK MASK MASK”

The difficulty of the words ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is well known. Serv. and Donatus suppose the meaning to be that Andromache does not yield to the honour of Ascanius, does not give him less than his due. Heyne, that Andromache does not yield to the liberality of her husband. Wagn. thinks that ‘MASK’ is the subject of ‘MASK MASK’ the mantle does not yield to the beauty of the other embroidered robes. Others have adopted ‘MASK MASK’ the reading of Pal., Gud. a m. pr., and another MS., which Serv. mentions as approved by Scaurus. Sil. 12. 412 has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but the general sense is not very parallel. Retaining ‘MASK MASK’ I would suggest that the words may possibly mean, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” give way to honour, as if she were contending with it,—a poetical equivalent to the prosaic “MASK MASK MASK MASK” as in Hom. we might have MASK MASK MASK . I do not remember any precisely parallel expression in Virg. or elsewhere: but the language, so interpreted, seems admissible in itself and suited to the context (comp. ‘MASK’ immediately following).

Henry understands ‘MASK MASK’ loads by putting them on his shoulders, comp. Ter. Phorm. 5. 6. 4, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but it seems simpler to suppose the reference to be merely to the abundance of the presents. “MASK MASK MASK” occurs 10. 620.

Tibull. 3. 5. 31. Helenus and Andromache are congratulated on having their fortune accomplished, i. e. on having done with chance and change. Here, as in the next line, fortune and fate are looked upon not as the constituents of human life, but as disturbing agencies. Or we may say that Helenus and Andromache are spoken of as having attained while living the happiness which in general is only predicated of the dead, and so comp., with Forb., 4. 653, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Lucan 4. 361, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is used rather than ‘MASK MASK’ which we might have expected, as Virg. chooses to describe their condition rather than expressly assign a reason for their happiness. For ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK” would have been more strictly correct: but the third person generalizes the proposition— ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Cerda and others punctuate ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ &c., an ingenious way of getting rid of the harshness of expression, but less like Virg.'s manner.

The early copyists and editors misunderstood the sentence, not seeing that the apodosis began at ‘MASK MASK’ Thus some MSS., and probably Serv., give ‘MASK MASK’ while ‘MASK’ was supposed to refer to ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ being relegated to the following clause. The sense is, we will make the kindred nations one Troy in mind. All that Aeneas need mean by this expression is an engagement of amity and alliance: but Virg. is likely enough to have intended a special reference to some historical relations between Rome and Epirus, and the words ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ are too pointed to be passed over lightly. Such relations have been found by the commentators in the founding of Nicopolis by Octavianus (Serv.), and the establishment of a Roman colony in Buthrotum (Forb.). The former seems more likely to have been intended, as the event was recent, and the compliment one which Virg. would be glad to pay, while the transaction itself would be more flattering to the national vanity of the Epirotes, who were spoken of, Serv. tells us, in the charter of the city as kinsmen of the Romans, than the mere establishment of a Roman colony among them. ‘MASK’ may go with ‘MASK MASK’ kinsmen of old: but it is perhaps better to take it with ‘MASK MASK’ we will one day form. ‘MASK’ may be explained either like ‘MASK’ of relationship, or of actual proximity.

and ‘MASK’ must be taken as local ablatives. Viewed in this way, the reading is very plausible, as it is not easy to see how it can have arisen, while it is sufficiently recondite to present temptations to a tampering transcriber. ‘MASK’ however was read by Serv. presents a difficulty. The custom of dividing the rowingbenches among the crews by lot is mentioned by MASK foll. (comp. On the other hand, the various ways of avoiding the difficulty that have been proposed fail to commend themselves. ‘MASK MASK’ would be a harsh expression for ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ even if it were established that such was the custom, while Henry's notion that they cast lots for the oars, to be used as tent-poles, introduces a detail for which no authority is quoted but a passage in Rutilius Numatianus (Itin. 1. 345 foll.), and which consequently we should have expected to be mentioned in full, if Virg. really intended it, not briefly indicated. of time, not of place, as the bay of Tarentum could not be seen from the Castrum Minervae. Henry. ‘MASK MASK’ the ordinary legend attributed the founding of Tarentum to Taras, son of Poseidon. Heyne, in an Excursus, collects the various notices which connect the name of Hercules with Tarentum, doubting however whether they do not belong to a later time, after Tarentum had been colonized from Lacedaemon, so that he supposes Virg.'s actual authority to be some story, now lost, of the foundation of Tarentum by Hercules. He remarks that the southern coast of Italy was full of memorials of Hercules. Virg.'s ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ may be meant to point to the fact that there were other and opposing legends.

The Lacinian promontory had a celebrated temple of Juno, some pillars of which are still standing, and give the spot its modern name, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Serv. gives various legends accounting for the name of the promontory, two of them connecting the foundation of the temple with Hercules, who, according to one story, built it to commemorate the death of the robber Lacinus, while another represents it as built by a king Lacinius, who refused hospitality to Hercules, and signalized the affront to the stepson by a temple to the stepmother. This latter tale would give some point to ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ the temple being supposed to rise in defiance. The temple and the goddess are identified, as in v. 275 above.

From Od. 9. 136, MASK MASK MASK MASK . Virg.'s ‘MASK MASK’ are however not the same as Hom.'s MASK MASK , which was not on the east coast of Sicily near Aetna, but by Drepanum and Eryx. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ may possibly be an attempt to combine the two expressions ‘MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The similarity between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ of course amounts nearly to a jingle; but those who have followed Virg. in his plays on the different senses of the same word in poetical combinations will hardly think it impossible that he may have used one compound with the intention of reminding his readers of another, though the two are really heterogeneous. ‘MASK’ is complained of as harsh by some of the later editors, who do not see how the size of the haven should point a contrast with Aetna, as ‘MASK’ shows that it is meant to do; Virg. however evidently intends to say that so far as the haven went, it was commodious, being sheltered and large, but that the neighbourhood of Aetna was a drawback.

The following description is more or less parallel to one in Pind. Pyth. 1. 34 foll. Gell. 17. 10 reports a criticism on the two passages by Favorinus the philosopher, very unfavourable to Virg., who is blamed for confusing night and day (see on v. 575), confounding smoke and flame, and generally exaggerating Pindar's simple truth. Later critics have defended Virg.; but Heyne (Excursus 15) thinks he has studied poetical ornament rather than physical accuracy. ‘MASK’ is commonly used of a downfall; here it stands for an eruption or throwing up, just as ‘MASK’ is said of sending up smoke MASK . Forc. remarks that ‘MASK’ sometimes means merely violent motion forward, and quotes Val. Fl. 4. 694, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” of Tiphys escaping through the Symplegades. See on MASK .

active, 1. 246. Virg. follows MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” a line which he also had in his mind in writing MASK . In the earlier passage he applies to an ordinary conflagration words borrowed from a description of an eruption; coming afterwards to write of an eruption, he recurs not only to the description in Lucr., but to the use which he had himself made of that description. Precisely the same thing may be traced lower down, v. 577, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ where we shall not doubt that he was thinking of his own words in a simile about a storm, MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK” where we remember that those words form part of a sentence obviously imitated from a line in this same description in Lucr., “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” A criticism like this, which professes to detect what was passing in the poet's mind is of course liable to make discoveries which have no real existence; but when cautiously applied, it can hardly be out of place in dealing with an author like Virg., where expressions are at once so studied and so borrowed.
“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK . Lucr. l. c. has “MASK MASK MASK”

Virg. distinguishes eruptions of smoke, fire, and cinders from eruptions of rocks and lava: Pindar, the smoke by day from the fire by night. ‘MASK’ gave the hint to Sir Richard Blackmore for the description, quoted in the Treatise on the Bathos, where the mountain is represented as ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ though the ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ to which the ‘MASK MASK’ is attributed, look as if he had been to school to Lucretius.

For ‘MASK’ a few MSS. give ‘MASK MASK’ which Burm. prefers; but the common reading is supported by 7. 529., 9. 239, as Heyne remarks, and by the Lucretian word ‘MASK MASK’ while it is well adapted to express the labour of upheaving masses of rock into the air. ‘MASK’ is Pindar's MASK .

MASK MASK , Pind. l. c., as ‘MASK MASK’ is from MASK MASK . Henry refines too much when he says that ‘MASK’ means not ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ but ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as it is evident that both notions enter into the word, though the latter may be the more prominent here.

The name of the giant who was supposed to be placed under Aetna was variously given in the legends. Pindar l. c. and MASK make it Typhocus or Typhon, MASK Briareus. In A. 9. 716, following (though misinterpreting) Hom., Virg. places Typhoeus under Inarime or Pithecusa. ‘MASK’ is found here in most of the MSS., including Med., which has the same form in 11. 200. For ‘MASK’ some MSS. give ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK’ which Serv. prefers. We have already had the variety MASK , where we saw reason to adopt ‘MASK MASK’ Here ‘MASK’ seems the better word, as containing a more distinct notion of relief, not to mention that the frequentative ‘MASK’ would be inconsistent with ‘MASK MASK’ In Stat. Theb. 3. 594, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” evidently an imitation of this passage, the MSS. do not vary, except that one of them gives “MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ also occurs Ov. M. 13. 937, where there can be no doubt about the word, as it is coupled with “MASK MASK” It is stronger than ‘MASK MASK MASK’ expressing not only stirring, but turning from side to side. is read by some MSS., while some insert ‘MASK’ before ‘MASK MASK’ The Trojans disembark, like Ulysses under similar circumstances Od. 9. 150 foll., and pass the night on the land. Monstra, are the terrible and unaccountable phenomena. ‘MASK MASK’ occurs 7. 21, of suffering a monstrous transformation.

The two clauses, as usual, mean the same thing, ‘MASK’ being not disjunctive but copulative, as in MASK . The incident that follows is apparently Virg.'s own. Ovid borrows it in his account of Aeneas' wanderings, Met. 14. 160 foll. It enables Virg. to introduce a description of the Cyclops' cave without involving the Trojans in any perilous adventure, at the same time that it furnishes a sort of counterpoise to the story of Sinon in Book 2, from which one or two circumstances are taken. ‘MASK’ (properly the morning star, MASK MASK ) here stands for the morning, as the parallel passage 11. 4 shows. So probably 5. 42, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” For the position of ‘MASK’ comp. 5. 225.

This advance of Achemenides from the woods to the shore (below v. 598) has been thought to show that the Trojans could not have spent the night in the woods (above v. 583). We need however only suppose that they had risen and were on the shore again, a circumstance which Virg., more suo, tells by implication, as indeed there was no occasion to specify it. ‘MASK MASK’ the last extremity. So Caes. B. MASK talks of “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK” and “MASK” are similarly used: see Fore.

like “MASK MASK” 4. 556, “MASK MASK MASK” 6. 289, ‘MASK’ in each case expressing external appearance. ‘MASK MASK’ i.q. “MASK MASK MASK” So “MASK MASK” 5. 730, though ‘MASK’ there refers to social habits, here to dress.

the Trojans were apparently turned towards the sea, attending to their ships, when the approach of the stranger leads them to look back. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is alluded to by Ov. M. 14. 166, who speaks of Achemenides when under Aeneas' protection as “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and perhaps, as Forb. thinks, by Tac. Germ. 17, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The commoner form ‘MASK’ is found in some MSS., and was the old reading. We need hardly ask how Achemenides is known to be a Greek —whether by the remnants of his dress, or, as Serv. thinks, by his language and gait.

as Wagn. remarks, has the force of “MASK MASK MASK” Burm. read ‘MASK MASK’ from one MS., but Heyne rightly brought back the old reading. The words do not necessarily imply that he was then wearing the armour of a Greek (Forb.) but only that he was a Greek who had fought at Troy—a fact which they may have recognized as he drew nearer, though at first he was ‘MASK MASK MASK’ or which may be mentioned in anticipation of his confession v. 602.
has here the sense of ‘MASK MASK’ like ‘MASK’ and MASK . Forc. does not mention this use. The common notion is that of adjuring, which applies equally to a witness and to a person entreated.

of taking on board 6. 370, as in Hor. 2 S. 6, 42 of giving a lift in a carriage.

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ MASK MASK ’MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ cum periero :’” Donatus, who is right in calling attention to the mood and tense, though the meaning seems rather to be ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ was the reading before Heins. The structure of the sentence obliges us to take ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ not with ‘MASK MASK’ The abl. will then be local. Some MSS. have ‘MASK MASK’ but the intransitive use of the participle is sufficiently Virgilian, and the frequentative is very forcible here. ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ is frequent in prose: see Forc.
Comp. 2. 74, 75. Some MSS. give ‘MASK MASK MASK’ See on MASK .

is not unfrequently used by Virg. out of its place (see on 1. 195), so that Jahn and Forb. may be right in connecting it here with ‘MASK MASK’ But a very good meaning may be extracted from it as it stands, not by connecting it, as Wagn. does, with ‘MASK’ in the sense of ‘MASK MASK MASK’ a sense which Forb. rightly denies to be supported by 5. 741., 9. 781., 12. 888 (where see notes), but by referring it to ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Achemenides is asked what is his birth, and what have been his subsequent fortunes. ‘MASK’ is used because the present is inquired about as well as the past, and is indeed the more prominent object of curiosity. The word might be understood in a neutral sense, Fortune being said ‘MASK’ a person, as a person is said himself ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ &c. (a conversion of subject and object not unusual in Virg.), but it is better taken in its less favourable acceptation, as they would naturally assume that Achemenides had been persecuted by Fortune.

“‘ MASK MASK : ’MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ ei . ’” Heyne. ‘MASK’ has a force of its own, as contrasted with ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ seems to mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as ‘MASK MASK’ is money paid down at once, ready money, ‘MASK MASK’ a debt that has to be discharged immediately. Anchises' action was an earnest of something further, but it brought immediate comfort. ‘MASK MASK’ MASK .

It signifies little whether ‘MASK’ is regarded as a substantive, or with Wund. as an adjective. ‘MASK’ answers to the Homeric MASK .

was found by Pierius in all the ancient MSS. which he consulted, and Heins. speaks of it as the reading of ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ however is the reading of Med., Gud., and some others. Rom. and fragm. Vat. are deficient, and Pal. illegible. Either would be in accordance with Latin usage, while ‘MASK’ would perhaps be the more liable to alteration. On the whole I have preferred ‘MASK MASK’ contrary to the opinion of the modern editors, Ribbeck excepted, on account of its external authority. Those who support ‘MASK’ are not agreed on its construction, some making it a nom., some an acc. ‘MASK’ not ‘MASK MASK’ is the reading of Med., supported by the Greek MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ is not constructed with ‘MASK MASK’ but taken absolutely, like “MASK MASK” 10. 205. The clause however is equivalent to saying that his father sent him to Troy .

So Sinon's father is ‘MASK’ 2. 87. Here, as there, poverty is the reason why the soldier's calling is chosen, ‘MASK’ &c. being tantamount to ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” 2. 110. So “MASK” is used in a parenthetical sentence, 11. 901.

2. 265. The description is copied from Od. 9. 371 foll. in all its loathsome details. We need not however blame Virg., as some crities have done, for introducing such things into an after-supper speech. Writing of Homeric events, he naturally adopts the Homeric manner.

Hom. (vv. 331 foll.) makes them cast lots for four who should take part with Ulysses. Virg. apparently means that they settled by lot which part of the work should fall to each, all being assumed to share in it.

Ti. Donatus read ‘MASK MASK’ a reading mentioned by Serv., which has a certain superficial plausibility in connexion with ‘MASK MASK’ But this poetical prettiness would be out of place here. ‘MASK’ expresses a process which Hom. describes in several lines (vv. 382 foll.), the rest forcing the stake into the eye, while Ulysses from above twirls it about, as a ship-carpenter bores a hole in a plank. The ‘MASK’ is doubtless the stake.

seems to express the appearance of the eye as he lay, sunken, and overshadowed by the huge brow and lashes, not as Serv., “MASK MASK MASK” Here again, as in v. 535 above, Serv. represents Donatus as reading unmetrically ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but these words look more like an attempt at explanation founded on an etymological blunder, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” like that mentioned by Pierius as given by Varro, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” It does not appear that ‘MASK’ existed as a various reading, but one copy has ‘MASK MASK’

Heyne and Henry seem right, after Cerda, in connecting ‘MASK MASK’ with ‘MASK’ The Cyclops live on the mountain-tops (Od. 9. 113), and Achemenides sees them skulking among the woods on the low ground. So immediately below, v. 655, ‘MASK MASK’ belongs not to ‘MASK’ but to ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ may either mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK” MASK , or ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The singular furnishes no objection, as Achemenides may well be thinking of a single occasion when he saw and heard a Cyclops on a cliff. ‘MASK’ however, as Mr. Long remarks, is in favour of supposing Achemenides to have mounted a rock for observation, as he apparently does v. 651.

Key (Lat. Gr. § 973) would connect ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ comp. v. 636, and referring to other places in Virg. where the relative stands in the same part of the verse, preceded by a spondee in the same clause. But “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 4. 181 is in favour of the old pointing, and there is more force in making the line consist of four attributes of Polyphemus, dreadfulness, hideousness, vastness, and blindness. ‘MASK MASK’ too seems intended as a translation of MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK Od. 9. 190. Another novelty is proposed by Henry, who understands ‘MASK’ not of the eye, but of the light of day,—a view supported by Ov. M. 14. 197, where Polyphemus says “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (comp. v. 200 “MASK MASK MASK MASK”) Virg. perhaps did not distinguish the two meanings as sharply as we do: but the use of ‘MASK’ vv. 635, 663 confirms the old interpretation, as does the fact that elsewhere he uses ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ of the darkness not of the blind but of the dead.

The Cyclops in Hom. (vv. 319 foll.) has a huge club of pine-wood, as long and thick as a mast, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . This is doubtless intended here by ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ where ‘MASK’ expresses personal exertion (see on MASK ). There is another reading ‘MASK MASK’ which though not supported by the oldest extant MSS. (Med. has it from a correction), is as old as Quinctilian, who says (8. 4), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” But it is difficult to see how the staff guides the hand, though it is the instrument by which the hand guides the steps. Burm. however adopted ‘MASK MASK’ Serv. read ‘MASK MASK’ though he curiously enough understood it of the pine, connecting ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’— “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Whether the object of ‘MASK’ is Polyphemus or his footsteps matters little. Comp. 6. 30, which favours the latter view.

Ulysses and his companions had carried off the rams, but left the ewes. With ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which awakens our sympathy for the blind monster, comp. his playful address to his pet ram Od. 9. 447 foll.

Pal., Gud., and some others fill up the hemistich with the words ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ or as one or two give it, ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The variety would itself excite suspicion, being what we find in other places where later copyists have amused themselves by filling up ‘MASK’ (see e. MASK ., 3. 340), while the detail belongs to Theocritus' Polyphemus, not to Hom.'s. Thus the presence of the words in Pal. merely proves that they are of earlier date than most of the Virgilian interpolations. Heins. however seems to have been the first to omit them.
There is no difficulty in ‘MASK MASK’ though ‘MASK MASK MASK’ must be taken as a MASK MASK .

For ‘MASK’ Med. has ‘MASK MASK’ the original reading (a m. pr.) having been ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is the spelling of Med. and most other MSS.; but the word so spelt is supposed to be long, as in MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK” according to Serv.'s first explanation. Comp. the Homeric MASK MASK , which shows that we need not press the words here with Forb., as if they meant that he takes up some of the water in his hand to bathe his eye with.

For ‘MASK’ there is an old variant ‘MASK MASK’ supported by Serv. (who however mentions ‘MASK’), Pal., Gud. a m. p., and a correction in Med. For ‘MASK’ some give ‘MASK’ (the first reading of Med.), others ‘MASK MASK’
Partly from Od. 9. 471 foll., partly from 10. 126 foll., where Ulysses escapes from the Laestrygons.
is rightly taken by the later editors as a participle, not as an adverb. “MASK MASK” is similarly used by Val. Fl. 2. 145.

is the reading of Med., Pal., Gud., and others, supported also by Donatus. In itself it might stand well enough, as it is frequently used of ploughing, while “MASK” is said of rowing by Val. Fl. 1. 450. But we have already had “MASK” of rowing vv. 208, 290 above, and we shall find it used elsewhere, 5. 778., 6. 320 (“MASK” being given by Pal. in the latter place), after the example of Ennius, A. 14. fr. 1, quoted by Gell. 2. 26, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Independently of this authority, ‘MASK’ would seem the better word under the circumstances, expressing rapidity of motion, and answering more nearly to Homer's MASK MASK MASK MASK (Od. 9. 472). Whether “MASK” in 5. 141., 10. 208 comes from “MASK” or from “MASK” is doubtful: see on the former passage. ‘MASK’ of the action of rowing compared with the action of driving 5. 147.

It signifies little whether ‘MASK’ be understood of the MASK or of the plashing of the oars (comp. v. 556 above “MASK MASK MASK MASK”); but the latter seems simpler, and agrees better with ‘MASK’ v. 667. The pleonasm ‘MASK MASK’ need hardly trouble us.

‘MASK MASK’ is the reading of fragm. Vat., Pal. (corrected), Gud., and others, supported by Med., a m. pr. ‘MASK MASK’ but the words would have no meaning, as “MASK MASK” is to aim at a thing. Serv., whose notions of metre sometimes seem peculiar, says, “‘ MASK : ’MASK MASK MASK‘ consistunt . ’” The perf. seems to be aoristic, there being no definite time in comparisons. As Serv. remarks, the oaks are the ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ the cypresses, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ she being regarded as an infernal goddess, while the cypress was sacred to Pluto. ‘MASK’ fragm. Vat. corrected and others.
note on v. 267 above. With the general sense comp. v. 269, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

This and the two following lines are condemned by Heyne and removed from the text by Wagn.; they are however found in all the MSS. Those who retain them are agreed about their general sense, viz. that in the extremity of their fear the Trojans remembered Helenus' warning about Scylla and Charybdis, and feeling that to be a greater danger even than the Cyclops, resolved to put back again, when the north wind sprung up and carried them into safety; but the processes which have been devised for getting that sense from the words are sufficiently various. On the whole the punctuation which gives the best sense seems to be that suggested by Vulpius on Tibull. 4. 1. 70 (after a hint of Serv.) and followed by Heyne and Henry, though there is still room for some difference of opinion on details of interpretation. Taking ‘MASK’ in the sense of “MASK” and regarding ‘MASK MASK’ as in opposition to ‘MASK MASK’ or, better perhaps, as a kind of cognate accusative expressing the effect of ‘MASK MASK’ (see on MASK ), I would translate ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The construction ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is fixed by the parallel 9. 143, where the words recur (as also in Ov. M. 7. 426), and by the similar expression “MASK MASK MASK” 10. 511, so that it will be a descriptive ablative. ‘MASK MASK’ may refer to the two passages, the one nearer to Scylla, the other to Charybdis, both of which were taken by Ulysses—or it may be only a poetical way of describing the one passage as dangerous on both sides. The use of ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK’ is supported by Donatus and Serv., and has vouchers in inscriptions and fragments of lost writings (see Forc.), while it is perhaps to be retained in such passages as MASK . For the position of ‘MASK’ comp. MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ occurs again 4. 46: “MASK MASK” we have had above v. 283. ‘MASK’ does not occur elsewhere in Virg.; but as it is a perfectly good Augustan word, that can be no reason for objecting to the genuineness of the lines, supposing it to be otherwise unimpeached. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as in Hor. 1 Od. 34. 3, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” On the whole we may pronounce that the harshness of the lines, though not to be extenuated, is not great enough to justify us in questioning their authorship, in the face of all external authority—backed as it is by Priscian, who quotes them twice, 15. 2, and 18. 79. The chief difficulty perhaps is in ‘MASK MASK’ for which we should have expected ‘MASK MASK’ as ‘MASK’ v. 682 points to ‘MASK’ rather than to ‘MASK MASK’ The meaning may conceivably be that Aeneas' companions were more alarmed than himself, and took the matter into their own hands, as Ulysses (Od. 12. 224) fears his comrades may do. Heins. conj. ‘MASK MASK’ Ribbeck reads ‘MASK MASK MASK’ from fragm. Vat., and transposes vv. 685, 686, reserving explanation for his (unpublished) Prolegomena. The history of such passages as the supposed exordium of Book 1 and the episode of Helen in Book 2 shows that the early grammarians were jealous of interpolations in Virg.'s text, one recension being in fact a check upon another, so that intrinsic considerations require to be strong indeed in order to shake the credit of lines which no early critic is known to have suspected. With ‘MASK MASK MASK’ comp. MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”, where the subject is, as here, the passage between Scylla and Charybdis. Considering the relation of Virg. to Apollonius we may perhaps adduce the fact of the imitation as a further proof of genuineness.
