‘MASK’ an unusual adjective from “MASK MASK” like “MASK” from “MASK MASK”

These lines also are rejected by Wagn. on internal grounds, this time with the slight external support of the Codex Wittianus, which places them in the margin. There is however nothing unVirgilian in their language. ‘MASK’ does not stand simply for “MASK MASK” but has its usual sense, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ are undoubtedly MASK MASK in Virg., but they occur in other Augustan writers, and there is nothing in the last of them, as Forb. thinks, foreign to the Epic style: nor is it strange that Aeneas should call Ulysses ‘MASK MASK’ speaking of him in connexion with the partner of his wanderings, and for the moment sympathizing with him as a fellow-sufferer with himself. It may be true that the places mentioned here find no place in Hom.'s account of Ulysses' voyage: but Virg. evidently intends to accommodate Ulysses' journey, as he has done Aeneas', to his own views of geography, as we have just seen in the case of his territory of the Cyclops, which, though not the same as Hom.'s, is still represented as that which Ulysses visited. The intimation that Achemenides informed Aeneas of the names of the places, or (as the words may well mean) acted as his guide, was not necessary indeed, but cannot be called out of place. The construction of the words is not quite clear, as ‘MASK’ may be connected either with ‘MASK MASK’ or with ‘MASK MASK’ or again with both: but the last seems the most probable view. ‘MASK MASK’ then may be compared with “MASK MASK” Ov. F. 4. 573, though the meaning here is not so much ‘MASK MASK’ as ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ For ‘MASK’ some MSS. give ‘MASK’ It is noticeable that these verses also have the support of Priscian (11. 5. 21).

by the oracle, which is preserved by Serv., MASK MASK MASK : MASK MASK MASK , words which in modern days have passed into a proverb against meddling even with admitted evils. The story is that the place was surrounded by a marsh, which the inhabitants drained in spite of the oracle, thus making the spot accessible to the enemy, who took it. It is not known to what period of history this story refers, though Thuc. says (6. 5) that the place was three times founded, the inhabitants having been twice expelled. In any case Serv. is doubtless right in saying that Aeneas in making this and other allusions is speaking in the poet's language rather than in his own. Comp. 2. 21 note.

The meaning of ‘MASK’ is much disputed, some referring it to the size of the place, which however is not known to have been very large, others to the tyrants who ruled it, while the later editors understand it as a genitive, not very probably, and refer it to the dangerous character of the river. In lengthening the final syllable of ‘MASK’ Virg. has followed the Greek (see Lachm. on MASK ). Silius Italicus on the contrary, in a similar enumeration of Sicilian cities (14. 218), has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” A difficulty has been made about ‘MASK MASK’ the “MASK” in the genitive being said not to be found in Virg. is the single instance in which Virg. has admitted a crasis in the genitive of an adj. of the second declension. The form occurs again 6. 307. MASK . Agrigentum was famous for breeding horses, which were not only taken care of while living, but honoured with sepulchres when dead, Pliny 8. 42. Theron, whose Olympic victories Pindar celebrates, was of Agrigentum. ‘MASK’ comes in strangely, as it can hardly mean any thing but ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The only supposition seems to be that Virg., who throughout this paragraph lets Aeneas speak as he himself would have spoken (see on v. 700 above), here forgets himself, or rather his hero, so completely as to point a contrast between the time of the narrative and the time of the poem. A poet with his mind full of the literary and historical interest of his subject is perhaps not unlikely to allow the expression of that feeling to escape him even at the most inappropriate time. We may remember how gladly he avails himself of the prophetic power of Anchises in Book 6 to contrast the small beginnings of Italy with its subsequent greatness (6. 766), and how readily in the later books of the Aeneid he introduces a reference to his own time (12. 134).

“‘ MASK ’MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. Heyne may perhaps be right in supposing the epithet also to refer to the character of the coast, which is said to be a barren salt marsh. Wund. comp. the Homeric MASK MASK (Od. 11. 94).

There is a question of reading between ‘MASK’ (Rom., Pal., Gud.) and ‘MASK’ (Med.). The former is supported by the majority of MSS., and was read by Serv. If we adopt it, the sense will be that after surmounting so many storms, Anchises at last died in harbour, the feeling being like that of v. 711. ‘MASK’ on the other hand will express the same feeling as ‘MASK’ v. 710, Aeneas having sustained his trials by his father's help, and now being left alone just when he could bear it least. Or we may vary the thought slightly, and say that he means to represent this blow as the crowning evil of many, which is Wagn.'s view. Comp. 1. 240, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK” occurs also 7. 199. On the whole I have followed Med., with Heins., who however doubts between the two, and subsequent editors, except Ribbeck. A single MS. gives ‘MASK MASK’ which had occurred to myself.

The death of Anchises was fixed in different places by different authorities. His tomb is still shown at Drepanum; Eustathius however represented him as buried in Mount Ida, Theon in Pallene, Conon on the Thermaic gulf, the Arcadians in Arcadia, while Cato and others made him land in Italy with Aeneas. Had Virg. followed this last legend, his story would have been embarrassed by the presence of Anchises at Carthage, as Serv. and later critics remark.
Virg. may have thought of Il. 17. 410 foll. MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .

Aeneas calls the death of Anchises his ‘MASK MASK’ losing in his sense of it all recollection of the subsequent shipwreck, which is barely glanced at in the next line. Thus Virg. consults the natural feeling of his hero, at the same time that he avoids tiring the reader with any thing like repetition.

It seems idle to attempt to clear this line of tautology, by making minute distinctions between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ No doubt the two may be said to represent the same thing as regarded in slightly different aspects: but that is no more than might be urged in any case of admitted repetition, such as those in Homer. Virg. is fond of saying the same thing two or more times, partly from an imitation of epic simplicity, partly owing to his own love of variety in expression. To understand ‘MASK’ of ‘MASK MASK MASK’ with Wund. is less natural: but the word may fairly be said to suggest that notion, and thus to prepare us for Dido's broken slumbers at the beginning of Book 4.

Perhaps it would not be going too far to translate ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is not to be pressed, as Virg. is expressly speaking of Dido's neighbours on one side only. ‘MASK MASK’ again may be meant to have a double reference—primarily to the Syrtes as unfriendly to ships, secondarily to the tribes near as barbarous to strangers —the latter being of course that which constitutes the real point of the words, as part of Anna's argument. is rather pointless, as Anna's meaning is that the aid of the Trojan alliance is necessary against barbarous neighbours: but we must suppose that having launched into the enumeration of the discomforts of their position, she includes dangers of more kinds than one. The mention of Barce is an anachronism, as the town was not founded till long afterwards by the descendants of Battus, Hdt. 4. 160. Dido's fears from Pygmalion are glanced at again v. 325.

Dido's wishes were on one side, her fears and scruples on the other, so Anna, by removing fears and scruples, allowed her to hope. The expression ‘MASK MASK’ apparently refers back to v. 27. Here of course it is in thought that the restraints of shame are broken.

Dido acts on the advice given v. 50. ‘MASK MASK’ is rightly explained by the later editors of going from altar to altar. Comp. the contemptuous words of MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ MASK note.

Ceres, Apollo, and Bacchus are propitiated on this occasion as having to do with marriage, as Henry appears to establish by a reference to the Pervigilium Veneris v. 43, where all three are named, Stat. 1 Silv. 2. 219 foll., of Bacchus and Apollo, and Himerius, Orat. 1. 3, of Apollo. Possibly they may also be invoked as gods of the new colony, to further the political union between the Carthaginians and the Trojans. The epithet ‘MASK’ (a translation of MASK , a title of Demeter, Hdt. 6. 91 &c.) points that way: Apollo again is known to have been celebrated as the founder of cities (Dict. B. ‘MASK’), and Dionysus like Demeter was called MASK (Orph. H. 41. 1). Heyne goes farther, and attempts to show that these three divinities, like Juno, had a special relation to Carthage. Serv. accumulates a number of heterogeneous reasons for their introduction here, which are not worth quoting: he has preserved however two lines of Calvus, which illustrate the mention of Ceres: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” There is a tantalizing passage in Macrob. Sat. 3. 12, where one of the speakers asks another whether he does not think Virgil has committed a great mistake here, in first saying ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ and then as it were recollecting himself and adding ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ a question which is followed by no answer or explanation of any sort, so that there is evidently a lacuna. For ‘MASK’ Rom., fragm. Vat. a m. pr., and other MSS. give ‘MASK’ which would seem to be a correction by some one who knew nothing of Ceres the Lawgiver.

We need not press the attribute here given to Juno, as if the other deities were not invoked for the same reason, any more than we need suppose that Juno is invoked only as the goddess of marriage, and not also as the patroness of Carthage. MASK and MASK were titles of the Greek Hera.
MASK's own part in the ceremony is described more in detail, as Wagn. remarks.

like “MASK MASK” 5. 78. ‘MASK MASK’ is doubtless the more usual expression; but that is no reason for restricting ‘MASK’ to ‘MASK’ and supplying ‘MASK’ here. The libation was preliminary to the sacrifice: comp. 6. 244. Serv. on the latter passage says this was done to try the fitness of the victims—“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” In Hom. the wine seems to have been poured either on the burning flesh of the victims (Il. 1. 462., 11. 775) or on the ground (3. 295, 300). Lersch (Antiqq. Vergg. p. 170) thinks the cow was offered specially to Juno, citing Tab. Fratr. Arval. 13, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and Livy 27. 37.

as Wagn. says, merely distinguishes different parts of the same scene. Whether there is any special propriety in making Dido walk majestically before the altars does not appear. Serv. says that Roman matrons when about to sacrifice performed a sort of slow dance before the altar with torches in their hands; and the early editors follow him, referring to Hor. A. P. 232, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and to a passage in Prop. (2. 2. 7), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” which unfortunately is ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ 7. 764. Comp. below v. 202, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The statues of the gods, being in the temple, are of course supposed to be looking on. So v. 204, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Wagn. seems more successful in his attempt to fix a ceremonial sense in ‘MASK’ than in the case of ‘MASK’ (see on MASK ), with which he couples it. The account of this peculiar meaning would appear to be that stated recurrence is a notion so inseparably connected with any thing ritual, that recurring celebration comes to be talked of when nothing more than mere celebration is meant. It is nevertheless true that in many of the passages where it is used of observances there is a more distinct propriety in the notion of renewal, as in v. 145 note, 5. 94, where it is explained by “MASK MASK” 7. 146., 8. 283, where a second feast is spoken of. Thus Stat. Theb. 2. 88, borrowing the words “MASK MASK” from Virg., applies them to a feast which had been interrupted by a brawl. So in Livy 25. 16, when the sacrifice has been disturbed by a portent, it is said “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” It would be possible to give it some such reference here, Dido being said as it were to revive the flagging solemnities of the day as it wore on by ordering new sacrifices; but this would be too artificial. It is however countenanced by Donatus, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. says, much less plausibly, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Ladewig supposes Dido to order one sacrifice after another, a reference to which he sees in ‘MASK MASK MASK’ in the hope of obtaining a favourable manifestation, and then, when all fail, to throw the blame on the prophet or priests, v. 65; an exceedingly ingenious view, but one which an attentive consideration of the context will, I think, scarcely warrant. Dido, as the queen, would naturally be at the cost of the public sacrifices, like Clytaemnestra Aesch. Ag. 87 foll. Comp. 1. 632 note.

of attentive gazing, as in Val. Fl. 5. 468 of attentive listening. Macrob. Sat. 3. 5 (closely followed by Serv. on v. 56 above) quotes Trebatius “MASK MASK MASK MASK” as distinguishing between two kinds of sacrifices, those made for the sake of consulting the will of the gods, called “MASK” and those where there is simply an offering of the victim's life, called “MASK MASK” Virg., he says, has mentioned both, the former here, the latter in v. 57. But surely a question may be raised whether the latter did not include the former. ‘MASK’ of palpitation; see Forc. s. v., where instances are given of its use ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

has been connected with ‘MASK MASK’ as in 8. 627, in the sense of ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’—a view which might be plausibly supported from v. 464 below. But the ordinary interpretation, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is clearly right, confirmed as it is by Appuleius, Met. 10. p. 682, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where the reference is to the powerlessness of physic in the case of love, and by Sil. 8. 100, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” also an imitation of this passage (both quoted by Forb.). There is however some room for doubt as to the sentiment intended; Heyne thinks the prophets are censured as ignorant of the terrible future of Dido's love; Gossrau supposes Dido and Anna to be the ‘MASK MASK’ while Ladewig, as we have seen, understands the words as the expression of Dido's impatient despair. Probably Henry is right (after Serv. and Donatus) in supposing the meaning to be that “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” He goes on to say, “‘ Est mollis flamma medullas Interea : ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The hint of the words he seems right in tracing to a curious passage in MASK , where an oracular raven is heard ridiculing a prophet for his ignorance of the ways of a woman in love. The early critics raised aesthetic objections to this exclamation, saying that an epic poet ought not to obtrude his personality, and that Homer never does so. Heyne replies that this is no real obtrusion of personality, but merely an expression of the poet's sympathy with his subject: he might have added that Hom.'s MASK MASK , MASK , MASK MASK MASK (Il. 4. 127: comp. ib. 147) is an interposition of just the same kind.

might go with ‘MASK MASK’ not in the modern sense of “MASK MASK MASK” but expressing the subtle penetrating nature of the flame, and so harmonizing with ‘MASK MASK MASK’ It seems better however to take it with ‘MASK MASK’ which is strongly supported by Catull. 43 (45). 16, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” a passage possibly imitated by Virg. Probably ‘MASK’ does not express the ease with which Dido's vitals become a prey to love, as Forb. thinks, but by calling attention to a characteristic of the ‘MASK MASK’ makes the image appear more real. So we might say ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ meaning to express no more than ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ See on 2. 173.

Macrob. Sat. 5. 6 supposes Virg. to have imitated Il. 11. 475 foll.: there however the circumstances differ, the simile being taken from a wounded stag which, escaping from the archer, sinks under the arrow, and falls a prey to savage beasts. ‘MASK’ of a weapon reaching its mark, 9. 698., 12. 362.

MASK note, A. 1. 191 note. “MASK MASK” occurs Lucr. 1. 970. The epithet is not without force here; it is because the steel is ‘MASK’ that the archer cannot ascertain its fortunes and does not recover it. ‘MASK MASK’ is repeated 8. 694.

“MASK‘ MASK ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. The thought may have been intended by Virg., and we need not wonder that it should have found favour with modern critics; but perhaps a severer judgment would reject it in a passage where it is not supported by any thing in the context. Why the archer's ignorance should have been introduced into the simile is obvious enough: it accounts for the doe being left to wander alone, bleeding to death; while it is itself accounted for by the fact that he is shooting among the trees. The early commentators however seem generally to have taken ‘MASK’ passively, unknown by his victim, so that it would be a virtual repetition of ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ seems almost = ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 5. 218. Comp. ‘MASK’ 2. 321 &c. Or we may say that ‘MASK MASK’ = “MASK MASK MASK” as “MASK MASK” = “MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is read by fragm. Vat. and some others.
for “MASK MASK” see on 2. 234.

need only refer to the banqueting-hall, though there is nothing against supposing that Aeneas was lodged not in the palace but elsewhere. ‘MASK MASK’ has been variously explained —‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ i. e. she gets up from her couch and lies down again—in other words, she passes a restless night; ‘MASK MASK MASK’ left by Sychaeus (comp. MASK ): but the only natural interpretation is that suggested by Serv., ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Dido being supposed to throw herself on it when he is gone. This use of ‘MASK’ is supported by Heyne from Ov. M. 5. 34.

Of ‘MASK MASK’ Serv. curtly remarks “MASK MASK MASK” He might have added that in logical strictness only one ought to have been used. But the poetry of the passage of course gains much from the iteration of the notion of absence. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ With the general sense Taubm. comp. vv. 4, 5 above.

Much difficulty has been found in this and the following line, as they are supposed to imply that Ascanius is left behind, so that the queen can fondle him after his father has retired. To obviate this, Peerlkamp and Gossrau would place them after v. 79, while Forb. connects them closely with what precedes, supposing them to come under ‘MASK’—‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ But the whole perplexity vanishes if we do not tie down Virg. to a narrative of the events of a single day. In saying ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ vv. 74, 77, he does not necessarily mean the morning and the evening of the day succeeding Aeneas' arrival, probable as it may be that such were the occupations of that day; and there is nothing to show that ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is to be restricted to the night after they have parted. The simple meaning is, that whenever they are separated, she has him always in her mind, and, when she can, solaces herself by the presence of Ascanius. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” 3. 489, except that ‘MASK’ here is not said of Ascanius, but of the appearance that he wears. We may observe as an instance of Virg.'s manner of indirect narration that he does not mention Ascanius' return in the place of Cupid, but only leaves us to infer that it has taken place.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ coaxes him to stay with her. Comp. 1. 670, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ see on 2. 3. ‘MASK MASK’ 6. 78. For ‘MASK’ fragm. Vat. and others have ‘MASK’ from v. 296; Rom. has ‘MASK’ from the previous line.
As Serv. and Donatus say, Virg. means us to contrast this with the description of activity in 1. 423 foll., 504 foll.

a variety for “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Comp. 3. 281, “MASK MASK MASK” with 6. 642, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” So “MASK MASK” and similar expressions in prose writers. ‘MASK’ 1. 427. is taken by Henry in the technical sense of military works, which it might certainly bear (see Forc.): but perhaps the general is more poetical here. At any rate it is so far general as to include the two details that follow, the ‘MASK’ and the ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is taken by Serv. of the battlements, so called from “MASK MASK” (he comp. “MASK”) but Heyne justly remarks that such a sense would be less poetical (comp. “MASK” MASK note), and that it seems confined to late writers. On the other hand the ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is a forcible and original expression, arising from the use of “MASK” in such passages as 1. 162 note.

has been variously understood of a pile of building (Heyne), a sense apparently founded on its use by Lucr. in such phrases as “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” a turret on the wall (Wagn.), a military engine (Wund., Henry), as in 2. 46, 151, 237, a scaffolding (Gossrau), and a crane, which is supported by Vitruv. 10. 1, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” I rather prefer this last, though it produces an awkwardness with ‘MASK MASK MASK’ If the crane cannot be said ‘MASK MASK MASK’ it nevertheless forms a natural part of the picture of incompleteness: while its magnitude shows the greatness of the works suspended.

“MASK MASK MASK” E. 10. 28. For ‘MASK MASK’ almost all subsequent editors have adopted ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the conj. of Heins., which would introduce a more usual construction, and might be supported by 9. 143, where the MSS. are divided between “MASK MASK” and “MASK MASK MASK” But I believe the ablative to be as admissible as the accusative in this construction, though it is apparently very rare. The only undoubted instance of it I have met with is in the Pseudo-Donatus' Life of Virg. § 61, where a parody on the first line of E. 1 is quoted, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (“MASK” conj. Heins.: but the parodist would naturally keep as close as he could to Virg.'s word). In Hor. 1 Ep. 5. 12, the best and most numerous MSS. give “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and in MASK one MS. has “MASK MASK MASK MASK” In expressions of this sort the MSS. are apt to vary considerably, as will be seen by consulting the various readings on the two passages just quoted: “MASK” is substituted for “MASK MASK” and the nominative for the acc. or abl.; e.g. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Thus when in Sen. N. Q. 1. 16 the MSS. are found to vary between “MASK MASK MASK” and “MASK MASK MASK MASK” or in Mart. 5. 53. 2 between “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” it is not clear whether we are to understand “MASK MASK” “MASK MASK” “MASK” as intended for nom. or abl. I think then there is no reason for departing here from a reading which is found in all MSS., especially when we consider the infinitely few instances in which the combined testimony of those MSS. has been generally admitted to be in error. How the abl. is to be explained is another and a difficult question: but I suppose ‘MASK’ to be = “MASK MASK MASK” which is itself, it should be remembered, used in other constructions than that with the abl. Wakef. explains “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Gossrau makes an aposiopesis “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” the suppressed words being “MASK MASK MASK” I am glad to see that Mr. Munro in the introduction to his recent recension of the text of Horace seems to consider the construction with the abl. satisfactorily established.
may be comp. with “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK” “MASK MASK” “MASK” (see Forc.), ‘MASK MASK’ with “MASK MASK” 1. 499.

Serv. explains ‘MASK MASK’ on the analogy of “MASK MASK MASK” Forb. cites Ov. M. 4. 675, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” of Perseus catching love from the sight of Andromeda. But ‘MASK MASK’ seems to show that the chief notion present to Virg.'s mind was that of length or extension, the flame coursing through the bones, ‘MASK’ being used as a strong poetical expression for “MASK MASK MASK” Comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

is a predicate, and so is coupled with ‘MASK MASK MASK’ expressing how Juno and Venus are to govern Carthage. In ‘MASK MASK’ the reference is to the phrase “MASK MASK MASK” which signifies that Roman magistrates alone during their time of office had authority to take the auspices, so that the words here mean no more than ‘MASK MASK MASK’ The words are repeated 7. 256, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where they are to be constructed with ‘MASK’ rather than with ‘MASK’—‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Lersch (Antiqq. Vergg. pp. 4, 5) rightly calls attention to the parallel between the proposed union of Carthage and Troy here and that nearly consummated between Latium and Troy in Book 12, suggesting that Virg. took the hint from the legendary union of the Sabines and the Romans. Serv. seems quite wrong in supposing the reference here to be magistrates appointed by equal auspices such as the consuls.

of the sun, note on 6. 725. Here and in 5. 65, where the words recur, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is generally taken of the sun's rays removing the curtain of night from the world—an interpretation sufficiently supported by 9. 461, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” But it is worth considering whether, as has been suggested to me, ‘MASK’ may not be from “MASK” ‘MASK’ being the orb of the sun, which having been unwoven at night is rewoven in the morning. The expression is likely enough to have been suggested by Lucr. 5 389, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where the absorption of water from the sea by the sun is spoken of. Ov. M. 7. 531 has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where, though the sense of “MASK” is precisely opposite, that of unweaving, the expression is identical. Virg. himself (12. 763) has “MASK MASK” of reweaving a circle, i. e. performing a circular movement a second time. The form “MASK” for “MASK” is supported by Manil. 4. 214. Perhaps, however, the context of 5. 65 is rather against this, as it is there Aurora, not MASK, that is spoken of.

There is no reason to doubt with Forb. whether ‘MASK’ here is active or neuter. Even if the use of ‘MASK’ actively were less rare than it is, an active participle here would be awkward to the last degree, as may be seen by substituting any word which would at once suit the metre and agree in sense with ‘MASK MASK’ such as “MASK” or “MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ being a raincloud, so that it is a shower of mingled rain and hail that is here meant.

Gossrau, Ladewig, and Henry are, I think, right in following Serv. against the later editors, and explaining ‘MASK’ as the “MASK” who appear from Isid. Orig. 10 quoted on MASK and other old authorities to have been a distinct class of huntsmen. They are generally supposed to have been mounted like cavalry, of which the ‘MASK’ of the Roman army originally consisted: Mr. Long, however, thinks that they were beaters or drivers, so called from their position on the flank, the people for whom the game was driven answering to the legions in the centre. The other interpretation, understanding it of the red feathers with which the game was scared (see on MASK ), is not in Virg.'s manner, though it may suit a more modern taste, dwelling as it does on an unimportant circumstance, with the object of producing a picturesque effect. The change of nom. at ‘MASK MASK’ too, is an objection to this view, though a slight one. A similar question has been raised on the use of ‘MASK’ in a passage in Silius Italicus (2. 418), describing this very scene: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” There however the proprieties of the description, as well as the word ‘MASK MASK’ require that we should connect ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ the hunters being supposed to take shelter in the woods, not, as Heyne would have us think, behind the feathers of the net. ‘MASK’ then is to be understood of hurrying hither and thither. ‘MASK’ here and elsewhere seems to mean the process of catching wild beasts by stopping up the outlets of the woods with nets, men, dogs, &c. (see on MASK .)

seems to imply not that the rest of the party are to be sheltered or hidden, but that they are to be shrouded so that they cannot see Dido and Aeneas. It would be possible of course to take ‘MASK’ = “MASK MASK MASK” but ‘MASK MASK’ is rather against this.

Henry seems right in contending that by ‘MASK’ we are here meant to understand not merely the bridal, which, as he remarks, is expressed elsewhere in Virg. and in other writers by the plural, but the god of marriage, whose presence was invoked at the ceremony, and is here promised by Juno. ‘MASK’ then will be the adverb, not the pronoun. Henry however apparently goes too far in supposing that stress is meant to be laid on the concurrence of the three deities essential to a perfect marriage, Juno, Venus, and MASK, as though this may be the spirit of the passages which he quotes from Ovid, esp. M. 9. 795, the absence of any reference to MASK below vv. 166 foll. seems to show that Virg. did not regard him as co-ordinate with Juno. Venus too, we must remember, is asked to give her tacit consent, not her active co-operation. ‘MASK’ may go either with ‘MASK’ or with ‘MASK MASK’ perhaps the latter is more probable. Rom. has ‘MASK MASK’ which is mentioned by Serv.

The first is surely far the best, in point of sense; while in point of language it is sufficiently vindicated against Heyne's objection by the passages adduced by Gossrau, esp. Claud. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” MASK . Used absolutely, ‘MASK’ seems to stand for Lucifer, the morning star (see Forcell.); nor is there any reason against following Serv. in giving MASK that sense here, though MASK would be possible to refer MASK to ‘MASK’ in the preceding line.

On ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ see Dict. A. ‘MASK MASK’ where the latter is said to be much smaller than the former, and to have been placed across roads and narrow openings between bushes. The general notion of the following simile, and the geographical names in the first two lines, are taken, as Henry remarks, from MASK foll., where Jason is compared to Apollo. The other circumstances of the simile correspond, as Heyne observes, to those in the simile of Dido to Diana 1. 498 foll. Apollo is supposed to fix his winter quarters in his temple at Patara in Lycia , and thence to go to Delos. Nothing is said about his dividing the year between the two, so that we need not speculate with Henry whether Delos is more than a halting-place on the way to Delphi. The journeyings of Apollo formed the subject of a paean by Alcaeus, the substance of which is preserved by Himerius, Orations 14. 10, and is extracted by Bergk, Poetae Lyrici Graeci , pp. 569, 570 (1st edition). From this it appears that when Apollo was born, Zeus gave him a mitre, a lyre, and a car driven by swans, and sent him to Delphi; but he chose first to go to the Hyperboreans, spending a year with them, and thence going to Delphi, where nature as well as men greeted him with demonstrations of welcome. A passage from Procopius cited by Turnebus, Adversaria 24. 26, speaks of the MASK MASK (an expression supported also by Himerius l. c.) as a festival at Delphi. Serv. says definitely that Apollo was supposed to give oracles for the six winter months at Patara, for the six summer ones at Delos: a practical realization of the belief in Apollo's migratory habits which is supported by Hdt. 1. 182, as Heyne observes in his Excursus. But the meaning may be, as Mr. Long thinks, that Apollo leaves Lycia in the winter, and goes to the more genial Delos—an interpretation already suggested as a question by Serv., “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

v. 63 note, here of a renewal of intermitted observances. Members of the different nations where the worship of Apollo was especially kept up appear to have engaged in his service in other countries. So in Homer's Hymn to Apollo, vv. 391 foll., Cretans sailing to Pylos are brought by Apollo to Crisa and established as his priests. It is also possible, as Heyne suggests, that these strangers may have been sent on sacred embassies to Delos. See on the whole subject of the worship of Apollo Müller's Dorians, Book 2.

The Dryopes, who originally lived in the neighbourhood of Parnassus, were consecrated as a subject people to the Pythian Apollo (Müller, Book 1, ch. 2, § 4). The MASK, who, like their neighbours the Geloni ( MASK ), are called ‘MASK MASK’ tattooed, represent Apollo's Hyperborean worshippers.
On a comparison of 1. 498, 501 it seems probable that Apollo is represented as himself joining in the dance.

His hair is twined with a wreath of bay and a circlet of gold. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” 6. 80. The notion is that of restraint and regulation. Henry cites MASK , to show that golden dress and ornaments specially belonged to Apollo.

The hint of this passage is doubtless taken, as Henry has pointed out, from MASK foll., where the union of Jason and Medea is made to take place in a cave; but there is nothing in the description of the elder poet to remind us of Virg., except the mention of Juno and of the Nymphs.

seems rightly explained by Henry, after Taubmann, of the Earth as the oldest of the deities, comp. “MASK MASK MASK” 7. 136, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK Aesch. Eum. 1, 2. The ‘MASK’ was a matron who had only been married to one husband, and her function was to conduct the bride to the “MASK MASK” (Dict. A. Marriage, Roman). Juno performs this office here, as in MASK : but we may doubt with Keightley (Myth. p. 454, ed. 3) whether it was ever one of her regular titles. The whole description is rightly regarded by Henry as one not of an inauspicious but of an auspicious marriage, in which the gods take the parts ordinarily performed by mortals; the various phenomena of the storm being in fact regarded by Virg. as representing the various parts of the wedding solemnity, the lightning the holding up of the torches, the sounds of waters or woods the nuptial MASK . But he goes too far when he supposes the descent of rain upon the earth to be itself a symbolical marriage union between two great parts of nature. Such a notion is found in other passages of the classics (e. g. MASK ), but there is nothing to show that it is intended here.

It may be doubted whether ‘MASK MASK’ here means ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ (comp. 3. 239, 519 &c.), or ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ (comp. 8. 523., 12. 245). Nor is it clear in either case what parts are meant to be assigned to the Earth and Juno respectively, supposing, as was observed in the last note, that some natural phenomenon is intended by each of the actions ascribed here to the various deities. Taking ‘MASK’ as a sign, and so regarding ‘MASK MASK’ as that in which the sign consisted, we may account sufficiently well for the operation of Juno, who is the mistress of the atmosphere; but the office of Tellus is still undetermined. The generality of commentators, regarding the appearances as inauspicious, suppose the sign given by Earth to be the shock of an earthquake. This was probably the interpretation of Milton, who doubtless intended to imitate the passage in his description of the effects following the first act of sin (Par. Lost, 9. 782 foll., 1000 foll.). Henry thinks ‘MASK’ is a signal, which he supposes to be given by Tellus and Juno simply as persons, not as presiding powers of nature, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but this would spoil the symmetry of the passage, nor is it supported, as he thinks, by Claudian in Prob. MASK Olybr. Cons. 205 foll., where ‘MASK’ is evidently a sign or portent. Gossrau, who regards the manifestations as ambiguous, is similarly at a loss to know what part to assign to the Earth, and concludes “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is rightly explained by Wagn. as i. q. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” For nuptial torches see MASK .

‘MASK’ Med., ‘MASK’ Rom. Pal. corrected, Verona fragm. So Lucan 6. 258, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” The nymphs may be Oreads, Dryads, or Naiads, according to the view we take of the nature of the sound. Henry argues from ‘MASK MASK’ that they are Oreads, comp. MASK . The words, as Heyne remarks, are probably from MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”, but the sense is different.

This description of Fame has furnished a commonplace for critics, especially those of the last century, some of whom have thought its introduction under any circumstances needlessly ambitious, while others, though admiring MASK generally, think MASK is carried on too long. A reader of the present day will, I think, wonder rather at the poet's reticence than at his exuberance. The mighty power of Fame or Rumour is a conception which will bear dwelling on; the thought is appropriate here, as one of the main causes which lead to Dido's death is the sense of the disgrace to which she has brought herself before the world: and Virgil's treatment of MASK is quite in the taste of classical poetry. Such mythological personifications are common enough in Ovid, and MASK is hard to see why Virg. should be altogether debarred the use of them, though doubtless they are to be more sparingly employed in a poem like the Aeneid than in a poem like the Metamorphoses. The hint, as usual, is from Homer, who personifies MASK Il. 2. 93, Od. 24. 412, which last line Virg. has almost copied in the present v. 173; the elaboration of detail too partly comes from the Homeric, MASK , Il. 4. 442, 443. Probably too he thought of the Hesiodic MASK (Works 760 foll.). Ovid has an ingenious passage on the dwelling of Fame, the receptacle of all the reports in the world (M. 12. 39 foll.), which, though not copied from this of Virg., forms a good pendant to MASK. Valerius Flaccus (2. 116 foll.) and Statius (Theb. 2. 426 foll.) tread in the steps of Virg., but for a much shorter distance.

With Forb., Jahn, and Ribbeck, I have restored ‘MASK MASK’ the reading of Med., Rom., and Gud., for ‘MASK MASK’ that of fragm. Veron., which, though admissible, seems less natural and straightforward. Pal. has ‘MASK’ altered into ‘MASK MASK’ Serv. mentions both. Whether Forb. and Jahn are to be further followed in removing the stop after ‘MASK’ is more doubtful. On the whole it seems better to regard v. 175 as a separate sentence. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

The Giants, according to one story, were produced by the Earth in her anger that the Titans had been thrust down to Tartarus. Virg. however, like others of the later writers, seems to confuse Titans and Giants, Enceladus being a Giant, Coeus a Titan, though he may merely mean that Fame, like the Titans and the Giants, was the offspring of Earth. ‘MASK’ with gen. of the cause of quarrel occurs 2. 413., 9. 736: it is here extended to the person against whom anger is felt, like MASK and MASK in Greek.

So Stat. Theb. 3. 430, of Fame, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” imitating this passage. It is difficult however to see wherein Fame, in the present instance, transgresses the bounds of truth. Dido had accepted Aeneas as her husband, and what is said of their intentions for the winter agrees very well with the actual state of things as it appears to Jupiter (comp. v. 221 &c.). ‘MASK MASK’ may perhaps be a little inconsistent with the interest Aeneas takes in the works of the city, vv. 260 foll.; but Aeneas was neglecting his own kingdom, and we have already seen (vv. 86 foll.) how indifferent Dido had become to hers. The winter was not yet over, perhaps had hardly yet begun: but there was every prospect that Aeneas would have spent the whole of it at Carthage if Jupiter had not interfered.

The common reading is ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ but as Med., Pal., and many other MSS. omit the preposition, and Virg. elsewhere invariably uses ‘MASK’ with a simple abl., I have preferred, with Ribbeck, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ though ‘MASK MASK’ is found in Rom.
Emm. comp. Ov. M. 8. 325, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

of Carthage and Italy, as Serv. rightly explains it. See on v. 190.

Iarbas seems to have been connected with Dido in the original legend, as he appears in Justin 18. 6 as a king of the Maxitanians or Mazyes, who offers Dido marriage, threatening war in case of her refusal, whereupon she kills herself. He is here made a son of Ammon, the Libyan god whom the Greeks identified with Zeus and the Romans with Jupiter: and Virg. chooses to represent him as having introduced the worship of his parent-god among his countrymen. The spelling ‘MASK’ is supported by Med. and Rom. ‘MASK’ apparently means Libyan generally. ‘MASK’ as in 1. 28.

Wund. seems right in saying that ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ really refer to the same time, which is regarded from two different points of view. The everburning light was kept up at the great oracle of Jupiter Ammon, as appears from Plutarch De Oraculorum Defectu , p. 410 B, referred to by Taubm. ‘MASK MASK’ 2. 502.

stands in a loose apposition to ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the fire being kept up by attendants of the god, who are thus said to be his watchers. ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ are considered by Wag. to be independent nominatives: but it seems better to make them accusatives, somewhat loosely connected with ‘MASK MASK’
Wagn. illustrates ‘MASK MASK’ by referring to the Lucretian ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but it may support itself very well without. See MASK note.

It is difficult to see why Virg. should have weakened his narrative by introducing ‘MASK MASK’ but the love of variety was probably what tempted him. For ‘MASK’ Serv. mentions another reading ‘MASK MASK’ which is very plausible, as ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ would answer exactly to “MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK . ‘MASK’ however gives an excellent sense: ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Comp. 1. 447.

Henry with the later commentators calls attention to ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ points to banquets like Dido's in Book 1.
“MASK MASK MASK” 1. 736, “MASK MASK” MASK . Here as there ‘MASK’ seems to be a secondary adjective from ‘MASK’ ( MASK ) regarded as a substantive. Comp. “MASK MASK” 1. 686, and see on v. 552 below.
instead of the vague ‘MASK MASK’ because Iarbas is insisting on real relationship, as Henry observes.
The emphasis is on ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

elsewhere applied to the effect of sound (above v. 160), is here applied to sound itself, expressing the vague confused rumbling of thunder. Thus, though not specially belonging to ‘MASK MASK’ it is in perfect keeping with it. By a poetical variety the lightning is made the cause of the thunder.
For the fact comp. 1. 365 foll.
merely means land by the sea. So 7. 797, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Dido in MASK says of her kingdom “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

like ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ in English, is used for a husband or lover in a sense which may be either invidious or the reverse according to the feelings of the speaker. See Forc. Here it is of course invidious, like “MASK MASK” v. 103. With ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which implies not merely a hospitable welcome but association in the kingdom, comp. v. 374, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

in his supposed effeminacy and in his conquest of the bride of another, MASK , MASK . The reproach of effeminacy against the Phrygians generally belongs not to Homeric times, but to a later period. Comp. Eur. Or. 1369 foll. In the same way in 9. 617 they are stigmatized as the worthy worshippers of Cybele, which will further illustrate ‘MASK MASK MASK’

The ‘MASK’ appears again as part of the Phrygian costume 9. 616. In Greece it appears to have been confined to women. See Dict. A. ‘MASK’ ‘MASK’ is used vaguely, as the Lydians and Phrygians were neighbours. Essenced hair is one of Turnus' reproaches against Aeneas 12. 100.

With some hesitation I have restored, as Henry and Ribbeck have done, ‘MASK MASK’ though found but in one MS., the Leyden. ‘MASK’ might stand, in nearly the same sense, the chin and hair being said to rest on the cap or capstrings, agreeably to the use of “MASK” ( MASK note) and MASK . But it is more credible that the two words should have been confused, as their cognates not unfrequently are (see 1. 448., 5. 279), than that Virg. should have used the less appropriate in preference to the more appropriate. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ enjoys his prey, ‘MASK’ as in 7. 749. So Helen is called MASK MASK in relation to Paris Aesch. Ag. 535. From this line to 5. 37 Rom. is deficient.

The force of ‘MASK’ here is very doubtful. There is no question that it is used in other places where a sarcasm is intended, e. MASK ; but that does not enable us precisely to fix its meaning. Here it might refer more or less to the whole clause; ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ &c. But perhaps it may be better to restrict its reference to ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ answering to ‘MASK MASK’ To understand it as causal with Wund. and Forb. is, I think, to mistake the sense of the passage. It seems more in keeping with the context to understand ‘MASK’ generally of the reputation of Jove as a god than to explain it with Wund. specially of his reputed relation to Iarbas.

Nearly repeated 6. 124. The touching of the altar added solemnity, 12. 201.
occurs Cic. pro Sest . 66.

Imitated from Od. 5. 28 foll., where Zeus sends Hermes to recall Ulysses from the island of Calypso. There is little or no resemblance between the two speeches: but in the subsequent description Virg. closely copies his master. For ‘MASK’ some MSS. have ‘MASK MASK’ which was the old reading.

MASK MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ may seem to make Mercury too dependent on the breezes, as if he were a sailor; but it may be answered that as a god he has the power of nature at his command, and that it would be no proof of divine strength to refuse to employ them. The words indeed, even when used of human navigators, seem simply to mean that the breezes are at a call: comp. 3. 253., 5. 211., 8. 707. The line is of course modulated so as to express speed.

No authentic instance is quoted of this use of ‘MASK’ as simply = “MASK MASK” though ‘MASK’ with an object or object clause is sufficiently common. But this need not drive us to Jahn's harsh expedient of supplying ‘MASK’ from the next clause: ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ not, as Heyne and Forb., foreshown, but assigned. See 3. 255.

It is not casy to see the force of ‘MASK MASK’ which in a connexion like this can hardly be an unmeaning epithet, repeated as it is below v. 357; but the notion may be that the breezes accelerate Mercury's flight (see above v. 223), though ‘MASK’ regards them rather as the medium through which he flies.

Wund. remarks on the skill with which Virg. has avoided the awkwardness of an oratio obliqua . With the form of expression ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ comp. 11. 152. Pal (originally) and some other MSS. have ‘MASK MASK MASK’ and so Ribbeck.

can only refer to the two deliverances of Aeneas with which Venus is associated, that from Diomede (Il. 5. 311 foll.), and that from the Greeks at the sack of Troy (A. 2. 589 &c.). The deliverance from Achilles would form a better parallel to the deliverance from Diomede, but it was accomplished by Neptune, not by Venus; the deliverance from the destruction of Troy under Laomedon would answer more completely to the deliverance from the second destruction of Troy (comp. 3. 476, with Wagn.), but there is no reason to suppose that Aeneas was born when it took place. If ‘MASK’ is any thing more than a poetical past, we may explain it by saying that the effects of the preservation still continue.

The construction is resumed from ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ has been variously explained; as ‘MASK MASK’ (Serv.), which Heyne justly rejects as weak, as ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ and as ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Virg. probably meant to include both of the latter interpretations. That he was thinking of the future of Italy is shown by the word ‘MASK’ and by the whole context, as the temper of the Italian nations at the time of Aeneas' arrival was a matter of infinitely small moment compared with the destiny in store for them: at the same time it was the imperious and unbridled character of those nations which marked them out as instruments in the conquest of the world after they should have been conquered themselves, first by Aeneas and eventually by Rome, so that Italy could be said to be not only the future mother of empire, but actually teeming with it at the moment when Jupiter was speaking. The plural may be used with reference to these various nations, but it need be nothing more than a poetical hyperbole, expressing the everincreasing sway which Virg. saw before him. So 8. 475, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where one thought in the poet's mind seems to be the material afforded by the Etruscans for a great empire. With the expression comp. “MASK MASK MASK” 10. 87.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ having the sense of “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” see Forc.
= ‘MASK MASK’ Forb. comp. the expression ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Aeneas is said to do what Rome ultimately did.
See on 6. 405.

is the same construction which we have had 1. 750: here however the sense of ‘MASK’ is extended into that of ‘MASK MASK’ perhaps on the analogy of MASK . The introduction of ‘MASK’ between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ is also Greek, MASK MASK MASK , but it occurs elsewhere in Latin, being especially used by Ovid, who, as Wagn. remarks, finds it convenient in making a pentameter, e. g. as under Juno's patronage, and as the destined opponent of Rome's supremacy. The later editors rightly put a comma after ‘MASK MASK’ so as to connect it with ‘MASK MASK MASK’ The expression thus becomes exactly parallel to that in v. 225.

is the same as ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ regarded from another side. There we were to think of Rome as derived from Troy : here we are to think of it as the representative of Italian greatness. So ‘MASK MASK’ points out the new kingdom.

as we should say, this is the point; in this ‘MASK’ every thing is concentrated. So “MASK MASK” 12. 572 is the centre, the head and front of the war. ‘MASK MASK’ is taken with Wagn., after the older commentators, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ = “MASK MASK MASK MASK” as “MASK MASK” 2. 170 note = “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Val. But Heyne, Forb., and Gossrau may be right in taking ‘MASK’ of the tidings or message, as, though there is no certain instance of this use of the word in Virg., it might have that meaning in 6. 456., 7. 437., 8. 582., 9. 692., 11. 897. For the nature of the caduceus see Dict. Biog. Hermes. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is a parenthetical sentence, as Jahn has seen, answering the purpose of a relative clause, to express the ordinary functions of the wand. ‘MASK’ then will mean “MASK MASK MASK” while ‘MASK’ v. 245 on the contrary refers simply to what Mercury is doing during his present journey to Carthage. Hom. merely dwells on the power of the wand to produce or dispel sleep, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . Virg., while including this notion in ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ extends it to breaking or producing the sleep of death, Hermes being the MASK .

Hermes has his wand when he conducts the souls of the suitors to the shades at the beginning of Od. 24. ‘MASK MASK’ Med., Pal., &c.: ‘MASK MASK’ was the order before Burm. For ‘MASK’ Pal. originally had ‘MASK MASK’

I follow Henry in accepting Turnebus' explanation (Advers. 24. 26) of ‘MASK MASK MASK’ by a reference to the Roman custom of closing a friend's eyes at the moment of death and afterwards opening them again when the body was laid on the pile seven days afterwards. ‘MASK’ (Stat. Theb. 3. 129) and ‘MASK’ (Varro ap. Non. 2. 785) were used of closing the eyes of the dead, so that ‘MASK’ would naturally express the reverse process. It does not appear that this action is clsewhere attributed to Mercury; but it would be a natural part of the Roman conception of a MASK , the object being, as Henry suggests, that the dead might see their way to the lower world. We may add this then to the other instances in which Virg. has mixed the customs of his own times with those of the heroic age. ‘MASK’ then will mean during, i. e. after, death, and the words will = “MASK MASK MASK MASK”
as Heyne remarks, is probably an imitation of Homer's favourite MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ drives before him.

In Hom. Hermes comes down from Olympus upon Pieria, and thence throws himself on the sea. Virg. knows nothing of the local Olympus, but, wishing as usual to follow Hom., makes Mercury take Mount Atlas as a halting-place between the sky and Carthage. The belief that Atlas stood as a pillar between heaven and earth doubtless seemed a reason for his introduction here, though perhaps it rather confuses the image. Voss (Mythologische Briefe, vol. 2, letter 27, referred to by Henry) suggests a more elaborate explanation, according to which there were three openings in the heavenly Olympus, one in the vertex, immediately over the earthly mountain, the other two at the sides, eastern and western, the latter being the route taken by Mercury as the nearest to Carthage. I do not know whether it is an objection to this view that when in 1. 225 Jupiter looks down upon Libya, he is expressly said to be standing not at the west gate of Olympus but at the vertex: but in any case it seems rash to suppose that the ancient poets generally were agreed in their notions of Olympian topography.
is rightly explained by Serv. “MASK MASK” recalling us in fact to the sufferings of the old Titan, which Aesch., it will be remembered, regards as parallel to those of Prometheus ( MASK ).

It has been questioned whether there are pines in Africa. In any case ‘MASK’ is a natural epithet of a mountain (E. 10. 14 &c.). The identification in detail of the mountain and the Titan perhaps seems a little ungraceful. Sides, head, and shoulders are natural enough; but the chin and the beard strike a modern reader as grotesque. Henry however rightly reminds us that Virg. is not personifying the mountain, but describing one who having been a demigod had become a mountain by transformation, so there is some excuse for pursuing the resemblance minutely.
in the enumeration of the items of a description MASK &c.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is generally understood to be an expression for ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as the wings would then appear more level than when the flier was at full speed. So in 5. 657., 9. 14, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” is explained as marking the beginning of flight. But it may be questioned whether the words mean more than ‘MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ so as to be applicable to any moment in Mercury's flight.
implies effort, as in 10. 127 &c. Hom. has MASK MASK MASK MASK .

Hom. goes on, MASK MASK MASK MASK . Virg. leaves this to be supplied, partly from the description of the bird, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ partly from v. 256. Virg. does not specify the bird, but Hom. has MASK MASK MASK .
indicates the object of the bird. Hom. gives it plainly, MASK MASK .

This and the two following lines were condemned by Heyne and Bryant, and are rejected by most of the later editors. The external grounds for suspecting them are, that in one of the Berne MSS. they are written in later ink, that some MSS. place v. 258 before v. 257, and that most copies give either ‘MASK MASK’ (Med., &c.) or ‘MASK MASK’ (Pal. a m. s., Gud. a m. pr., &c.). See note at the end of this book. The chief internal ground is the awkwardness of expression in v. 257, as it would be equally objectionable to remove the point after ‘MASK MASK’ so as to connect ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ to make ‘MASK MASK MASK’ a zeugma for “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and to adopt the reading ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which the instances quoted by Weichert do not sufficiently support. But I believe the difficulty will vanish if we understand ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ i. e. he was flying close to the shore, so as to be, as it were, between the winds and the land—a repetition in more specific and defined language of ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ So v. 695, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” = “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The jingle ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ whether graceful or not, is not unexampled in Virg. Nor can any argument unfavourable to the genuineness of the lines be founded on the words ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The poet may seem somewhat late in remembering Mercury's relationship to Atlas; but it is not unlike the indirect manner in which he sometimes introduces what he has to say. The fact of the relationship he was likely enough to mention, as he has done afterwards, 8. 138 foll., where again Atlas is spoken of as the upholder of the heavens. This note must not conclude without a mention of Bentley's proposal to read ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ a substitution which, if we might deal with Virg.'s verses as a tutor with a pupil's exercise, might be accepted as an improvement, but has no probability on critical grounds.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’
see on 1. 421, MASK .

Aeneas is taking part in the erection of buildings public and private, which we have had described more at length 1. 423 foll. ‘MASK’ apparently with reference to the huts which these more splendid edifices were to displace.

It does not seem necessary to follow Wagn. in beginning a new sentence with ‘MASK MASK’ as if that particle were meant to call attention to an unexpected novelty. It has rather the usual continuative force, implying that Aeneas' Tyrian dress was quite in keeping with the work he had undertaken as Dido's architect. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ shining with jaspers as with stars, either on the hilt or on the scabbard. Comp. Juv. 5. 42 foll., where the present passage is alluded to. The sing. seems to have a plural force, as in Juv. 5. 38, “MASK MASK MASK” Wagn. rightly remarks that ‘MASK’ is quadrisyllable.

with ‘MASK MASK’ The ‘MASK’ seems here to be a mark of luxury, as in Pers. 1. 30; but it appears from Juv. 5. 131., 7. 73 that it was also worn by the poor. See Dict. A. s. v. The stress then is here probably to be laid on the colour as indicating the costliness.

Comp. 11. 72 foll., where v. 264 is repeated. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as the context shows, can only refer to the ‘MASK MASK’ but Virg. was probably led to use the plural by thinking at the same time of the sword, which was doubtless MASK's present also.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ See Dict. A. ‘MASK MASK’ For the change of construction comp. MASK note.

attacks him, like “MASK MASK” v. 92, but stronger. Forb. comp. Tac. A. 6. 4, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where a speech in the oratio obliqua follows. Wagn. thinks ‘MASK’ inappropriate in the mouth of Mercury, but it has its force here, as well as in v. 97 (note)—the same which is expressed in the next line by ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’
may be rendered ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Dido was not Aeneas' wife; but he was acting as if she were. Comp. 2. 344, MASK notes.

It signifies little whether we put a note of interrogation after ‘MASK MASK’ as most editors have done, or, as Wund. prefers, one of exclamation. In either case ‘MASK’ had better be connected with the preceding sentence, being in effect equivalent to ‘MASK’ (comp. 2. 283 note), instead of constituting a kind of interjectional sentence by itself. The first reading of Pal. was ‘MASK MASK’ perhaps, as Ribbeck hints, from 3. 382.
MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , Il. 11. 201.

It is questioned whether ‘MASK’ here refers to physical movement or to government. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 9. 93 is for the first, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 12. 180 for the other. If we must decide a question which probably did not present itself as sharply to Virg.'s mind as to ours, we shall perhaps do wisely in saying with Wagn. on 9. 93 that the physical sense is the prominent one here in ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the moral in ‘MASK MASK MASK’ For ‘MASK MASK’ Pal. and Gud. have ‘MASK MASK MASK’

Serv. accounts for the change from the language of v. 235 by saying that Aeneas would not have recognized Carthage as hostile, though Jupiter knew it really to be so. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” &c. Cerda, remarking on ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ thinks that Virg. intended to allude to the etymology of “MASK” from “MASK MASK” This is of course absurd; but the jingle can hardly have been unintentional, either here or in such passages as v. 238, “MASK MASK MASK” 10. 191, 192 “MASK” ib. 417, 418 “MASK” See on 2. 494.
See on 6. 405.

This line is omitted by Med., Pal., and several other MSS., while in others it bears the mark of having been added afterwards. Pomponius Sabinus has a note on it, which unfortunately is imperfect, merely containing the words “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” On the one hand it may easily have slipped out, especially if the transcriber was writing from his recollection of Jupiter's speech; on the other hand it may as easily have crept in from that speech. There it was almost necessary, as there is no pronoun in v. 232 to fix the reference pointedly to Aeneas: here the emphatic position of ‘MASK’ in v. 260 renders the addition needless, though it is still graceful. On the whole it seems best to print the line in brackets.

not the hopes of the kingdom entertained by Iulus, but the hope of manhood afforded by Iulus. See on 1. 556. Comp. 6. 364, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is used of a race springing up MASK . ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ form a good instance of a mere poetical repetition, both being simply appellative names, so that according to the ordinary rules of language they ought, as employed here, to stand for two persons.

Wagn., Q. V. 40, finds an inconsistency between this line and v. 236, where he understands ‘MASK MASK’ of Silvius (see 6. 760 foll.). If it is an inconsistency, it is one not confined to this passage, as it is clear from 1. 267 foll. that Virg. at times regarded Ascanius as the founder of the Alban, and hence of the Roman dynasty. See further on 6. 764.

Mercury vanishes like Apollo MASK foll., where this and the next line are repeated with the change of a single word. ‘MASK MASK’ is Virgil's indirect way of telling us that Mercury appeared in a visible though divine form. At the second apparition (v. 556 foll.), which however differs from this as taking place in sleep, the fact is told us directly. Serv. remarks that Mercury had repeated all his message, and accordingly understands ‘MASK MASK’ to mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ in other words, without giving Aeneas time to reply. Donatus has the same interpretation, which is certainly an ingenious one. Gossrau accepts it. But we should not be justified in fixing this special sense of ‘MASK’ unless we could prove that it was never used where only one person was speaking, which 12. 940 shows not to be the case. ‘MASK MASK’ then will have its ordinary sense, which must be explained by supposing either that Mercury became actually invisible before his speech was ended, or that his speech seemed to end abruptly from the suddenness with which he closed it and vanished. In either case the expression is rhetorical and must not be closely pressed, as all that the poet means is to give the effect of a sudden and transient apparition. So below v. 388 there is no sign of imperfection in Dido's actual speech, but “MASK MASK MASK” is intended to mark the abruptness and violence of her manner in closing it.

It is difficult to say how far ‘MASK’ here is meant to be physical and how far mental. Perhaps we may render ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’
with inf. 2. 105.

The thoughts that pass through his mind are expressed in a sort of oratio obliqua , as in MASK , 505. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” Hor. 1 Od. 35. 5, comp. by Wund. Heyne says “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but the words are rather contrasted than parallel, as ‘MASK’ expresses an indirect, ‘MASK MASK’ though general, a direct mode of approach.

is illustrated both in expression and in substance by Eur. Iph. A. 1124, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK ; MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . But the reference may conceivably be to action rather than to speech. ‘MASK’ has the force of “MASK MASK” as in Hor. 1 Od. 12. 2, A. P. 38, so that the expression is not strictly parallel to “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK” occurs MASK , where Munro suppeses the metaphor to be from beginning a web. ‘MASK MASK’ was read before Heina.

These lines, an expansion of what Hom. expresses more briefly by MASK MASK , have been suspected by several of the editors, as occurring again, 8. 20, 21. Here v. 286 is omitted by fragm. Vat., Gud., and Pal., the two former adding it in the margin in a later hand, so that Ribbeck is perhaps right in placing it in brackets. ‘MASK’ is rightly explained by Wund. by regarding the preceding couplet as equivalent to “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is used with ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ as a verb of motion, on the analogy of its use with the dative of the persons among whom a thing is shared. But there is an apparent confusion between Aeneas dividing his mind, and bestowing the whole of it at one time here, and another there. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ hurries it in this direction and that, as v. 630 below shows.

MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , Il. 14. 23., 16. 652, which shows, if proof were needed, that Cerda is right in making ‘MASK’ agree with ‘MASK MASK’ against Heyne, who takes it with ‘MASK MASK’ The neuter use of “MASK” is not unexampled, being found three times in Pliny: see Forc.

For ‘MASK’ some inferior MSS. have ‘MASK MASK’ which was the reading before Wagn. On internal grounds it might seem as if Brunck were right in pronouncing that Serestus and Sergestus are only two forms of the same name (see on 1. 611); in 12. 561 however, where this line recurs, all the MSS. except one, of no great authority, give ‘MASK MASK’ so there seems no sufficient reason for resisting the weight of external evidence here. ‘MASK’ may either be a critical correction made by some transcriber who thought with Brunck, or an introduction from 1. 510. So some copies here read ‘MASK’ Forb. remarks on Virg. having told us not the resolution but the action to which it led. Thus we get a rhetorical contrast between the state of uncertainty and that of decision.

The subjunctives are a sort of oratio obliqua , depending on the sense rather than on the expression of the previous line. Comp. 2. 652. ‘MASK MASK’ 3. 472. ‘MASK’ Med., fragm. Vat., ‘MASK’ Pal., Gud., which Heins. and Heyne prefer.

The simile is more natural, as queens frequently took part in Bacchanalian orgies. Hence Hor. 1 Od. 18. 11, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The noise excites the Bacchant (Thyias), who is caught by the frenzy.

Dido has regarded Aeneas as her husband, the pillar of her home, and says that it will fall in ruin if he leaves it: she will be driven to despair and her enemies will come upon her. Comp. vv. 36, 37 above. Either we must suppose Dido to have known of the indignation of Iarbas on hearing of her preference of Aeneas, or we must understand her to mean no more than that she has alienated her neighbours by refusing them the love which she has since bestowed on Aeneas. The last would be a sufficiently natural way of speaking in the bitterness of her despair, especially as she would feel that the indignation of her former suitors would be doubled as soon as she was known to have given herself to another. Perhaps the same explanation may apply to ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which according to this would refer either to suitors at Tyre (v. 35) or to Pygmalion, either of whom might be expected to resent the new alliance. But Gossrau's interpretation, referring ‘MASK’ to the Carthaginians, who are indignant at their queen for surrendering herself and them to a stranger, is on the whole more plausible. See on v. 466. For ‘MASK’ some MSS. have ‘MASK’

is explained by Wagn. and Forb., ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ by Henry, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The latter is better suited to Dido's feeling. She has lost the one thing of which she could boast, the fame of unblemished fidelity to her dead husband's memory, and now she is all undone. In vv. 653 foll. she takes a prouder and more complacent view of her past life; but that is done under the influence of a totally different feeling. With the expression Germ. comp. Od. 19. 108, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , said by the disguised Ulysses to Penelope.

MASK, as we have seen (v. 198), was not strictly a Gaetulian; but Virg.'s notions of poetical liberty lead him here as elsewhere to put one tribe for another, by a kind of synecdoche. See general Introduction, pp. 9 foll. The epithet here has a force of its own in the mouth of one of a foreign nation, as we might say ‘MASK MASK MASK’

Dido's meaning is ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Anna had already spoken to her of the pleasures of being a mother, v. 33. As Heyne remarks, we must not judge such an expression of feeling by our modern standard. Other princesses of mythical antiquity had children by heroes that forsook them, and Dido is only carrying out her determination to regard her union with Aeneas as a lawful marriage. To suppose with Gossrau that the passage could have been interpolated before the time of Juvenal, who, as is well known, alludes to it Sat. 5. 138, is extravagant. Comp. also MASK , where the thought is the same, though differently touched. ‘MASK MASK’ a synonyme of ‘MASK MASK’ is usually said of the father, who takes the new-born child and brings it up. the old reading, apparently found in inferior MSS., is preferred by Henry to ‘MASK MASK’ as more consistent with the reproachful tone of Dido's speech. But throughout the speech tenderness is mixed with indignation; and that there is tenderness in this its last sentence is evident not only from the tenor of the wish itself, but from the form of expression ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which is all that affection can make it. ‘MASK’ has a consolatory force—‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ See on E. 10. 31. is synonymous with ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ in ordinary Latin is restricted to those actions which a person does of his own will or authority, whence the elliptical use of ‘MASK’ alone for ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ &c., though this seems to have been in the first instance a poetical licence. seems to be used in two somewhat different senses with ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ the notion in the first case being that of inhabiting, in the second of paying respect. Aeneas means to say that he would inhabit Troy again, and thus honour the relics of its former state. The imperfect, as contrasted with the pluperfect v. 344, may thus be explained as speaking of a continuing act, so that we need not think with Wund. of the definite action of sacrificing at the graves of the departed, which he ingeniously remarks might be spoken of in the imperfect, as repeated once a year. ‘MASK MASK’ like ‘MASK MASK’ of restoration to permanence; the expression however is doubtless meant to intimate that the restoration would efface the memory of the fall, reminding us of the language of 2. 56. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

‘MASK’ is rather a favourite word with Virg., occurring again 7. 322., 10. 58, each time as an epithet of ‘MASK MASK’ It has nothing to do, as Serv. and other commentators have thought, with the ordinary sense of “MASK MASK” as if it could mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ but belongs to the special use of “MASK” = “MASK MASK” Thus it is parallel to “MASK” “MASK MASK” just as “MASK” and “MASK” “MASK” and “MASK” exist together. Some MSS. give ‘MASK’ The words are frequently confounded, being virtually synonymous as well as similar in appearance. ‘MASK’ here is almost pleonastic; but it seems to contain, in however slight a degree, the notion of personal and successful effort, so as to be virtually equivalent to “MASK MASK” See on MASK .

oracles. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Hor. A. P. 403. We know nothing from Virg. of any response of Apollo on the subject of Italy except that given at Delos in Book 3; but these new particulars may have been either invented by the poet, or taken from some legend. On the one hand Virg. is fond of conveying information indirectly; on the other the difficulties of his subject, the embarras de richesses of his materials— traditions incompatible with each other, yet equally capable of being used in poetry —and his own love of poetical variety, make him sometimes inconsistent. For a similar use of ‘MASK’ Wund. quotes Cic. Att. 10. 9, “MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Serv. has a good note: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ MASK , ’‘ MASK MASK , ’MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ MASK , ’MASK MASK MASK” The line in fact supplies a good instance of the delicacy and (so to call it) sensitiveness of Virg.'s language, as while the words themselves in Dido's mouth and in the present context have undoubtedly the meaning which Serv. attributes to them (comp. vv. 310, 313), in another context and in the mouth of another speaker they might have indicated a prosperous voyage undertaken under good auspices. Thus “MASK MASK MASK” 2. 25, if it has any special meaning, points to the wind as favouring the journey. See also on v. 361 above. Some MSS. connect ‘MASK’ with what follows.
see on 2. 536. The Ovidian Dido is more lenient, vv. 61 foll.

of suffering to the full, like MASK , and the old Latin ‘MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Cic. 1 Tusc. 35. Waardenburg thinks there is a special reference to death by drowning; but though such a wavering between two meanings would be sufficiently like Virg., Aeneas' repeated cries on Dido would precede, not follow, his ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ It was natural that those who could not understand ‘MASK’ should conjecture ‘MASK MASK’ as Erythraeus did; but ‘MASK’ presented a difficulty, which was not satisfactorily surmounted by reading ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ implies of course shipwreck on a rock. ‘MASK’ may either be the Greek accusative or the vocative. The latter is more probable, as Virg. elsewhere studiously avoids using any inflexion of the word, adopting ‘MASK’ instead in oblique cases. Comp. Prop. 1. 18. 31, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Ov. however, while not using any other inflexion of the word, has ‘MASK’ twice as an acc., vv. 7, 133. Cerda collects instances from the Latin poets of drowning persons calling out the names of those who were most in their minds. Comp. also Croesus' cry on Solon in Hdt. 1.

Dido will haunt him like a Fury with funeral torches when she is really far away; in other words, the thought of her, angry and revengeful, will ever be present to him. The threat is from Medea in MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”. Comp. Id. 3. 703, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . Dido will appear like Clytaemnestra v. 472 below. ‘MASK’ are firebrands, as in 2. 276., 9. 570. They are murky and smoky, so as to increase the horror. Thus Alecto's torches (7. 456) are “MASK MASK MASK MASK” For ‘MASK’ see above v. 83. According to the Greek belief the living as well as the dead had their Erinnyes, which were in fact curses personified, as Müller remarks in his Dissertations on the Eumenides, so that Virg. has not deviated from mythology in making Dido become a Fury while she is yet alive, at the same time that he agrees with the more modern conception of the absent being made present by recollection. Jahn and Wagn. (smaller ed.) revive the old interpretation, Dido following Aeneas with her funeral flames, which he will see when at sea (comp. v. 661 below, 5. 3 foll.); but this would not suit the present context, as the pile would not be lighted till Dido was dead, while it would represent the thought of death too definitely for Dido's present state of mind. She has talked of death from the first (v. 308); but the notion does not become a resolution till v. 450, and the means are not devised till v. 474.

Another proof (see on v. 353) that the apparition of a dead person was regarded by Virg. as separable from the spirit below. Here Dido in the shades is to hear of the effects produced on Aeneas by her spectre. The Homeric belief seems to have been that news of things above reached the shades through the newly dead or other visitors. Comp. Od. 11. 457 foll., 24. 106 foll. ‘MASK MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ see on 2. 170.

Henry may be right in pressing the meaning of ‘MASK MASK’ to distinguish, as contrasted with “MASK MASK” (See Forc., who shows that the words are sometimes discriminated, morefrequently confounded.) Henry remarks that the propriety of the following comparison is much enhanced if we suppose the Trojans to be seen from a distance, as Dido herself is represented as seeing them immediately afterwards (comp. ‘MASK’ v. 408).

The MSS. seem divided between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ the reading of Med. being variously reported. Wagn. thinks Virg. does not use ‘MASK’ before a vowel. There is the same variety in the MSS. in v. 441., 6. 707. The hint of the comparison seems to be from MASK foll., where the Minyans are compared to ants or flies; but Virg. goes much more into detail. A somewhat idle question about the poetical dignity of the simile has been raised by the earlier critics. Hom., as Heyne remarks, has two similes from flies, Il. 2. 469 foll., 16. 461 foll., the point of comparison in the one case being their numbers, in the other their numbers and pertinacity. Here the point is numbers, division of labour, and assiduity, much as in the simile of the bees 1. 430 foll. With the expression of this line comp. MASK .
