Serv. says there was a story, told apparently by Varro, that Diomed actually took up Anchises' bones, which he afterwards restored to Aeneas under the pressure of calamity. This may have suggested the thought to Virg., though he had not adopted the tale. The feeling against the violation of tombs, generally strong in antiquity, was especially so at Rome: see Dict. A. ‘MASK MASK’ The removal of the ashes would disquiet the spirit, so that ‘MASK’ is naturally joined with ‘MASK’ as well as ‘MASK MASK’ The two things are used almost convertibly by Pers. 1. 38, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Comp. also v. 34 above (note). ‘MASK’ was restored by Heins. from Med. and others, for the common reading, ‘MASK MASK’ found in Pal. and Gud., and recalled by Ribbeck. One MS. has ‘MASK MASK’ which Serv. mentions to condemn.

So Livy 34. 50, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (quoted by Forc.). She tells him in effect that the last request she will ask him is that he will abandon an intention fraught with danger to himself—an artful way of pleading for her own interest. Thus there may be a special force in ‘MASK MASK’ In vv. 309 foll. she regards his voyage in a stormy season rather as cruelty to her, as showing his resolution to leave her at all hazards.

of course conveys a sneer. Serv. opportunely reminds us of “MASK MASK” MASK , where the epithet similarly expresses the feeling not of the speaker but of the person spoken to.

need express no more than Dido's disparagement of the boon she seeks, as a thing which it is perhaps foolish to ask, and which Aeneas would find no difficulty in granting: but Val. Fl. 3. 657 has “MASK MASK” in connexion with “MASK MASK” for a season of inaction, and there is also a technical use of “MASK MASK” in Quinct. 9. 4, the employment of a short for a long syllable, the Greek MASK MASK . Accepting this view, which Serv. supports, I should understand the inaction to refer not, as he thinks, to the relations between Dido and Aeneas, as if she were content that he should no longer regard her as his wife during the rest of his stay, but to Aeneas' journey; a time when he will do nothing, and when she may consequently breathe. Comp. the use of “MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ is a combination like “MASK MASK MASK MASK” the notion being “MASK MASK MASK MASK”

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is the fortune of being baffled, and the lesson to be taught is how to bear defeat; or we may take ‘MASK’ conquered by Fortune, which teaches its victims to comport themselves as victims should, to grieve and bear their grief. Many MSS., including Med. a m. pr., give ‘MASK MASK’ which could scarcely be reduced to sense.

These two lines must be taken together, as the sense of ‘MASK MASK’ depends on that which we attribute to v. 436. The latter is well known as the most difficult in Virg. The reading is not quite certain. Not to mention the obvious errors of unimportant MSS., a considerable number of copies give ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ while Med., Pal., and Gud. a m. pr. have ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ and Med. ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ These varieties are all mentioned by Serv., who says that ‘MASK’ was the reading of Tucca and Varius. ‘MASK’ may be dismissed as probably an interpretation of ‘MASK MASK’ fixing it to the particular sense of returning a favour at death as a bequest left by the dying. There is the same variety in the MSS. in Pers. Prol. 5. ‘MASK’ is more plausible, as the ‘MASK MASK’ may be well said with Henry to answer to ‘MASK MASK MASK’ v. 429, the grace of a brief delay. But Henry has forgotten that it may answer equally well to ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ v. 420, the favour which Dido begs of her sister, of carrying this message to Aeneas: and it cannot be denied that ‘MASK MASK’ is strongly in favour of so interpreting it, though the words might mean—‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ There is then no overpowering prima facie reason for adopting ‘MASK MASK’ nor do the interpretations proposed by its supporters supply any additional argument in its favour. If indeed we might read with the Delphin editor ‘MASK MASK’ we should obtain a clear and intelligible sense—‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ I do not know why Wagn. calls this “MASK MASK” the objection which occurs at first sight, that Dido would thus speak too plainly of a resolution which she afterwards takes such pains to conceal from her sister, is, as we shall see, not convincing: the expression would, I think, strike any one as sufficiently natural and unforced, if the reading were undoubted; and the strongest improbability in the case is the general one founded on the almost invariable trustworthiness of one or other of Virg.'s MSS. Henry's interpretation adopts not only ‘MASK’ but ‘MASK MASK’ understanding Dido to say that if Aeneas grants her the favour of a little delay, she, though brought lower than the grave (‘MASK MASK’ = in aggravated death, in a state worse than death), will abate her passion. The intransitive sense of ‘MASK’ is possible enough: but the interpretation of ‘MASK MASK’ is absolutely impossible, and not justified by a less forced expression in a more forced writer, Statius, who in Theb. 11. 582 speaks of Oedipus' blindness as “MASK MASK MASK” On the whole, the chief value of ‘MASK’ seems to be that it has given occasion for a very ingenious conjecture of Schrader, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which would suit ‘MASK MASK’ the sense produced being ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Accepting the ordinary reading as having the authority of Serv., we shall not find much difficulty in giving ‘MASK’ the sense of “MASK MASK” though it does not seem to have been generally used as its conventional equivalent (comp. Hor. A. P. 349, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”), while ‘MASK’ will naturally mean ‘MASK MASK’ as in Livy 2. 23, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ may be either the abl. instr. with ‘MASK MASK’ or used as in v. 502 below, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Here again the difficulty is in the general sense. Roughly considered, the meaning seems to be that Dido's death will bring to Anna a return for her kindness; but it is not easy to see what the return can be, and so to determine whether the death is to be the cause of its being made or merely the occasion. Wagn.'s notion that Dido hints that she will bequeath her kingdom to Anna is unworthy of the occasion, and not supported by any thing else in this book, while it has not even the justification of consistency with the legend, which makes Anna after her sister's death migrate into Italy. Perhaps we may say, borrowing a hint from Serv., that Dido's language is intentionally obscure, her meaning being that her return for Anna's kindness will be that she will kill herself, and so rid her sister of the burden. Anna would take the words as a mere expression of desperation, their very obscurity preventing her from attaching too much meaning to them. So her language in v. 419 is worded in a manner which might have led any one already on the watch to infer the worst, while an unsuspecting person like Anna would take it in a good sense, knowing moreover, as Virg. reminds us v. 502, that Dido had once before endured successfully what seemed even a worse sorrow. Generally we may say that while Dido's purpose is still undecided, she does not shrink from speaking of death, though her words are little more than those of vague desperation. It is only when she has seen death to be her only course that she is anxious that no one should suspect what she is meditating. Sophocles has represented just the same change of feeling in Ajax, who talks wildly of death on his first recovery from his frenzy, but afterwards, when he is quite resolved to die, contrives an elaborate blind for Tecmessa and the Chorus. Thus that Dido should speak of death here is no more than we should expect, though the precise import of her words may be left undetermined. does not merely mean blowing from the Alps, but intimates that the tree is standing and the scene laid there. ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ come in strangely after ‘MASK MASK’ as if the north wind blew from different quarters: so we must either suppose that Virg. means N.E. and N.W., or set it down as one of his many voluntary or involuntary inaccuracies, Boreas being to him the poetical expression for any violent or cold wind. In 1. 85 (note) we have had a similar, though less glaring inaccuracy. Mr. Long however is of opinion that Virg. means any wind which blows from the Alps towards the plains, and therefore any wind from the north side of the circle.

It has been asked why should Dido pray for death when it was in her own power: as if the resolution of selfdestruction were not likely to be preceded by an intense yearning for death, finding vent in prayer. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is elsewhere a synonyme for living, but here it has its full force: the very sight of day is a weariness to her. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” 6. 241 &c.

Wagn. seems right MASK saying that the structure of the sentence requires us to connect ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ though the meaning of the words is not to be pressed, as if the hooting of the owl, or even the mournfulness of its note, like the call of the dead man, existed merely MASK Dido's imagination. Otherwise there would be nothing strange MASK an historic inf. following closely on an inf. governed MASK some other way, the use of the word MASK one case preparing us for its use MASK the other. Comp. 2. 775, MASK . ‘MASK’ seems to be proleptic, expressing the effect of ‘MASK MASK’ With ‘MASK MASK MASK’ comp. “MASK MASK MASK” MASK , and see also on MASK .

I agree with Henry in reading ‘MASK’ from fragm. Vat., Pal., and Gud., rather than ‘MASK’ (Med.). The latter would not be as inappropriate as he supposes, as the holiness of the seers would lend authority to their predictions: but the notion of antiquity is still more awful, and ‘MASK’ seems almost necessary to bring out the sense that Dido's mind is haunted with the remembrance of old predictions, which she supposes to be accomplishing themselves. Here again the alliteration appears intentional. Serv. recognizes both readings. Pomponius Sabinus attests that Apronianus read ‘MASK MASK’ which merely means that the adoption of that reading in Med. is deliberate. Silius, speaking of the disasters that followed the destruction of the serpent on the banks of the Bagrada, says “MASK MASK MASK MASK” (6. 288); but the epithet may be from A. 6. 662, the general thought from A. 5. 524.
The effect of the thought of Aeneas on her mind takes a material shape in her dreams, where he appears to drive her, as Argus drove Io, goading her to frenzy. Hence ‘MASK MASK’

At other times the thought that is present MASK her dreams is that of her loneliness. She seems to be undertaking a long solitary journey, looking for her Tyrian subjects, whom she cannot find: they have forsaken her, and she has to be queen of a desolate country, like Creon MASK Soph. Ant. 739. This latter feeling throws light on v. 320, “MASK MASK MASK” The notion of loneliness is thus enforced MASK two ways, which with great psychological truth are made to blend together confusedly: she loses MASK, and she loses her own subjects too. Thus we see that Schrader's plausible conjecture ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK’ would be no gain but a loss. MASK her waking moments Dido thinks of following MASK alone MASK his flight, below, v. 543. The same image of a long fruitless wandering occurs MASK Ilia's dream MASK Enn. A. 1. fr. 38: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

The double vision of Pentheus is in Eur. Bacch. 916, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . Whether Virg. is more likely to have followed Eur. or Attius (Serv. talks of Pacuvius, but he is not known to have treated the subject of Pentheus) of course cannot be known: probably he followed no one poet, but simply thought of Pentheus as he appears in tragedy. No difficulty need be made about ‘MASK MASK’ which either may be the poetical plural for the singular, or may represent, as Wund. suggests, the multiplying power of Pentheus' vision, just as Orestes in Aesch. Cho. 1057 says MASK MASK MASK . In 6. 572 however Tisiphone is represented as calling “MASK MASK MASK MASK” where this latter explanation would not apply. The number of Erinnyes in the old mythology was indefinite, the Fury being the personified curse (see on v. 384): it was not till the Alexandrian period that they were reduced to the three, Alecto, Megaera, and Tisiphone, whom Virg. generally seems to recognize. Pomp. Sab. says that Urbanus read ‘MASK’ a supposed collateral form of “MASK MASK” which possibly may have been suggested to the grammarian by the adjective “MASK” or by the apparent parallel of “MASK” and “MASK MASK” On the whole it seems better to make ‘MASK’ acc. after ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ referring to ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ only. Comp. 8. 107, 108.

For ‘MASK’ some MSS. give ‘MASK MASK’ apparently from a recollection of 3. 331. The sense which it would yield has found favour with several critics, Markland conjecturing ‘MASK’ (used as in Greek for a title of the Furies), a suggestion of great plausibility, supported by Val. Fl. 7. 147, which will be quoted below, accepted by Wakef., and approved by Heyne, while Lersch and Henry (the latter of whom now withdraws the interpretation) wish to give ‘MASK’ the sense of MASK MASK . Hildebrand, followed by Ladewig, emends ‘MASK MASK’ which I suppose is meant to be constructed with ‘MASK MASK’ The object of all these expedients is to avoid the reference to the stage, it being supposed that an ancient poet would more naturally think of the real Pentheus and MASK as parallel to Dido, herself a personage of similar antiquity, than of their theatrical representatives. But it is quite in keeping with Virg.'s literary tastes that he should interest himself more in the dramatic persons that he had seen or read of than in their supposed prototypes. Such a feeling, it is true, is not the simple feeling of an old poet: to conceive of any thing of the kind in Homer would involve a grotesque impossibility. But the comparison of one mythical person to another is equally foreign to Homer. His similes are limited in their range: heroes and their actions are paralleled to the more ordinary occupations of life, to inferior creatures or natural phenomena. He does not tell us that Achilles resented the abduction of Briseis as Meleager did the slight offered to Atalanta. Virg. must be judged by his own standard; and there is nothing inconsistent with that standard in supposing that the Pentheus of his thoughts was the Pentheus of Euripides, the MASK of Aeschylus. He doubtless felt that it was to the stage that he owed the glorious vision of their madness, and he was glad to make the acknowledgment. It is this feeling which dictates the presents, ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ The frenzy of the Theban and the Argive is not a thing of the past, embalmed in legend; it is constantly repeating itself; it is present as often as the Bacchae or the Eumenides are acted, read, or remembered. As before, we cannot determine whether Virg. had any single play exclusively in his mind. Serv. says that Pacuvius (in his Dolorestes or Dulorestes?) represented MASK as entering Apollo's temple at the instance of Pylades and being attacked by the Furies when he tried to leave it. In Aesch. Eum. the ghost of Clytaemnestra appears, but does not haunt MASK, contenting herself with stirring up the Erinnyes. ‘MASK MASK’ I understand to mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ the sense of ‘MASK’ being fixed by the context, and by the parallels 3. 331., 12. 668, Cic. Rosc. Am. 24, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” That Ausonius uses the words ‘MASK MASK’ in the sense of ‘MASK MASK MASK’ may prove that he had Virg.'s words in his mind, but need only prove further that he did not consider himself bound by Virg.'s meaning, when another suited him better and suited the genius of the language as well. In other words, the objection to the interpretation which Serv. gives as an alternative to that adopted above, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” is not that it is doubtful Latin, but that it would yield a very frigid sense. I will now transcribe the passage to which I referred from Valerius Flaccus , as the detail into which the description is carried makes it more than a mere repetition of Virg. The comparison is to Medea's lovesick distraction— “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Clytaemnestra is represented as herself having the attributes of the Furies. Alecto throws a snake at Amata 7. 346, a torch at Turnus ib. 456. Eur. Iph. T. 285 foll. makes Orestes speak of the Erinnys as attacking him with her serpents, Clytaemnestra being in her arms.

The threshold, Henry remarks (following Germ. on 6. 563), was the peculiar and proper seat of the Furies. He refers to 6. 279, 555, 574., 7. 343, Ov. M. 4. 453. See on 6. 563. Here they doubtless prevent the egress of their victim as he flies before his mother. ‘MASK MASK’ comp. 7. 324, 454., 12. 845. Pal. and the first readings of fragm. Vat. and Gud. have ‘MASK MASK’

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” or “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ is a common expression (see Forc.), apparently answering to our common phrase ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though generally similar, seems to arrive at the result by a different process, the notion there being that of estimation by measurement. ‘MASK MASK’ 3. 358. the extreme limit set by the Ocean, which is regarded, as in Hom., as surrounding the world. Comp. 7. 225, MASK . So the poem to Messala, attributed to Virg., v. 54, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Homer's Aethiopians live by the Ocean, Il. 1. 423.
like “MASK MASK MASK” MASK . The meaning seems to be, not, there is the extreme point of Aethiopia, but, there is Aethiopia, the extreme point of earth. ‘MASK MASK’ 1. 741.

of the sky, 2. 512. Here it chimes in with ‘MASK MASK’ which, as Heyne says, is “MASK MASK MASK MASK” expressing the diurnal motion of the heaven. The line, as Macrob. Sat. 6. 1 informs us, is altered from Enn. A. 1. fr. 37, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ here bears its participial sense of ‘MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ as frequently in Lucr.

the special term for the general. Both Massylians and Mauretanians were Libyans, so Virg. takes the poetical licence of substituting the one for the other. To suppose that a Massylian woman had been employed in Mauretania would be to complicate the poet's details needlessly. The general meaning evidently is that Dido had secured the services of one who had been keeper of the garden of the Hesperides.

Virg. has chosen to represent the garden of the Hesperides as a temple, whether following any authority, does not appear. Perhaps he may mean no more than to translate the Greek MASK , which means a sacred enclosure as well as a garden.

The meaning is that the priestess preserved the golden apples by inducing the dragon to preserve them. The dragon is induced by being fed with dainties, ‘MASK’ &c. standing in effect for “MASK MASK MASK” Henry rightly understands ‘MASK MASK MASK’ of sprinkling the food with honey and poppyseeds, which he shows from various passages in Petronius, from Pliny 19. 8. 53, and from Hor. A. P. 375, to have been considered a great delicacy among the Romans, forming, at least in early times, part of the second course at a banquet. That ‘MASK’ means sprinkling on the food, not sprinkling on the ground as a separate and substantive article of food, he argues from a passage where Petronius says, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ too favours this. ‘MASK’ it must be admitted, is a very unfortunate epithet, as the object of the food cannot have been to lull the ever-wakeful dragon; it is not simply inappropriate or idle, like other epithets which Henry or others quote, but actually mal à propos. As a physical description it is accurate enough, the “MASK MASK“somniferum”MASK MASK” being specified by Pliny as the particular kind of poppy whose seeds were so employed. All attempts to modify or evade this obvious sense must be pronounced failures: e. g. Serv.'s new punctuation, adopted by Gossrau, which connects ‘MASK’ &c. with what follows, Turnebus' fancy that the dragon required to be put to sleep occasionally that he might not break down from overwatching, Jahn's supposition that honey and poppies were strewn about to keep intruders away, and Waddel's suggestion that the priestess may have dealt with soporifics as Macbeth wished to deal with physic, throwing them to the dogs to keep them out of the dragon's way. But perhaps it may still be open to some unusually audacious critic to hint that Virg., by a strange confusion, such as might possibly happen to a great writer who never lived to revise his poem, thought of the dragon for the moment as a creature which the priestess was to subdue or elude, and so made her exercise her charming power in sending it to sleep. Medea, who, as we have seen, has been in his mind throughout the composition of this Book, sprinkles her MASK on the dragon's eyes ( MASK foll.), and Virg. himself in describing an enchanter 7. 750 foll. speaks of him as one “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Ribbeck, with sufficient improbability, places v. 486 after v. 517 below. ‘MASK MASK’ to Juno, to Venus, or to Earth, according to different accounts.

With this description of the professions and practice of the enchantress compare generally the song of the Pharmaceutria in Ecl. 8. ‘MASK’ as in v. 479 above. Comp. the opposite expression in Greek MASK MASK , Aesch. Eum. 306.
Changing the course of rivers and stars was a common exertion of magical power. So Medea in MASK . ‘MASK’ is doubtless dative.

as Taubm. remarks, alludes to Aeneas' ordinary epithet ‘MASK MASK’ Its reference here is probably to his whole conduct to Dido, not, as Henry thinks, to the want of feeling shown in leaving his arms hung up in her very chamber. The ‘MASK’ are doubtless articles of dress. Comp. MASK note. The object of the enchantress there is to bring back her lover, which, as we have seen v. 479, is one of the alternatives which Dido proposes to herself. We can easily understand how the burning of the ‘MASK’ should be supposed to conduce also to the other alternative, the extinguishing of the passion. A funeral pile is raised, with all its accoutrements (see v. 506), really to serve for Dido , but apparently for Aeneas, who is to be burnt in effigy (v. 508), as being dead to Dido. The description of the pile is parallel to that of the pile where Misenus is actually burnt, 6. 214 foll., and there the arms of the dead man are similarly placed on the top of the pile (comp. 11. 195), just as Eetion in Il. 6. 418 is burnt with his armour.

‘MASK’ is the reading of fragm. Vat., Med. a m. pr. &c. The common reading (Pal., Gud., Med. a m. s.) is ‘MASK’ but there is an unmetrical variety ‘MASK’ found in some copies, which seems to show that the text has been tampered with. Anna would naturally require assistance, so that the plural is not inconsistent with the injunction of secrecy. In the actual narrative, v. 507, Dido is made to do these things herself, Virg. as usual caring for variety more than for apparent consistency.

Again the MSS. are divided, between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ The former is in fragm. Vat., and would appear to be intended as a correction in Med. The two words are occasionally confounded, ‘MASK’ being sometimes written ‘MASK’ in MSS. So here Pal. has ‘MASK’ altered into ‘MASK’ Gud. ‘MASK’ altered into ‘MASK MASK’ As far as sense and propriety of language go, there is here nothing to choose between them. I have followed Wagn. doubtfully. Serv. read ‘MASK MASK’ explaining it “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Dido will then mean that she gratifies the natural feeling of destroying what she has so much cause to hate, at the same time that she is performing an injunction which is to lead supernaturally to a certain result. ‘MASK’ with inf. in the sense of ‘MASK MASK’ 9. 44. We shall meet the word as applied to sacrificial directions below v. 636, as we have already done MASK .
in spite of her paleness. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ comp. v. 172 above.

We have already in 2. 236 (where see note) had ‘MASK’ used of the operation of binding. Virg. has here taken a further licence, inverting the expression, so as to put the bandage into the instrumental abl., the thing bound into the acc. This new variety he repeats 5. 503, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” where however there is probably something more gained by the inversion. ‘MASK MASK’ e. g. cypresses, pitch-trees, and yews. We have already had the use of the effigy in incantations for restoring love MASK . Its use in getting rid of the passion has been adverted to on v. 496. ‘MASK MASK’ the “MASK MASK MASK” v. 496. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ seems to mean that though her arrangements might seem to her sister to have one object, they were really devised with another. The words are perhaps from Hor. 1 S. 1. 35.

= “MASK MASK MASK” as in 3. 63. Enchantresses had their hair unbound while performing their incantations, Hor. 1 S. 7. 24. See further on 3. 370. ‘MASK’ is sufficiently explained from v. 483; but it is used, as Wund. remarks, of enchantresses, as in Val. Fl. 1. 755.

Some of the editors, following a hint of Serv., take ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ remarking that a hundred is the ordinary number of the gods, while the repetition of an act three times was supposed to have a magical propriety. But the sense produced is frigid, and contrary to the obvious meaning which the words would suggest; nor is it supported by the imitation in Sil. 1. 94, where, though a hundred is the number of the gods, nothing is said about a threefold invocation. On the other hand Virg., as Wagn. admits, talks of “MASK MASK MASK” 8. 716 as dedicated by Octavianus after the victory of Actium. If the number is exaggerated, as seems probable, we must attribute it partly to the well-known colloquial use of the numeral to express a great multitude, partly to the prejudice, just noticed, in favour of the number three in magic. ‘MASK’ of loud utterance 11. 383. ‘MASK MASK’ shows that the invocation was chiefly of the infernal gods. Comp. 6. 264 foll.

The ancients believed that foals were born with tubercles on their foreheads, which were bitten off by their dams, and that if the tubercle was previously removed in any other way (as is here supposed to be the case), the dam refused to rear the foal. So Aristot. H. A. 6. 22., 7. 24, Pliny 8. 66. The name given to this flesh was hippomanes, and it was supposed to act as a philtre. In MASK we have had a hippomanes of a different kind, though in similar request with enchantresses.
a love-charm, a sense for which no other authority is adduced.

Dido takes a subordinate part in the ceremony. The ‘MASK MASK’ or salt barley cake, was broken and thrown into the fire, MASK . ‘MASK’ is a constant epithet of things connected with sacrifice: “MASK MASK” v. 637 below, “MASK MASK” 5. 745. Here it seems = “MASK MASK” The abl. is modal. Comp. Madv. § 257. Med., Pal., Gud. a m. pr. &c. have ‘MASK MASK’ an easy corruption. Ribbeck recalls it, inserting v. 486 after the present line.

Other writers speak generally of the person performing the incantation as barefooted, Hor. 1 S. 8. 24, Ov. M. 7. 183, where ‘MASK MASK’ can hardly be understood MASK a more particular sense. Heyne refers to a passage MASK Artemidorus, 4. 67, as confirming Virg.'s representation, and says that the single unsandalled foot is found MASK ancient works of art. The reason Serv. gives, that Dido herself may be loosed from love while Aeneas is bound, seems scarcely adequate, though approved of by Lerch, Antiqq. Vergg. § 68. ‘MASK’ of sandals, Ov. F. 5. 432. The loosened dress was another ceremonial and probably symbolical observance, Ov. M. 1. 382., 7. 182. Canidia however MASK Hor. 1. c. is represented “MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ as MASK 5. 179., 7. 167., 12. 169.

The stars are appealed to as knowing the secrets of destiny, probably that they may witness that she had no choice but to act as she had done. Their knowledge is appealed to somewhat similarly 9. 429, though there it is merely the knowledge which they have as constant spectators of all that is done on earth.

She invokes the gods who watch over unhappy love. ‘MASK MASK’ is well paralleled by Henry to Theocr. 12. 15, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , of a passion returned, and Martial 4. 13. 8, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ are not the two unequally matched lovers, but the class of lovers who have unequal yokefellows. With the general sense Wagn. comp. Ajax's dying appeal in MASK

This description of a night where a lover only is wakeful is from MASK . Virg. is more general in his treatment than his prototype, who discriminates the time by saying that the sailors gazed from their ships on Helice and Orion, that wayfarers and porters began to long for sleep, that even bereaved mothers slumbered, and that the barking of dogs was hushed. Comp. also 8. 26, 27., 9. 224, 225, where Virg. repeats himself in a compressed form.

The meaning seems to be that rustling woods and dashing waves are lulled in the windless calm, and that the creatures who inhabit them are asleep. To restrict the meaning to the first sense would be inconsistent with the context, as the animal creation is evidently brought into prominence throughout, as affording a contrast to Dido, while ‘MASK’ on the other hand shows that the poet was thinking of the waters as they are in themselves, and not merely in relation to their inhabitants. ‘MASK’ is not the same as “MASK MASK” it means ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

seems to refer back to ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as if he had said ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The emphatic word is ‘MASK MASK’ it is midnight, and the stars are half-way in their course. ‘MASK’ is applied to the stars by Cic. Div. 1. 11.

may refer to the cessation of the toils of husbandry, though it is not to be restricted to that sense. i. q. “MASK MASK” as in 2. 644. Whether ‘MASK’ is the dat., ‘MASK MASK’ or the abl. ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ is not clear. Perhaps ‘MASK MASK’ is the most probable, as in the expression ‘MASK MASK’ MASK , MASK , comp. by Forb. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ 7. 87.

This line, which, with the variation of ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ occurs again 9. 225, is omitted here by Med., Pal., and others of the better MSS. After all that has been said, it seems to be almost wholly a question of external evidence, as the passage would I think be equally good with and without it; though the pointing, as has been said above, will have to be differently arranged according as it is accepted or rejected. The change of ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK’ may perhaps be, as Forb. contends, a slight argument for its genuineness; but though ‘MASK’ is a word which Virg. might have written, it is no more than might have occurred by a slip of the memory to an ingenious grammarian. On the whole, while considering that the balance of probability is against the verse, I have retained it in brackets, as I have usually done in such cases.

is a passionate exclamation. We should probably say ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Dido grieves that she could not live an unwedded life. Probably she is not thinking here of Sychaeus, though in the next line she bewails her unfaithfulness to his memory. She wishes that she had been born to a wild life in the woods, like Camilla, without any thought of wedlock. It is not constancy to her first mate, but simply wildness, undisturbed by human passions and frailties, that is now in her mind. ‘MASK MASK’ is startling, but it ceases to be strange if we understand it, with Henry, not of a beast's life as contrasted with a man's in respect of the union of the sexes, but generally of the life of beasts as contrasted with civilization and its attendant weaknesses. Camilla's virginity arose out of her wild life: she would not submit to a husband's yoke, as her father would not yield to civic restraints, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 11. 568. So Orpheus, obdurate to love after Eurydice's death, wanders among rocks and snows, MASK —an instance which may be urged by those who think that ‘MASK MASK’ is to be understood with Serv., “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” So the saying that a man who delights in solitude must be MASK MASK MASK MASK . The Greek use of MASK for unmarried seems indeed to express the main thought which Virg. wished to convey. This may perhaps be a sufficient account of words which have caused so much perplexity, though it would be well if further illustration could be obtained. Serv. thinks the reference is to a particular kind of beast, such as a lynx, which, if a quotation he makes from Pliny is to be trusted, after losing its first mate never takes a second. Mr. Long explains ‘MASK MASK’ by ‘MASK MASK MASK’ beasts having no sense of good and evil. Quinct. Inst. 9. 2. 64 notes this as an instance of concealed feeling breaking out, Dido, in the very words in which she inveighs against marriage, acknowledging that it is the state for men as men. It matters little whether ‘MASK’ be taken with ‘MASK’ or with ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ expresses with more self-reproach what is afterwards expressed by ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ to meddle with. Otherwise we might have had “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” comp. 12. 933.

For ‘MASK’ I have restored ‘MASK’ from fragm. Vat., Pal., Gud., &c., as the less common word, and so more likely to be corrupted. ‘MASK MASK’ is an imitation of Ennius (A. 1. fr. 46), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” which is itself an imitation of MASK MASK . An ordinary partitive genitive individualizes some members of a class in order to distinguish them from others: here there is individualization where apparently no division is intended.

There is no reason to suppose that Aeneas had any doubt that it was Mercury whom he had seen, as we are expressly told that the Mercury of the dream was in all respects like the real god. The case is even stronger in 9. 22, where Turnus, having first addressed Iris by name, afterwards says, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though there, as possibly here, the doubt may be about the god who had sent down the messenger. But it seems to have been usual to throw in a saving clause, from motives of reverence, in case the speaker should have mistaken the god or addressed him by a name unacceptable to him. Serv. says that the pontiffs were accustomed to pray “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” exactly the MASK MASK MASK MASK of Aesch. Ag. 160.: comp. 9. 201, and see further Serv. on 2. 351, Gell. 2. 28. Possibly there may be something in another suggestion of Serv. that the doubt is expressed in consequence of the number of gods bearing the same name, e. g. three Mercuries are spoken of. Heyne, who censures the “MASK” of Serv. and others, can hardly be said to have explained the matter by reminding us that Aeneas only saw the form of Mercury, and had no guarantee for its reality. ‘MASK’ refers back to ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Some MSS. however give ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ 3. 189.

‘MASK’ is the emendation of Heins. for ‘MASK MASK’ See on 1. 211., 3. 267, and comp. MASK . Bentley remarks that the Latin poets generally disliked a full stop at the end of the fifth foot. The present case is an exception which proves the rule, the whole passage being intentionally made more abrupt and broken than usual.

One MS. and some grammarians give ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which was generally adopted before Wagn. It would naturally strike a copyist as the more familiar expression: he might fancy it more suited to the context: he might be anxious to complete the variation from the paralled line 9. 37, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Dido however wants weapons to engage the Trojans as well as fire to burn their ships, nor would she be likely in her haste to speak of both sailing and rowing.
A momentary return to calmness. ‘MASK’ probably in its ordinary sense, though it might virtually = “MASK MASK” or “MASK MASK”

was the old reading before Heins., ‘MASK MASK’ being supposed to mean ‘MASK MASK’ which it could scarcely do. It is still a question whether ‘MASK MASK’ is said by Dido of herself or of Aeneas. The latter is supported by Dido's language v. 496 above, and by Tibull. 3. 6. 42, quoted by Wagn., “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” of Theseus' desertion of Ariadne. But in this case it is difficult to explain the next line, the full construction of which must be ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Dido had no reason to think Aeneas treacherous when she offered him a share in the crown: he had treated no one else with the same perfidy. Wagn. attempts to get over this by understanding ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but the question recurs, had be given ground for suspicion? The very next words seem to say that all his previous actions had been in his favour, and that his present faithlessness makes her disbelieve that they ever took place. Her regret for not having slain him, vv. 600 foll., refers not to the time of her welcoming him, but to that of her becoming first aware of his treachery, as ‘MASK’ v. 604 shows. It seems better then to understand ‘MASK MASK’ of Dido's own faithlessness to the memory of Sychaeus, with Henry, who comp. Medea's self-reproach, MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”, and Deianira's “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK . It may seem indeed that Ovid himself sanctions this interpretation, as his preceding line is “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” which may be an imitation of v. 595. Heyne, who also refers ‘MASK MASK’ to Dido, thinks she is struck with horror at her wish to avenge herself on her lover, and then wishes that her moral sense had been as keen earlier: but this is far less likely, and scarcely consistent with the access of fury v. 600, or indeed with the tone of the whole speech, which, tempestuous as it is, gives no sign of relenting towards Aeneas. celebrated with the MASK . The word is similarly used by Stat. Theb. 3. 158. Hecate was called Trivia as being invoked in the crossways. The word however may have reference to the howling of Hecate's dogs: see on 6. 257.

4. 473 above. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ seems to refer to the Roman notion that each person had a presiding deity, who was called Genius in the case of a man, Juno in that of a woman. One belief seems to have been that this deity was twofold, which would account for ‘MASK MASK’ and for the habitual use of ‘MASK’ for the spirit of a single person. The custom of erecting two altars to a dead person (3. 63 note) points the same way. What precise notion of twofold personality may have been at the bottom of this seems hard to say: but we may compare the Etruscan conception of the gods as both male and female, or as existing in pairs.

Virg. has doubtless framed Dido's imprecations so that, while intended by her to be all that is dreadful, they should be susceptible of a much more endurable fulfilment. The imprecation of Polyphemus in Homer is something of the same kind: there however the relief is found in the fact that the curse only extends to Ulysses' arrival MASK home, and so is not incompatible with his subsequent triumph over his enemies. Dido is more unrelenting: she prays that he may have to fight, to leave his settlement and his son, implore foreign aid, submit to a disgraceful peace, die prematurely, and be deprived of burial. Aeneas does meet with opposition (Book 7): he has to leave Ascanius in the camp and entreat aid from Evander (Books 8 and 9): the final peace involves concessions to the Latins and the extinction of the Trojan name (Book 12): while his death, according to one legend, which Virg. probably followed (see 1. 265), happened when he had reigned only three years, and his body, if not left ‘MASK MASK MASK’ did not meet with burial, being swallowed up in the Numicius, or, according to another account, not being found after a battle. Yet Aeneas' career after reaching Italy would have been felt to be a prosperous one, just as the Romans of Virg.'s day would feel that the eternal feud between Troy and Carthage, and the actual appearance of the threatened avenger, were not painful but glorious recollections. The Sibyl, however (6. 83 foll.), takes a similar, though less gloomy view of Aeneas' future in Italy. These lines, as is well known, had a more terrible fulfilment in our own history in the case of Charles the First, who opened upon them when he consulted the Sortes Vergilianae in the Bodleian Library MASK Oxford. ‘MASK’ after ‘MASK MASK’ MASK . The epithet ‘MASK’ is given four times to Turnus in the later books (7. 409., 9. 3, 126., 10. 276), once to the Rutulians generally (9. 519). ‘MASK MASK MASK’ 1. 545.

Dido concludes her imprecation by praying that the enmity of the two countries may be as thorough as it is lasting. Perhaps we may say that she expresses herself as if she wished their opposition in situation (1. 13.) to symbolize their inward hostility. To suppose with Serv. that there is a reference to the terms of treaty between the two nations, forbidding them to approach each other's coasts, &c., would only weaken the force of a grand peroration.

Med., ‘MASK’ Gud. In Pal. ‘MASK’ is nearly erased. The change was evidently made to avoid the hypermeter. ‘MASK MASK’— the present generation of Tyrians and Trojans and all that follow them. The prayer is that hostility may begin at once and never cease; another way of putting ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Wagn., Forb., and Gossrau refer the words exclusively to the Trojans and their Roman descendants, supposing Dido to wish that the nation may be cursed with perpetual war. But a thought so weighty would not have been included in a single hemistich, nor can ‘MASK’ well stand, apart from the context, for “MASK MASK MASK MASK” while Gossrau's attempt to give the sense to the previous sentence, which he would commence with v. 627—‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’— though ingenious, is by no means natural.

Heyne and others have suspected this line without reason. ‘MASK’ is peculiar, but not unexampled (see Madvig, § 490. b.) and was doubtless used partly for the sake of emphasis, partly as the only pronoun of the third person. ‘MASK MASK’ is like “MASK MASK” v. 458 above. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is a confusion between ‘MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK MASK’—the natural identification of the human dust with the dust of earth. So the Greek MASK , doubtless the same word as ‘MASK MASK’ is used of both, though such expressions as MASK MASK MASK (Thuc. 6. 59) in epitaphs do not prove, as Wagn. and Forb. appear to think, that the Greeks talked of a man as interred in his ashes. The line is a touch of circumstantial detail, which may very well have been invented by Virg. to give verisimilitude to his narrative, though it is possible that the legend may have mentioned the death of Dido's nurse.

The difficulty of this line is well known. Its natural meaning is that the sword had been procured for or begged by Dido (according to the sense we give to ‘MASK’) as a present to herself from Aeneas. So the ancients seem themselves to have understood the passage, MASK and Sil. 8. 148, speaking of Dido as slaying herself with the sword Aeneas had given her—if indeed the coincidence does not show that this was one of the points of the legend. Yet this seems inconsistent with the words of v. 507, which can hardly be understood of a thing which did not belong to Aeneas at the time of his departure. The alternative seems to be to suppose the sword to have been Dido's present to Aeneas, already mentioned v. 261 foll., which he may be assumed to have left behind him MASK his haste. ‘MASK’ then would have to mean ‘MASK’ as Aeneas was not likely to have begged for it. MASK that case however we should have expected Virg. to have made more of the thought of Dido perishing by her own gift. On the whole I incline to the first interpretation, while professing myself unable to reconcile it satisfactorily with v. 507. Possibly it may be another instance of “MASK MASK MASK MASK” The objection that a sword was not a natural present to a lady may or may not be valid MASK itself, but it proves nothing against the probability of the interpretation, as Ov. and Sil. clearly did not feel it.

Some have wished that this line should be placed before v. 657, so as to close Dido's enumeration of her actions; but independently of the authority of the MSS., which is unequivocal, with the exception mentioned in the next note, it is easy to see that as a matter of taste the present arrangement is preferable. Iris is Juno's usual messenger, 5. 606., 9. 2, after Il. 18. 166 foll. She is here sent on an extraordinary mission, to do what is usually done by Proserpine. Whether there is any precedent for giving Iris a function in connexion with violent deaths, which of course formed a large class by themselves, or whether this is an isolated act on the part of Juno ‘MASK MASK’ does not appear. Perhaps we may compare the MASK MASK of Hermes, who is a sort of male Iris .

Henry rightly explains ‘MASK’ of a natural, ‘MASK MASK’ of a violent death provoked by some action on the sufferer's part, comparing for the first “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Pliny Ep. 1. 12, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Justin 9. 8, for the second “MASK MASK MASK MASK” above 2. 434, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Tac. H. 1. 21. The opposite of these kinds of death is expressed in the next line, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” she did not wait till fate summoned her: her death was not predestined but sudden. The distinction which Virg. intends is practical rather than philosophical, and the words employed must not be weighed too nicely. Serv. felt there was an inconsistency, asking how Dido's death ‘MASK MASK’ can be reconciled with Jupiter's declaration 10. 467, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but his distinction between ‘MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ scarcely removes it. In one of the passages quoted by Henry to substantiate the sense of ‘MASK MASK’ Tac. A. 2. 71, the dying Germanicus says that if he were dying a natural death, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” he should still have to complain that his end was premature. ‘MASK MASK’ may be the Homeric MASK MASK Il. 20. 336; in the Iliad however things do not happen MASK MASK , as we are expressly told Il. 6. 487 foll., though supernatual interference is sometimes required to prevent such a catastrophe, as in Il. 2. 155., 17. 321., 20. 30, 336 &c. the MASK MASK of Od. 1. 33, 34 is not quite the same thing.

Pal. and Gud. have ‘MASK MASK’ apparently mistaking the construction. The cutting off of the lock of hair (a custom referred to by Eur. Alc. 76, as well as by later writers) is explained by Turnebus Adv. 19. 17 from the analogy of sacrifices, where a few hairs are plucked from the forehead of the victim as part of the MASK (“MASK MASK” 6. 246), a dying man being regarded as a victim to the powers below. Perhaps we may illustrate also from the story of Nisus and Scylla. “MASK MASK” above v. 590. ‘MASK’ is emphatic, as the lock was taken from the crown of the head. Henry quotes Etym. M. s. v. and ‘MASK MASK’ belong to the physical rainbow, which in 5. 601, 658., 9. 15 Virg., unlike Hom., makes the accompaniment of the mythological Iris. ‘MASK’ apparently as the colour of light, v. 585. ‘MASK’ apparently expresses length.

“MASK MASK MASK” 3. 308 of fainting. “MASK MASK MASK” 5. 526. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 11. 617. Additional note on v. 257.] As neither Heins., Heyne, nor Ribbeck specifies any MS. as containing the ordinary reading ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ I have examined ten of the Bodleian MSS., the same which I examined MASK reference to 5. 573 (see the Preface). Five of them read ‘MASK MASK MASK’ four ‘MASK MASK’ one ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Those which read ‘MASK’ are numbered respectively Auct. A. A. 1 (first half of 15th century), Auct. B. B. 1 (14th century), Auct. B. B. 2 (? apparently late), and Auct. F. 2. 5 (middle of 15th century). MASK A. A. 1 and B. B. 2 ‘MASK’ is written above the line. MASK F. 2. 5 ‘MASK’ appears for ‘MASK MASK’ there being a blank space where ‘MASK’ has been erased. MASK B. B. 2 ‘MASK’ is written apparently by the same hand as the rest of the line, but at a later time, as if a blank space had been originally left and afterwards filled MASK. MASK A. A. 1 and B. B. 2 v. 257 precedes v. 256, but the order is corrected MASK the margin. The inverted order is also found MASK the text of one of the other MSS. which I examined, and MASK the margin of another. It appears then that the reading ‘MASK MASK’ like ‘MASK’ 5. 573 is at any rate prior to the invention of printing, so that it may have some better authority than critical conjecture.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

is not to be pressed, merely meaning that he had got well on his way. Most of the instances quoted however for this loose use of the word are scarcely in point, e.g. MASK , 519, where though all that the context requires is that the operation spoken of should have begun, there is no reason why it should not have been exactly half finished at the time mentioned. In other words, Virg. assumes for rhetorical purposes that the thing is half done, an assumption which here is contrary to the fact, while there, for aught we know, it may be consistent with it. 4. 277 is nearer the mark, as we can hardly suppose that Mercury ceased to be visible in the middle of his speech, so that we may say that there the word stands for something more than half, as here for something less than half. ‘MASK MASK’ 2. 359.

unwavering, as an arrow going straight to its mark is called “MASK MASK MASK” So Henry, rightly, reconciling Serv. and Wagn. Neither love nor stormy water deterred Aeneas from his purpose: he looked back to Carthage, but he went sailing on. ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ Taubm. refers to Gell. 2. 30, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Aeneas encounters the danger Dido threatened (4. 310), and we see the consequence in the next paragraph.

Dido did not light her own pile, as some of the commentators have fancied: but she had a pile made to burn, as she gave out, the effigy of Aeneas: she killed herself upon it, having ascended it apparently for the purpose of lighting it: and it would naturally be made use of to burn her body.
and ‘MASK’ are the subjects of ‘MASK MASK’ They are not properly co-ordinate: but ‘MASK’ is intended to stand for the thought of the pangs.
see on 3. 61. ‘MASK MASK’ the knowledge; a use of the neuter participle often found elsewhere, especially in Livy, who has (7. 8) “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Their minds are led through a sorrowful presage: that is the course their thoughts are led to take. ‘MASK’ means no more than conjecture, as “MASK” 7. 273, so that it is not a full realization of Dido's wish, 4. 661.

Nearly repeated from 3. 192— 195. The old reading here in v. 9 before Heins. was “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” as in 3. 193.
as in 3. 201. Things were so bad that even the pilot &c.
‘MASK’ 10. 6, an archaic word. Quinct. Inst. 8. 3 thinks it, like ‘MASK MASK’ lends dignity to the passage.
below v. 400, where, as here and in 7. 135, ‘MASK’ is out of its place, belonging not to the participle but to the verb. Comp. 2. 391, and for the transposition of ‘MASK MASK’ 1. 195.

of a ship's furniture, as to 6. 353, where the specific reference is in the rudder, and possibly in 3. 371., 4. 290, though there I have preferred the more ordinary interpretation. We have already had “MASK MASK” 4. 299. So MASK Od. 2. 390, 423, 430., 12. 410, passages which may have suggested to Virg. this use of the word, as no instances are quoted in the lexicous from other Latin authors. The precise meaning however of ‘MASK MASK’ is not quite certain. It seems generally to be understood of taking in part of the sails. M. Jal, in his ‘MASK MASK’ (‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ &c.) explains it of stowing away those parts of the ship's furniture that the wind might take hold of, streamers, &c. Mr. Long thinks Virgil means generally to make every thing tight and prepare for a squall. But it is possible that Virg. may have meant ‘MASK’ as well as ‘MASK’ to be metaphorical, speaking of the sailors as men resuming the arms which they had laid down and preparing for action; or even that he may have thought of the phrase “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” which he twice uses later in the poem, 10. 412., 12. 491. “MASK MASK MASK” 10. 294.
He turns the sails so that the wind may catch them sideways. Forb. comp. Livy 16. 39, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

a Homeric address, like MASK MASK Il. 6. 145. ‘MASK’ has its technical sense of guarantee, its union with ‘MASK’ implying that he who gives the promise is in this case the person to make it good, as Mr. Long remarks.
= “MASK MASK MASK” as we might say ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ with pres. inf. 4. 337 &c.

adverbially, as in MASK . The meaning seems to be, the wind is changed, and instead of being favourable blows right across our path. Comp. the metaphorical use of the word Cic. 1. 168. ‘MASK’ of bringing into harbour. Neither Forc. nor the commentators give any other instance of this use, which must doubtless have been an idiomatic one. We may compare it with ‘MASK’ of reaching a place, and MASK &c. of returning home. This seems better than to suppose a special reason for the notion of descent here, such as that of the sea appearing higher than the land. The majority of MSS., including Pal. and Med., have ‘MASK MASK’ a common error: Ribbeck however adopts it.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Comp. for the thought 1. 550, for the language 1. 546. The living friend is contrasted with the dead father.
Perhaps from MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Virg. seems to mean that the wind, which distressed them while they were sailing against it, was now in their favour. Thus ‘MASK’ here agrees with ‘MASK’ v. 19. This however, as Mr. Long remarks, obliges us to suppose that Virg. had misconceived the relative position of Carthage and the west part of Sicily. So perhaps ‘MASK’ may intimate that the sea was still excited (comp. 1. 118., 3. 564 &c.), though elsewhere it simply means ‘MASK MASK’ e. g. below vv. 160, 209.
of bringing a ship to land, MASK &c. Comp. also A. 1. 158. ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK” Serv.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

Serv. raises a question between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK MASK’ The former has been generally preferred: but Wagn. and Forb. adopt the latter, on the ground that ‘MASK’ without a preposition could only mean ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ however appears to mean ‘MASK MASK MASK’ 1. 403, and perhaps 4. 168, both of which in different ways are parallel to the present passage. On the other hand it does not seem likely that Virg. should have written ‘MASK MASK MASK’ thus creating an ambiguity which he might easily have avoided by writing ‘MASK MASK’ itself the reading of one or two MSS., recommended by Bentley. The choice then seems to lie between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ and the weight of external evidence is decisive for the former. With this pregnant use of ‘MASK’ comp. v. 727 below, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
hendiadys.

Wagn. rightly joins ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ following the earlier editors against Heyne. The expression is unusual, but not unexampled. Ruhkopf (cited by Wagn.) comp. Stat. Theb. 4. 221, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. comp. Enn. A. inc. 46, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Wagn. now (ed. 3) comp. MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK”. ‘MASK’ is an adj. peculiar to Virg., here and 8. 368, where the half line recurs. Pliny 8. 83 denies that there are bears MASK Africa: but they are mentioned by Herodotus and Solinus: Virg. too is followed by Martial and Juvenal, the latter perhaps an independent authority. They do not appear to have been found there by modern travellers.

‘MASK’ is the reading of only one MS., the great majority giving ‘MASK’ But the Greek name of the river was MASK or MASK . The story as told by Serv. on 1. 550 is that Poseidon in punishment of Laomedon's fraud sent a sea-monster to ravage the Troad, that Trojan maidens were ordered to be given to it, that fathers in consequence sent their daughters away, that one Hippotas put his daughter Segesta or Egesta on board a ship which carried her to Sicily, and that there a union took place between Segesta and the river-god Crimisus, the fruit of which was Egestus or Acestes. It should be mentioned that Serv. there says Virg. calls Crimisus Crinisus by poetic licence. The common construction is ‘MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Pliny 8. 16 has “MASK MASK MASK”
his mother's Trojan ancestry.

No authority is quoted for this construction of ‘MASK’ with an acc. Perhaps it is best to understand ‘MASK MASK’ Comp. Tac. A. 6. 21, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where the sense is ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is a Persian word transferred into Greek and Latin, and signifying ‘MASK MASK’ so that with the epithet ‘MASK’ it produces a kind of oxymoron, like “MASK MASK” MASK .
as might be expected, is the reading of a few MSS.

MASK speaks from a mound, like a Roman general, as Heyne remarks.
“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 6. 500 note. Some MSS. have ‘MASK’ here. The Trojans are called the descendants of the gods, because Dardanus was the son of Jupiter, 7. 219.

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 3. 63.

Wagn. has restored ‘MASK MASK’ from Med., Rom., Pal., &c, for ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the old reading. Either might stand. Serv. has a curious fancy that the saving clause is thrown in on account of the confusion in the calendar which existed before Cæsar. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ the day on which he is speaking is the actual anniversary: comp. 104 below, “MASK MASK MASK MASK”

is a formula of resignation. Standing where it does, it seems to mean that the gods willed the day to be one which should excite mingled grief and reverence, by willing the event which invested it with that character.

with ‘MASK MASK’ To understand ‘MASK’ as = ‘MASK’ and explain ‘MASK’ by an anacoluthon, as if Virg. had intended to end with ‘MASK’ which is Heyne and Wagn.'s view, is to introduce a needless irregularity. Aeneas' language is of course hyperbolical, his meaning being that he would celebrate the anniversary under the most adverse circumstances. The Gaetulian Syrtes, like the Argive (Aegaean) sea, are doubtless chosen as associated not only with natural dangers, but with human enemies.

‘MASK’ surprised, not however by a storm, which is a common application of the word (see MASK , where I have too hastily referred to this line as parallel), but by the arrival of the day at an inopportune time. So Heyne, rightly. ‘MASK’ couples MASK with the Aegaean as distinguished from Aeneas' African foes. ‘MASK’ Med., Pal., Gud., from a nom. ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ Rom. Other variations are ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ With the gen. comp. “MASK MASK” 1. 247.
is to be understood strictly, of a funeral procession. Here as elsewhere Virg. is thinking of Roman observances. ‘MASK MASK’ MASK . ‘MASK’ = “MASK MASK” as in 3. 548.

of funerals: see Forc. ‘MASK MASK’ to pile up: 1. 704. ‘MASK’ = “MASK MASK” as in 6. 142. ‘MASK’ here and in v. 93 seems to be used vaguely for ‘MASK MASK’ if the view is true which restricts ‘MASK’ to the superior gods.

has its primitive sense of ‘MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ See on 2. 145. ‘MASK’ virtually = ‘MASK MASK’

It is true, as Forb. contends, that ‘MASK’ may be used with other persons than the 1st sing.; but that is no reason for taking it with ‘MASK’ here, when usage is in favour of taking it with ‘MASK MASK’ Comp. 6. 848, MASK , where, as here, the clause is constructed parenthetically. Comp. also 4. 45, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ goes not with ‘MASK’ but with ‘MASK MASK’ &c. The confusion of the order, which may readily be paralleled, is easily accounted for by supposing a half confusion between the two modes of expression, ‘MASK’ parenthetical and ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ like ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Cic. N. D. 1. 2. “MASK MASK MASK” occurs 10. 640 of a voice without meaning. “MASK MASK MASK” 2. 777, ‘MASK’ meaning will or purpose, as in 2. 123 note. It is the Homeric MASK MASK MASK .

“MASK MASK MASK” 3. 219. Lachm. on MASK explains ‘MASK’ as a contraction for ‘MASK MASK’ but it seems more likely that a poet like Virg. should have simply used the present for the perf., as is frequently done by Pope and his school.

the order before Heins., seems to have little or no authority. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Aeneas means to say, Let our service be a cheerful one: the gods have done well in bringing us here, and are intending to do well to us hereafter. The word ‘MASK’ is rather a common one in connexion with sacrifices, e. MASK (where “MASK MASK” is found), 279 (comp. ‘MASK’ ib. 275).

It is natural enough, as the later commentators remark against Heyne, that the Trojans should take this opportunity of asking for a prosperous voyage, especially as the satisfactory observance of this sacred anniversary is in the next clause adroitly made conditional on their landing in Italy. But a question still remains, whether the prayer is made to the winds themselves, or to Anchises. The latter interpretation, which perhaps is that more obviously suggested by the context, was evidently maintained by Lactantius, who says of Anchises (Inst. 1. 15) “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Klausen too, in his work on Aeneas and the Penates, considers that Anchises is recognized as a god of the winds. On the other hand offerings were made as a fact to the winds themselves at the end of the ceremonies to Anchises, v. 772 below, as we have seen done already 3. 115 foll., where “MASK MASK” is like ‘MASK MASK’ here. Possibly too Virg. may have had in his mind the prayer which Achilles offers to the winds just before the funeral of Patroclus, Il. 23. 194, though the object there is quite different. For ‘MASK’ some MSS. and Lact. l. c. have ‘MASK MASK’ which has found its way into some editions.
The abl. abs. ‘MASK MASK’ really contains the gist of the prayer. In Soph. El. 457 Electra prays for victory over her mother and Aegisthus that she may be able to honour her father better.

MASK, like a true son of Troy , supplies the materials for the sacrifice. ‘MASK MASK’ shows the spirit in which the present is made, like “MASK MASK MASK” 1. 196, also of MASK. With the division according to ships comp. 1. 193.

of animals numerically, 3. 391. Virg. was also thinking of MASK MASK MASK Il. 23. 360 (the book of the Games for Patroclus), which Heyne compares. ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ as in Hor. 4 Od. 5. 32, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” comp. by Heyne. ‘MASK’ is correlative to ‘MASK MASK’ being the word for invoking or inviting the presence of the gods. Comp. (with Forb.) Ov. F. 4. 827 foll.:— “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

MASK this feast, as MASK the games shortly to be mentioned, Virg. follows the Roman custom. Comp. Dict. A. ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

This use of ‘MASK’ where ‘MASK’ might have been expected has given some trouble to the commentators. Serv. suggests that the contingency may lie in the word ‘MASK’—if the day should be fine. It would seem to be a modest, perhaps religious way of speaking of a future event. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Catull. 14. 17. Other instances given in Forc. are perhaps to be explained somewhat differently. ‘MASK MASK’ the ninth day after the anniversary. Virg. is here thinking of the ‘MASK’ the festival on the ninth day after death, when the mourning ceremonies were brought to an end. There was another festival of a different kind which bore the same name, lasting nine days, and Virg. seems to have blended the characteristics of the two: see v. 762. We may comp., as the commentators have done, Il. 24. 664 foll., where Priam proposes that the mourning for Hector should last nine days, the burial and funeral feast take place on the tenth, and the tomb be raised on the eleventh.
See 4. 119 note.

doubtless means first in order, though the other games are not distinguished numerically. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ note on MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the collective noun for the distributive, not merely for metrical purposes, but because the race was open to the whole fleet, and, as we might say, an encouragement to the naval interest. See v. 115.
7. 807. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ MASK MASK .

In the actual games the ‘MASK’ precedes the archery. ‘MASK’ seems to point to a different kind of contest, throwing spears: comp. MASK , Il. 23. 884 foll., where a darting-match is proposed, but not carried out. Either Virg. has expressed himself loosely, or when he wrote this line he thought of introducing one more game. In any case ‘MASK’ (Med., Pal.) seems better than ‘MASK’ (Rom.). ‘MASK’ is used rather strangely, as it can hardly refer to the way in which the competitors carry themselves during the contest, which is what we should have expected. Probably it is to be explained of the proud bearing of those who anticipate victory or have actually gained it. Comp. Hor. Epod. 15. 17, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 10. 735. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 9. 178.

and ‘MASK’ are treated as equivalents, as in 12. 685, 686. ‘MASK MASK’ MASK . ‘MASK’ seems here = ‘MASK MASK’ In Lucan 4. 615 “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” the meaning appears to be that Antaeus placed little confidence in the fact that he touched his mother earth with his feet—a somewhat different use of the construction. In the two other instances of ‘MASK’ with an inf. quoted by Forc. the inf. has a different subject.

MASK . Here there seems to be a confusion between two notions, the competitors awaiting the award of the prize of victory, which would fall to the one who deserved it, and the competitors looking forward to a number of prizes which would be awarded according to their several deserts.

Henry raises a question about the meaning of ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which he thinks has been wrongly interpreted of silence. But a reference to Forc. ‘MASK MASK’ where the matter is fully treated, will show that the common interpretation is substantially right. The point was that none but good words should be uttered before a sacrifice, and the spectators in consequence either repeated what the priest said or did not speak at all. It may be worth while to extract in extenso two of the most important passages which Forc. quotes. The first is from Ov. M. 15. 677 foll.:— “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The other is from Pliny 28. 2, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” On certain occasions the same proclamation was made with an opposite though parallel object, that people should abstain from good words: see Forc. Here the injunction means that the sacred rites are going to begin. Comp. the use of ‘MASK’ 1. 735., 8. 173, where it would seem from the context that good words are intended rather than silence, the term being perhaps understood liberally on festive occasions. ‘MASK MASK’ Med., Pal., ‘MASK MASK’ Rom. Putting on wreaths was part of the ceremonial: comp. 7. 135., 8. 274.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’
Comp. MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ see on 2. 249., 3. 174.

Helymus is named by Dionys. Hal. 1. 52 as having accompanied MASK from Troy to Sicily. Strabo 13, p. 608 B. makes him land in Sicily with Aeneas, Virg. makes him a companion or retainer of MASK, but younger, vv. 300, 301 below. In any case his name was connected with Sicily, as the mythic founder of the Elymi, a people there, Thuc. 6. 2. ‘MASK MASK’ means merely of ripe years, not necessarily implying old age: ‘MASK’ however is frequently used of the old, with reference either to their experience or to their age, and is in effect a comparative term. Comp. 9. 246, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” who is distinguished in this way from Nisus and Euryalus, to whom he is speaking, and from Ascanius, who follows him. So Hor. 4 Od. 4. 55, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” id. A. P. 115, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Here it discriminates MASK from Ascanius, and perhaps from Helymus and the rest, ‘MASK MASK MASK’
“MASK MASK MASK MASK” 7. 614. ‘MASK’ of following an example 1. 747.

MASK note. For these libations to the dead generally comp. 3. 66 (note), MASK : also Il. 23. 170, 219 foll. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ a solitary instance in Virg. of the use of the word in its proper adjectival sense. The abl., for which the gen. would be more usual, may be called material or descriptive. Comp. MASK note.
“MASK MASK MASK” is said by Anchises himself of funeral offerings to young Marcellus 6. 884. The custom was the same in Greece, Aesch. Pers. 618, Soph. El. 895.

It is very doubtful whether ‘MASK’ refers to Aeneas' second visit to the tomb, or simply to the repetition of the address ‘MASK’—in other words, whether it should be connected in pointing with the first or the second clause in the line. Serv. says the address to the dead was repeated thrice, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” On the whole I have not thought it worth while to disturb the pointing of Heyne, Wagn., and Forb., who place a semicolon after ‘MASK MASK’ though Ribbeck punctuates differently. The ‘MASK’ was either equivalent to the final ‘MASK MASK’ or accompanied it. So 11. 27, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Aeneas' final address to the dead Pallas. Thus also the “MASK MASK MASK” of Catullus 99 (101). 10 to his dead brother. At any rate ‘MASK’ has nothing to do with this second visit, as no such sense can be got out of the word, though Forb. says “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The ashes welcomed Aeneas again, not he them. Henry is evidently right in explaining ‘MASK MASK’ of Aeneas' rescue of his father from Troy , which he calls in vain, as he was to lose him after all, and comparing 3. 711, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and 6. 111, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” In that case however it would be very harsh to make ‘MASK’ agree with ‘MASK MASK’ so that we shall probably do well to make ‘MASK’ the gen. sing., combined with ‘MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK MASK” and similar expressions. For ‘MASK’ used of the appearance of a single person see 4. 571. No other instance is quoted of a similar use of ‘MASK MASK’ but Virg. may have been tempted by the analogy of ‘MASK MASK’ even if he did not distinctly realize the belief of the twofold personality of the dead, referred to on 4. 610. An old Schol. printed by Mai observes that Virg. has enumerated the three parts of man, the dust that returns to earth, the spirit that goes into heaven, and the shade that dwells below.

It may be doubted whether there is any special meaning in the seven coils of the snake, though Serv. thinks they indicate the seven years of Aeneas' wandering, comparing the portent of the serpent in Iliad 2, and Heyne thinks seven is chosen as a mystical number. ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ are probably the same; Wagn. however explains it as a sort of hendiadys, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”—“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
As Heyne remarks, this is the first we hear of the altars, which were doubtless erected as soon as they came to the tomb. Comp. 3. 63., 4. 509.

Med., Pal., ‘MASK’ Rom. There is little to choose between the two words on the ground of intrinsic propriety, though some of the later critics think otherwise; but it seems more likely that Virg. should have varied the line 4. 701 than simply repeated it. Either gives a vivid poetical image, ‘MASK’ of the length of the bow, ‘MASK’ of the glancing brightness of the colours, ‘MASK MASK’ being used like ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as Forb. remarks. Lucr. has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 2. 823, and “MASK MASK MASK MASK” (‘MASK’ of the coating or film which he supposes to be given off from the surface of visible things), 4. 95: indeed the words ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ figure rather largely in his philosophical descriptions. This is an additional reason why the use of the word here should be attributed to Virg. rather than to a transcriber. ‘MASK’ may = ‘MASK MASK’ or may be connected with ‘MASK MASK’ flings on the clouds.

probably the offerings on the altars, which, though not mentioned, of course must be assumed. It may however refer to the libations and flowers. See on 3. 301.

because of ‘MASK MASK’ See 4. 63 note, and comp. Livy 25. 16 there referred to. The meaning is not, as Forb. thinks, that he renews the ceremonies of the year before, but that he carries on what had been begun before the appearance of the serpent.

7. 136. The Genius was frequently represented under the form of a serpent. Comp. Lersch, Ant. Verg. § 57. 21, where instances from Herculaneum and Pompeii are cited. Lersch also quotes a passage from Livy 25. 16, where two serpents appear during a sacrifice performed by Gracchus and eat the liver of the victim, remarking that such a visitation might be interpreted differently according to the will of the haruspex, the omen having been in that case thought a bad one. The discovery of serpents in tombs seems to have suggested the notion mentioned in Ov. M. 15. 389 in a speech of Pythagoras, and referred to by Serv., that the human marrow when decomposed became a serpent. ‘MASK MASK’ Anchises as a god might have had an animal to attend him. Sil. 6. 288 speaks of a serpent as “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Val. F. 3. 458 of “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Sil. 13. 124 speaks of a doe as “MASK MASK MASK” and Ov. M. 8. 272 of the Calydonian boar as “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Pal., Verona fragm., Gud., &c. have “MASK” which was the old reading, a mistake probably originating in an unmetrical variant “MASK MASK” which is found in Rom. There is no authority for the number 5, whereas 2 was one of the sacred numbers, as we have just seen, v. 77. ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK’ as in MASK &c. The three kinds of victims are the same as those sacrificed at the Suovetaurilia or Solitaurilia. Comp. 1. 634. 635.

the shade being assumed to be present in order to partake of the funeral offerings. Comp. the words of the shade of Darius, Aesch. Pers. 689, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . Perhaps the appearance of the serpent encouraged the feeling in Aeneas.

MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ the reading of the early editions, is found in one of Ribbeck's cursives. Jahn seems right in supporting the omission of the copulative on the ground that ‘MASK MASK’ develope the notion of ‘MASK MASK MASK’ As Wagn. remarks, Virg. is here describing the occupations of some of the Trojans only, ‘MASK’ being supplied from the next verse, as in 4. 592. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ may be a MASK MASK , as the altars would be loaded with dishes of entrails &c. from the slain victims (“MASK MASK MASK MASK” 8. 284., 12. 215): but the meaning may be that while some are making offerings from victims already slain, others are slaying fresh victims.
