‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

MASK is the Homeric and Hesiodic epithet of the sun (Il. 11. 735 &c.), and is used by later writers as a name of the sun-god (e. g. Val. Fl. 3. 213, “MASK MASK MASK MASK”). This is doubtless its sense here, as a reference to the adventure of the legendary Phaethon with his father's horses would be obviously out of place. As Gossrau remarks, the epithets of the gods were not unfrequently made into children of the gods, demi-gods, &c. In Od. 23. 244 foll. the dawn-goddess has horses of her own, one of which is actually called Phaethon. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ abl. of circumstance.

I have restored ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK’ from Med. and two other MSS. Perhaps it is scarcely worth while, as the transciber may have altered the less usual form; but there is a slight advantage in the imperfect, which is thus shown to be the effect of which the pluperfect ‘MASK’ is the cause. The whole passage, and this line in particular, seems to be imitated from Catull. 62 (64). 31 foll.: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
“‘ MASK MASK : ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Donatus. We may remember that Virg. might have said “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK’ comp. MASK .

The enumeration of the prizes is from Il. 23. 259 foll., though the details are not the same. ‘MASK MASK’ we must either suppose Virg. to have forgotten himself here, as it is not until v. 289, after the ship-race is over, that they go into the circus, or take ‘MASK’ of the concourse of people, used perhaps proleptically. Hom. l. c. has MASK MASK MASK .
Tripods are given MASK Hom. vv. 259, 264 &c. ‘MASK MASK’ to be used MASK sacrifice.
The ‘MASK’ ( MASK note), a post-Homeric institution, were confined to the conquerors: see below, vv. 472, 519.

dyed or saturated. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK . ‘MASK’ fragm. Vat., Rom., ‘MASK’ Med., Pal., Gud. The latter was restored by Wagn., but Ribbeck seems right in recalling the former, as it appears from v. 248 that the crew of each ship received a talent of silver, unless Heyne is right in supposing that a talent was divided among the crews. Hom. talks of two talents of gold. The meaning then will be that there was several talents' weight of gold and silver (comp. 10. 526, 531), the talent of course not being a coin but a weight. In 11. 333, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ seems to be dual, denoting a talent's weight of each.

The trumpet, as is well known, is not heroic, appearing only in a Homeric simile; but it was one of the ways of commencing the shows at the circus. Gossrau refers to Pliny 2. 7, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ occurs in Cic. ad Q. 3. 4 6, Fin. 3. 2. 8. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ a mound in the centre of the company, perhaps the same as in v. 44.

Virg. naturally substitutes the ship-race for Homer's chariot-race, which Aeneas' wandering heroes could not well have conducted: he has kept his eye however on the incidents of the Homeric contest. Wagn. thinks ‘MASK’ must refer to swiftness, not to size, supposing the Chimaera to be larger than the rest, being a trireme, while the others are assumed to have been biremes. In v. 153 however the weight of Cloanthus' vessel is said to be the reason why he did not get ahead of Gyas, so that the two ships probably did not differ much in size. It seems more likely that in the following description Virg. as usual has studied variety, calling the Pristis swift and the Scylla sea-coloured without meaning that the others were not swift, or implying any thing about their colour, and thus that in dwelling on the size of the Chimaera he has no intention of disparaging that of the rest. ‘MASK MASK’ of course does not mark out the ships as adapted for swift sailing, but leads us to think of the difficulty of the feat, while indicating their actual character.

‘MASK’ Rom., fragm. Vat., ‘MASK’ Med. Virg. seems generally to prefer the Latin to the Greek termination. For the word see on 3. 427. The ships doubtless derived their names from the ‘MASK’ on their prows. Comp. the description of Aulestes' Triton 10. 209 foll.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The connecting of Roman families with Trojan heroes is not MASK fancy of Virg.'s, but dates from an earlier period. Varro wrote MASK book ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Virg. may or may not have derived MASK from MASK , Memmius from ‘MASK MASK’ but he evidently follows the analogy of those words in his etymology, as MASK became ‘MASK MASK’ so MASK became ‘MASK MASK’ It is disputed whether ‘MASK’ is nom. pl. or gen. sing., but perhaps the latter is the simpler, as Wagn. remarks, comp. v. 123. ‘MASK MASK’ 4. 288.

Wagn. thinks ‘MASK’ refers to bulk generally, ‘MASK MASK’ to height; but Gossrau's view seems more natural: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” like Homer's MASK MASK . It is singular that MASK is not mentioned as the founder of any house, as it appears from Serv. that the Geganii, a great Alban family, afterwards a patrician house at Rome (Livy 1. 30), regarded him as their progenitor. It is supposed however that they may have died out before Virg.'s time, as they are not mentioned in the later history of the republic. At any rate Virg. indemnifies MASK by dwelling at much greater length on the points of his ship. ‘MASK’ 1. 222. It occurs again Ov. F. 6. 639, of a house built by Vedius Pollio and left to Augustus, who pulled it down. The lines are worth quoting:— “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

is a singular expression for “MASK MASK” Stat. Cic. Verr. 5. 34, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Cerda comp. 8. 691, of the battle of Actium, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where however see note. ‘MASK’ of a tier of oars, Livy 23. 30. Virg. has been guilty of an anachronism, as triremes were not invented till the historic period (Thuc. 1. 13), about B.C. 700, at the same time that he must have failed to impress a notion of vastness upon his readers, who had known ships of ten tiers at the battle of Actium, and had heard of others of sixteen, thirty, and even forty. rather than ‘MASK’ (which is however the reading of a few copies, supported by Nonius), agreeing with ‘MASK’ understood. Forb. cites “MASK MASK MASK” (urbe) 8. 561, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (fabula), Suet. Tib. 2. ‘MASK’ 1. 222.

abl. of circumstance. ‘MASK’ is frequently used as a subst., and hence ‘MASK’ is sometimes found adverbially, a step beyond its use here. See Forc. It matters little whether ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK’ be regarded as the subject of ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ being in this case = ‘MASK MASK’

It is difficult to give the force of ‘MASK MASK’ which doubtless is intended to characterize the act, like “MASK MASK” 1. 196, “MASK MASK” ib. 412, “MASK MASK” ib. 692. Perhaps on a comparison of vv. 358, 424 below we may say that it denotes Aeneas' acting as the president and patron of the games, directing the sports of those who are mostly younger than himself. In v. 521 it indicates Acestes' display of his prowess as a veteran.
They had probably to sail round the goal; at any rate it served as the turning-point of the race, which was like a Greek MASK . “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 3. 430.

They choose their places by lot, as it was an object to secure the place which as nearest to the goal involved the shortest turn. Comp. Il. 23. 352, where the result of the lot-drawing is given at length, as below vv. 409 foll.
the commanders, as distinguished from ‘MASK MASK’ the pilots (v. 161).

The rowers are partially naked, and wear garlands of poplar. ‘MASK’ 3. 174. Serv. says the poplar was chosen because these were funeral games, that tree having been brought from the shades by Hercules when he went to fetch Cerberus. See on MASK .

3. 289. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ followed immediately by ‘MASK’ has given some trouble to the commentators. Probably the repetition is intentional, as Gossrau remarks, to enforce the notion of intense eagerness. There is something strange to a modern judgment in the use of the same word first in a literal and immediately afterwards in a transferred sense; but the contrast between the two was doubtless not so sharply present to the poet's mind. ‘MASK MASK’ occurs below, v. 403. Here the meaning seems to be that every nerve and muscle is strained in expectation of the contest. There is some resemblance between this passage and Enn. A. 7. fr. 6, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

from their respective places, which were their limits until the signal was given. It is the ‘MASK’ of v. 316, the ‘MASK’ of the circus. Ribbeck reads ‘MASK MASK’ seemingly from his own conjecture.
apparently expresses both the onward bound of the vessel and the rising of the rowers. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 2. 488. ‘MASK MASK’ 3. 128.

It is doubtful, as was intimated on 3. 668, whether ‘MASK’ here and ‘MASK’ in the parallel passage 10. 208, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” come from “MASK” or from “MASK MASK” “MASK” is used several times of rowing (see 3. 668), while to support the use of “MASK” in that sense we must perhaps look to the analogy of ploughing, “MASK MASK MASK” &c. But the participle “MASK” from “MASK” is exceedingly rare; and though “MASK” is the more natural word for rowing where quick motion is the notion intended to be brought out, “MASK” would seem to be fitter to express great exertion and disturbance of the water, which seems to be the meaning both here (comp. ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ another metaphor from ploughing, ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’) and in the passage from A. 10.
“MASK MASK MASK” MASK . ‘MASK’ expresses the regular movement of the oars of each vessel; or it may refer to the ships as abreast of each other at starting. ‘MASK’ as in a storm, 1. 106.

Repeated 8. 690. In both passages an unmetrical reading ‘MASK’ seems to have got early possession of the text, to the perplexity of the grammarians, who had recourse to various ways of scanning it, a molossus or amphimacer in the fourth foot, the suppression of s as a consonant which the Etruscans scarcely sounded at all, and the shortening of i by the poet ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Pierius, who mentions these devices, himself asks “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ convolsum MASK MASK stridentibus MASK ’MASK” Others, less ready for metrical tours de force, omitted ‘MASK MASK’ while others again changed ‘MASK’ into ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ The reading ‘MASK’ was mentioned to Pierius, apparently as a conjecture, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” by Angelus Colotius. It is found in Med., fragm. Vat. (originally), Pal., and some other copies, and is unquestionably the true one, expressing as it does accurately the shape of the ship's beak (Dict. A. ‘MASK’). It is supported also by an imitation in Val. Fl. 1. 688, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Rom., Gud., &c. have ‘MASK MASK’

Virg. may be said to glance indirectly at his master in asserting that the ships moved faster and the rowers showed more eagerness than the chariots and their drivers. The comparison of a ship to a car at full speed is Homer's own, Od. 13. 81 foll., while the lines descriptive of the chariots and their drivers are partly taken from Virg.'s previous description of a chariot-race, MASK foll., which is itself modelled on the chariot-race in Il. 23. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK , 104, where see notes. ‘MASK MASK’ is the poetical equivalent of “MASK” or “MASK MASK MASK”

expresses the darting forward of the horses. So MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (note). It is here joined with ‘MASK MASK’ as the yoke would move as the horses' necks moved, while the yoke naturally occurs in connexion with the reins.

Heins. restored ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is a later correction in Med., supported by two of Ribbeck's cursives and the MSS. of Sen. De Ben. 6. 7. ‘MASK’ has the advantage of being the more difficult reading, involving a bold and perhaps a harsh metaphor, as Gell. 10. 26 tells us that Asinius Pollio censured the use of ‘MASK’ as applied to navigation in Sallust. On the other hand ‘MASK MASK’ occurs elsewhere in Virg., 1. 401., 11. 855, the last a compound of the present line, and v. 166 below, while ‘MASK MASK’ occurs nowhere else, so that a transcriber may very well have slipped into the expression with which he was more familiar. With Wagn. and Ribbeck I have, after considerable hesitation, allowed ‘MASK’ to stand. Ribbeck reads ‘MASK’ from Rom., Pal., &c.

as we talk of ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Forb. comp. “MASK MASK MASK” Hor. 1 Od. 25. 3. ‘MASK’ here is the rock, which Gyas wished to pass as closely as possible, as Antilochus is advised to pass the goal by Nestor, Il. 23. 338 foll. From ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ it appears that they were to pass the goal on the left. ‘MASK’ gives briefly what Hom. l. c. expresses more fully, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . safe from any danger of collision, there being no rock to graze. ‘MASK’ seems merely a poetical plural, to avoid the repetition of the same termination.

Menelaus is angry at being passed by Antilochus, Il. l. c., but the tears are borrowed from Diomed, ib. 385, when Apollo takes away his whip just as he is trying to pass Eumelus. ‘MASK’ is taken by Forb. as a second dative, epexegetic of ‘MASK MASK’ but it seems simpler to regard it as an abl., as it doubtless is in 9. 66, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” which he quotes.

i. q. “MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ are here the same (comp. vv. 224, 867, below 6. 353), though ‘MASK’ is sometimes (not in Virg.) used of the captain.

‘MASK’ usually means the tiller (“MASK MASK” Serv.): here however we must either give it the sense of the rudder, or suppose that Virg. expresses himself loosely, meaning merely that Gyas turns the tiller so as to bring the ship towards the rock.

Mnestheus talks to his men as Antilochus Il. 23. 403 foll. talks to his horses. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ he mixes with them and addresses them personally.

Forb. seems right in adopting Serv.'s second interpretation of ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK” Mnestheus tells his men that they once fought by the side of Hector, and afterwards, when Troy fell, were chosen by himself as his own comrades. To understand ‘MASK’ as = ‘MASK’ with Heyne (comp. 1. 273, “MASK MASK MASK”) would, as Forb. remarks, be rather feeble, and would make ‘MASK’ somewhat tautologous with ‘MASK MASK’ Mnestheus speaks as if he had raised a company to sail with Aeneas. The time referred to is either that mentioned 2. 799, or that mentioned 3. 8. ‘MASK MASK’ Hor. 2 Ep. 171. So “MASK MASK MASK” 2. 11, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Claud. Eutrop. 2. 289, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Tac. H. 1. 3.

I. e. when they were sailing from Crete, 3. 190 foll. The headland of Malea was proverbially dangerous. Strabo 8. p. 250 has preserved a saying MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ because when the ship was once entangled in them she would find it hard to escape; following the ship, as Serv., not, as Heyne, following each other.

4. 431. There seems a mixture of pride and modesty in Mnestheus' mentioning his own name, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The disclaimer is from Il. 23. 404 foll., where Antilochus says he does not contend with Diomed, who has just been helped miraculously. ‘MASK MASK’ MASK MASK , v. 338.

‘MASK MASK’ is the contraction of a wish, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” or something of the sort. Comp. 11. 415, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The rest of the line is not intended, as Gossrau and Forb. think, for a consolation, as if Mnestheus meant that Cloanthus, who was certain to beat him, would do so by the favour of MASK. Antilochus might express himself so, but no special mark of divine favour had been vouchsafed to Cloanthus, who being second already, had just become first by the misfortune of his rival. The meaning plainly is that in a contest like this it is no disgrace not to be first, but it is to be last; the former contingency cannot be certainly gained, but the latter may be certainly averted; Mnestheus accordingly leaves the one in the hands of MASK, and urges his crew to see to the other.

It is very doubtful whether ‘MASK’ is to be taken together with ‘MASK’ or separately, ‘MASK MASK’ meaning ‘MASK MASK MASK’ The latter is rendered highly probable by an apparent imitation in Sil. 4. 429, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” in the very same context however, v. 412, we find “MASK MASK MASK MASK” while “MASK MASK MASK” occurs Ov. M. 10. 322. Stat. Theb. 6. 181. ‘MASK MASK’ might stand, in the sense of overcoming a disgrace (comp. v. 155 above); but ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as explained above, seems more idiomatic, and brings out better the allusion to the victory that Mnestheus has disclaimed v. 194. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Nor does it seem that Wagn. is right in saying that ‘MASK’ could not stand without a pronoun. Why should it not stand here as well as in 2. 585? Here as there, we may render it ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ indefinitely. ‘MASK’ is merely a strong term used by Mnestheus in his excitement, with no reference, such as Gossrau supposes, to the dishonour done to the deified Anchises by failing in a contest instituted in his honour, a crime which one of the four competitors was certain to commit.

stronger than ‘MASK MASK’ they throw themselves forward. ‘MASK’ of the oars, like “MASK” 10. 208. ‘MASK’ = “MASK” Serv. supposes the word to mean no more than strong, observing that it was the prow, not the stern, that was armed with brass. between Mnestheus and the rock: see on v. 185, and comp. v. 170. ‘MASK MASK’ apparently because he was hemmed in between the rock and his rival's ship close following him. They seem to have sailed out to sea (v. 124), so that there cannot have been a naturally narrow passage between the rock and the shore, as in the parallel case of Antilochus and Menelaus Il. 23. 416 foll. In other respects Sergestus' misfortune resembles that of Eumelus, Il. 23. 391 foll.: see below on v. 270.

dashed against the rock. So of ‘MASK’ MASK , 223. ‘MASK MASK’ being broken, v. 209. ‘MASK MASK’ being entangled in the rock: comp. 10. 303, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Wagn. thinks ‘MASK’ weak, and supposes it either to have some unknown technical force or to be corrupt. It has been suggested to me that the notion may be that of backing water. But surely the simple meaning of the word is significant enough in a passage where we have just had the notion of the highest competitive speed impressed upon us. Instead of straining every nerve to push on, Sergestus' crew is now brought to a standstill, and we know that Mnestheus must be improving the opportunity. ‘MASK MASK’ they cry aimlessly, or perhaps for help, v. 221.

Heins. restored ‘MASK MASK’ which is found in Pal., Rom., and Gud. The old reading ‘MASK’ however is supported by Med. ‘MASK’ is doubtless the better word, as explained by Isid. This line explains how the dove comes to be MASK the cave. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ see on MASK . “MASK MASK MASK” 12. 587. We need not press the termination MASK ‘MASK MASK’ which probably means no more here than adapted for shelter.

is said generally of the direction she takes, applying to the whole of her flight, the circumstances of which are developed MASK the clauses that follow, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ denoting her first fluttering and tumultuous escape, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the after stage, when she recovers herself and flies swiftly and smoothly. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 2. 498. “MASK MASK MASK” below v. 505.

A line well known for its imitative rhythm. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is possibly a translation of “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK , ‘MASK’ being used here not of grazing or skirting a boundary, but of skimming a smooth surface, as in MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” of the race between Hippomenes and Atalanta. This part of the simile is taken from some pleasing lines in MASK foll., where the bird described is a hawk: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Henry is right again in explaining ‘MASK MASK’ of the latter part of the course, that which remained after the goal had been passed. Comp. “MASK MASK MASK” v. 225, and also “MASK MASK” v. 317. Virg. is here speaking generally of MASK' course (just as he spoke generally of the dove's flight in the words “MASK MASK MASK MASK”), contemplating him as he darts rapidly along. Afterwards he steps back, as it were, to regard the various stages through which the hero advances towards success. Sergestus can hardly be said to be in the ‘MASK MASK MASK’ being apparently entangled with the rock which formed the goal before he turns: MASK is not in them while he passes him, but reaches them the moment after, when he leaves his rival behind him, ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is explained by ‘MASK MASK’ in the next line. The force which MASK has employed in the critical moment of turning the goal carries him swiftly on, as it were without further exertion, just as the dove when fairly launched into the sky appears not to be moving her wings. was restored by Heins. from Med. and Rom. for ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the reading of Pal. and Gud. One MS. gives ‘MASK MASK MASK’ and Pierius hints at the possibility of an amphimacer Quinct. 8. 3 speaks of “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
Possibly Virg. may intend a Greek construction, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but it is simpler not to place a comma after ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ like ‘MASK MASK’ already made their own.

In 12. 49 Turnus says to Latinus “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where, though the contrary word is used, the sense is the same. As Heyne well remarks on the latter passage, in the one case a covenant is made about life, as a thing to be given up, in the other a covenant is made about death, as a thing to be undergone. He might have observed further that there is great propriety in the change of terms: Cloanthus and his crew do not look upon death as a serious thing, so that the mention of it would strike a wrong chord: with Turnus death is only too stern a reality.
i. e. ‘MASK MASK’ not as Serv. and some of the later commentators think, ‘MASK MASK’ Their success makes them believe that they have the power, and the belief gives them it. So Henry.

The form of expression is from Hom., who is fond of introducing an unexpected event as something but for which things would have taken a different turn, e. g. Il. 23. 382. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” above v. 157.

In Il. 23. 768 foll. Ulysses wins the foot-race by praying to Athena, by whose special favour Diomed had won the chariot-race (ib. 399). The language of this line is perhaps from Il. 1. 350. For the irregular ‘MASK MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ see Madv. § 495, obs. 2, where instances are given from Caesar, Sallust, and Livy.

“MASK MASK MASK” v. 514 below, 7. 471., 12. 780. The meaning here doubtless is, summons or invites them to be parties to his vow, like “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 3. 222, which Heyne comp.

MASK note. So the victim is said ‘MASK’ MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ MASK note. ‘MASK’ is used in Roman law with a gen. of the thing in respect of which a person is bound, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ &c.: see Forc.

‘MASK’ was the technical term for presenting entrails to the gods, as Macrob. Sat. 3. 2 remarks, citing Veranius, who quotes from the 1st book of Fabius Pictor , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Here, as it is the sea-gods who are invoked, the offering is made by casting the entrails into the sea, a custom also mentioned by Livy 29. 27, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” This application of the word happens to suit the etymology, if it is rightly derived, as Festus thinks, and the form of the word would suggest, from ‘MASK MASK MASK’ instead of being a cognate form of ‘MASK MASK’ Most MSS., including Med. (originally), Pal., Rom., and Gud., give ‘MASK’ a natural variation, recognized by Serv., but expressly condemned by Macrob. l. c. see on MASK . “MASK MASK MASK” 7. 621. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is from Enn. A. 558, preserved by Schol. Veron. here: but Virg. may also have thought of Il. 15. 694, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . Portunus comes in appropriately here as the Roman sea-god, identified with the Greek Melicerta or Palaemon (v. 823 below, MASK ). The announcement of the conqueror in the Greek games was made by the herald. In Homer the competitors seize on their prizes as soon as they come in.
‘MASK’ a rare word, the only other instance being quoted from Lampridius' (one of the Scriptores Historiae Augustae ) life of Commodus 15.

the reading before Heins., is found in Gud. a m. s., and three other of Ribbeck's cursives: but it would be difficult to give it any good sense. Il. 23. 512, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ shows that the reward is given to all the crews, and so ‘MASK MASK MASK’ who are mentioned in contrast. the silver talent was heavier than the gold: see Dict. A. ‘MASK’ Comp. note on v. 112 above, and see on 9. 265.
A ‘MASK’ (Dict. A. s. v.), or scarf embroidered with gold, with a double border of purple.

is from MASK . ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK’ is used metaphorically by Cic. in Pison. 22, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Here it implies that the border (usually called “MASK” 4. 137) was a wavy one. With ‘MASK’ the commentators comp. MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK Il. 6. 320. Comp. also Il. 23. 561, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , which was evidently in Virg.'s mind, though it is said of the border of a breastplate. It is disputed whether MASK is the town of Thessaly, which is evidently intended by Lucr. l. c. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” or an island at the mouth of the Orontes, which was famous for purple-fish. ‘MASK’ is formed from it as an adj. by poetical licence, as in 3. 401 “MASK MASK MASK”

The picture is embroidered on the scarf, not, as Forb. apparently thinks, on the border. ‘MASK’ is loosely constructed with the clause ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as if “MASK MASK” had preceded. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ a local abl. Henry is probably right in supposing that two scenes are represented, Ganymede hunting and Ganymede carried away. Heyne's notion that the early part of the description is merely intended to inform us that the carrying away took place while Ganymede was hunting is inconsistent with ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which is evidently pictorial, at the same time that it could not have been represented as Ganymede's expression while he was in the eagle's talons: and Wagn.'s solution of the knot by saying “MASK MASK MASK MASK” is not very likely in a case like this, where the inconsistency must have been as obvious to the poet as to his readers.

So of the representation of Porsenna on the shield of Aeneas, 8. 649, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ seems to belong to ‘MASK MASK’ as Gossrau thinks, not to ‘MASK’ It thus answers the purpose of telling us that the scenery is the same as in the former representation. ‘MASK’ means no more than swift, without indicating whether the motion is up or down. Ovid is fond of using the word as a subst., like “MASK” (comp. M. 4. 714, where he calls the eagle “MASK MASK”), and this may be the meaning here: but the use occurs nowhere else in Virg., and in 9. 564, where part of v. 255 is repeated, ‘MASK MASK’ is a subst., not an epithet. The story of Ganymede is glanced at in Il. 20. 234, where it is merely said that the gods carried him off for his beauty, that he might dwell with them and be Zeus' cupbearer, and referred to more at length in the Hymn to Aphrodite, vv. 203 foll., where we are told that he was carried away by a storm.
The picture is not unlike that in v. 669 below, where Ascanius' keepers try in vain to hold him. The attitude is that of despairing supplication and appeal to heaven: comp. 2. 405, 406.

v. 546. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is said by Macrob. Sat. 6. 2 to be taken from a passage in Varius, a simile of a dog looking for a deer, where however the resemblance of the thought is entirely general, and the verbal similarity is confined to the words “MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ means more than “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 2. 759, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 6. 561, containing, as Wagn. remarks, not only the notion of the bark ascending to the sky, but that of its being directed against the sky, the dogs baying savagely at the eagle as he loses himself in the clouds, and so at the heaven itself, as they are said to howl at the moon.

Serv. fancies ‘MASK’ is meant to contrast with the favour of the gods by which Cloanthus won. He might have supported the view by quoting Il. 23. 515, MASK , MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK . Virg. however can have had no such meaning, though he doubtless meant to indicate that Mnestheus' place was well won.

The reading of the first two words of this line is involved MASK considerable doubt. ‘MASK MASK’ is found MASK Med. (corrected into ‘MASK’), Pal., Verona fragm., and Gud. a m. p.: “MASK MASK” MASK Rom., Gud. a m. s., and the Medicean of Pierius, supported by Prisc. 861 P, 904 P, and Eutychius 2. 17: ‘MASK MASK’ the common reading before Heins., MASK some old MSS. which Pierius does not name (a suspicious circumstance which throws doubt on many of his readings), and two later copies. Wagn. and the later editors restore ‘MASK MASK’ which they understand of the serpent working itself on with its coils, that being its normal state of motion, which its mutilation retards. The fact however is traversed by Mr. Long, who observes to me that the motion of a serpent is laterally sinuous, not vertically sinuous or MASK coils; and the argument for ‘MASK’ like that for ‘MASK’ 4. 217, is not easily to be resisted, viz. the improbability that Virg., speaking of twines and coils, should have passed over ‘MASK’ and chosen a word so nearly resembling it. ‘MASK MASK’ too will enable us to account readily for the variations: the construction was seen to be an unusual one: so while one set of correctors altered the abl. into the acc., another altered the verb. (Wagn. however argues with some plausibility that ‘MASK’ was first altered into ‘MASK’ as the more natural word, and then ‘MASK’ into ‘MASK MASK’) ‘MASK MASK’ then will be a Virgilian variety for ‘MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ being used intransitively, like other transitive words MASK Virg., and ‘MASK’ a modal abl. is a piece of indirect narrative. The rewarding of Sergestus is parallel to the rewarding of Eumelus Il. 23. 534 foll.

MASK note. ‘MASK’ here merely denotes the extent of the course, which, as we have seen, was probably not a circular one. ‘MASK MASK’ the starting-point, what in the Roman circus would be called the ‘MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK’ The use of the word seems to be only a poetical metaphor of Virg.'s own.

There is probably no reference to a cloud of dust, as in the chariot-race in MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” as here they seem to have run on the grass. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ visu , ’MASK MASK MASK‘ notat et designat oculis . ’” Serv., followed by most commentators. The ellipse however is harsh, and scarcely to be defended from 2. 423, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and the parallel Il. 23. 757, MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK , might suggest another interpretation, the indication of the goal by a line drawn or some other means. The subject of ‘MASK’ then would have to be understood from the context, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ We might have expected ‘MASK MASK’ but Aeneas was standing near the starting-place, and so could not be at the goal. This view seems to be as old as Donatus, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and was once supported by Henry, who has now apparently abandoned it. Forb. objects that the goal ought to be marked out before the start, not simultaneously. This difficulty might be removed by understanding ‘MASK’=‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ but this would be weak in so spirited a passage, so that it would be better to say that either for the sake of variety or to give a greater notion of the rapidity of the proceeding, Virg. represents the line of the goal as being drawn at the very instant at which the competitors start. Those who adhere to the old interpretation may comp. Nestor's advice to Antilochus, Il. 23. 323, where MASK MASK MASK is said of a good charioteer.

‘MASK’ frequently denotes proximity: the peculiarity here is that the proximity is of two persons in motion. ‘MASK’ makes the proximity closer, as in 3. 5. The acc. is most usual in this sense; and Pal. a m. p. actually has ‘MASK MASK’

The picture is from Il. 23. 763 foll.: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK MASK MASK . Virg. has however varied it slightly. The general meaning evidently is that MASK is just a step behind Helymus. It is a question however whether we are to take ‘MASK’ as put for the whole foot (or, which is the same thing, say that ‘MASK’ is used carelessly or hyperbolically where a stricter or more prosaic writer, e. g. Sil. 16. 491, comp. by Henry, would have said the toe), or whether it is meant that the heel of MASK' fore foot came into contact with the heel of Helymus' hind foot. Probably Virg. would himself have been at a loss to say which of these various considerations determined his choice of the word.
the present subj. used rhetorically for the pluperf., as in 6. 293, 294.

= “MASK MASK” Perhaps we may say Diores in passing his predecessor might have crossed his path so as to place himself actually before him. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ comp. v. 151 above. ‘MASK’ seems to be the reading of every known MS., though the common reading, ‘MASK’ was said by Heins. to have been found in all his copies. If by ‘MASK MASK’ is meant to leave the contest undecided, which is the general opinion (Heyne, who adopts it, referring ‘MASK’ to Helymus as a person), there can be little doubt that ‘MASK’ should be read, as it could not be said that in a context like this the two cases could be represented except as alternatives. And this interpretation seems to be exactly confirmed by Il. 23. 382, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK , which Virg. probably had in his mind, as ‘MASK MASK’ seems to be modelled on Hom.'s description in the three lines immediately preceding. But there is another passage which also Virg. had before him, Il. 23. 526, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK , and this would suggest another interpretation of Virg.'s words, proposed long ago by Turnebus 14. 4, apparently adopted by Cerda, and now revived by Henry, who does not seem aware that he has been anticipated, giving ‘MASK’ the special sense of leaving behind in a race, like the passive MASK (comp. Hor. A. P. 417, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and other places), so that the meaning will be ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ i. e. would make him doubtful no longer, but clearly defeated. This view I now accept, as satisfactory in itself and recommended by the unanimous concurrence of the MSS. in ‘MASK MASK’ though, had the preponderance been reversed, I should see no sufficient reason for leaving the ordinary interpretation. Against the new one it may perhaps be urged that it does not bring Virg. into absolute conformity with Hom., who does not mean that Menelaus and Antilochus were MASK as it was, but that Menelaus in a longer course would not only have become MASK but superior, while Virg. on the other hand, as thus interpreted, represents Helymus as already no more than ‘MASK MASK’ and also that the case of Helymus and Diores is more like that of Eumelus and Diomed, who were nearly even from the first, than that of Menelaus and Antilochus, whose places were reversed during the race by an act of fraud, so that Menelaus, in passing his rival, would only have been asserting the intrinsic superiority which he had all along. But these points, though worth considering, do not seem to me sufficient to overbalance the general probability that this line is meant as a translation of Il. 23. 527, not of ib. 382. I have therefore restored ‘MASK MASK’

Nisus' accident is taken from Ajax's Il. 23. 774 foll. Mr. Gladstone (Homeric Studies, 3, p. 521) blames Virg. for introducing the slaughter of oxen here with the word ‘MASK MASK’ without any such reason as is assigned by Hom.l.c., the sacrifice at the tomb of Patroclus. But without going back to the sacrifice nine days before, v. 97, we may suppose not unreasonably that a sacrifice had been performed to Anchises before the games, though Virg., true to his love of variety, even at the expense of perspicuity, has not chosen directly to inform us of it. We need not settle the topography of the circus; but it cannot have been at any great distance from the tomb. ‘MASK’ expresses, not that the slaughter was an ordinary occurrence, but that part of the course happened to pass over the ground where the slaughter had taken place—a thing which is fairly called accidental, as it cannot have been intended. Serv. says, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”—‘MASK’ may be transferred from time to place, as in Catull. 11. 3, comp. by Wagn. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Id. 17. 10, comp. by Cerda, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Virg. however has no other instance of this sense, and ‘MASK MASK’ might be explained here ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as MASK is used sometimes to denote the co-ordination of two things that are really cause and effect.

With some doubt I follow Ribbeck in changing the period after ‘MASK’ into a comma. He is perhaps too rigorous in proscribing the use of the participle as a finite verb (see on 1. 237), though we have as yet to judge him only by his practice, his theory not having been stated: in the present case, however, the change of punctuation adds elegance to the passage, which is thus assimilated to 1. 3, as at present pointed.

is a sort of loose apposition, into which those who have occasion to speak of ‘MASK’ in English not uncommonly fall, identifying the prizeman with the prize. No earlier instance of the expression is quoted, but it has been imitated by later writers, such as Silius: see Forcell. The use of ‘MASK’ in MASK is not quite parallel, as has been there remarked. Here we might have expected the word to be restricted to the victor, see v. 111 above, but it is extended to the three who stand in the relation of victors to the rest, receiving not only presents but prizes. ‘MASK MASK’ having been originally fifth.

Salius' complaint is taken partly from Antilochus' against the decision in favour of Eumelus Il. 23. 541 foll., partly from Menelaus' against Antilochus himself ib. 566. “MASK MASK” 8. 636. Virg. is again using theatric language. The words are from MASK , “MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is again Roman, an allusion to the “MASK MASK MASK MASK” the seats for senators and distinguished persons in the orchestra. ‘MASK’ is used doubtless of the ‘MASK’ as spectators, perhaps also as expressers of a favourable or adverse opinion. But its combination with ‘MASK’ is harsh, as the meaning cannot be that they echo Salius ' clamours. There is a good parallel to the whole line below, v. 577, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but the harshness in “MASK MASK” is considerably less.

is not quite co-ordinate with ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ as the enthusiasm of the spectators was doubtless caused by Euryalus' graceful bearing: but it is possible that previous partiality may be meant. For the special use of ‘MASK’ for theatrical enthusiasm see Forc. Euryalus' are tears at the threatened loss of his victory.

Med. a m. p., Rom., ‘MASK’ Med. a m. s., and two of Ribbeck's cursives, ‘MASK’ Pal. The subj., as Wagn., who restored it, remarks, expresses Diores' feeling on the matter. Forb. objects that in that case we should have expected ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ to be in the oratio obliqua also, as equally forming part of Diores' plea. But Diores' plea is not really contained in those words, which are intended to express not the ground which he put forward in his appeal, but the reason why he made an appeal at all. On the other hand the indic., though more regular, would have been comparatively tame. The union of the two forms of expression is grammatically irregular, no doubt: but here as elsewhere the violation of grammar is a gain to rhetorical and poetical effect. We are told that Diores is speaking: we are reminded of what his real grievance is, not in his own words, but in those which would occur to a third person; and then we just catch, as it were, a few of the words which he actually utters. ‘MASK’ as his due, v. 386 below.

In Hom. Achilles would have given the second prize to Eumelus if Antilochus, who had gained it, had not protested: as it is, he gives an extra reward (Il. 23. 536—565). With ‘MASK’ &c. Aeneas' laughter partakes both of the smile of Achilles at Antilochus' humorous petulance, Il. 23. 555, and the mirth of the Greeks at Ajax's rueful appearance after his fall, ib. 784. ‘MASK’ with dative MASK . Med. a m. p. has ‘MASK MASK’

from the ships. MASK . . . MASK MASK Il. 23. 564. Didymaon is not known otherwise as an artist. In Val. F. 3. 707 he appears as a warrior. ‘MASK’ of works of art, Hor. 4 Od. 8. 5 &c. The pl. is here used rather than the sing. for the sake of poetical variety, the artist's labour being regarded in detail rather than as a whole. Pal. and Rom. however have ‘MASK MASK’ Gossrau remarks that a shield may derive its reputation either from an illustrious maker or from an illustrious possessor. With the apposition he well comp. 8. 729, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

The meaning is generally supposed to be that the shield had been fastened by the Greeks on the gate of a temple of Neptune as an offering from their spoils, and reclaimed thence by Aeneas. But it is not so easy to see how this is to be obtained from the words. Serv. says “‘ MASK , ’MASK MASK” which later commentators adopt, seemingly mistaking his meaning (Ladewig is an exception), which is that the shield was torn down from a Trojan temple by the soldiers of Pyrrhus, and given by Helenus to Aeneas. This would give a satisfactory construction: but the story which it tells is indirect, even for Virg. If we accept the sense given above, I have only to suggest that ‘MASK MASK’ may be a pregnant construction, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though I have no satisfactory parallel to adduce. Aeneas himself hangs up in a Greek temple a shield taken from a Greek chief, 3. 286 foll. Cerda comp. Hor. 1 Od. 28. 11, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 1 Ep. 18. 56, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Lersch § 50 quotes two instances from Livy of spoils thus removed from a temple 22. 57., 24. 21; but both of them are cases where men in want of arms take down offerings hung up in their own temples, as David takes the sword of Goliath.

Comp. also Il. 13. 713 MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , where courage seems to be the notion. ‘MASK MASK’ may go with ‘MASK’ as well as with ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but it signifies little. is variously taken to mean either ‘MASK MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The first would be more natural so far as mere language goes: but no instances are quoted of fillets intertwined with gold, whereas bullocks with gilded horns were not unfrequently offered in sacrifice, as in 9. 627, Hom. Od. 3. 384. The custom belonged to the old Romans no less than to the Greeks of the heroic time. Lersch Antiqq. Verg. § 63 refers to the Tables of the Fratres Arvales 19. 7 &c. We must then suppose ‘MASK’ to be used with both by a kind of zeugma, which is not unnatural. Hom. has MASK MASK MASK . The process is described ib. vv. 432 foll.

So in Il. 23. 664 foll. Epeus comes forward at once. Virg. has softened the traits of his original, as the Homeric champion is more boastful and self-confident than Dares, and more successful also. ‘MASK MASK’ without ‘MASK’ would have been more usual: the addition of the preposition however seems to give the notion that he rose with all his bulk about him, as we might say. The expressions classified by Madv. § 257 obss. are not quite of the same kind. We may however comp. the use of MASK , as in Hom. Od. 24. 192, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .

= “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ of approbation. Serv. ingeniously suggests that the lines that follow contain the substance of what the people whisper: but the rules of construction will not admit this. We may however thank the critic for the hint, as Virg. may have intended us to fill up his description in this way, though there is nothing in his words to indicate it.

We hear nothing of Paris' pugilistic skill in Hom.: other accounts however made him excel in athletic sports, the story being that having been brought up among shepherds, he first made himself known to his father by proving himself the conqueror in all of a series of games instituted by the king. (Hygin. Fabb. 91. 273.) It is remarkable that the champion in Il. 23. 670, proclaiming his own prowess, admits that he is inferior as a warrior: MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK ; MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .

Both the use of ‘MASK MASK’ elsewhere in Virg., and the requirements of the present passage oblige us to take ‘MASK MASK’ here not ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but ‘MASK MASK MASK’ so that it is to be constructed as if it were “MASK MASK MASK MASK” or “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Comp. 7. 750 with ib. 803. It is more to the point to say that the pugilist was a descendant of the mythic champion Amycus, whom Pollux conquered and killed, than that he was merely one of the same nation. ‘MASK MASK’ a poetical variety for ‘MASK’ as Amycus was king of the Bebryces: comp. 6. 2., 7. 207, 209.— This description of the champion, as Heyne remarks, is modelled on Il. 23. 679, where Euryalus, the less fortunate candidate, is characterized as having come to Thebes to the funeral of Oedipus, and having there conquered all the natives.

Rom. has ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ seems a frigid epithet, like “MASK MASK” 2. 483. If we could suppose the mention of Dares' exploits to have been actually made by the spectators, the epithet might pass as one of those details which sometimes associate themselves in the memory with more important events, and so might have a psychological truth. Such a thing however is not likely to have occurred to Virg., whose style of art is different: so we must put down the use of the epithet to an unseasonable imitation of Homeric simplicity. More might have been said for it had it occurred in the course of the ordinary narrative, as there many details may bear to be enumerated, whereas in a brief recollection like this only the more important points can properly be noticed. In 9. 589 however, where the words are partially repeated, the epithet is exchanged for a less prominent, though not less expressive one, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Ov. M. 10. 716 (quoted by Forb.) has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” of the death of Adonis, where there is some force in the epithet, as used by a lively colourist, suggesting as it does a contrast with the white flesh and the red blood. ‘MASK’ like MASK Eur. Med. 585, of laying low.

MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , which may have led to the use of ‘MASK’ here and in v. 436 of a blow irrespectively of the wound given. ‘MASK’ seemingly means without producing a decided effect, not that the blows were parried, as the next three lines appear intended, as Heyne remarks, to express in detail what is here put generally.

It is doubtful whether ‘MASK’ is neuter here, as in MASK , ‘MASK MASK’ being the subject, or active, as in v. 457 below. The latter is rather more natural; but there is some awkwardness in taking, as we must then take, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ of producing sounds from their adversary's breast. An imitation in Stat. Theb. 1. 418, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” is in favour of the active sense. One MS. gives ‘MASK MASK’ but ‘MASK’ is against this. He eludes the blows not by moving his legs, like Dares (v. 430), but by a slight motion of the body aided by constant vigilance. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ effugere ’MASK MASK’ seems to have been a phrase. Taubm. quotes Cic. 1 Cat. 6, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is a natural extension of the metaphor in ‘MASK MASK’ referring to the caestus. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ because watchfulness would be all the more needed where the combatant did not change his posture. For ‘MASK’ comp. 11. 750, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” The general notion is that of getting out of the way of a thing, as in MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” whence it comes to be used of evading, and even, as in 11. 750 just quoted, of repelling.

Entellus is apparently playing a defensive game at this part of the contest, while Dares attacks. The comparison is Virg.'s own. Apoll. has two others, one of a wave threatening to overwhelm a ship which succeeds in avoiding it, MASK foll., another of two men hammering at the same timber, MASK foll. ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ works of offence. Gossrau comp. Livy 2. 17, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” See also 9. 711.

like ‘MASK MASK’ is the technical term for a blockade. Here however a siege is obviously meant. ‘MASK MASK’ (= ‘MASK MASK’ v. 585) may possibly be meant to express as much by qualifying the verb. Forb. however quotes from Val. Max. 7. 4, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where a blockade is evidently intended.

I incline to refer these two lines to Dares, not to the subjects of the two comparisons, as the omission of the apodosis of the comparison would be awkward here, where there is no complication of clauses to excuse it. Virg. has however chosen to express what Dares does in language proper only to the case of those with whom he has just compared him. The comparison in fact helps us to the metaphor. ‘MASK’ seems to belong to ‘MASK’ by a kind of zeugma, as we should have expected ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ With the language comp. 11. 766. Rom. has ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

MASK now leaves the defensive, and attacks. The circumstance is from MASK foll., where Amycus aims a crushing blow at Pollux, who partially avoids it. ‘MASK’ seems to mean little more than ‘MASK MASK’ though there may be, as Serv. thinks, a more or less distinct reference to the slow prepared character of the old man's blow, which has the effect of preparing his adversary. ‘MASK MASK’ comp. v. 425 above, 11. 697., 12. 728 foll., 902.
The motion here is something more than that intended in v. 438, as ‘MASK’ shows.

is not simply a proverbial expression for wasting his strength, but has a strict propriety here. Dares evaded the blow altogether, which fell with all its force on the air and so caused Entellus to lose his balance. Comp. Catull. 62 (64). 111, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” of the Minotaur attempting to wound his enemy but only wounding the air, a passage which Virg. had MASK his mind, as we shall see on v. 448. ‘MASK MASK’ without any impulse from Dares. Forb. explains it ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which is not improbable.

As in v. 118 above, the same thought is enforced twice by a partially verbal repetition. Virg. was perhaps thinking of MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” We may strengthen the false distinction if we like by connecting ‘MASK’ closely with ‘MASK MASK’ discriminating the heaviness of the man more sharply from the heaviness of his fall; but ‘MASK’ may be intended to repeat the notion of ‘MASK MASK’ or, if Forb. be right on the preceding verse, to add to it the notion of spontaneity. For this use of the copula to connect an adjunct which is not a predicate with one that is, comp. 2. 86 note, note on v. 498 below.

Aeneas' address, as Heyne remarks, is modelled on Poseidon's to Aeneas himself, after he had rescued him from Achilles, Il. 20. 332 foll. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK . MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . MASK . MASK . Il. l. c.

has been variously understood, most taking it of Entellus' power, which has been changed, either simply increased, or superseded by divine power, while Peerlkamp understands it of Dares', which has been diminished. The former is supported by an imitation in Val. Fl. 4. 125, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where the meaning evidently is strength of a different grade from Amycus'. But for this authority, I should prefer taking the words more generally, making ‘MASK MASK’ the human equivalent to ‘MASK MASK MASK’—“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” This would certainly answer to the parallel passage in Il. 20. 334, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . The objection to understanding it of a new, i. e. divine power brought on the scene seems to lie in ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as it would be awkward to say that the gods generally turned against Dares when a god helped his antagonist. Virg. evidently thought also of Il. 8. 140, MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK ; though the verbal resemblance is not close enough to enable us to fix his precise meaning. Lucan, 7. 648, seems to have had Virg. in his mind, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

can hardly be pressed with Serv., as if it meant that they were too humbled or too busy to come without a summons. rising to the stroke Comp. v. 443 note. Rom. omits ‘MASK’ an omission approved by one or two earlier critics, and adopted by Ladewig after Fleckeisen in Jahn's Jahrb. 61, p. 32. Comp. v. 167, where the omission of ‘MASK’ after ‘MASK’ rests on the same authority, is approved by nearly the same critics, and must be vindicated on the same grounds, as likely to have been altered by those who did not understand the metrical licence. Here however, putting aside the question of accidental omission, which probably after all may be the true account, there is the counter probability that ‘MASK’ may have been left out by some one who did not understand the construction ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ For other instances of ‘MASK MASK’ see Forc. ‘MASK MASK’ breaking into the skull and scattering the brains. Turneb. Adv. 14. 4 &c. explains ‘MASK’ by the Greek custom of propitiating the gods when a second victim, for any reason, had to be substituted for a first, by exclaiming MASK MASK . Whether such a custom prevailed in Rome (where substituted victims were called ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK’), is not stated: but the illustration seems plausible enough. So Turneb. explains 12. 296, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” There may also be some contempt intended to Dares in the word, the allusion being, as Germ. thinks, to the trial of the victim (see on 4. 61), which Plutarch calls MASK MASK MASK . ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Serv. apparently thinks the bull is called ‘MASK’ merely as compared with unbloody sacrifices. Peerlkamp conj. ‘MASK MASK’ comparing Ov. F. 6. 162, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” said of a young pig sacrificed for a child. If we could suppose this to have been a common expression, we might consider that Virg. alluded to it, without adopting it.

a sacrificial term, 8. 62. Rom. and one or two others give ‘MASK MASK’ Entellus hangs up his arms to Eryx as an ‘MASK’ like Horace 3 Od. 26. 3 foll. to Venus, Veianius Hor. 1 Ep. 1. 4 foll. to Hercules. Trapp bestows just praise on Dryden's rendering of Entellus' speech. The passage is worth quoting, expressing as it does the veteran combatant's feelings as conceived by the veteran poet. The chord struck is not quite the same as that struck by Virgil, but they are very noble lines: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

The archery match follows Hom. closely, vv. 850 foll., except that there it is a match between two, one of whom divides the cord, the other kills the bird —the odd thing being that the result is apparently foreseen by Achilles, who offers the inferior prize for the former feat, the superior for the latter. With this and the next line comp. vv. 291, 292.
With Ribbeck I have restored ‘MASK’ from Pal. and Gud., supposing ‘MASK’ (Med., Rom., Verona fragm.) to have been introduced from a recollection of v. 292. See on 1. 668., 4. 564.

Serv. explains ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK” and others have thought of taking ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ It clearly however belongs to ‘MASK MASK’ and is to be taken like “MASK MASK” v. 241, “MASK MASK” 11. 556 (of Metabus), the Homeric MASK MASK , expressing the gigantic stature of the hero, “MASK MASK” 6. 413, and showing how he could set up the mast himself. Serestus is apparently the same who was mentioned 4. 288, his ship not having engaged in the contest. It must be confessed however that this passage affords a strong argument for identifying him with Sergestus, whose shattered vessel might naturally be utilized in this manner. The mast is taken from the ship, ‘MASK MASK’ and set up on the sand, Hom. v. 853.

winged, implies the notion of fluttering, like “MASK MASK” MASK . the competitors. ‘MASK MASK’ occurs Caes. B. C. 1. 6, quoted by Gossrau. “‘Deiectas sortes’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Heyne. the place, for the lot fixing the place. ‘MASK MASK’ after ‘MASK’ 2. 40 &c. ‘MASK’ like MASK MASK Il. 3. 325, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK Il. 7. 182. Hippocoon seems to be brother to Nisus, who was also son of Hyrtacus, 9. 177. In Il. 2. 837 we have MASK MASK , who comes from Arisbe. Hippocoon is not otherwise known.
“MASK MASK” Juv. 2. 73. ‘MASK MASK’ though he was only the second winner.

All the naval competitors, or at least three out of four, got some kind of chaplet, v. 269. Cloanthus is crowned with bay (v. 246): possibly the others had each a different kind of wreath, the distinction being intentional. The three prizemen in the foot-race however are all crowned with olive, v. 309, so that it is also possible that Virg. may have mentioned olive inadvertently here, forgetting that he had made bay the naval wreath.
MASK is not known otherwise. He is appropriately made the brother of Pandarus, the great archer (‘MASK’） of the early part of the Iliad, the special favourite of Apollo (Il. 2. 827., 5. 105).

by Athene. The story is told Il. 4. 86 foll. “MASK MASK MASK” 12. 290, where the broken truce between Latins and Trojans is copied from the broken truce between Trojans and Greeks. ‘MASK’ is a translation of Homer's own expression, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , Il. 4. 269.
of shooting 11. 773., 12. 461 (modelled on the present line). Pandarus did not shoot at random, but aimed at Menelaus, whom he struck.

and ‘MASK MASK’ virtually express the same thing by different grammatical forms. Grammatically they would be classed as different parts of the same sentence, requiring no copulative to join them, as they are not strictly speaking co-ordinate. Virg. however has chosen to unite them by ‘MASK MASK’ as in 10. 734, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” an almost exact parallel quoted by Wagn. Q. V. 34. There “MASK” is connected with “MASK MASK” but not so closely as “MASK MASK” which forms part of the grammatical construction: here ‘MASK’ is connected with ‘MASK’ but not so closely as ‘MASK MASK MASK’ With ‘MASK MASK MASK’ comp. the stories of persons throwing clods of earth as their lots into helmets full of water, that the lots might not be shaken out, MASK , MASK . ‘MASK’ for the lot of Acestes, a very natural identification, common not only in poetical but in familiar English. Burm. and Heyne read ‘MASK MASK’ which seems to have no MS. authority, and is intrinsically inferior here.

“MASK MASK MASK” 11. 505. ‘MASK’ here seems to have the notion of force, its general sense in Virg., as the two words ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ both seem to show. ‘MASK’ Med. a m. pr., which has been praised as an elegance, but is obviously an error in writing. showed its fear by fluttering and clapping its wings. Comp. v. 215 above. Here ‘MASK’ is constructed as an abl. of the part affected with ‘MASK MASK MASK’ The novelty consists in connecting a verb expressive of mental action with an abl. of a part of the body. Neither ‘MASK MASK’ nor ‘MASK MASK’ would have been at all remarkable.

“‘ MASK : ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. Heyne, Gossrau, and Forb., however understand ‘MASK’ of the wings, as in the parallel v. 215. But Virg. translated Hom. v. 869, MASK MASK MASK , though he has transferred the applause from the shot which cut the cord to that which struck the mast: in each case however it is the first shot that draws the plaudits forth, naturally enough.

Both here and in v. 513 Virg. has had his eye on Homer's description of the second shot with which Meriones kills the dove after Teucer had cut the cord. The lines, as they appear in our editions, are difficult, as it would seem that Meriones shot with the same bow as Teucer, but that he had taken aim with his arrow, which he held in the same place, even while snatching the bow from Teucer's hand. MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK : MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . Eustath. however tells us that in the Marseille recension, MASK MASK MASK , the lines were read MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK : MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . We cannot tell what reading Virg. had in his copy of Homer; but at any rate he has given his competitors a bow apiece. ‘MASK MASK’ keen; not quite the same as MASK , ‘MASK MASK’ as Mnestheus had not the same occasion for haste. ‘MASK MASK’ may be illustrated by Il. 4. 123, MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK . ‘MASK’ is here put of the whole, string as well as bow, the string of course being that which he drew to him. See on 9. 632. ‘MASK MASK’ took his stand. “MASK MASK” in a different sense MASK note. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ seems to mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The latter action would precede the former, but might continue along with it. “MASK MASK” 2. 485. “MASK MASK” we have just had v. 489. Pandarus, having been a great champion in life, is regarded after death as a deified patron of archery, at least within his own family, as Eryx is Entellus' patron of boxing. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ note on v. 234 above.

MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , Hom. v. 874. Hom. keeps his perpetual epithet: Virg. substitutes ‘MASK MASK’ The clapping of the wings which follows seems to be a sound of joy. The arrow strikes her while in the midst of her exultation. Hom. however mentions the wing as the part where she was struck, v. 875. ‘MASK’ expresses that she was high up in the air, with no other object near her. Comp. MASK note. It cannot be paralleled with “MASK MASK” MASK , which seems to imply freedom from clouds.

Hom.'s description is more detailed: the arrow passes through the bird, and falls at Meriones' feet: the bird settles on the mast, droops her neck, drops her wings, dies, and falls at a distance (vv. 876—881).

was read before Heins. The confusion naturally arose from the change of the text in v. 518. ‘MASK’ Med., Rom. (first reading), ‘MASK’ Pal., Med. (second reading). Difficulties about the metre or about the sense of ‘MASK’ have led to varieties in the MSS., “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK” For the force of ‘MASK’ see above on v. 130. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ i. e. he displays his art by making his bow sound, the loudness and shrillness of the sound being the test of his skill and strength. Perhaps also there may be a reference, as Forb. thinks, to the goodness of the bow.

The meaning seems to be, as most of the editors have seen, that what then came to pass was really a portent of evil, though not understood so at the time, its true meaning being taught by the event, when the prophets of the day pointed out the connexion between the omen and its fulfilment. Aeneas, immediately on its appearance, as we shall see (v. 530), interprets it favourably, but what happened subsequently showed that he was mistaken. What then was the event portended? The old interpretation was, the burning of the ships: but this disaster, soon over and soon repaired, would hardly suit v. 524, which points apparently to something more terrible and more distant. Wagn. supposes it to be the impending war in Italy; but Acestes had nothing to do with this either as actor or as sufferer. It seems more probable that Heyne is right in referring it to the wars between Rome and Sicily. But there is no need to fix it at all, as long as we regard it as identified with some adequate occurrence in the subsequent history of Sicily. Wagn. censures the awkwardness of alluding to something extraneous to the poem and not specified; but Gossrau remarks that Virg. is probably not inventing this story of the portent and its supposed accomplishment, but repeating what he found in a legend. Med., Pal., Gud., Rom., and others have ‘MASK MASK’ as Med., Pal., and Verona fragm. have in 2. 680: wrongly in both places. The awkwardness of the connexion “MASK MASK” might be got over (see above on v. 498); but ‘MASK’ would create an inexcusable ambiguity with ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ itself is not strictly co-ordinate with ‘MASK MASK’ being a predicate. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ strictly speaking the thing was an ‘MASK’ already, but as it was not understood as such, its augurial character is spoken of as future. In other words ‘MASK’ points to the estimation of the thing, not to its nature. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” 7. 146, the epithet being equally applicable to good and evil.

does not of itself indicate the omen to be a bad one: comp. 2. 680, above referred to. Here it probably refers not to any thing future, but to the impression made on the spectators, who recognized it as a thing supernatural, but did not understand its character (vv. 529 foll.).

See on v. 522. is a sort of epexegesis of ‘MASK’—MASK its flight, MASK the sky. Henry complains of other editors, who, from Serv. downwards, say that ‘MASK’ = ‘MASK MASK’ understanding the words himself of the untroubled clouds of a sunny sky as opposed to the turbid clouds of wintry weather. But vv. 512, 516 seem to show that Virg. had no such notion definitely before his mind, if indeed he did not mean expressly to exclude it. Here as MASK 7. 699 (referred to by Forb.), “MASK MASK MASK” (if the reading is certain), I take ‘MASK’ to be used not of a clear sky as opposed to clouds, or of one kind of cloud as distinguished from another, but generally of clouds as opposed to solid matter like earth.

seems to include both doubt and fixedness of attitude. They prayed that the omen might be for good, not for harm: comp. 3. 34 foll.

The Greek and Roman belief was that if a favourable interpretation could be put on an appearance, it would turn to good. Hence the phrases MASK MASK MASK , ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Serv. says “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Why MASK allows himself to accept this omen has been questioned: but he probably interpreted it on the analogy of that in Book 2 already referred to. ‘MASK’ seems to mean that Acestes, proud of his feat, was himself quite ready to accept the favourable view. Rom. has ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which arises from the spelling ‘MASK’ See on 4. 312.
“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 3. 485. The ‘MASK MASK’ here seem to be the single present mentioned in the speech, unless we choose to include the laurel-wreath.

Acestes had been the occasion of an omen which was interpreted as a good one, and it might be supposed that Jupiter by connecting a supernatural phenomenon with his shot, had recognized it as something better than the best. The speech to Acestes is modelled on that with which Achilles gives Nestor the prize that had remained over from the chariot-race, which is itself a bowl, MASK MASK (Il. 23. 615 foll.), with a glance also at Achilles' compliment to Agamemnon, ib. vv. 890 foll., to whom he gives a prize on his mere appearance as a competitor, begging him not to enter the contest. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK , MASK , MASK MASK , Il. 23. 618. In his reply Nestor calls Achilles MASK , v. 626.

Rom., Pal., Med. a m. pr., Gud. a m. pr.; ‘MASK’ Med. a m. sec., Gud. a m. sec. The latter was the old reading before Heins., and Wagn. has restored it. The corrections seem to show that both readings belong to old rescensions, so that the decision between them must turn on intrinsic considerations. These again are as nearly balanced as may be, as both sing. and pl. are equally good and Virgilian, as Wagn. remarks, comp. vv. 342, 347. Nor is there any thing to show which of the two is the more likely to have been altered: the sing. may have been changed to discriminate ‘MASK’ from ‘MASK MASK’ the pl. to assimilate it. If we adopt ‘MASK MASK’ it had better be constructed with ‘MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 8. 552, and the Greek phrases MASK MASK MASK , MASK , MASK (Lidd. and Scott MASK ). The proper application of the word is to a thing exempted from the ordinary division of the spoil by lot and given to some distinguished person. Here it is applied to the extra prize, of superior value to the rest, which is given to Acestes as an extraordinary thing. ‘MASK MASK’ see on v. 385 above, and comp. 8. 552 (note). Here there seems to be a further reference to the phrase “MASK MASK MASK” as if to say that Acestes was to draw a prize without the risk of drawing. For similar extensions of meaning see on 1. 508., 2. 201, and comp. Prop. 4. 21. 12, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” with Paley's note. Achilles says to Nestor 1. c. MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .

Henry, in a long comment, sets forth the peculiar beauties of this new show with great judgment and delicacy of perception. It was a special boon from MASK to the spectators, who had not been told to expect it in the programme of the games (above vv. 66 foll.)—a custom not uncommon in the actual games MASK Rome , where a surprise was sometimes contrived for the people (Henry comp. Pliny, Paneg. 33)—and it formed a peculiarly graceful contrast to the violent exertion and passionate striving of competitive sports among men, besides being an appropriate compliment to Augustus, who revived this very sport (Suet. Aug. 43), and a pleasing memento to the great Romans, whose sons had exhibited themselves as the young Trojans, their progenitors, are made to do. ‘MASK MASK’ v. 130. Here there is of course a further reference to MASK' relation to Ascanius. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ v. 286. MASK gives his directions before the shooting-match is over, that the procession may come on MASK once, and the surprise be complete, the spectators not having had time to think of separating.
of senior attendants 11. 33, of “MASK” 10. 703.

This line presents great difficulty. The natural way of understanding would seem to be that all have their hair bound (comp. 4. 148, “MASK MASK MASK”） with a wreath of stripped leaves (‘MASK MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ comp. v. 774, MASK note). But how is this to be reconciled with their wearing helmets (v. 673)? Wreaths were sometimes put over the helmet, as appears from 7. 751, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” which would agree with ‘MASK’ here, that being probably a sign that oliveleaves are meant (v. 774 &c.). But MASK that case the hair must be confined by the helmet, not by the wreath. Cerda proves from MASK , Fast. 3. 2 that ‘MASK’ would naturally be said of the pressure of a helmet (comp. also 9. 612, “MASK MASK MASK”), as ‘MASK’ of its removal; but this will not help us here, unless we are to suppose that Virg. is thinking of wreath and helmet both, while only mentioning the former. Peerlkamp apparently considers the wreath to be under the helmet, to which Forb. answers, that MASK that case the helmet would not fit. But it seems possible that there might be a wreath worn just below the helmet, so as not to interfere with it— a variety of the custom mentioned 7. 751. And MASK this interpretation I incline to acquiesce, till a better shall have been proposed. Henry, following Gesner MASK his Thesaurus, thinks the meaning is that the hair of the boys was cut round, as was that of the Roman boys (a custom expressed by ‘MASK MASK’ according to Virg.'s usual habit of ascribing Roman usages to the Trojans). He compares the words used by St. Jerome MASK translating and commenting on Ezekiel 44. 20, where the poll of the Jewish priests is spoken of (a mode of wearing the hair which he believes to have been as nearly as possible the same as that MASK use among the Roman boys), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” the use of ‘MASK’ for pruning or lopping leaves ( MASK &c.), and that of ‘MASK’ MASK modern Italian for pollarding a tree. But these parallelisms are by no means equal MASK value to those adduced MASK support of the other interpretation: and moreover the passage, so interpreted, would be inconsistent with 10. 137, where we are expressly told that Ascanius' hair was not cropped, but only confined by a gold band. ‘MASK MASK’ which he thinks cannot refer to any peculiarity of the game, this being its first exhibition, need merely mean ‘MASK MASK MASK’ implying that all observed the fashion, established as it was then for the first time. seems here virtually for “MASK MASK” the cardinal number for the ordinal. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” are found in enumerations (see Forc. ‘MASK’): and here Virg. has put ‘MASK’ and followed it by ‘MASK MASK’ which is an ordinal, not a cardinal. ‘MASK’ is used more or less strictly, indicating a quasi-triumphal procession, as in 6. 589.

“MASK MASK MASK” 12. 348, a passage which will illustrate at once the custom referred to, especially common in Greece (Aristoph. Birds 283, Thuc. 8. 6 &c.), of giving the grandson the grandfather's name, and the language in which it is expressed. ‘MASK’ seems here, as there, to mean ‘MASK’ It might also mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ owning, possessing, which is perhaps its meaning in 7. 49, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though there other meanings might be suggested, ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ as in Martial 5. 17. 1, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (comp. with this passage by Gossrau), or by a mercantile metaphor, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ a variety for “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Such are the uncertainties of the interpretation of a single word where there is no doubt of the general meaning—uncertainties perhaps complicated by the possibility that Virg. himself, according to the peculiarity so often illustrated, may have intended to shadow forth more meanings than one. Pal. a m. p., has ‘MASK MASK’ Pal. a m. p., Med. a m. p., and Rom. ‘MASK MASK’ For Polites see 2. 526. The use of the vocative here, as in 7. 49 just referred to, will show that this form of expression is not always adopted by Virg. for metrical reasons alone.

The name of Polites was connected by legend with various parts of Italy, some accounts representing him as a companion of Ulysses (Od. 10. 224), others as a companion of Aeneas. See Serv. here, and Lewis, Credibility of Rom. Hist., vol. 1, p. 329. Virg. having represented him as killed by Pyrrhus, naturally introduces his son here. ‘MASK’ perhaps includes the notion of bringing honour to the Italian nations as well as that of swelling their numbers. Thrace abounded in horses (comp. the horses of Rhesus), and is called MASK by Hes. Works 507, as Cerda remarks. With the threefold reiteration of ‘MASK’ Gossrau comp. 1. 448. It is not clear whether the ‘MASK’ here refer generally to what is afterwards expressed in detail, the white pasterns and white star on the forehead, or to other spots on other parts of the body. If the parallel just cited from A. 1 could be pressed, it would support the latter view.

poetically for the feet themselves, as in Catull. 62 (64). 162, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is explained by Cerda of the fore feet: but Taubm. saw that it meant the fore part or pastern of each leg.

The introduction of MASK as the supposed founder of the Atian gens is a compliment to Augustus, whose mother was an Atia. The special attachment of Iulus to him is another stroke of compliment, as if the future union of the two houses were prefigured even then. MASK is not otherwise known as connected with Troy : but the name occurs in Livy's enumeration (1. 3) of the kings of Alba. ‘MASK MASK’ either for ‘MASK MASK’ or, as Heins. suggests, because the MASK came from Aricia. ‘MASK’ may be either gen., as “MASK” probably is v. 117, or nom. agreeing with ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” v. 123. The latter here is the simpler and more natural. ‘MASK’ is a correction in Med.

like “MASK MASK” 3. 329, “MASK MASK” 1. 684. Med.(? Ribbeck is silent) and another MS. have ‘MASK MASK’ which Jahn thinks may be explained of choosing into the band: but ‘MASK’ is obviously right. The commentators inquire why Atys' horse is not mentioned, and suggest that Virg. has not completed the passage, as v. 574 shows. But we have had a parallel omission v. 118 (note), and Virg.'s love of variety will account for both.
Virg. uses ‘MASK MASK’ with a positive, as here, with a comparative, as 1. 347, and with a superlative, as 7. 55.

F. 2. 6) assigned by my friend Mr. Coxe to the early part of the twelfth century, the others later; so that, whatever the pedigree of the reading, it is not posterior to the invention of printing. There can be little doubt of its truth, as ‘MASK MASK’ which Ribbeck adopts, would be extremely flat, ‘MASK MASK’ if constructed with ‘MASK MASK’ contrary to the sense. “MASK MASK” v. 301, where, as here, the epithet is intended to mark a contrast.
simply, rides: not as in 1. 476, MASK , where the passive is emphatic, expressing a negation of action.

welcome them on their entry. Virg., as Henry remarks, goes back to v. 555, the intermediate lines simply describing their appearance as they were seen to enter, not any thing that they did after entering.

may either mean simply elder, as contrasted with the youth of the boys, or it may show that ‘MASK’ is not to be restricted to parents, but includes remoter ancestry. Thus the young Priam may have reminded the spectators of his grandfather.
