“MASK MASK MASK” 11. 190. There may be a reference to the use of the word ‘MASK’ for a review (Dict. A. s. v.), though the troops were there ‘MASK’ themselves, and did not ‘MASK’ others.

MASK, the loud-voiced herald (see on v. 547), gives a signal shout which can be heard at a distance, and cracks his whip. “MASK MASK” 7. 451. The two phrases differ no more than when we say ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK MASK’

Henry has explained this passage by supposing the three ‘MASK’ each to divide into two parts, ‘MASK MASK’ of six horsemen each, one part retiring (say) to the right, another to the left, after which the three right ‘MASK’ and the three left turn about and severally charge each other. Heyne thought that ‘MASK MASK MASK’ perhaps meant each splits into four companies of three horsemen each, which would complicate the picture needlessly: Wagn. and Forb. suppose no more to be meant than that the three ‘MASK MASK’ having been together while they passed in procession, now separate: but, as Henry remarks, the previous context, so far from leading us to suppose that they ever formed into one, distinctly suggests the contrary. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ according to Virg.'s wont, is explained by the following clause. There is something antithetical in the combination of the two words, ‘MASK’ alone suggesting the notion of irregular dispersion (9. 164., 12. 590), as if it had been said “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ being distributed into three, that being as it were the basis of their ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK MASK’ they separate, keeping their original distinction into three, so that there are not simply two companies, right and left, but three pairs of companies. One difficulty remains which Henry has not noticed: when the three companies are divided into pairs, there are still only three leaders. This may not be fatal to the interpretation; but it can only be met by charging Virg. with an oversight.

the reading of Rom. and Med., was adopted by Jahn: but ‘MASK’ is necessary to the sense, and ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ are so frequently confused that MS. authority on the point goes for nothing, even if ‘MASK’ were not found in Pal. See on MASK , 354 &c. There seems nothing technical about the word ‘MASK MASK’ which is simply a poetical equivalent for a company, so that it may apply either to the “MASK” (‘MASK MASK’ = “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”), or to the divisions of the “MASK” produced by the “MASK” The latter seems the neater, as enabling us to realize better the three pairs of companies. ‘MASK MASK’ by their captains, or perhaps by Epytides, as Serv. explains it, “MASK MASK MASK”

is used both of flight and of rallying after a flight: see Forc. Here it expresses something analogous to the latter, being applied to the ‘MASK’ wheeling about after having retired right and left. “MASK MASK MASK” 12. 252. “MASK” 2. 529, here with ‘MASK MASK’

Henry thinks that in these three lines another definite picture is presented, the ‘MASK’ severally wheeling about, one set (say) E. and W., another W. and E., and thus meeting in the middle of the ‘MASK MASK’ when they come into collision so as to prevent each other from completing the circle, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ and then pretend to fight for passage, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Accepting the definite picture which he had developed out of the preceding lines, I think he has been too anxious for explicitness here. Virg.'s words, it seems to me, become purposely rather indefinite at this point, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ merely expressing that these retreats and charges keep going on in one form or another. ‘MASK MASK’ (so Wagn. from Med. and Rom., for ‘MASK MASK’ Pal. and Gud.) seems to imply that they still keep their ground, right and left respectively, as they took it in v. 580, though they are continually advancing and retreating over the ground. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ opposed in point of ground, is of course the same thing as ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘alternisque’MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is I think rightly referred by the generality of the commentators to complicated circular evolutions as it were entangling each other. The ‘MASK’ are not really confused, but their movements are so ingeniously intricate that they appear confused: the effect produced is that of circles involved in or cutting each other. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” occurs 8. 448 of the shield of Aeneas, where, though the entanglement of the circles is not the same as that here supposed, the picture is still less like what Henry imagines, circles preventing each other from being circles. Besides, Virg. has himself shown that he intends not single but highly complicated evolutions by the comparison to the labyrinth which immediately follows—a comparison which would be unmeaning if the movements of the ‘MASK’ had been such as the eye could easily trace. Whether these circular evolutions are the same as what is described generally in v. 583, or something different, it is not easy to say. There will be no reference in any case to the military sense of ‘MASK’ ( = ‘MASK’） for a mass of men. ‘MASK’ implies that the complication was reciprocal. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ seems to be general—‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The expression is from MASK , 324, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” which is actually copied below v. 674. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ above v. 440.

Sometimes they fly, sometimes they turn on their pursuers, sometimes they (all the six ‘MASK’ or three ‘MASK’) ride in the same direction. ‘MASK MASK’ a former reading, found in two of Ribbeck's cursives, could hardly be defended, whether ‘MASK’ were explained for the purpose of flight, a phrase which would want authority, or ‘MASK MASK’ in the sense of “MASK MASK MASK MASK” which Wakef. tries to support from MASK , where Lachm. seems right in reading “MASK MASK MASK” after Lambinus, for ‘MASK MASK’ Even “MASK MASK MASK” is not found in Virg. (comp. 12. 463, MASK , where ‘MASK’ is the reading), though Cic. Att. 7. 23 has “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Ov. 3 ex Pont. 2. 8, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” while ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is a common phrase (see Forc.). Lucan 4. 713 has “MASK MASK MASK MASK” (comp. by Wagn.). ‘MASK’ then = ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ as constantly in Virg., e. MASK ., 4. 155. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ turn against the pursuers. Rom. Heyne supposes that Virg. despaired of reproducing what would have been the most apposite description for his purpose, that of Daedalus' dance as represented on the shield of Achilles Il. 18. 590 foll., and so took the thing which suggested itself next, Daedalus' labyrinth. ‘MASK MASK’ rising from the sea. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 6. 23, comp. also by Cerda. a way constructed with blind walls, walls without door or window, which might give the traveller a glimpse of his bearings. The following words are imitated from Catull. 62 (64). 114, 115, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Comp. also Virg.'s own lines 6. 27 foll. Virg. has as usual refined on his model. Catullus, simply enough, speaks of the maze baffling the person emerging from its windings: Virg. talks of it as eluding the traces of observation. ‘MASK’ seem to be the marks by which a person would try to identify the way by which he had come. ‘MASK MASK’ then will be “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ having the sense of tracking, or, if we like, of following a way in the hope of finding the right point. These marks, or rather any attempt to proceed by their help, the perplexed puzzle of the labyrinth is said to mock and elude. The puzzle is ‘MASK MASK’ undiscovered or undiscoverable, though here again there is a certain looseness of expression, as it is not the ‘MASK’ but the secret of the ‘MASK MASK’ the solution of the difficulty, which ‘MASK MASK’ Connected with ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ slightly changes its meaning. It now becomes the winding course which brought the traveller into the heart of the maze, and which he cannot retrace. The word occurs again 6. 425 of the Styx, which once crossed cannot be recrossed, MASK , MASK . ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Three MSS. give ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK’ (comp. 6. 27): “MASK‘ dolus ’MASK” says Heyne. Pal., Rom., Gud. &c. have ‘MASK MASK’ which is perhaps recognized by Serv. and Donatus. Possibly it might be defended from MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but it would be very harsh, and cannot be put into comparison with ‘MASK’ (Med.), though Ribbeck adopts it.

the old reading, is in two of Ribbeck's cursives. Rom. combines both words, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Probably the proximity of ‘MASK’ led to the variety, though Pal. and Gud. have ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ make entangled movements.

make complicated evolutions in sham flights and sham fights. ‘MASK’ is the important word, which, taken in connexion with ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ brings out the comparison with the labyrinth. ‘MASK’ = ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ as in v. 674 below. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

Henry remarks with considerable taste, that the simile of the dolphins was almost required after that of the labyrinth, to bring out the conception of lively motion after that of lifeless artistic mechanism. There is a simile from dolphins in MASK , where their gambols are dwelt on more in detail: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” But Virg. has perhaps shown judgment in not describing their movements after having been so minute in representing the evolutions which he compares to theirs: he does little more than name them, and leaves his readers who have seen them to fill up the picture for themselves. For a similar instance of judicious reticence see on MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ apparently a solitary example of the use of ‘MASK’ with a gen. in Virg. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” 12. 476.

Heyne would have preferred ‘MASK’ but Wagn. remarks that the meaning is that the dolphins pass to and fro between the two seas. Virg. doubtless intended to express the extraordinary swiftness and agility of the dolphin tribe. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is wanting in Pal. &c., added in Med. and Gud. a m. sec., but found in Rom. Heyne condemns and Wagn. omits it, but it seems unobjectionable and even good in itself. As usual in such cases, I have retained it in brackets. It is without one at least of the marks of an interpolation, variety of reading.

He taught them to celebrate it as he had celebrated it when a boy: i. e. he taught them the routine of which we have just been hearing.

Repeated 9. 2. The old grammarians (see Serv.) attempted to distinguish between the offices of Mercury and Iris; but no difference can be found in Virg. Iris indeed seems to be peculiarly under the command of Juno, which sufficiently accounts for the character of her intervention here and elsewhere in the Aeneid: but she is Jupiter's messenger too, and on one occasion (9. 803) takes a minatory message to Juno.

She seems to have been sent down with general instructions to burn the ships, the way of doing so being left to herself. With ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Serv. well comp. “MASK MASK” addressed by Jupiter to Mercury 4. 223 (note). The construction is the same as in 8. 373, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” though there the word is used metaphorically.
“MASK MASK MASK” 3. 34. With ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ comp. 1. 25: with ‘MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK” v. 781 below. Some MSS. (none of Ribbeck's) have ‘MASK’ here.

Med. (originally) gives ‘MASK MASK’ see on 4. 641. The bow serves as Iris' means of passage from earth to heaven—a piece of machinery perhaps hardly consistent with the employment of the winds, unless the meaning is merely that she describes a semicircle in her passage. ‘MASK MASK’ answers the purpose and occupies the position of an epithet, as if it had been “MASK MASK” See Madv. § 298. b. where, though the peculiarity treated of is different, the referring of a preposition with its case to a single substantive (e. g. “MASK MASK MASK MASK”), the principle is the same, and the defect of the Latin language as compared with the Greek, in the want of a definite article, is properly noted. ‘MASK’ followed quasi-pleonastically in the next line by ‘MASK MASK’ as by ‘MASK’ MASK note. The propriety of the position of ‘MASK’ here is not quite easy to see, as there is no palpable connexion between swiftness of motion and a virgin goddess.

the way and the course along it being identified. Or we may say with Gossrau that the change is in ‘MASK MASK’ which may mean ‘MASK MASK MASK’ i. e. sloping. The speed seems connected with the invisibility, though absolute invisibility of course was one of the prerogatives of the gods.

In Il. 3. 121 foll. Iris, sent with a message to Helen, assumes the form of Laodice, Priam's daughter and Helicaon's wife. Nothing more is known of this Beroe. The nation of her husband is disputed, the word being variously written in the MSS.; the varieties however reduce themselves to two, ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ the rest, which are more or less obvious errors, tending to support ‘MASK MASK’ We have already seen the MSS. vary between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ MASK . Internal evidence, as Heyne admits, would seem to be in favour of ‘MASK’ Thrace and Troy were neighbouring and allied countries, and a Trojan woman might easily marry a Thracian; while those who vindicate Tmarus have to suppose that Beroe left Troy with Helenus, married in Epirus, and (probably becoming a widow) accompanied Aeneas. But the external authority for ‘MASK’ is too great to be resisted, the only evidence for ‘MASK’ among Ribbeck's MSS. being an abortive attempt in Med. to correct ‘MASK MASK’ the original reading, into ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK’ so that we must suppose Virg. to have introduced another reference (comp. note on v. 360) to Aeneas' visit to Epirus, either from a legend now lost, or from his own spirit of invention, seeking to give an air of verisimilitude to a narrative which has not the background of a consistent history. Lachmann's decision (on MASK ) that the final vowel in ‘MASK’ would not have been elided by Virg. seems arbitrary. The name of Doryclus occurs Il. 11. 489, as that of a natural son of Priam, killed by Ajax.

probably refers to Beroe, not to Doryclus, who is mentioned merely as part of his wife or widow's antecedents. ‘MASK MASK’ exactly as we say family, meaning ancestors of name: comp. Hor. 1. In other words, it makes us think of Beroe as Iris thought of her.

For ‘MASK MASK’ (Med.) Rom., Pal. &c. give ‘MASK MASK’ which Ribbeck adopts and Wagn. at one time adopted. Some again have ‘MASK MASK’ which Heyne retains. There is perhaps sufficient reason for ‘MASK’ followed by ‘MASK MASK’ in the fact that look and tone of voice are more closely connected with each other than either of them with gait; but such considerations are rather microscopic, and one is almost tempted to follow Wakef. in embracing “MASK MASK” from Pal. and a few other copies, as the word may have been altered to meet a supposed metrical necessity. There is yet another variety of reading in the verse, many inferior MSS. having ‘MASK MASK’ With ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ comp. 1. 327, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” with ‘MASK’ ib. 405, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

is perhaps better represented by ‘MASK’ than by any other word. They were unfriendly to the ships, though at first they were doubtful about treating them as enemies. Gossrau thinks their feeling is excited by seeing the ships burn and the prospect of sailing to Italy destroyed; but the context would not lead us to suppose that Iris' torch had taken so serious an effect.

active, = ‘MASK’ a sense found in Tac., where it is constructed with a gen., as in “MASK MASK” Ann. 1. 7. ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ are of course not quite co-ordinate. Strictly speaking, the two things between which they doubted were either the two countries or their feelings for the two countries respectively. see on 4. 252. Here the meaning seems to be ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ This and the following line are nearly repeated 9. 14, 15.

Whether ‘MASK’ means ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as Henry thinks, or ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as Heyne takes it, is a question rather of sense than of language, as in either case ‘MASK MASK’ must mean to trace the line of the bow, and so cannot be compared with ‘MASK MASK MASK’ &c., where the accusative denotes the space divided. There is nothing in the context to show whether the bow along which Iris descended (v. 609) was visible, or, like herself, invisible, nor yet whether it remained after she came down. On either supposition there would be enough to show to the Trojan women the supernatural character of the appearance, the main point being that Iris, the goddess, having come down unseen, re-ascended in the most visible and conspicuous manner. ‘MASK’ v. 586 note.
as Henry remarks, denotes “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Comp. 9. 73 foll., which is generally parallel to this passage. ‘MASK MASK’ 10. 63.

(which occurs Catull. 66 (68). 102) must be referred with Donatus and the commentators generally to the hearths in the ‘MASK’ of adjoining houses. Some brought embers and brands from the hearths, others boughs from the altars to hurl at the ships, the act of hurling, which is of course meant to be common to both parties, being, with Virg.'s usual preference of variety to perspicuity, predicated only of one. Thus it would be worse than useless to follow Henry in putting ‘MASK MASK MASK’ within brackets.
may include the boughs that wreathed the altars (2. 249., 3. 25), as well as firewood.

reminds them at once of their relation to him and of the city the hope of which they are destroying. Ascanius supposes that they must fancy in their frenzy that they are burning a Greek camp or fleet, as Agave fancied that she was tearing a calf in pieces when she was dismembering her son. But their delusion was of a different kind, as the context shows. Thus it seems out of place to suppose with Forb. that they do not recognize Ascanius, though doubtless he believes that they do not, and takes off his helmet accordingly. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ v. 679 need not imply that they were ignorant of the persons of their friends, but that they were ignorant of their true character; that as they now recognize the ships to be what Ascanius here calls them, their hopes, so they see that Aeneas and those who were for continuing the voyage had their true interests at heart. If this seems forced, we must say not that they were not perfectly aware that they were burning their own ships, but that in their frenzied enthusiasm they thought only of their purpose, and were unconscious of the whole world beside.
“MASK MASK MASK” 7. 452.

simply means his empty helmet, as in MASK , the epithet here as there being perhaps intended to make us think of the sound as it strikes the ground, though it may also be meant to give the picture. To understand it of a helmet for show, not for use, with Forb. and Henry (who however says nothing about it in his published commentary), is to put a forced sense upon a plain word. “MASK MASK” used of a tiger's skin Stat. Theb. 6. 715, means not so much that the skin is sham and void of meaning or terror, though that doubtless enters into it, as that it is actually empty of the savage beast that filled it.

4. 66. ‘MASK’ of heat is very common in Lucr. Here we are meant to think of heat and smoke both, as distinguished from bright flame. ‘MASK’ &c.: the plague (‘MASK’ as in v. 699., 9. 540, here accommodated to ‘MASK’) sinks into the vitals and pervades the whole frame of the vessels.

Aeneas and his friends, who would be stronger than ordinary men. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ form a sort of hendiadys, as the strength of these heroes would chiefly be shown in flinging large quantities of water. ‘MASK’ might mean river-water, like “MASK” 2. 686, or it might simply denote the pouring of the water on the ships, so as in fact to repeat ‘MASK MASK’ but the former part of the line seems to show that it is used hyperbolically, as if whole rivers were showered down.

gives urgency to the request, as in 12. 158, where as here another imperative without ‘MASK’ has preceded. ‘MASK MASK’ seems at the first sight to be most naturally taken ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ a sense with which Wagn. well comp. 12. 643, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” But I believe Jahn is right in following a suggestion disapproved by Heyne, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” as the parallel passage v. 796 below goes far to show. The antithesis may seem to require ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ not ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ but Aeneas' thoughts flow too fast to conform to balanced rhetoric. He first says ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ then as he looks at the ships burning one by one, he says, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ There is a fragment of Attius' Nyctegresia (9 Ribbeck) of which Virg. perhaps thought, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but, as we know nothing of the context of the passage, it does not help us here. ‘MASK’ is in favour, it must be admitted, of supplying ‘MASK’ as the object of ‘MASK MASK’ but there is nothing harsh in making Aeneas identify himself with the Trojans, of whom he is the head, and resting their safety on his deserts. On the other hand, an objection might perhaps be raised with justice to Aeneas' separating himself from the rest, as he does according to the common interpretation, and calling for his own destruction as the one thing wanted to crown the national misery. On the whole then I think ‘MASK MASK’ includes both generally the fortunes of Troy , the ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ and specially the vessels still unconsumed, which is the main meaning in v. 796. ‘MASK MASK’ note on MASK .

Strictly speaking of course the discharge of the rain would diminish the blackness of the sky: but Virg. may mean to describe the first moments of a storm, when rain and blackness are seen together, and the supposition of a close connexion is favoured both by the order and by MASK , though there the ‘MASK’ are called ‘MASK’ while still in the clouds.

For ‘MASK’ two MSS. give ‘MASK’ which would be more consistent with ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ But Virg. has chosen to combine the two notions of changing cares, i.e. entertaining one anxious thought after another, and moving cares, anxious thoughts, to one quarter or the other, so as to give ‘MASK’ the sense of changing the place of a thing, or as we say, shifting it, much as he talks 3. 581 of “MASK MASK MASK” where some copies have “MASK” For a somewhat similar confusion see on 4. 285, 286. Thus ‘MASK’ like ‘MASK MASK’ Peerlkamp's conj., would only make the passage less Virgilian. ‘MASK’ 4. 286, 630, here taken closely with ‘MASK MASK’ the clauses that follow depending on both words.

“‘ MASK , ’MASK” Serv. This is perhaps the neater explanation; but the ordinary sense of ‘MASK’ would stand very well. We must remember that Latin poets did not distinguish the meanings of words in their own minds as sharply as modern critics are obliged to do in their lexicons. “MASK MASK” 4. 346.

This MASK was said to have been the priest of MASK, and to have carried the Palladium away from Troy into Italy, whence it passed to his descendants, the family of the Nautii at Rome . See Dionys. H. 6. 69. Serv. refers to Varro's treatise ‘MASK MASK MASK’ (see on v. 117). ‘MASK’ in the sense of ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is generally found in Virg. combined with some other words which denote the relative character of the pre-eminence. Comp. 1. 15., 2. 426., 12. 143.

Ruhkopf is, I think, right in regarding, as Gossrau and Henry have done, these lines as parenthetical, to explain the nature of the power given by Pallas to Nautes. The tense of ‘MASK’ and the clauses ‘MASK MASK MASK’ &c. are so plainly general that it would be far less tolerable to force them into any other sense than to submit to the harshness of an anacoluthon in ‘MASK’ v. 708, taking up the sentence unfinished in vv. 704, 705. Henry well expands the meaning: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” For this division of events he (after Gossrau) comp. Claudian, De Bello Getico v. 171 (speaking of the irruption of the barbarians into Thrace), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” There is still however an unexplained difficulty about the expression. The sense would seem to require that we should supply some antecedent for ‘MASK’ from the sentence itself, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ &c., or regard ‘MASK’ as acc. pl. of ‘MASK MASK’ But I believe Virg. meant ‘MASK’ to be connected with ‘MASK MASK’ speaking of the responses as portended by the wrath of heaven or demanded by the order of fate, to show how completely the responses represented and were identified with the events. The events or responses are said to be portended by the wrath of the gods, whereas we should rather expect to hear that the wrath of the gods was itself portended by supernatural appearances: but though ‘MASK’ seems generally to bear the latter meaning, the substantive ‘MASK’ is quite in accordance with the former. ‘MASK MASK’ occurs elsewhere, as in MASK , of a god giving forth a response to those who consulted him, but there can be no reason why it should not be used also of suggesting a response to another which he is to give forth. Ribbeck reads ‘MASK’ after Dietsch, from one of his cursives. ‘MASK’ of the fates 3. 376. ‘MASK’ of the fates 4. 614., 7. 272., 8. 12, 477.

The later editors rightly follow Gliemann's suggestion that the period formerly placed after ‘MASK’ should be changed to a comma, ‘MASK MASK’ being sometimes found after a participial clause, as MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”; Livy 2. 29 “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” &c. So it is used in an apodosis 7. 376., 11. 633. ‘MASK’ is used of other excitements than those of anger and love, 4. 360.

The MSS. are divided between ‘MASK’ (Rom., Pal., Med.), and ‘MASK’ (Serv., Probus, Gud. a m. s. &c.). ‘MASK’ was the reading before Heins., who introduced ‘MASK MASK’ We might also have expected ‘MASK’ (see on 2. 120); but it does not seem to be found. The ‘MASK MASK’ of Virg. is perhaps rather MASK favour of ‘MASK’ (comp. “MASK MASK” 1. 579, “MASK MASK” 4. 395, with “MASK MASK” 4. 285, “MASK MASK” 4. 630): ‘MASK’ however is supported by “MASK MASK” 8. 370, by the combination of Rom., Pal., and Med., and by its being less obvious than the acc., so that I have on the whole been led to adopt it, with Jahn, Wagn. (ed. mi.), Ladewig, and Ribbeck. Rom., Gud. corrected, &c. have ‘MASK MASK’ With the image comp. 4. 285. The cares are here represented as the parts into which Aeneas' being is torn.

Wagn. seems right in connecting this line rather with what follows than with what precedes, the meaning being, as he says, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Comp. 10. 256, where he has similarly changed the pointing. ‘MASK’ however does point to what precedes, indicating that Aeneas was still occupied with these thoughts when he retired to rest.

= ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ as in 2. 622. ‘MASK MASK’ is explained by Heyne as said “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” vv. 733, 734. But it appears from 6. 687 foll. that the shade of Anchises in Elysium was unconscious of the effect produced by these visions (comp. 4. 353), so that we need not suppose that this appearance is identical with the Anchises of the lower world. Serv. gives an alternative, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The first view would be countenanced by some passages in Homer, but does not seem to have been held by Virg.: the second is simple and probable enough, this appearance being really a dream, such as Zeus is said to send Il. 1. 63., 2. 6 foll. Pal. has ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which Ribbeck adopts. Helenus had told Aeneas that he would see the Sibyl at Cumae, and learn his destiny from her (3. 441 foll.), but had said nothing about going down to the shades. Assuming that it was necessary to bring him thither, we need not complain of the mode of effecting it here as inartificial: still, it looks almost like an after-thought, as Aeneas in effect learns his destiny not from the Sibyl but from Anchises, and the very words in which her assistance is promised (3. 458, 459) are transferred to what is actually done by Anchises (6. 890—892).
seems to be used generally of the shades (7. 91), perhaps with a special reference not so much to the lake and valley of Avernus as to the whole of the region before they reach Elysium.
was found by Pierius in most of his MSS. Some others have ‘MASK MASK’ But either word would be ill chosen here, being inconsistent with 6. 698 foll. For the position of ‘MASK’ see on MASK .

The MSS. are divided between ‘MASK MASK’ (Med. a m. pr., Rom., Pal., Gud.), ‘MASK MASK’ (Med. a m. sec., and according to Heyne, ‘MASK MASK’ including Balliol MS.), and ‘MASK MASK’ (one of Ribbeck's cursives corrected). The first, though adopted by Heins., Heyne, and Rib. beck, is weak. The third might stand very well, as all that is required by the sense is that a distinction should be made between Tartarus and Elysium: but when a reading well supported in itself affords the means of observing Virg.'s own division into Tartarus, Elysium , and the intermediate state, where the sorrows of life are continued after death, it seems a pity not to adopt it. There is no force in Jahn's objection that ‘MASK’ is required to sustain the balance between ‘MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as it is a mere assumption that any such balance exists.
here simply means a meeting, perhaps with an additional notion of a place of meeting. 6. 673 foll. will show that no formal assembly is intended.
Comp. 6. 153, 243 foll. ‘MASK’ abl. instrum. ‘MASK’ implies that the sacrifice is to be large, as is the case 6. 243 foll.
The first part of the promise is fulfilled at length 6. 756 foll.; the second is perhaps meant to be included in the general words of 6. 890 foll. ‘MASK MASK’ 3. 85, 255 notes.
Night is just at its full, and the first faint breath of morning is making itself felt.

Comp. MASK note. ‘MASK MASK’ as excluding Anchises from the upper air, and breaking in on the intercourse of father and son. The belief in the exclusive connexion between ghosts and night is natural enough. An English reader need hardly be referred to the Ghost in Hamlet. Gossrau has quoted his words from Tieck's translation, “MASK MASK MASK”
Comp. MASK , 500. Pal. has ‘MASK MASK MASK’

Serv. says “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” an inversion which here at any rate is of course quite impossible. The words seem to answer exactly to our ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ conveying a reproach for not remaining longer. ‘MASK’ MASK , where the full reflexive form is used.
“MASK MASK MASK” 6. 466, MASK . Comp. Aeneas' words 6. 698.

Aeneas offers sacrifices after supernatural appearances 3. 176 foll., 8. 542 foll. The latter passage (where see note) is closely parallel to this. The words ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ recur 8. 410 in a simile. They must be explained here from the next line, as Aeneas is in his own house, and so would only have household deities about him: otherwise we might have supposed that he revived the sacrificial fire, which had doubtless been burning for his father the day before.

‘MASK MASK’ is probably the same as “MASK MASK” mentioned by Ascanius along with the Penates, and Vesta 9. 259, where “MASK MASK MASK” is repeated. So perhaps 8. 543. ‘MASK’ points to the old religion, of which the worship of Vesta formed part, like “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 1. 292 note. Serv. gives an alternative, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The last notion shows ingenuity, but is hardly likely to have occurred to Virg., even with his love for combining allusions, though it might have suited the less chastened taste of Ovid.

“MASK MASK” Hor. 3. Od. 23. 20, where as here offerings to the Penates are spoken of. Comp. ib. 9 where the Lares are propitiated “MASK” (Virgil's ‘MASK’） “MASK MASK MASK” (the ‘MASK MASK’) “MASK MASK MASK”
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

Comp. 3. 58, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though there the reference seems to be more formal: see note there. ‘MASK MASK’ the old reading before Heins., is supported here by Med., Rom., Gud. a m. s. &c. The question is of course one to be decided on grounds far wider than can be supplied by the MSS. of a single author in a single passage. The result seems to be that ‘MASK’ is apparently the correct form according to analogy, but that ‘MASK’ has every where such respectable support from the MSS. that it is probably to be admitted as a co-ordinate form in use in the best ages of Latinity. A mistaken spelling founded on a mistaken analogy may easily come into vogue in the purest period of a language. Which form Virg. preferred we cannot of course tell, nor is the point of any importance. Med. is inconsistent, giving ‘MASK’ here and in 6. 119, ‘MASK’ in 10. 11, MASK .
and ‘MASK’ both point to previous indecision. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 9. 191.

seems to mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ comp. v. 639 above. But it might possibly be ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ i. e. it is short, or they do not debate at all. “‘ Iussa , ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. The first interpretation seems the right one: comp. 4. 503. In each case perhaps the choice of the word may have been regulated by the fact that the request has something of the authority of a command, embodying here the injunction of a deity, there that of a priestess.

Serv. says of ‘MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” No other instance is however quoted of this use of the word, which is perhaps only adapted by Virg. from ‘MASK MASK’ the regular word for entering a colony already formed.

“‘ MASK , ’MASK MASK MASK” Serv., rightly. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Hirt. Bell. Alex. 1. 34. They had of course been already landed: but the word expresses with some vividness the fact of their subtraction from the ships' crews. It is perhaps hardly worth while to combine with this Heyne's explanation, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. mentions another interpretation, according to which a stop is placed at ‘MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK’ taken with ‘MASK’— “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” says Taubmann. ‘MASK’ forms an apposition like ‘MASK’ above v. 729. ‘MASK’ expresses not the absence of the thing, but the sense of its absence—a change of meaning equally observable in our word ‘MASK’ as Henry remarks. Thus the expression is exactly contrasted with “MASK MASK” v. 138 above, 6. 823. With the construction Henry comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” One or two MSS. have ‘MASK MASK’ which has met with some approbation in later times .

contrasts those who go with those who stay. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ either make new benches or repair the old. Comp. “MASK MASK” 4. 260. ‘MASK’ of repairing, i. e. setting up again, in a new form. Forc. quotes Tac. A. 1. 63, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

not “MASK MASK” like “MASK MASK MASK” 7. 134, but in the same sense as “MASK MASK MASK” to give a thing to a person. There was a doubt about the pointing even in Serv.'s time, some putting the stop after ‘MASK MASK’ as Heins. has done, with the approbation of Heyne: but the old commentator rightly prefers punctuating after ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is used elsewhere of getting a ship into order, 4. 289. As applied to oars, it refers more particularly to shaping them (comp. 1. 552), as applied to ropes, to attaching them to the vessel (comp. 3. 472).

forms rather a bold apposition to ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but there is a similar one in 11. 338, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (comp. also by Forb.). “MASK MASK” 11. 386. It matters little whether ‘MASK’ be dative, “MASK MASK MASK” or abl.

With the passage generally comp. the description of the building of Carthage 1. 423 foll. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the custom is thus explained by Serv., “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The same account is given more briefly by Varro L. L. 5. 143 Müller. The passage of Cato is given by Isidorus 15. 2, 3, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” So when MASK first lands in Latium, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 7. 157.

is found in a few MSS., and was adopted by Burm. and Heyne, perhaps under a mistaken notion that its external authority was greater. The participle would clearly be out of place, as the clause ‘MASK MASK’ &c. has nothing to do with what precedes. The meaning is, he assigns the sites for private dwellings by lot, and gives names to the different quarters of the city. With ‘MASK MASK’ comp. 3. 137, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” with the remainder, v. 633 above, 3. 349 foll. Wagn. explains ‘MASK’ of the city, ‘MASK’ of the region: but the city was called Acesta, and ‘MASK’ in Helenus' city can scarcely have been the region, which Helenus had called Chaonia (3. 334 foll.). Strabo 13, p. 608 C. comp. by Wagn. says that the rivers about Aegesta had the names of Scamander and Simois.
gives the reason of Acestes' joy at seeing the old names revived.

The constitution of the state proceeds pari passu with the building of the town, as in 1. 426., 3. 137. See note on the former passage. ‘MASK MASK’ is apparently explained on the analogy of “MASK MASK MASK” to hold a court, ‘MASK’ being used as in “MASK MASK MASK” &c. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ to make laws, was part of the kingly office as conceived by Virg. See on 1. 293. Lersch. § 2, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” quotes from Livy, 1. 8, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” a passage exactly appropriate to the present. So 7. 246, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” On a comparison of the passage in Livy with two others in Virg., “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 1. 507, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 8. 670, it may be doubted whether ‘MASK MASK’ here and “MASK MASK” 7, l. c. are abl. abs. or MASK. In any case the sense is the same. A council, large or small, is summoned, and the laws given by the king. Gossrau remarks that this was not only the old Roman practice, but that established or revived by Augustus, who consulted the senate but was not bound by it. Wagn.'s explanation ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ teaches the senators their duties, is less likely, though it might receive some support from 1. 731, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

The temple of Venus on Mount Eryx was famous. Dionys. 1. 53 (cited by Heyne, Excursus 2) instances the alter MASK MASK MASK as one of the proofs that Aeneas visited Sicily, and Tac. A. 4. 43 says that the Segestans sent an embassy to Rome , begging that the temple might be restored, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” doubtless its foundation by Aeneas. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 2. 460.

seems an ordinary epithet, as Venus is not likely to have been specially worshipped on Mount Eryx as Idalia, though Venus Erycina was worshipped at Rome , Livy 22. 10. We might have expected “MASK MASK MASK” but the only variation in the MSS. is that one gives ‘MASK’

Anchises, as a hero, has a MASK bestowed on him. Comp. 3. 302 foll., where we read of a similar honour to Hector. ‘MASK’ suggests the Greek way of indicating a temple by a neuter adjective, MASK MASK . ‘MASK’ was restored by Heins. for ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ occurs again of a grove 8. 598. Forc. seems to explain it rightly (s. v. ‘MASK’), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though it would be possible to explain ‘MASK’ as indicating an extraordinary and more than local sanctity, just as e. g. the words in this sense might be applied to Delphi. Pal. has ‘MASK MASK’

We have already had the ‘MASK’ (see on v. 64): but Virg. may be thinking of the solemnities of which that formed the close, and perhaps also of the other ‘MASK’ which actually lasted nine days (Dict. A. s. v.), though it had nothing to do with a funeral.
See MASK note.

MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , Il. 24. 512.

Forb. comp. Livy 7. 42, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ is best taken as the ordinary acc. of the object, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ something like “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 3. 481. The notion is partly that of making the time move slowly by crowding so much into it (comp. 1. 748 note), partly that of actually prolonging the time before sailing.
for ‘MASK’ a few MSS. repeat ‘MASK MASK’ which, though plausible at first sight, is inconsistent with ‘MASK’ v. 770. Others were weary of the sea besides the matrons, v. 716 above.

With Ribbeck I have recalled ‘MASK MASK’ the reading of Heins. and Heyne, found in Pal., Med. a m. pr. and a quotation in MASK. p. 307. The common reading is ‘MASK MASK’ two MSS. have ‘MASK’ as a various reading, and Rom. and another MS. give ‘MASK MASK’ The last is adopted by Henry: but it seems to have arisen from a recollection of 4. 53, as has so often happened in similar cases. Between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ the question is more difficult. Wagn., reading ‘MASK MASK’ appeals to the deification of MASK or MASK . Henry replies that Virg. speaks of gods of the sea, but not of the sea itself as a god. The sea is called “MASK” below v. 849 in a passage somewhat similar to this: but such an analogy does not help us much. Admitting then that if the notion involved in ‘MASK’ would be satisfactorily supported, the word would be appropriate and poetical, I think this passage is one of the innumerable exceptions to the critical rule that the more difficult reading is to be preferred. Virg. may have thought of the Homerie MASK MASK , Od. 19. 260, 597., 23. 19. But it would be more satisfactory if a parallel could be adduced from his own works, though the expression may seem to be one which does not stand in need of any such support. The confusion is of course common: see 4. 94 note.
Comp. v. 619 above, 3. 160.
his and their kinsmen, as being half Trojan. It shows the ground on which Aeneas commits them to Acestes' protection.
Eryx is worshipped as a hero. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Hor. Epod. 10. 24. Comp. above 3. 120. Med. has ‘MASK MASK’

followed by ‘MASK MASK’ comp. 3. 61, MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ I incline to take as i. q. ‘MASK MASK’ like ‘MASK’ above, v. 53, the reference here being to the previous sacrifices. And so I see Serv. explains it, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ Phrygiamque ex ordine Matrem Invocat . ’” As an alternative he adds, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” an interpretation which would almost require ‘MASK MASK’ the reading before Heins., and would be less Virgilian. Some of the earlier commentators strangely understood ‘MASK MASK’ by a MASK MASK of cutting the rope with which the victims were tied: see Emmenessius' note.
MASK (note), where ‘MASK’ occurs instead of ‘MASK MASK’

Some MSS. give “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” apparently from 3. 527. Libations and sacrifices however seem usually to have been made from the stern: comp. the passage just referred to, and MASK foll. Heyne suggests, plausibly enough, that on leaving the harbour they would naturally perform the ceremony from the prow, looking to the sea over which they were to sail. ‘MASK’ is not easy: perhaps it may refer to the distance from the shore, implying that the offering is thrown far into the sea: or it may refer to the height of the prow above the waves, Virg. preferring it to ‘MASK’ on rhythmical grounds. Entrails would be placed MASK ‘MASK’ as well as wine (Dict. A. ‘MASK’).
v. 238 above (note). Here the MSS. are said to be unanimous for ‘MASK’ or some such word, ‘MASK’ being due to Heins.
Repeated from 3. 130.
Repeated from 3. 290. In Pal., Gud., and another good MS., the first Mentelian, this and the preceding line change places.

(‘MASK’ Pal., Med. corrected, &c.) was restored by Heins., from Med. and others for ‘MASK MASK’ The MSS. sometimes vary between simple adjectives with negatives prefixed and adjectives compounded with negatives, e. g. “MASK MASK” and “MASK MASK” “MASK MASK” and “MASK MASK” With the sense comp. above v. 608., 7. 298. ‘MASK’ seems found nowhere else.

Caesar B. C. 1. 9 has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” See other instances of this use of the word MASK Forc. The usual combination seems to be ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which is here found MASK some of the MSS. of Serv. Gossrau well comp. “MASK MASK MASK” 4. 413, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Hor. 3 Od. 29. 59. So also Tac. A. 1. 12, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
as Aeneas had endeavoured to propitiate Juno 3. 547. It might however be extended to other acts of piety not affecting Juno, 6. 405.

The change of the nom. is harsh, as we are not warned of it by a change in the gender. ‘MASK MASK’ Jupiter had declared himself favourable to Aeneas in Book 1, and had checked Juno afterwards by sending him away from Carthage. ‘MASK’ Med., Rom., Pal., ‘MASK’ fragm. Vat., Gud. It signifies little which we adopt. The command of Jove and the will of destiny are naturally combined, tending as they do the same way, and as naturally distinguished. “MASK MASK MASK” Ov. M. 6. 626. With the general language of the line comp. Juno's own words 7. 297, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Juno is not satisfied with having torn Troy as it were out of the heart of Phrygia. “‘ Exedisse ’MASK MASK MASK” says Serv., which is perhaps the best way of accounting for Virg.'s use of so harsh a metaphor, at the same time that he was probably thinking, as Heyne well suggests, of the taunt of the Homeric Zeus to Hera Il. 4. 34 foll.: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
Henry reads ‘MASK’ from fragm. Vat. and several MSS., and probably Donatus: but it may be doubted whether ‘MASK’ occurs in Virg. in this sense: see on 2. 637.

‘MASK’ an abbreviated form, like “MASK” 4. 682, “MASK” 11. 118. So “MASK” MASK . Its strangeness has led to many alterations in the MSS., some of which, including Med. a m. pr., write the word in full, ‘MASK MASK’ regardless of the verse, while others, adopting ‘MASK’ omit ‘MASK MASK’ Pal. and fragm. Vat. originally had ‘MASK MASK’ With the expression ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Ruhkopf comp. Eur. Iph. T. 257, MASK MASK MASK . Comp. also 3. 315, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The old punctuation continued the sentence to ‘MASK MASK’ Torquil Baden on Sen. Herc. F. p. 32 proposed to put a stop at ‘MASK MASK’ continuing ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ and Wagn. has improved on this by removing the comma after ‘MASK’ Gossrau points ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ fortifying himself by the authority of Med., which on questions of punctuation is worth very little. The objection to this, as to the old pointing, is that it makes too subtle a distinction between ‘MASK MASK’ the remains after the destruction of Troy , and ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ the remains of those remains, which have survived subsequent persecution.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Serv. says “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ me duce Dardanius Troiam expugnavit adulter ? ’”

It seems better to remove the comma which many editions place after ‘MASK MASK’ as ‘MASK MASK MASK’ refers rather to ‘MASK’ than to ‘MASK MASK’ though the latter combination might be defended, if necessary.

The language closely follows 1. 133, 134, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Venus' language however has a slightly more colloquial air than Neptune's, as she speaks under feminine excitement and refers to an event which, being some time past, need not be characterized so exactly. In 1. 134, as there remarked, Neptune may refer to the mountains of waves: Venus evidently means no more than ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is one form of the proverbial expression, the other form of which is given in 1. 133. Juv. combines the two 2. 25, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” In another passage he has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (6. 283).
Comp. generally Neptune's speech 1. 132 foll.

For ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the reading before Pierius, found in one of Ribbeck's cursives, was “MASK MASK MASK” So “MASK” and “MASK” are confounded MASK . Heyne gives a choice of interpretations, ‘MASK MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ i. q. “MASK MASK” and ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The latter seems best. Ruhkopf comp. such expressions as MASK MASK MASK , MASK , &c., Heyne “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Hor. 1 Od. 3. 26.

Aeneam. ‘MASK MASK’ is of course exaggerated, though she qualifies the words in v. 796, if the interpretation adopted in the note there is correct. There is the same spirit of exaggeration in her language 1. 251, where she talks of “MASK MASK MASK” though she doubtless knew at the time that only one ship was really lost.

is another touch of exaggeration, as elsewhere the Trojans speak of Sicily as familiar and friendly, above vv. 24, 28 foll., 630. But she may call it so with reference to the separation between Aeneas and those left behind, who will be strangers to him henceforth. ‘MASK MASK’ is read by Med., Gud. a m. pr., first Mentelian, &c.: but the dat. which is found in fragm. Vat. is more poetical and less obvious, and so more likely to have been altered. Rom. exhibits the error in its transitional state, reading ‘MASK MASK MASK’ and the original reading of Pal. was perhaps ‘MASK MASK MASK’

There is even more variety of opinion about ‘MASK MASK’ here than in v. 691 above. Heyne, who placed a semicolon after ‘MASK MASK’ seems to have regarded it as i. q. ‘MASK MASK’ to which Wagn. objects that the request which follows, so far from being an afterthought, is the main object of Venus' speech. This objection is not quite conclusive, as there might even be a dramatic propriety in the request so introduced. Venus has been carried on by her impetuosity into an enumeration of Juno's crimes, and now bethinks herself of what she wants to have done, at the same time that she may purposely adopt a phrase which rather disguises her anxiety about the main point. Such a defence however can hardly be urged against other views equally reconcilable with the language, and not requiring to be reconciled with the context. Henry understands it to mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which would agree with the common interpretation of the words in v. 691, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” But Neptune's help was really worth far more to them than this, though it may again be replied that it suits Venus' purpose to extenuate the boon. Two other interpretations are mentioned by Wagn., “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” or “MASK MASK” and “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The former brings the passage into conformity with what appears on the whole the best view of v. 691, at the same time that it supplies a subject for ‘MASK MASK’ which would otherwise perhaps be too obscure with ‘MASK’ following. Besides, the latter is open to one or two objections of its own: it is not suggested by the immediate context, which speaks of the burning of the ships, the Aeolian storm having been dismissed in v. 792: perhaps also it makes Venus assume too readily that their journey is near its end, as if distance and tempests had been the only causes of its prolongation. I think then that ‘MASK MASK’ is to be explained of the remaining ships and their crews, and that the probabilities of this interpretation here and in v. 691 may fairly be said to strengthen each other.

Most editors take ‘MASK’ as an ethical dative, virtually equivalent to ‘MASK MASK’ but the instances they quote are, as Forb. admits, not strictly parallel, and there can be no doubt that such a use of the word in a connexion like this would create a very awkward ambiguity. With Ladewig then I accept Heyne's first explanation, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” So perhaps in 12. 263 “MASK MASK” in MASK “MASK” may be the dat. after “MASK MASK MASK” We have already had a bolder innovation on the usual expression in 3. 9, “MASK MASK MASK MASK”

has to be explained from the previous knowledge of Neptune, as no city has been mentioned. Comp. 3. 100, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where the reference is scarcely more direct. With ‘MASK’ comp. v. 737 above.
The rhythm of this line is harsh: probably however we are meant to pause at ‘MASK MASK’ separating ‘MASK’ from ‘MASK MASK’
“MASK MASK” 3.55. “MASK MASK” 2. 402.
ut fideres. Beside the general ground for Venus' confidence, Neptune had given her further reason by his personal interference in Aeneas' behalf.

seems emphatic, as if he had said “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” substantiating the assertion ‘MASK MASK MASK’ The reason why he does not give ‘MASK’ its natural place may be that he wished to bring ‘MASK’ into prominence. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Some difficulty has been felt about ‘MASK MASK’ as the only interference recorded is that in Book 1. It is answered by Heyne that we may assume Neptune's protection to have been exerted on such occasions as vv. 8 foll. above, 3. 192 foll. This may have been what Virg. refers to: but it is perhaps more satisfactory with Burm. to say simply that he refers to occasions not mentioned (expressly at least) in the Aeneid.

is explained by what follows. The combat of Aeneas with Achilles (Il. 20. 158 foll.) happened before the MASK MASK of Il. 21, but both took place on the same occasion, the return of Achilles to battle, so that it is scarcely inaccurate to speak of them as contemporaneous.

The expression seems to be taken from Il. 21. 295, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK , words used by Poseidon himself to Achilles, though they had been previously used by Achilles himself (v. 225) in speaking to Scamander. For the fact see the latter part of Il. 20 and 21. A similar expression occurs in Tac. H. 2. 41 (cited by Forc. s. v. ‘MASK’), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Fragm.
