MASK note. The phrase was a common one at Rome , it being the custom to announce a public funeral (hence called ‘MASK MASK’） by the herald in the words “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (Festus s. v. ‘MASK’ Varro L. L. 7. 42 Müller). ‘MASK’ &c. is again from Il. 21. 218, where Xanthus says— “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
Virg. perhaps alludes to the connexion of the two senses of MASK .

as Scamander invokes Simois against Achilles, Il. 21. 307 foll. ‘MASK’ is used in post-Augustan prose of rivers emptying themselves: see Forc. For ‘MASK’ Pal. has ‘MASK MASK’ which might stand if ‘MASK’ were read.

Another reference to Homer's words, Il. 20. 334, where Poseidon blames Aeneas for encountering Achilles, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . ‘MASK MASK MASK’ does not express the same thing as the words just quoted, but it agrees with the Homeric narrative, where the Greek gods generally show themselves stronger than the Trojan, as MASK the wounding of Aphrodite and Ares Il. 5, and the MASK Il. 20. Comp. the words of Hera Il. 20. 122 foll. ‘MASK MASK’ occurs again MASK a similar connexion 10. 357, 431., 12. 218. With the sense comp. generally v. 466 above.

1. 516. The deseription is not quite the same as that in Il. 20. 321, where Poseidon puts a mist before the eyes of Achilles and then takes Aeneas away, but Virg. was doubtless thinking of other instances where Homeric gods carry off warriors in clouds, as in Il. 20. 444., 21. 597. ‘MASK MASK’ a former reading, is supported by a correction in fragm. Vat. There is some awkwardness in ‘MASK MASK’ followed by ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but we should lose rather than gain if we were to remove it according to Wagn.'s suggestion by placing a full stop after ‘MASK’ v. 808, and connecting ‘MASK MASK MASK’ &c. with the previous sentence, as ‘MASK MASK MASK’ would then produce an awkward tautology with what follows. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 2. 625.

The building of Troy by Poseidon and the perjury of Laomedon are sufficiently known. ‘MASK’ is read for ‘MASK’ in fragm. Vat. and Med. a m. pr., perhaps as Wagn. suggests, from a recollection of 2. 660; but the two words are easily confounded, and there is the same variety in the Virgilian Catalecta 11. 51.

Med., ‘MASK’ Rom., Pal., Gud., and probably fragm. Vat. The former is perhaps preferable, as we have “MASK MASK” 1. 202, while ‘MASK’ does not occur at all in Virg., though we have ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Wagn.'s distinction that the sing. denotes the apprehension of a particular thing, the plural the fear of many things, is I think refuted by 1. 202., 9. 90.

is the harbour of Cumae. Comp. 3. 441, 442., 6. 236 foll., and note on MASK . Serv., and after him Spence, find an inconsistency in the passage as ordinarily pointed, as Neptune's promise that Aeneas should reach Cumae is not the same thing as Venus' request that he may arrive at the Tiber, and propose to remove it by separating ‘MASK’ from ‘MASK’ and taking it with ‘MASK MASK’ but the dangers of the voyage were in fact over when they reached Cumae, and Virg.'s love of variety is not to be controlled.

is the reading of all Ribbeck's MSS., ‘MASK’ of one or two inferior copies, followed by most editors. Either would stand very well, ‘MASK’ referring to Aeneas, ‘MASK’ to Venus, who would gladly be identified with him in his care for the fleet. The latter is less obvious, without being at the same time less Virgilian, and external authority is, I agree with Henry and Ribbeck, decisive in its favour. Comp. Venus' language 1. 250 foll., “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and the assurance she afterwards gives Aeneas of the safety of his fleet ib. 390 foll. (see also ib. 584, 585.) ‘MASK MASK’ is like “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Hor. 3 Od. 24. 32, comp. by Forb. So 1. 217, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The person referred to is of course Palinurus, not, as Serv. thinks, Misenus, curiously fancying v. 814 to point to the latter, v. 815 to the former.

Here, as in 1. 147, 156, Neptune mounts MASK car and rides over the waves to smooth them. The description however is from Il. 13. 23 foll., where MASK object is to make a journey to the earth. ‘MASK’ is apparently proleptic, in this as in other places, though it is not easy to distinguish this use of an epithet from its more ordinary employment. Venus was sad before Neptune spoke: but she had become happy before MASK speech came to an end.

all Ribbeck's MSS., ‘MASK’ two or three inferior copies. The latter is evidently a correction to make the passage easier. ‘MASK’ for a thing made of gold is found elsewhere in Virg., e. MASK ; but the reference has in each case to be determined from the context, a task which here is somewhat difficult. Hom. does not help us, as though he talks of gold repeatedly, it is with reference to Poseidon's palace, the manes of his horses, and his own armour; unless we suppose Virg. to have understood MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK to mean that Poseidon put golden harness on the coats of the horses. Probably Heyne is right in taking it of the yoke, though it may be the harness. In either case it is doubtless abl., not dat., so that Wagn.'s objection that ‘MASK MASK’ is the proper expression, not ‘MASK MASK MASK’ falls to the ground. The horses are ‘MASK MASK’ fastened to the car, or to each other (comp. 3. 113., 7. 724, MASK &c.), with gold, ‘MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK MASK’ So Claudian, Phoenix 86, comp. by Heins., “MASK MASK MASK MASK” where ‘MASK’ is similarly supplied from ‘MASK MASK’ This seems more Virgilian than with Wagn. to make ‘MASK’ dat. = ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ of Neptune 1. 155, as of Tiber 8. 72, like ‘MASK’ (note on MASK ). ‘MASK MASK MASK’ puts on the bridles, harnesses them. “MASK MASK” 4. 135.
note on 2. 51. Here it may be meant to express the spirit of animals, like “MASK” in 4. 135 just referred to. “MASK MASK MASK” 12. 499.

Comp. 1. 147. ‘MASK’ of marine things MASK note (see on v. 123 of this book), though here it may be meant to be taken strictly. ‘MASK’ seems to include easy motion (6. 17., MASK ) and light pressure. Comp. v. 838 below.

seems to refer to the sounding of the sea, of which Virg. has chosen to remind us, perhaps with a little sacrifice of propriety, by affixing the epithet to the chariot-wheel at the time when it is calming the waves.

It may be doubted here and in 8. 89, whether ‘MASK’ is abl., ‘MASK MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK MASK’ or dat., ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Med. originally had ‘MASK MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Med. as a second reading has ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which Wagn. adopts against the whole consensus of the other MSS., objecting to the rhythm of ‘MASK MASK’ and asserting that it cannot be used appropriately of the sky, as it is used of things which inspire dread by their size, not simply wonder. The first objection is obviously futile: the second proceeds on a gratuitous supposition that because the word is used of objects of terror, it cannot be extended to cases where nothing is meant beyond enormous size, and that when ‘MASK MASK MASK’ &c. occur in a neutral connexion (e. MASK ), we are bound to suppose that Virg. meant us to regard the size as formidable, not simply as wonderful. Comp. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Enn. Sat. 3. fr. 4; “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Caes. B. MASK . 5; “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ib. 3. 9. 7. Following a hint of Jahn's, too, we may say that ‘MASK’ here may be meant to impress slightly the notion of the sky as a desert when unpeopled by clouds, not unlike “MASK MASK MASK” MASK note: and this would agree with the passage from Caes. just quoted.

“‘ MASK MASK MASK MASK ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Heyne. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK . Whales form part of Homer's description Il. 13. 27, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK , though they are not there combined with sea gods. ‘MASK’ a Greek pl., like ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ in Lucr.

like “MASK MASK” above v. 240. ‘MASK MASK’ old, like Glaucus himself, who was represented as so covered with marine incrustations as to have lost all trace of his pristine form (Plato, Rep. 10, p. 611), and to be constantly bewailing his immortality (Schol. on Plato l. c.). Keats has seized this point in his elaborate description of him in Endymion, Book 3. The ‘MASK’ are doubtless sea-gods, as in v. 240, though Glaucus was represented as accompanied by MASK when he went about yearly to the coasts and islands of Greece (Paus. 9. 22, § 6). ‘MASK MASK’ MASK .

“MASK MASK” 2. 415., 11. 171, 598. Comp. MASK , where the word is applied to the rooks. Here it is doubtful whether sea-gods or sea-monsters are spoken of. Pliny 36. 5, in his description of a sculpture by Scopas (quoted by Heyne), speaks of “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” which might be pleaded for the latter view. But probably the two were not very sharply distinguished.

neut. pl.: see Forc. ‘MASK’ Med., Gud. a m. s., ‘MASK’ Pal., Gud. a m. p. Rom. has ‘MASK’ Wagn. prefers the sing., Ribbeck the pl. Melite is one of the Nereids mentioned, Il. 18. 39 foll., among Thetis' companions, as are the five whose names follow hers here. “MASK MASK” above v. 240.
See on MASK . Here the line seems to be found in all the MSS., though, as usual, the proper names undergo strange transformations.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

The preceding picture resembles one in MASK foll. (referred to on v. 241 above), where Thetis and the Nereids push the Argo through the Planctae. There it is apparently meant that the powers of the sea were visible: here it would be needless to suppose it to be meant, any more than in v. 241. Aeneas sees the extraordinary calm, and his anxiety, of which we are not told expressly, though we may infer it from the cares which preceded, vv. 700, 720, as from Venus' own, is followed by joy.
“MASK MASK MASK” 1. 502.

Seeing the winds favourable, he orders the masts to be set up and the sails spread. Some copyists, not seeing the sense, wrote ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ as if ‘MASK’ meant the arms of the rowers, as in v. 136 above; and ‘MASK’ is actually found in both Rom. and Med., though Pal. and the majority of the MSS. have ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ however are the sail-yards, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” as Forc. says—a metaphor perhaps invented by Virg., and followed by Val. Fl. 1. 126, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” of the building of the Argo. ‘MASK’ then will be the abl., the meaning being that the sails are stretched on the yards, which Virg. has chosen to express by saying that the yards are stretched with or in respect of the sails. Comp. 4. 506 note.

The description is somewhat minute, perhaps in imitation of such passages as Il. 1. 433 foll. The important words are ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ the rest being merely a description of sailing with a more or less shifting wind. ‘MASK’ or MASK were the ropes attached to the two lower corners of a square sail (Dict. A. ‘MASK’). The word is as old as Hom., occurring Od. 5. 260., 10. 32. These are fastened to the sides of the vessel, towards the stern, an operation briefly expressed by ‘MASK MASK’ which follows the analogy of “MASK MASK MASK” The wind keeps shifting, so the sails are spread (“MASK MASK” 4. 574, opp. to ‘MASK’) first left, then right, to catch it, and this is done ‘MASK’ (like ‘MASK’) by all the vessels at the same time. The omission of ‘MASK’ before ‘MASK’ is to be noted. Forc. says it occurs sometimes, but gives no other instance of it.

the extremities of the ‘MASK’ (3. 549 note), are turned this way and that, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as the sail is shifted. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Hor. Epod. 9. 30, showing that what is said of the shifting of the wind above is not intended to be more than may happen in the most favourable voyage.
“MASK MASK MASK” 2. 40.

after or according to him, a use of the preposition largely illustrated by Hand. Turs. 1, pp. 107 foll. The accusative generally expresses, what is here implied, the rule or law that is followed, as “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK”

“MASK MASK” is a metaphor from the MASK , where the race is round the goal, which accordingly marks that half the course is over. We may then comp. Ov. M. 3. 145, who says, speaking of midday, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though the race he contemplates is a different one, from one point to another, each of which he calls ‘MASK MASK’ But it is possible that Virg. may have an entirely different meaning, considering the arch of the sky as a ‘MASK’ or cone, of which the topmost point is reached at midnight. This is evidently Serv.'s meaning when he says, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Such an interpretation is strongly confirmed by Cic. Div. 2. 6, who, speaking of an eclipse of the moon, says “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” words, as Forc. says, punctually commented on by Pliny 2. 10, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Heyne apparently confuses or combines the two explanations.

With Jahn, Ladewig, and Ribbeck I have restored ‘MASK MASK’ the reading of the earliest editions, and, as now appears, of all the best MSS., Med., Pal., Rom., Gud. &c., for ‘MASK’ The question between them is about as important as that between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ v. 107 above: either might well stand, ‘MASK’ being supported by ‘MASK’ v. 857, where the act is regarded as completed, ‘MASK’ by ‘MASK’ 9. 225, where it is regarded as continuing.
The meaning seems to be that they slept on the benches beside their oars. ‘MASK’ is a touch of late civilization which we should scarcely have found in Hom.
v. 819. ‘MASK MASK’ v. 518 note.
and ‘MASK MASK’ simply by flying through them.

Heyne preferred ‘MASK MASK MASK’ a reading which seems to be very slenderly supported. The distinction attempted by Wagn., as if ‘MASK MASK’ meant ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is surely overstrained. ‘MASK’ we may say with Forc. is put for ‘MASK MASK’ in other words the poet talks of dreams when he means no more than sleep.
‘MASK’ as he did not yield to sleep deliberately, but was overcome by drowsiness against his will.

Phorbas may be the same as the father of an Ilioneus killed by Peneleos Il. 14. 489 foll.: but all that we can say is that Virg. borrowed the name for one of Palinurus' comrades, who, from the speech he makes, may be reasonably supposed, as Gossrau observes, to have been acquainted with steering. ‘MASK’ was read before Pier.
Med. gives ‘MASK MASK’ as in v. 832: but the words are marked as faulty by some later hand.

not shifting, but taking the ship exactly in the stern (comp. v. 777), and filling the sails evenly. Comp. 4. 587 note. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is not explained by the commentators: yet it is susceptible of several meanings: (1) ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ (2) ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ (3) ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ i. e. every one is asleep. On the whole the second seems preferable, though I know of no parallel expression in Virg. or elsewhere which might place it beyond doubt.

11. 830, Hor. 2 S. 8. 58. ‘MASK MASK’ as Heyne remarks, is used like the Greek MASK , though no more is meant than withdrawing, “MASK MASK” much as we in a different connexion might talk of stealing a nap. The construction with the dative is one of those facts which seem to point to a connexion between the dat. and the abl. See on MASK .

seems to contain the notion of entering upon, as in ‘MASK MASK MASK’ So “MASK MASK” is said by Stat. Ach. 1. 280, not, as Forc. says, in the sense of ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ but with a special reference to a horse being only just submitted to the process of breaking in. Virg. probably avoided ‘MASK’ from his usual love of variety, wishing his readers to be reminded of the one compound by the other, while choosing a word which has a meaning of its own.

“‘ MASK MASK MASK ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. Heyne agrees with this preference of the latter interpretation, but Wagn. and Forb. are surely right in adopting the former, which agrees with v. 853. Strictly speaking MASK would have to turn rather than raise his eyes in order to look at the pretended Phorbas; but the attitude of looking down is so natural to those engaged in work, that we easily understand how Virg. came to speak of looking up.
of the sea 1. 35 &c.

Palinurus asks in effect, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is apparently used of the sea to express its strange and noxious qualities, much as we should use ‘MASK’ We may comp. its use of the Trojan horse, 2. 245, of Polyphemus, 3. 658, of Cacus, 8. 198, as well as note on MASK .

This and the next line present considerable difficulty, as the structure of v. 850 seems to show that ‘MASK’ is the dative after ‘MASK MASK’ while that of v. 851 pleads for coupling it with ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Serv. appears to have read ‘MASK MASK’ the reading of some of Pierius' copies, and originally of Pal., and so Ribbeck; but though this would make it easy to take ‘MASK’ as a dat., it would introduce clumsiness and obvious tautology. Donatus also read ‘MASK MASK’ reading too ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ and so making ‘MASK MASK MASK’ parenthetical. A further change, also sanctioned by some MSS. (e. g. Gud. a m. p.), would be to read ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but ‘MASK’ would then be an awkward and superfluous adjunct of ‘MASK MASK’ The proposal, revived by Bothe, to take ‘MASK MASK’ parenthetically, supplying ‘MASK’ to ‘MASK MASK’ and leaving ‘MASK’ to go with ‘MASK MASK’ had already been rejected with reason by Heyne as contrary to the sense of ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Accepting the ordinary pointing as the only natural one, we cannot separate ‘MASK’ from ‘MASK MASK’ as Jahn still wishes to do; while on the other hand to understand ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ with Heyne, Wagn., &c., seems scarcely natural. I would then regard it as one of the instances where Virg. has coupled by a copula two forms of expression not grammatically co-ordinate (see on 3. 329), ‘MASK MASK’ being equivalent to ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ to ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ As such it is rightly included by Wagn. in his Q. V. 34. 2, though with Heyne he gives to ‘MASK’ the sense of ‘MASK MASK MASK’ In these cases Virg. generally contents himself with coupling two words, such as an adverb and an adjective: here he goes farther, so that we might almost class it with instances of the confusion of two constructions, were it not that here the two constructions are completed before they are forced into co-ordination. ‘MASK’ was restored by Wagn. from Med. and Rom. for ‘MASK MASK’ which is found in Pal. from a correction and in Gud., and is supported by Donatus and the Dresden Serv.

Pal. and two other good MSS. have ‘MASK’ as in 9. 323 some have “MASK” for “MASK MASK MASK” varieties which support Lambinus' “MASK MASK” for “MASK” in MASK . The imperfects are intended to show that while he was speaking he moved neither hand nor eye. Virg. doubtless took his description from Od. 3. 281, where Menelaus' pilot dies by a visitation of Apollo in the performance of his duty, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . Comp. also Od. 5. 270 foll., MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK : MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . For ‘MASK’ Med. a m. p. gives ‘MASK MASK’ a natural variation, which might also be accounted for by the form ‘MASK’ found in Pal. a m. p. and adopted by Ribbeck.

For ‘MASK’ one MS. (Hamb. 1 a m. sec.) gives ‘MASK MASK’ which Wagn. was inclined to adopt: but Forb. rightly refers to Hand. Turs. 4, p. 349, where however the most apposite parallel, Plaut. Bacch. 5. 2. 84, rests on a false or doubtful reading. ‘MASK MASK’ is a phrase found more than once in Cic. where we might have expected ‘MASK’ (Ep. Att. 5. 11): and so Virg. has already used ‘MASK MASK’ 2. 620. There is however generally some little force in the substitution, which here there can hardly be said to be.

A branch is used by the god as the best instrument for sprinkling, as by Medea MASK foll. in putting the dragon to sleep. Heyne reminds us of the lustral bough, 6. 230. For the image of dew used in connexion with sleep see on 1. 692.

‘MASK’ to affect with sleep, is commonly applied to making persons, drowsy, more rarely, as here and 6. 420, to imparting soporific properties. The transition is sufficiently natural, especially in poetry, and may be illustrated by Shakspeare's ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ No illustration has been quoted of this supposed soporific effect of the waters of Styx. Perhaps the poet, having mentioned Lethe, added Styx, to show that this was not an ordinary sleep, but a baleful and fatal one. So Serv. “MASK MASK MASK”

of resistance 6. 211, MASK . Heyne rightly remarks that sleep may be said with equal propriety to bind or to relax the eyes. Comp. 9. 189 “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 10. 418 “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Here there is a special propriety in the image, as opposed to the unremitting tension which Palinurus had kept up. “MASK MASK” MASK .

followed by ‘MASK’ 2. 692 note. Burm. erroneously took ‘MASK’ in v. 858 as ‘MASK MASK’ which would involve the awkwardness of referring ‘MASK’ to ‘MASK MASK’ not to speak of other objections. ‘MASK’ has really the force of ‘MASK MASK’ as in 1. 723., 3. 69: but it is also meant to be taken of those limbs, or that part of them, which were first affected by sleep. We should say ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ looking at the process as separable into parts, though the effect of each part would extend equally to the whole body: Virg. chooses to suppose one part of the body affected before another

We need not, with one or two of the later editors, press Virg., as if the breaking away of the rudder and a part of the stern were unlikely in itself and inconsistent with v. 868, where Aeneas manages to perform the part of pilot. The account is at least consistent with 6. 349 foll.

For ‘MASK’ Med. and one or two other MSS. read ‘MASK MASK’ doubtless, as Wagn. remarks, from a recollection of such passages as 6. 506., 10. 873. ‘MASK’ is confirmed, as he observes, by 4. 384, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Some MSS. (including Pal. and Gud.) give ‘MASK MASK’ which would be the stronger expression of the two, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ rather than ‘MASK’ see Wagn. Q. V. 10. 1. ‘MASK’ is supported by MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is connected closely with ‘MASK MASK’ almost as if it had been “MASK MASK MASK” as in v. 657 above.
like “MASK MASK” MASK . Comp. also A. 3. 191, and v. 235 above.
without fear, because without danger. So perhaps 11. 837 “MASK MASK MASK MASK” referring to the position of the spectatress on a mountain. ‘MASK MASK’ see on MASK .

2. 567 note. ‘MASK MASK’ Hom. (Od. 12. 39 foll., 166 foll.) says nothing about rocks: he speaks of the island of the Sirens, but in detail we hear merely of a meadow, with a pile of human bones. Virg. has apparently introduced ‘MASK’ from a wish to rationalize the story, as if the real danger was from shipwreck. Accordingly he drops all mention of the song, employs the epithet ‘MASK’ (comp. Cic. Div. Verr. 11, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where however another reading is ‘MASK’), and describes the waves as even then plashing among the rocks. ‘MASK’ is another instance (see on 3. 700, 704) of Virg. voluntarily or involuntarily separating the time he is writing of from the old heroic age.

referring to ‘MASK MASK’ not contrasted with ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ qualifies ‘MASK MASK’ as Wagn. remarks. The recurrence of the hissing sound is doubtless intentional. “MASK MASK MASK” MASK . Perhaps Virg. imitates MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”.
The sound, and perhaps the unsteady motion of the ship, wake Aeneas, who discovers his loss. ‘MASK MASK’ is perhaps from MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
see on v. 161 above.
v. 700 above.

This and the following line are the words of Aeneas, as we learn from the beginning of the next book. Heyne thought them spurious: but the only charge he brings against them, except that of frigidity, is that they are inconsistent with the fact, Palinurus having met his fate precisely because he refused to trust the sea and take his natural rest—a charge at once answered by Aeneas' ignorance of the circumstances of the case. ‘MASK MASK’ is a singular expression (in Stat. Silv. 3. 2. 10 the reading is doubtful): but Virg. doubtless felt that ‘MASK’ paved the way for the extension of the epithet.

an erroneous reading, took possession of the early editions before Pierius. ‘MASK’ apparently combines the two notions of uncovered by the water (comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”) and unburied. Comp. Soph. Ant. 409, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . ‘MASK’ as opposed to a grave in his own country. To be buried in a foreign land would have been a sorrow (comp. Soph. El. 1141, Catull. 66 (68). 99 &c.): to lie unburied in a foreign land was sorrow upon sorrow. ‘MASK’ is significant, as the corpse would be thrown up on the shore, and lie there. Serv. and Probus (quoted by Pomp. Sabinus) preserve a tradition, which Ribbeck follows, that Virg. added to this book vv. 1, 2 of Book 6, but that Tucca and Varius, or some one else (for the versions of the story vary) transferred them to their present place. The story is easily explained if we suppose with Conrads (see Introduction to this Book) that the present book is an afterthought, Virg. having originally intended to bring Aeneas direct from Carthage to Italy. In that case vv. 1, 2 of Book 6 really belong to the later draught, and in that sense are separable from the lines which they at present precede. As the poem now stands, no reader of taste will, I think, wish to disturb the arrangement of the ordinary editions, supplying as it does an affecting close to the book, which would be spoiled by carrying our thoughts on to Aeneas' safe arrival. The apparent abruptness of the opening of the next book, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is doubtless due to an imitation of the opening of Il. 7, Od. 13. In concluding Book 3 Virg. chose an opposite course: but his object there was precisely the contrary: he did not wish his readers to dwell on Aeneas' last words about the death of Anchises, and so purposely carried them farther, that they might end with a sense of repose.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

On this and the next line see note at the end of Book 5. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is Hom.'s MASK MASK MASK (Il. 1. 357). ‘MASK MASK MASK’ means that he spread his sails to the wind. Comp. 3. 131, 569. ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Livy 8. 22. The colonization from Euboea was subsequent to Aeneas' time: but Virg. as usual thinks of his own age. ‘MASK’ is the reading of Rom.: but see on MASK .

The custom in the heroic times was to stop rowing so as to land stern foremost, the head of the vessel being turned to the sea for greater convenience in departure. Ruhkopf refers to Gronovius, Obss. 4. 26.

in this sense is found in Claudian, De Mall. Cons. 113, who however probably imitates Virg. Elsewhere it is used for making a bottom to a ship: see Forc. ‘MASK MASK’ A difficulty remains about the use of the imperfect, which is perhaps to be explained by supposing that the mooring of the several ships would occupy some time, and so may be represented as a continuing act.
The keels fringe, or, as we should may, line, the shore towards which they are turned. “MASK MASK MASK” 12. 327.
Comp. the landing MASK Africa 1. 174, where Achates strikes fire from a flint. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ MASK MASK Od. 5. 490. Lucr. talks of “MASK MASK” 6. 160, 206.
“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK .

It is questioned whether ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ refers to scouring the woods for game, water, &c., or to stripping them for fuel. ‘MASK’ in the latter case would be parallel to “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 2. 374, in the former to “MASK MASK MASK” Stat. Theb. 5. 3. Heyne objects to the latter interpretation that in that case ‘MASK MASK MASK’ would be mere bombast. But the parallel which he himself quotes, v. 179 below “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” makes for the view which he censures. Wild beasts are mentioned there, though the object of going to the woods is not to take game but to hew timber, so that there seems no reason why they should not be mentioned here, though the object is only to get fuel. In the one passage we hear of “MASK MASK MASK” as our attention is meant to be drawn to the size of the trees: in the other of ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as we are meant (so it may be urged) to think of the thickness of the foliage. “MASK” was a common military occupation, and is naturally classed with “MASK” If we suppose the pursuit of game to be meant, we may compare Aeneas' deerslaying 1. 184 foll. ‘MASK MASK’ = “MASK MASK MASK MASK”

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

It is worth while to compare Virg.'s account of MASK' interview with the Sibyl with Ovid's (M. 14. 101—157), a large part of which is occupied by the Sibyl's own story, told by herself to MASK in the course of a conversation with which, as we are told, they beguile the hardships of their journey. We must remember however that Ovid's business is to tell marvellous stories, and that the Sibyl's naturally came in as one of these. Henry is doubtless right in regarding the Sibyl's cave as the adytum of the temple of MASK, in opposition to Heyne and Wagn., who make the two independent and MASK some distance from each other. He cites the parallel instance of Delphi. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” he says, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” On the lower part of this hill, on one of the sides not next the sea, he places the sacred grove, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ on the sloping part of the hill a hypaethral temple, having the grove on both sides and in front: in the front sculptured doors: on the fourth or hinder side, consisting merely of the bare perpendicular rock of the hill, a number of other doors, leading into a vast cave in the substance of the rock. ‘MASK’ seems to point to the hilly position as well as to the height of the temple. “MASK MASK” 10. 875, where majesty seems the prominent notion. Here it would be difficult to exclude the notion of physical elevation, already indicated by ‘MASK’ (comp. “MASK MASK” 11. 837): perhaps also height of stature is intended. This would agree with the fact, mentioned by Serv. on the authority of Caelius, that the statue of MASK MASK Cumae was fifteen feet high.

seems rightly taken by Forb. in its strict sense, as the aspect of the Sibyl under the divine afflatus might well inspire horror: comp. vv. 47 foll., 77 foll. ‘MASK’ is explained by Heyne and Wagn., in conformity with their general view, of the distance of the cave from the temple: by Henry, of the distance of both from the place where Aeneas landed. Perhaps it rather denotes the depth of the cavern, stretching far into the distance. ‘MASK’ 8. 463, MASK .

is doubtless the Homeric MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , as Cerda and others have remarked, ‘MASK’ referring to the power of insight, ‘MASK’ to energy of conception, language, and gesture, as Forb. says. The rhythm and expression are from MASK : see Munro there, who regards the words as a mere poetical tautology. But there is still a question, which Heyne states, as to the construction of ‘MASK MASK’—whether it means that Apollo breathes a mind and spirit into the Sibyl, or, as we should say, inspires her mind and spirit, i. e. with the knowledge of the future. If we adopt the latter, which Heyne prefers, we must take ‘MASK’ closely with ‘MASK MASK’ = ‘MASK MASK’ as ‘MASK’ 4. 3 = ‘MASK MASK’ But though ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is doubtless an admissible construction, the instances quoted by Forc. are both from later writers (“MASK MASK MASK” Quinct. 12. 10, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Justin 43. 1), while the conception of ‘MASK’ as a thing communicated is abundantly supported by such passages as 1. 304., 12. 554, MASK .

‘MASK MASK MASK’ is not an unmeaning description of Apollo here, as it implies that the same power which is manifested at Delos is manifested at Cumae. As Heyne remarks, Apollo is Jupiter's prophet, just as the Sibyl is Apollo's: comp. 3. 251, Aesch. Eum. 19. 616 foll.
They enter first the grove that surrounds or abuts the temple, then the temple itself.

For MASK and the stories connected with him see Dict. Myth. The bulk of tradition seems to point to Sicily as the place where he took refuge after leaving Crete: but Sardinia was also mentioned as a spot to which he went. Italy as well as the adjoining islands would naturally associate his name with its works of art: and so Sil. 12. 102 makes him the builder of a temple of Apollo at Capua, under circumstances similar to those in the text—one of Silius' many imitations of Virg. ‘MASK’ probably includes the government as well as the kingdom. At any rate ‘MASK’ is significant, as it was on Minos' account that MASK fled from Crete.

Virg. might have spoken of flying as either trusting to wings or trusting to the sky. Here he has chosen the latter, ‘MASK’ being the instrumental abl. This is better than to make ‘MASK’ dat., ‘MASK’ abl., whether ‘MASK’ be connected in that case with what precedes, or, as Heyne suggested and Wakef. punctuates, with what follows. “MASK MASK” MASK is different: see note there. ‘MASK’ here merely means ‘MASK’ and has no augurial reference.

We have already had ‘MASK’ and one of its compounds used of flying, 4. 245, MASK . But Virg. may have been thinking of MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” of the soul quitting the body. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ has perplexed the commentators: but Wagn. after Hand. Turs. 1, p. 82, seems right in explaining it as meaning no more than that Daedalus flew northward, which would be the case whether we think of his rising from the ground, or of the position of Cumae as north of Crete.

&c. gives the reason of what follows. This being the place where he alighted, he paid a thank-offering to Apollo here. Here the majority of MSS. MASK restoring it, though with considerable hesitation. ‘MASK’ indicates that the Athenians sending their children to death was a second subject represented. How it was represented may be gathered from v. 22, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” With ‘MASK MASK’ comp. Catull. 62 (64). 173, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” of the Minotaur.

interjectional, like ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ &c. Heinsius' latest notion that it could stand for ‘MASK’ is contrary to Virg.'s usage: see on 3. 704. ‘MASK’ the story mentioned seven youths and seven maidens: but Virg. has chosen only to name the former.

see on 2. 18. The force of the periphrasis here is the same as when in the writ of Habeas Corpus the body of a prisoner is required to be produced. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ = ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK”

We need not inquire how many of the subjects hinted at by Virg. were separately represented. It is sufficient to say that there was a plurality of sculptures in the Cretan part, as there had been in the Athenian. “MASK MASK” E. 10. 29. Here the epithet is meant to excite our pity for Pasiphae as a victim, as she actually was, the passion having been Venus' revenge on her for revealing the goddess' adultery with Mars. ‘MASK’ = ‘MASK’ 4. 337. Comp. 7. 283, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

“‘ MASK MASK , ’MASK MASK” Heyne. ‘MASK MASK’ pl. for sing., referring only to the Minotaur. The licence is one of the many metrical licences of Roman epic poetry.

Forb. would make ‘MASK’ nom. in apposition to ‘MASK MASK’ like 7. 248, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” but it is doubtless gen., probably to be explained as definitive (Madv. § 286), like ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ The labour is that of Daedalus, not, as Heyne thought, that of the wanderers in the labyrinth. Perhaps also ‘MASK’ is to be constructed with ‘MASK’ as in Catull. 62 (64). 115, which Virg. had in his mind, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though the construction would not be quite the same as that with ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 5. 591.

Virg. recapitulates the heads of the story briefly, and, to one unacquainted with it, unintelligibly. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is not, what it would seem from the context it must mean, the passion of the queen Pasiphae, but that of the princess (comp. 1. 273: so Valerius Flaccus uses it repeatedly of Medea: see Forc.) the framer of the puzzle consented to solve it. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” Catull. 1. c.: comp. also 5. 590.

not his own footsteps, but those of Theseus—another instance of Virg.'s ambiguity. The expression is from Catull. v. 113, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where Theseus is the subject of the sentence. Comp. also 3. 659.
“MASK MASK MASK” MASK . On the construction ‘MASK MASK’ see Madv, § 442 a. obs. 2. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is omitted by Rom. and some other MSS., Ribbeck thinks on account of the length of the line.

like “MASK MASK” 1. 643. ‘MASK MASK’ successively, MASK . The choice lies between regarding ‘MASK’ as a dactyl, and compressing it into a spondee by synizesis: a hypermeter, which Macrob. Sat. 5. 14 talks of, is not to be entertained, as in the case of other hypermetric verses in Virg. the following line begins with a vowel. See on MASK . The hypothesis of a dactylic ending would not be impossible in itself, but becomes highly improbable in the face of the fact that of all the possible instances in Virg. some, like MASK ., 3. 449, may be regarded as hypermeters; others, like the present one and 7. 237, may be resolved by synizesis. ‘MASK’ then will be a dissyllable, like ‘MASK’ 5. 269. Copyists sought to get rid of the anomaly by substituting ‘MASK’ (actually found in Rom.), ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ as in 7. 237 they substituted ‘MASK’ ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’

Terentius Scaurus in his treatise De Orthographia contends that Virg. wrote ‘MASK’ a form printed by Ritschl in some passages in Plautus on MS. authority. For the rhetorical use of the imperf. for the pluperf. see Madv. § 347 b. obs. 2. The plural is used because Aeneas had several companions with him: comp. vv. 13, 41, 54. ‘MASK MASK’ sent on by Aeneas, that the Sibyl might be ready for him on his arrival at the temple. “MASK MASK” 1. 644. ‘MASK’ probably with ‘MASK’ rather than with ‘MASK MASK’

“MASK MASK MASK” 10. 537, of Haemonides. Holdsworth and Spence (Miscellanea Virgiliana, pp. 207 foll.) distinguish between the priestess and the Sibyl, who they say, being a goddess, required some other person to introduce worshippers to her. But their distinction is not really borne out by Virg., who must have intended the same person in vv. 46 foll. and 77 foll., a patent fact which they are compelled to deny. The Sibyl is nowhere called a goddess by Virg., as in v. 258 ‘MASK’ is Hecate: she is called a priestess v. 321, as they admit. It is true, as they assert, that in Silius Italicus, Book 13, where Scipio goes down into the shades, he deals in the first instance not with the Sibyl, but with the priestess Autonoe: but Silius' Sibyl is not alive, but dead: she is like Homer's Tiresias, who drinks the blood of the victim, and then acquires the power of speech, and tells the visitor what he wishes to know. They object that Deiphobe the daughter of Glaucus was not the Sibyl's name; but there were several Sibyls, and the Cumaean Sibyl in particular had several names (Dict. Myth. ‘MASK’), so that Virg. may have followed some legend unknown to us, or may have thought himself at liberty to invent a name. On the whole subject see Heyne's Excursus. Glaucus, as the commentators remark, is a natural personage to be a Sibyl's father, being himself a prophetic god.
of Aeneas, as in v. 55 &c. Some MSS. leave out ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’

is found in Rom., and is the earlier reading of Med. The editors think it intrinsically inferior to ‘MASK MASK’ but there is little difference between making the time call for the thing to be done, and making the thing to be done call for the time. It might even be urged that as ‘MASK’ apparently goes not with ‘MASK’ but with ‘MASK MASK’ the latter is here the more natural expression. ‘MASK’ however is more likely to have been altered into ‘MASK’ than vice versa , as copyists are apt to alter the number to make the verb agree with the noun immediately preceding. See Wagn. Q. V. 8. Serv. recommends ‘MASK MASK’
by the yoke, more fully expressed MASK (note) by “MASK MASK MASK” The sacrifice is to Apollo and Diana.
the subj. has the force of the Attic optative with MASK , courteously avoiding a direct and dogmatic assertion. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ 4. 57 note. Fragm. Vat. has ‘MASK MASK’

is a substantive, so that ‘MASK MASK’ is like “MASK MASK” 3. 547, “MASK MASK” MASK . ‘MASK’ then will mean to delay to execute, or execute slowly, as in Val. F. 7. 60, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” possibly an imitation of Virg.
see on v. 9. They had been standing before the gate, and now are summoned within.

A description, as Henry rightly takes it, not of the temple but of the adytum, which, as at Delphi, was a cavern MASK the rock. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the rock or hill of Cumae: see on v. 9. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is a variety, as Heyne observes, for “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

and ‘MASK’ seem rightly explained by Henry as a sort of Virgilian hendiadys, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ But it is not easy to understand what these entrances were. On the whole the consistency of the description seems to require that we should understand them to be the entrances of the adytum, opening into the temple (comp. 3. 92, where the ‘MASK’ is opened similarly at the giving of the response): but a hundred doors communicating from one side of the temple to a cavern beyond form a picture which is not readily grasped. Meanwhile the general tenor of the narrative is well illustrated by a graphic description of a worshipper at Delphi approaching the ‘MASK’ in the Oxford ‘MASK MASK MASK’ for 1859, by my friend Mr. Bowen of Balliol College. I quote it in an Appendix to this book, as it is too long for a note.
expresses the general practice: through these doors the responses of the Sibyl are habitually communicated.

sc. ‘MASK MASK’ whether identical with any of these doors we are not told. The Sibyl goes into the cave (comp. v. 77); Aeneas and the Trojans remain outside. ‘MASK MASK’ is explained by what follows, v. 52. The sacrifices had been performed, but prayer was still necessary to obtain the response, and this was the time for prayer, the god having already manifested himself. The words seem to mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ being used as in 1. 382 &c. Comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and possibly A. 3. 456, where however see note. Elsewhere, as in 7. 272 &c., the fates themselves are said ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK” 9. 12. For the construction see on MASK .

like ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ = ‘MASK MASK’ with which it is not unfrequently joined: see Forc. The sense is not that her countenance and colour keep changing, but that they are different from what they were before.

Heyne remarks that her hair would be already unbound, as the sacrifice had been made (see on 3. 370), so that Virg. must here mean that the hair stood on end or was tossed about. But we need not press the poet so closely. Unbound or dishevelled hair was usual when a priest or prophet approached the gods: and Virg. has chosen to represent the hair of the Sibyl as becoming disordered at this particular point of the story.

‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ As the forms of the gods and of the dead were supposed to be larger than those of ordinary humanity (see on 2. 773), so the Sibyl seems to increase in stature under the divine afflatus . In less poetical language we should say that she rises to her full height, and every limb is stretched with excitement. The picture is virtually the same as that of Wordsworth's Laodamis, expecting an answer to her prayer: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

might be regarded as a historical infinitive, with Serv. and some of the early editors: but Heyne rightly constructs it with ‘MASK MASK’ as if it were a translation of MASK MASK . Wagn. comp. “MASK MASK” Hor. 4. Od. 2. 59, “MASK MASK” Id. 1 Od. 19. 7. Some notion equivalent to ‘MASK MASK’ must of course be supplied from the context.

of a person speaking loudly, 12. 529. With the expression generally comp. 1. 328, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is causal rather than temporal, so that Heyne's suggestion, adopted by Jahn, to place a period at ‘MASK MASK’ and connect ‘MASK MASK’ with what follows, would be no improvement. With the position of ‘MASK’ comp. 10. 366, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. explains ‘MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ (subst.) are terms regularly used of divine inspiration (see Forc.), like MASK and its cognates.

With ‘MASK’ comp. the use of ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ of divine favour, and the cognate ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is a variety for the more ordinary use of ‘MASK’ with the abl., as MASK Cic. Sen. 5, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Forb. comp. “MASK MASK MASK” 2. 347. We should expect the construction ‘MASK’ with acc. after a verb signifying tendency to promote an object rather than the reverse: but the explanation doubtless is that the absence of such a tendency is considered to affect the object MASK question no less than its presence. The phrase is imitated by Sen., Medea 406, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK” 11. 158.

gives the reason why he should pray fervently, and ‘MASK’ refers to fervent prayer as implied in its opposite ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is used of the flying open of the doors, in accommodation to ‘MASK MASK’

The earlier commentators, following Serv., were satisfied with making ‘MASK’ = “MASK MASK MASK” Later editors, who see that both on poetical and grammatical grounds it is to be understood strictly, the house being conceived of and endowed with human feelings, are still divided as to the force which should be given to it, Heyne and Wagn. referring it to the effect of the sudden opening of the doors, Henry to the spell-bound silence which prevents the opening, while Forb. after Süpfl understands it generally of the condition of the cave as possessed by the god. On the whole Henry's interpretation seems to give the most consistent and poetical picture. He compares a similar application of the word in Lucan 2. 21, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The Sibyl, in describing the feelings of the ‘MASK MASK’ is in effect describing her own. The effect of the inspiration is to bewilder and confound her, so that she cannot at first master herself sufficiently to speak; and so now after a hurried injunction to Aeneas she relapses into her stormy silence.
iron as was the nature of the Trojan warriors, they trembled in every limb. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 2. 120.

in prose would be constructed with ‘MASK’ rather than with ‘MASK MASK’ but it is in any case emphatic, as its position shows. Achilles, the greatest enemy of Troy , had been destroyed by Apollo, and not only this, but destroyed through the instrumentality of a Trojan. The joint agency of Apollo and Paris in the death of Achilles was part of the Homeric tradition, Il. 22. 359, other stories making Paris the sole agent (Dict. M. ‘MASK’). In Ov. M. 12. 580 foll. Apollo, at the instance of Neptune, appears to Paris, encourages him to shoot at Achilles rather than at meaner foes, and guides his aim. ‘MASK’ see on 5. 786. With ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which may be called a species of hendiadys, the notion being a single one, the hand fixing the arrow or the arrow fixed by the hand, comp. Aesch. Ag. 111, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .
of surrounding, Ov. M. 5. 51, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Forc. So A. 10. 482.

is probably to be explained from the context, and especially from v. 62. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ implies that the seas were previously unknown to him, “MASK MASK MASK” as they are called 3. 373. ‘MASK MASK’ need not mean that Apollo showed the way, but merely that he prompted them to sail till they should reach Italy. Comp. “MASK MASK” 10. 92. ‘MASK’ 3. 364 note. ‘MASK’ is only an extension of the same notion, so that the two words = “MASK MASK MASK”

Perhaps it is more like Virg. to separate the noun from its epithet. ‘MASK’ is said to be the reading of eight MSS. examined by Burm. ‘MASK’ may be either present or perf., but the former seems rhetorically preferable. Hor. 3 Od. 3. 61, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ the perf. subj. used as a past opt. or imperative. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The use is not quite the same as that of ‘MASK’ 2. 325, as here the force of the past is partially given by ‘MASK MASK’

“MASK MASK MASK” MASK . ‘MASK’ is here used of that which creates dislike, without any reference to active opposition. So Sil. 17. 551 (quoted by Forb.), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” an obvious imitation of Virg., Pers. 5. 163, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 2. 325.

with gen. is found also in Val. Flaccus and Tac. (see Forc.), on the analogy of ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ &c. ‘MASK MASK’ for the sense see 3. 85 (note), for the construction 5. 689. Some editions make the parenthesis to end with ‘MASK MASK’ which Heyne rightly rejects.

It is extremely difficult to say whether ‘MASK’ is the dat., as Burm. thinks, or the abl., as Peerlkamp and Forb. contend. Either expression would be Virgilian (comp. 7. 120, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” with 11. 759 “MASK MASK MASK”), and either would yield an appropriate sense, as the fates may be represented either as satisfying the requirements of others, or as having their own requirements satisfied (comp. the passages where the fates are said ‘MASK MASK’ 4. 614 &c.). Where the fates are identified with an individual, as here by the possessive pronoun ‘MASK MASK’ they assume as it were a subordinate position (comp. 7. 293, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”), and so may be regarded not as causing events, but as demanding their fulfilment from some other power. The question then is whether the Sibyl is here regarded as the person through whom a demand is made on destiny, or on whom the destinies of private persons make their demand. On the whole I think it must be left open, as there seems nothing in the context, in the nature of the case, or in parallel passages to incline the scale either way, though Val. F. 5. 508 (quoted by Forb.), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” looks as if that author understood ‘MASK’ as dative. ‘MASK’ 4. 349, where as here the names of Italy and the Trojans are contrasted by way of emphasis. Rom. has ‘MASK MASK’
as in 12. 803, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” With the general sense Forb. compares Ilioneus ' language 7. 229.

The temple was built in honour of Apollo (Suet. Oct. 29), but it appears from the description in Prop. 3. 23. 15 that the statue of the god stood between statues of Latona and Diana. ‘MASK’ was restored by Heins. from Med. and Rom. for ‘MASK’ (Pal., Gud. &c.). Henry prefers the latter, but in the parallel instances he quotes the plural is put for the sing. for the metre, which could not be pleaded here: and the change seems due to some copyist who supposed two temples to be intended. “MASK MASK MASK” 4. 457, MASK .

is connected with ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ by a kind of zeugma, not unlike “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 1. 264. ‘MASK MASK’ occurs Val. F. 3. 426. Rom. has ‘MASK MASK’ which would suit ‘MASK MASK’ but not ‘MASK MASK’ The ‘MASK MASK’ are the ludi Apollinares instituted B. C. 212 (Liv. 25. 12).

It might appear at first sight as if Aeneas were promising the Sibyl a temple: but the reference is doubtless to the honours paid by the Romans to the Sibylline books, which were first placed in the Capitol, and afterwards deposited by Augustus under the base of the statue of his Palatine Apollo. The latter is of course especially alluded to. In Ov. M. 14. 128, to which Heyne refers, Aeneas promises the Sibyl a temple in so many words; but she expressly declines the offer, as not being a goddess. ‘MASK’ may possibly point to the secrecy of the place where the books were laid up: but it is often used rather vaguely, and in Sil. 13. 62 it seems to stand for a movable shrine, if not for the statue of a deity. ‘MASK’ of a thing in the future 7. 319 &c.

i. e. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ refers of course to the Sibylline books, which were entrusted to the charge of ‘MASK MASK MASK’ at first two, then ten, afterwards fifteen or more. ‘MASK’ of oracles 4. 346.

the oracles had not as yet been uttered but are conceived of as uttered at the time to which Aeneas looks forward, so that it is in fact an invitation to the Sibyl to utter them. Not unlike is “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 8. 629. ‘MASK’ is used much as in 1. 264, of setting up permanently.

is specially applied to goddesses, 1. 618., 10. 215, 220 &c., a sort of equivalent to the Greek MASK , and so is applied as a complimentary appellation to the Sibyl here and v. 117. ‘MASK MASK’ as Forb. remarks, is frequently used in adjurations, as in 8. 78. The request here made formed part of the advice of Helenus, 3. 456. “MASK MASK” 3. 444.
Comp. 3. 448 foll.

3. 457. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” is quoted from Lucilius by Non. v. ‘MASK MASK’ Enn. A. fr. inc. 108 has “MASK MASK MASK MASK” where Vahlen not improbably reads “MASK MASK MASK” Columna “MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ as in 1. 614 &c.; it might however go with ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Some critics have thought the hemistich spurious: but there is nothing un-Virgilian about it, and it is apparently found in all the MSS.

as the horse is said “MASK MASK” “MASK MASK” MASK , 208. ‘MASK’ qualifies ‘MASK MASK’ as if it had been ‘MASK’ (comp. MASK ), like “MASK MASK” 7. 510.
9. 512. ‘MASK MASK’ 5. 679 note. Here, as Forb. remarks, the metaphor is brought out more definitely, being that of a horse trying to throw its rider.

The perf. inf. is used like the Greek aorist, where a prose writer would have used the present: Madv. § 407, obs. 2. Wagn. remarks that it is much commoner in the elegiac poets than in Virg. The reason is doubtless to be found in the exigencies of the pentameter. ‘MASK MASK’ plies her till she is weary and gives in, the special reference here being to the use of the bit.

is meant to remind us at once of the mouth of the horse and the tongue of the Sibyl. The object of ‘MASK’ is the Sibyl herself, not ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ comp. Hor. 1 Ep. 2. 64, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where see note. ‘MASK MASK’ as it was by restraint that Apollo gained the victory.

See on v. 43. The doors are supposed to fly open simultaneously with the opening of the Sibyl's mouth. ‘MASK’ placed as in 3. 588. ‘MASK MASK’ the perf. of instantaneous action, MASK &c. Aeneas is in the temple, the Sibyl in the ‘MASK MASK’ the cavern beyond, and the sound of the prophecy is carried to him through the open doors; but the hundred passages form a picture which, as I have observed on v. 43, is hard to realize, and which scarcely seems appropriate to the circumstances of the narrative.

The address is not unlike “MASK MASK MASK” 1. 199. The Sibyl tells him that one class of perils is over, but that another, and a more grievous one, is at hand. The old pointing is doubtless right, the Sibyl's address in this line being in fact an announcement, which is followed by another announcement, ‘MASK MASK’ &c., as against Forb. and Henry, who would throw ‘MASK MASK MASK’ into a parenthesis.

Med., Pal., ‘MASK’ Rom. The former is the more difficult reading, and as such is, I think, rightly restored by Wagn. There is however still considerable doubt about the interpretation of it, as it may be either a possessive gen. or a locative gen. or dat. The former is sufficiently supported by 10. 57, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 1. 598, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” the latter has the analogy of ‘MASK’ in its favour, and is defended by such passages as 10. 555, 11. 87, MASK , and by ‘MASK’ 3. 162. The passage itself is perhaps rather in favour of the locative, as there would be a slight harshness in the omission of ‘MASK’ if it is intended to be closely constructed with ‘MASK MASK’ Yet it would be too hazardous to argue from the passages referred to that Virg. regarded ‘MASK’ as an actual locative like ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ as the ordinary sense of the dative can be traced more or less clearly in all three. The etymological history of a case is one thing, the manner in which it is likely to have been employed by a poet at a time when that history was forgotten or ignored, another. I think then that Wagn. and Forb. are right in their second thoughts, in regarding ‘MASK’ as a possessive gen. For ‘MASK’ Serv. mentions a variant ‘MASK MASK’ but the prophetess, as Heyne remarks, sees the future in the present, and calls the kingdom from the city which is to be built (1. 258).

There is the same kind of emphatic contrast in ‘MASK’ as in v. 57 above. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is not a purely poetical expression, as “MASK MASK MASK MASK” is quoted from Livy 30. 3. ‘MASK’ is more commonly used alone, as 1. 203.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is another way of saying ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK” 7. 41.
For the general sense comp. 8. 538 foll., for the particular feature 10. 24. Heyne refers to Il. 7. 329, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .

Serv. is perhaps right in supposing MASK and MASK to refer specially to the Tiber and the Numicius, the latter of which, according to the legend, was the scene of Aeneas' death or disappearance. The names may be used without any such reference; but without such a reference they would rather want force. ‘MASK MASK’ 2. 27. In 10. 60 foll., which Heyne compares, Venus asks that if the Trojans are to suffer a second destruction, they may at least suffer it in the old place, and have MASK and MASK near them again.

the perf. subj. or fut. perf. used instead of the ordinary future for poetical variety or metrical convenience. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ If any special propriety is to be discovered in its use here, we may say that the prophetess throws herself as far as possible into the future, so as to look at part of what is to come as already past. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Turnus. Heyne comp. Eur. Tro. 614, MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK , and Virg.'s own words, MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” For the peculiar sense of ‘MASK’ see on 2. 784. ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ not, as Wagn. thinks, with ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ according to Wagn., is the dat.; I would rather regard it as the abl., ‘MASK MASK’ like ‘MASK’ 2. 783 (not, as Wakef., ‘MASK MASK’), supplying ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ But it is very doubtful, as the sense may very well be, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

comp. 10. 75, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is rightly explained by the later editors as simply strengthening ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ So ‘MASK MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ which occurs frequently in Virg., e. g. vv. 528, 777 below.

connects what follows with the previous sentence as belonging to the same time, being in fact equivalent to ‘MASK MASK MASK’ The prophecy is fulfilled by the mission to Evander, which occupies Book 8. ‘MASK MASK’ of distress 10. 367.

This rhetorical interrogation or exclamation, introduced into a categorical sentence, is not uncommon in Greek. Comp. Aesch. Ag. 556, MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK ; ‘MASK MASK’ the perf. implies that Aeneas will have tried every resource, yet the evil will still be unconquered.

“MASK MASK MASK” 11. 480, also of Lavinia. Lavinia was to be the prize of this second war, as Helen had been of the first. The parallel is more natural in the mouth of an enemy of the Trojans, like Amata (7. 363), or Turnus (9. 136 foll.); but it has its place here, as the Sibyl's object is to show that the tragedy of Troy is to repeat itself.
(mala). ‘MASK MASK’ all the bolder for opposition.

For ‘MASK’ Heyne restored ‘MASK MASK’ the reading of the first Aldine edition, supported by the MSS. of Sen. Ep. 82, as it was not likely that the Sibyl should advise Aeneas to act contrary to his destiny. The objection to giving ‘MASK’ this sense, by connecting it either with ‘MASK’ or, as might be proposed, with ‘MASK MASK’ seems valid, in spite of Wagn.'s defence, as though a rhetorical writer, like Tac. Hist. 2. 46 (quoted by Cerda), might talk of opposing fortune, the sentiment is not in Virg.'s manner (comp. 5. 710), and would in any case scarcely have been put by him into the mouth of a prophetess. It seems better then with Heins. and Burm. to understand ‘MASK’ on the analogy of ‘MASK MASK MASK’—‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ With ‘MASK MASK MASK’ comp. 2. 387.
“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 12. 626. The expression is found in Livy: see Forc. ‘MASK MASK’ The city is of course Evander's, Pallanteum.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’
‘MASK’ MASK note.

is applied by Ov. M. 7. 761 to the riddle of the Sphinx, and is more than once used by Tac. in speaking of oracles: see Forc. ‘MASK’ is explained by ‘MASK MASK’ the cave echoing the scarcely human sounds (comp. 3. 92, where the ‘MASK’ is said ‘MASK’) which the Sibyl utters.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Cerda comp. Eur. Or. 891, MASK MASK MASK MASK , which Virg. may have had in his mind, though the reading there is not certain, Valckenaer conjecturing MASK , which Porson adopts. ‘MASK’ has the force of ‘MASK MASK’ see on MASK . The reference is not, as Wagn. thinks, specially to ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ but generally to the whole description of the Sibyl's ecstasy, which is ascribed to the agency of Apollo.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ We need not supply ‘MASK’ to ‘MASK MASK’ as in cases like this the construction of the second clause is not always formally assimilated to that of the first. See on MASK . “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 9. 718. ‘MASK’ need merely indicate the direction of the goad to the part wounded: but it may also imply the continual change of direction, the weapon being turned hither and thither. The whole description is simply one of prophetic excitement. MASK tames her and breaks her in (v. 79), but he also lashes her to fury.
Aeneas waits for a calm, that she may be able to listen to him. ‘MASK MASK’ v. 80.

MASK' meaning appears to be not, as Heyne explains it, that he has heard what is to happen to him from his father or Helenus, but that he has prepared himself for every possible form of danger by his own reflections, so that the passage is strictly parallel to Ter. Phorm. 2. 1. 11 foll., quoted by Cerda (see Mr. Parry's note), and to Eur. Thes. fr. 392 Nauck, referred to by Cic. Tusc. 3. 14, along with the passage from Ter.
like “MASK MASK” below v. 560, MASK . Like ‘MASK MASK’ the sense of appearance passes into that of type or variety. ‘MASK’ of a new thing emerging 1. 582.
For ‘MASK’ many MSS. give ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ of mentally going over a thing, like ‘MASK’ 4. 476.
as in v. 50. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” below v. 127.

= “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Comp. Soph. Trach. 638, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK ( MASK Herm., MASK Musgrave). ‘MASK’ must here be taken in the sense of overflowing, as it was the overflow of the river that formed the ‘MASK MASK MASK’ The river is apparently looked upon as imbibing the water which forms its current and disgorging it when there is too much. It matters little whether ‘MASK MASK’ is taken as a descriptive abl. or as abl. abs. Not unlike is 7. 569, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
the objective gen. after ‘MASK MASK’ Comp. 9. 261, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Pal., Rom., and Gud. a m. p. have ‘MASK MASK’ but ‘MASK’ does not seem to be used for ‘MASK MASK MASK’ There is no difficulty about ‘MASK MASK’ as the infernal gods had their honours as well as others. So “MASK MASK” v. 573 below.

Aeneas, in describing to Dido what actually happened, does not dwell on the fire and the enemy (comp. 2. 725 foll., where we hear of alarm rather than of real danger): but we have a similar image when he speaks of his journey from Priam's palace to his own home, 2. 632.

“MASK MASK MASK” 1. 524, the usual way in which the Trojans speak of their wanderings. ‘MASK’ is connected with ‘MASK’ by a kind of zeugma. There is however nothing tautologous in ‘MASK MASK’ after ‘MASK MASK’ as the sense is that he sailed on every sea and bore all the dangers of wind and wave.
Med. and one other MS. give “MASK MASK MASK MASK”
Anchises exceeded the destiny of old age by encountering what old men in general do not encounter.
Pal. a m. p., Rom., and Gud. omit ‘MASK MASK’

seems to show that the injunction was given more than once, so that we must suppose the reference to be not to Anchises' appearance 5. 731 foll., but to directions given while he was alive. The father might naturally advise his son to consult the Sibyl about the future, as Helenus does 3. 441 foll., quite irrespectively of his own death or life. ‘MASK MASK’ 4. 605.
v. 74. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is explained by ‘MASK MASK’ &c. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK” below v. 366, the Homeric MASK MASK (Od. 5. 27). See Burm. on Val. F. 1. 13.

as in MASK ., 4. 38. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The Sibyl was priestess of Diana, who is called Hecate in her functions in the world below, 4. 511. note. ‘MASK’ is explained by vv. 131, 138, 238 &c. below. ‘MASK’ adj., as in MASK .

has been variously taken as an unfinished sentence, as a protasis to ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ v. 123, and as following ‘MASK MASK MASK’ v. 117. The first explanation is perhaps nearest the truth; but the sentence does not strike us as unfinished, for the appeal which really forms the apodosis is implicitly contained in the context. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The story is of course that told at the end of Georgic 4. Med., Rom., and Gud. a m. p. have ‘MASK MASK’ see the lexicons.
4. 245 note. Comp. Orph. Arg. 42 (quoted by Heyne) MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK , doubtless an imitation of the present passage and of MASK .

The story was that MASK was allowed to impart his immortality to Castor and share his brother's mortality in return, the two dying according to one account on alternate days, according to another for alternate periods of six months. In Hom. (Il. 3. 243) both are mortal.

4. 468. Gell. 10. 16 tells us that Hyginus censured Virg. for introducing Theseus, who was detained in the shades, as we shall see below v. 618. Serv. meets the objection in a good note: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and Heyne remarks that the point of the appeal lies simply in the fact that Theseus was one of those who were allowed to go down to the shades alive. Theseus and Hercules are referred to below v. 392. It is difficult to say whether ‘MASK’ belongs to ‘MASK MASK’ as Wagn. thinks, following the old editors, or to ‘MASK MASK’ as Heins. and Heyne take it. There is more point in giving the epithet to the person named last: Hercules, who returned in triumph, seems to deserve it better than Theseus, who was kept below: and the epithet is bestowed on Hercules elsewhere in Virg., 5. 414, “MASK MASK MASK” 8. 103, “MASK MASK MASK” On the other hand ‘MASK MASK’ is supported by “MASK MASK MASK” which ends a verse similarly 10. 317; and we must remember that in an ancient poet punctuation is regulated rather by the ear than by the eye. On the whole then it seems safest to follow Wagn.
“MASK MASK MASK MASK” 1. 380.
