4. 219 note.
“MASK MASK MASK” 8. 36. See on v. 322 below. Serv. rather ingeniously remarks, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Med. (first reading), Pal., Rom., ‘MASK’ Med. (second reading). For the reasons for preferring the former, see on 3. 475. ‘MASK’ Med., Pal. a m. p., ‘MASK’ Pal. a m. s., Rom., Gud. Serv. mentions both. The dat. (see on MASK ) is more likely to have been altered into the gen. than vice versa , as the construction of a local case with a verbal noun might create a difficulty. It is paralleled however by a passage given in Forc. ‘MASK’ from Hirt. B. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Some MSS., including a correction in Med., have ‘MASK’ after ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ The sentiment apparently is the common one that the path to death is easily trodden, and in fact must be trodden by all, but can rarely if ever be retraced. Aesch. expresses it in his way, Pers. 689, where the shade of Darius says MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . Cerds quotes a Greek epigram, MASK MASK MASK MASK . Virg. makes use of the thought for his purpose here, though it does not seem very suitable. The difficulty is for a living man to make the journey; this, as we find afterwards, can only be surmounted by obtaining a passport of a particular kind (vv. 136 foll., 391 foll.): but when it has once been surmounted, the return does not appear to be less easy than any other part of the journey; at least we do not find that Aeneas had any obstacle to overcome (v. 898). Seneca, as his manner is, enforces the same truth in the same way, apropos of Hercules' descent, Herc. F. 675 foll.

The expression may remind us, whether it was intended to do so or not, of the Greek notion of Hades as a landlord who entertained all comers, as shown by such epithets as MASK Aesch. Supp. 157 &c. Heyne compares a passage from Varro quoted by Macr. Sat. 1. 16, from which it appears that on days when funeral offerings were made it was said that “MASK MASK MASK” which Varro explains “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The infernal gods were conceived of as dark: thus Ov. M. 4. 438 (quoted by Forb.) has “MASK MASK MASK” Hor. 2 Od. 13. 21 “MASK MASK MASK”
like “MASK MASK” 9. 125. With the whole line comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ 2. 458.

here implies kindness rather than justice, the feeling spoken of being expressly one of partiality. Serv., who is mystical in his interpretation of the whole of this passage, says that three classes of men are here pointed out as exceptions to the general rule that none can return from the shades, those who are born under a propitious star, those who are prudent, and those who are religious, the last being indicated by ‘MASK MASK MASK’

seems to denote actual or potential beatification, not mere renown, in spite of the distinction between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ laid down by Wagn. Q. V. 10. So “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 1. 259, which Wagn. admits to refer to deification. With the general thought comp. Hor. 3 Od. 3. 9 foll., ib. 2. 21 foll., though perhaps the last, to which Forb. refers, belongs rather to Wagn.'s view of the passage. A Roman poet however, it should be recollected, would not discriminate the literal and metaphorical senses as sharply as we do.

“MASK MASK” v. 394 below. In the spirit of the heroic time Virg. restricts the privilege to demigods, as even where it is earned by virtue, only demigods are supposed to be capable of virtue so exalted. ‘MASK’ &c.: Virg.'s meaning is that between the place where they are now standing and the shades a pathless forest and the river Cocytus intervene. Possibly, as Peerlkamp thinks, he may have intended to make the forest easier of entrance than of exit: but in the subsequent description the forest is not made an obstacle at all: Aeneas goes through it under the guidance of the Sibyl without a hint of difficulty, and the only real bar is the passage of the river, which the possession of the bough enables him to overcome. But Virg. was thinking of Hom.'s lines about the difficulty of approaching his Hades, Od. 11. 157: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

The form ‘MASK’ is restored by Wagn. from Med.; with Ribbeck however I prefer the Latin form from Rom., Pal., &c. See on MASK . ‘MASK’ expresses the winding of the stream that surrounds the shades. ‘MASK MASK’ the reading of all Ribbeck's MSS., was restored by Heins. for ‘MASK MASK’ It is used similarly in Tac. A. 2. 6, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
Comp. 2. 10, 349, and for the construction ‘MASK MASK MASK’ note on MASK . Wagn. and Ribb. omit ‘MASK’ after ‘MASK MASK’ from Pal. and a correction in Med.
From Circe's exclamation Od. 12. 21, MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . ‘MASK’ of sailing on, v. 369 below. ‘MASK MASK’ see on v. 323.

seems to express that the toil is excessive and objectless, the same feeling which is indicated by Circe's MASK . “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 2. 776. Possibly here we may be meant to understand ‘MASK’ from v. 133; but there is no necessity, as the feeling it would convey is expressed by ‘MASK MASK’

Whether this notion of propitiating Proserpine by a golden bough is Virg.'s own invention we cannot tell. Heyne acutely argues from v. 409 below that it probably was a feature in some other legend. The commentators have collected many things which might have suggested the invention to Virgil—the use of a bough in supplication, and also in lustration, the golden rod of Hermes, the gilded branch in the mysteries of Isis; while the appearance of the golden bough in the wood may conceivably have been suggested, as Heyne thinks, by the golden fleece hanging from the beech in the sacred grove of Hecate, MASK foll. Ov. M. 14. 113 follows Virg.
The bough is altogether golden, stem as well as leaves.

Proserpina is ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as Pluto is MASK MASK , “MASK MASK MASK” 4. 638. The same, or a similar title is given to her by Ovid, Statius, and Silius. ‘MASK’ is here used almost in the sense of “MASK” or “MASK MASK” naming or pronouncing being a way of setting a thing apart and appropriating it. So Serv. here and on 1. 73 (which see), and Bentley on Hor. 2 S. 2. 134. ‘MASK MASK’ as if the whole forest conspired to hide it. Comp. Aeneas' prayer below v. 186 foll.
The sense is virtually the same as if Virg. had said “MASK MASK MASK MASK” the glades being looked upon as the instruments by which the trees close up the golden bough.
still, in spite of the difficulty of finding the bough, it is the only passport. ‘MASK’ is used substantively more than once in Cic.: see Forc.

Wagn. restores ‘MASK’ from Med. and one or two other MSS. for ‘MASK MASK’ which is read by Pal., Rom., Gud., &c. Either would stand, as Wagn.'s objections to the indefinite ‘MASK’ seem untenable: but ‘MASK’ is the more likely to have been altered. The construction is ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ a natural confusion between the hour and the man, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is perhaps a coinage of Virg.'s own, on the analogy of MASK . Val. Fl. and Sil. have followed him: see Forc. ‘MASK’ of the bough as the produce of the tree, v. 207 below. In MASK it signifies fruit opposed to leaves.

need be no more than an ornamental epithet: but its position seems to show that the beauty of the gift is considered to be appropriate to the beauty of the goddess. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK , though there is not the notion here of restoring to the goddess her own. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK .
has the force of ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the first in each case, and ‘MASK’ of course is its correlative.

Wagn. and Forb. think ‘MASK’ feeble; but surely it has considerable force here, the meaning being that a golden bough is never wanting—no sooner is one plucked than another as golden comes in its place. ‘MASK’ is virtually = ‘MASK’ but it need hardly be pointed out as a special use of the word, as the truth seems to be that the two thoughts are generally convertible. It is doubtful whether Med. has ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ Foggini's volume gives ‘MASK MASK’ Heyne and Ribbeck's collation ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” v. 208.

its importance being such, v. 140. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is explained by v. 136. Serv. says, “‘ rite carpe , ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ rite repertum , ’” and later editors follow him. I am by no means sure however that Virg. did not intend to join ‘MASK MASK MASK’ successfully, or, as we might say, duly found. At any rate, there does not appear to be any notion such as Forb. supposes, that the bough is to be plucked by the hand, not separated by the knife. What follows merely means that if the seeker is favoured, no force will be necessary; if not, no force will be sufficient. ‘MASK’ then will be, as it often is in Virg., semipleonastic, though it has not, as elsewhere, a notion of force or personal agency, but forms a kind of contrast with ‘MASK MASK’
strengthened by ‘MASK MASK’ as in MASK . ‘MASK’ may be illustrated by 12. 423, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
in a good sense: in 10. 472 in a bad one. ‘MASK’ has sometimes the force of ‘MASK’ see Forc. With ‘MASK MASK MASK’ comp. 12. 782.
of overcoming resistance, there being a contest between the man and the branch. ‘MASK’ 3. 24, 31.

as a further thing to be done before approaching the shades, who would be offended by the neglect of the rites due to the dead. The notion of being unburied is contained in ‘MASK MASK’ the body being left to lie where it fell, instead of being taken up and burnt. So 2. 557 (note), 5. 871., 9. 486., 11. 102, in which passages however other words are added to bring out the notion more clearly. ‘MASK’ to show how the obstacle affected Aeneas.

like “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 2. 539, comp. by Forb. The whole fleet partakes in the pollution, so that it would be hopeless for the commander to approach the shades till the pollution has been removed. Comp. the language in Soph. Ant. 1016 foll. about the unburied body of Polynices and the extent of pollution caused by it.
are apparently the decrees of the gods or of destiny, so that “MASK MASK” = “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ of delay, as in Flor. 1. 13, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Some difficulty has been made about ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the choice however lies between taking it of the grave, as the natural resting-place of the dead, and the shades, as the natural abode of the spirit. The former might be supported by v. 328, the latter by v. 371. The difficulty is further increased by the apparent inconsistency of Virg.'s language or belief (see on 3. 68., 4. 34), the spirit and the body being elsewhere confused. ‘MASK’ however is in favour of supposing the grave to be meant, in spite of the tautology with the rest of the line, as the agency of Aeneas in transferring the spirit to its home would be only indirect. In any case ‘MASK’ is explained by ‘MASK MASK’ meaning to pay a due (comp. 2. 543 note). ‘MASK MASK’ 3. 68.

The sacrifice had no reference to Misenus (comp. below vv. 236, 243 foll.), but was intended to propitiate the shades towards their living visitor. ‘MASK MASK’ is more fully explained by vv. 243 foll. ‘MASK’ seems rightly taken by Heyne as previous or preliminary. So nearly 1. 24, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Med. a m. p. and Rom. have ‘MASK MASK’ a corruption which seems to have led to a false correction ‘MASK’ (Pal. a m. s. &c.), and hence to the omission of ‘MASK MASK’ which is supported by one of Ribbeck's cursives. Wagn. rightly restored ‘MASK MASK’ which is apparently the original reading of Pal. ‘MASK MASK’ it matters little whether the woods are supposed to overshadow the Styx, which may naturally be regarded as giving its name to the whole infernal territory. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ tells plainly what the Sibyl hitherto had only asserted indirectly. See on v. 126.
like “MASK MASK” 9. 324.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’
Comp. 8. 520, where as here the downcast eye indicates both sorrow and thoughtfulness.

seems to mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ or perhaps merely ‘MASK MASK’ comp. 8. 309. A correction in Med. gives ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ probably includes the various things he had heard from the Sibyl, the prediction of vv. 83 foll., the doubt about the golden bough, and the mysterious death.
MASK was with him, v. 34.

is so often used as a synonyme of ‘MASK’ that it would be most natural to take ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” MASK , or the more common “MASK MASK MASK” the meaning merely being that he walks along moodily. Forb. however, who contends against this, may be so far right that the use of ‘MASK’ may be intended to show that the tread is slow, the foot being as it were driven into the earth each time, though he is certainly wrong in making it equivalent to “MASK MASK” vv. 197, 331 below, where the notion is that of stopping. Comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where curiously enough all three verbs are used, though the use of “MASK” does not really support Forb.'s view. Serv. gives both explanations of ‘MASK MASK’ stepping and stopping.

“MASK MASK” 1. 748., 8. 309. ‘MASK’ was an old reading: but ‘MASK’ is found in all the best MSS., and recognized by Serv. ‘MASK MASK’ is as old as Plaut., and ‘MASK MASK’ occurs in Livy (see Forc.): it is doubtless to be explained by giving ‘MASK’ the sense of ‘MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ though Stat. Achill. 2. 35 has a strange expression, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” apparently taking it, if the reading is right, from ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ It is possible, as Serv. hints, that Virg. means to indicate that ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ are cognate words, according to Varro's explanation (L. L. 6. § 64), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though such a grammatical spirit belongs rather to the early Latin poets, who never forgot that they were literary teachers. The next line seems to show that Wagn. is right in understanding ‘MASK MASK’ not of various topics, but of various conjectures on one topic.

Heyne rightly remarks that it is strange they should not at once have thought of Palinurus, or rather strange that Virg. should not have perceived that Palinurus would at once be thought of as the lost comrade. As Forb. observes, it is probably one of those confusions which Virg. would have rectified had he lived to finish his Aeneid. With the construction comp. 2. 121. ‘MASK’ 10. 493., 11. 2 ‘MASK’ Pal., Rom., Gud., ‘MASK’ Med., which is more euphonious.
see on MASK .

It was one of the legends about the landing of Aeneas that he lost a comrade called Misenus at that time, and called that part of the coast after him (comp. v. 234 note). See Heyne, Excursus 4 and 7 to this book. One of the stories seems to have made him Aeneas' pilot, which might tend further to make Virg. waver between him and Palinurus. ‘MASK’ probably means, as Heyne thinks, the son of Aeolus, a Trojan of age and rank, killed afterwards 12. 542 foll. There would however be plenty of Homeric precedent for making him the son of a god, and some propriety in ascribing the birth of an illustrious trumpeter to the god of the winds. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ &c. may be taken, as Cerda suggests, from Il. 2. 553, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .

like “MASK MASK” MASK note. Misenus has already appeared 3. 239 as a trumpeter, an officer, as has often been remarked, unknown to Hom., who however mentions a trumpet in a simile Il. 18. 219. Serv. tells the story that “MASK MASK MASK” was added by the poet during the fervour of recitation, the line having been previously a hemistich. It is at any rate a good specimen of an effective and poetical tautology. The story as told in Virg.'s life says further that the previous line ended at ‘MASK MASK’ and that the remainder was similarly improvised, which is to the last degree unlikely, as ‘MASK MASK MASK’ postulates the existence of the previous words. Cerda thinks ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is imitated from Aristoph. Peace 310, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .
like Hom.'s MASK MASK . ‘MASK’ is like the use of MASK or MASK in Greek to express companionship.

The ‘MASK’ differed from the ‘MASK MASK’ which appears below v. 233 as Misenus' instrument, in being slightly bent: but the two are used as synonymous by Virg., just as he uses the names of various trees indifferently for the wood of which the Trojan horse is made. Heyne refers to Stat. Theb. 6. 120, 128 for a similar confusion of ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ but the two words do not occur there, though in the former line the ‘MASK’ is said ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ probably with ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” 10. 354 &c., and the Homeric MASK MASK MASK &c., which Cerda comp. “MASK MASK” occurs MASK , also comp. by Cerda.
like “MASK MASK MASK” 12. 935.
“MASK MASK MASK” 2. 339, MASK . ‘MASK’ is rightly explained by Heyne as a Grecism, MASK MASK for MASK MASK . Virg.'s doctrine of the equality of Aeneas to Hector appears again 11. 291.

is probably the same as the ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ being substituted for it as more appropriate to a performance on the water, and more likely to rouse the jealousy of Triton, whose instrument it was, 10. 209. Comp. Ov. M. 1. 333 foll. (too long to quote), where Triton is made by Neptune to sound on his shell a retreat for the waters of Deucalion's flood, the shell being afterwards spoken of as “MASK MASK” Emm., to whom this citation is due, also quotes Hesych. s. v. MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , a natural supposition enough. It is in fact the rationale of the myth which attributes the shell to Triton. It is possible however, as Peerlkamp and Forb. think, that Misenus is meant really to have taken up a shell on the shore and tried his powers. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK” v. 417 below. Here as elsewhere ‘MASK’ is followed by the present when the rest of the sentence would have led us to expect some other tense: see on MASK , MASK . Here there may be a rhetorical propriety in the discrepancy, the suddenness of the retribution being expressed by the intimation that it was over while the provocation was still going on.

is used like MASK Il. 2. 38 and elsewhere. Strictly speaking it belongs to the second clause here rather than to the first; but the act of defiance is implied in the first clause, so that Forb. is wrong in pointing it with the second, contrary to the Homeric parallels. ‘MASK’ in the sense of ‘MASK’ is found, though not very commonly: see Forc. ‘MASK MASK’ is very common in Virg., the general sense being apparently the same in all, that of calling to a place (e. g. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” to invoke the presence of the gods at a vow), though the particular applications are very different. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ occurs MASK (Forc.), but ‘MASK MASK’ is more usual. Heyne, Excursus 7, remarks that in mythical language men who excel in any thing are said either to have received it from some god or to have provoked the jealousy of some god by it. Misenus is in fact like Thamyris, Arachne, &c.
= ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ being used of surprise, as in 3. 332, MASK . “MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK . Virg. represents the cause of Misenus' death as mythical, as Forb. remarks.
implies that the provocation and its punishment took place on the coast, and ‘MASK’ perhaps points the same way.
of lamentation 4. 668.
“MASK MASK MASK” 1. 220.

with acc. 4. 575. ‘MASK’ Med., Rom., ‘MASK’ Pal., Gud., which Ribbeck adopts. But Sil. 15. 387 has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where Drakenborch notes no various reading. ‘MASK MASK’ seems rightly understood by Serv. not of the altars to the ‘MASK MASK’ (3. 63 note), but of the pyre piled up like an altar. ‘MASK MASK’ might be said of heaping the altar with boughs for fuel, but ‘MASK MASK’ points to a more considerable structure, and the gen. ‘MASK’ would be somewhat harsh for ‘MASK’ though ‘MASK’ might be more tractable. Sil. l. c. follows Virg. closely, evidently showing that he understood him in this way. Val. Fl. 5. 10, also quoted by Heyne, is somewhat doubtful: much more Ov. M. 8. 479, whom Forb. cites. MASK is used in Hom. of any raised place, and in later Greek actually of a tomb: see Lidd. and Scott.
MASK MASK MASK Il. 23. 139. MASK has MASK MASK MASK , which may have been in Virg.'s mind. “MASK MASK” 2. 186.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

The description is imitated from Il. 23. 114 foll. and also from Enn. A. 6. fr. 11, preserved by Macrob. Sat. 6. 2 The latter, as the rarer author, may be quoted: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Comp. also 11. 135 foll. “MASK MASK” 9. 388., 10. 723, which show that ‘MASK’ here means high, not deep. For the sense comp. note on v. 8 above.
Pitch-trees were used in funeral piles, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Pliny 16. 10, referred to by Heyne. With ‘MASK’ comp. Il. l. c. MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .
It signifies comparatively little whether ‘MASK MASK’ be connected with what precedes or with what follows. With the rest of the line comp. MASK .
from the mountains, as the sense shows: but the ambiguity is harsh. ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK” MASK .
not with ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which would be more modern than classical. ‘MASK’ is like ‘MASK’ above v. 176. “MASK MASK MASK” 4. 663.
He takes up an axe like the rest. ‘MASK’ here is metaphorical, like ‘MASK MASK’ but the word is sometimes used loosely: see on v. 570 below.

Comp. above v. 157, “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 8. 522. See on MASK . ‘MASK’ seems to mean the things which he eventually utters: but in that case ‘MASK’ follows rather awkwardly. Heins. restored ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ the old reading, which is found in only one MS. in the parallel passage in Book 8.

The reading is exceedingly doubtful, Med., Pal., Gud., &c. giving ‘MASK MASK’ Rom. ‘MASK MASK’ the Lombard of Pierius, and others ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ though preferred by Wagn., can scarcely be right, as it is not likely that Virg. meant to represent Aeneas' exclamation as fortuitous. An unexpected exclamation could hardly be intended to prepare us for any unexpected event, as the point lies in the unuttered prayer rather than in its expression. The word may easily have come from v. 190. Serv., who gives ‘MASK MASK’ regards it merely as a prop to the verse. ‘MASK’ on the other hand would have real force, praying aloud being contrasted with thinking silently. It does not appear, as Wagn. contends, that in 9. 403., 11. 784, where the words recur, any thing more than simple utterance is intended. Henry prefers ‘MASK’ to ‘MASK MASK’ but without saying why. What follows, as Cerda remarks, is rather a wish than a prayer: MASK MASK however is used in Hom. in addresses to deities.
on the tree, as in MASK . The sense is, Would that the first part of the Sibyl's words may prove as true as the second has done.
the Homeric MASK MASK MASK MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ like Aesch. Ag. 1241, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .
denotes the coincidence.
like “MASK MASK MASK” see Forc. ‘MASK MASK’ Serv. says that in augury certain distances were fixed, within which the omen was held to pertain to the person seeing it.
is found in Med. (according to Foggini: Heins. reports ‘MASK’） and one or two others.

Virtually = “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ your flight, not our course (which would be possible, ‘MASK MASK’ being taken i. q. ‘MASK’). ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK’ seems to occur nowhere in Virg., unless MASK (where see note) be an exception: it is found however elsewhere, as in MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” quoted by Forb., who refers to a note of Heins. there.

= ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ seems to refer to the richness of the soil which could produce a tree so gifted. Forc. gives various instances of ‘MASK’ more or less resembling the present, among others Lucan 9. 658 of the cloud which yielded Danae's golden shower. Trapp questioned the applicability of ‘MASK MASK’ for which he would have preferred ‘MASK’ but the poet's words are not to be so closely pressed, and we may say that ‘MASK’ is qualified by the juxtaposition of ‘MASK MASK’ Scaliger, Poet. 4. 16, referred to by Taubm., commends the word as “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
of forsaking a cause: see Forc. ‘MASK’ is of course the dat. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

The old editions had ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which Pierius says is found in Rom. and some others. Ribbeck however mentions no other reading than ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ see above on v. 159. ‘MASK’ might = ‘MASK MASK’ as in 11. 787, where however ‘MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ define the sense: but every thing here is in favour of the sense of ‘MASK MASK’ as Forb. admits. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” is quoted by Forc. from Val. Fl. 2. 454. So “MASK MASK” below v. 389, “MASK MASK” 2. 378. ‘MASK MASK’ is also found, as Forb. remarks, of treading in the steps of another (see Forc.); but this is not likely to be meant here.
= “MASK MASK MASK” as “MASK MASK MASK” 2. 171 = “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is used of omens: see on 4. 167.
The meaning seems to be that they keep flying on and alighting to feed alternately—in other words that in their feeding they fly on from spot to spot.

is rightly explained by Forb. as indicating the object of the doves in flying onward, as against Wagn., who thinks it implies repeated action—‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ &c. ‘MASK’ is used strictly of the pupil of the eye as the organ of vision. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Cic. N. D. 2. 57. ‘MASK’ of observing or keeping in view, as in v. 338 below, &c. ‘MASK’ may mean following with the eye, as Forb. takes it: but it would seem from the context that though Aeneas stopped at first, he afterwards went on as they went on, so that the word may have its more ordinary sense. We hear nothing later of Aeneas' movements till v. 210, where the expression shows that he did not remain standing for the whole previous time.
‘MASK’ is explained by vv. 240 foll. below. For the word comp. MASK .
may possibly refer, as Serv. explains it, to their desire to escape the stench, so fatal to birds; but the meaning is sufficiently clear without.

seems to mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ (comp. 1. 425., 3. 109, 132), as Heyne explains it. The birds are said to mark the spot before finally alighting there. Wagn.'s objection that ‘MASK’ is used of choosing the site of a permanent abode tells for little in a passage where the term is evidently used metaphorically, being applied to the birds simply in virtue of their being about to settle, no matter for how long. At the same time it is quite possible to take it ‘MASK MASK’ with Wagn., as though Aeneas wished for no definite spot, he wished for the spot where the golden branch grew, wherever that might be. ‘MASK’ is the reading of Med. and most MSS., and also of Priscian, p. 1001; I agree with Henry however that it cannot be made to yield a natural sense, though the word sometimes = ‘MASK MASK’ and is applied in this sense in poetry to Triton and Chiron: see Forc. ‘MASK MASK’ the reading of Rom. and the Longobardic MS., as quoted by Pierius, and a few others, was adopted by Burm. and Heyne, and gives, as Henry remarks, a vivid and natural picture. We do not care to know whether they flew precisely together; but that they settled at the same moment in the same spot is a pleasing circumstance. A Greek writer in speaking of it might change from the plural to the dual. ‘MASK MASK’ they alight at the top of the tree.

is explained ‘MASK MASK’ by Serv., who may be right in applying the same doctrine to Hor. 2 Od. 8. 24, but goes too far in making ‘MASK’ in this sense the root of ‘MASK MASK’ The account of this use of the word is apparently to be sought in the connexion between the notions of light and air (see on MASK , and comp. v. 747 below, “MASK MASK MASK”), and also between those of light and motion, as in MASK , &c., the gleaming light being naturally identified with the flickering breeze. The jingle is of course intended: see on 2. 494 &c. “‘ Discolor , ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Donatus. ‘MASK’ 1. 402 note. Rom. and another give ‘MASK MASK’

MASK of the birdlime collected from the mistletoe, here of the plant itself. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the mistletoe flourishes in the winter, and the time is naturally chosen for the sake of contrast between its leaves and the bareness of the tree on which it grows, though the circumstance really makes it less like that with which it is compared, as there the golden bough was seen among green ones.

might refer to the growth of the plant from a tree which is not really its parent, ‘MASK MASK’ being joined as in MASK : but it more probably alludes to the opinion of the ancients that it was really an animal product, the excrement of birds (Pliny 16. 44., 24. 4), not, as later research has proved it to be, a parasitic plant, the seeds of which are deposited by birds on other trees. ‘MASK’ then refers to natural production, as “MASK MASK” MASK seems to mean natural or kindly sleep. ‘MASK’ seems to be used vaguely in the sense of producing. Comp. the use of ‘MASK’ for plants in MASK , 356 &c. The word is prosaic rather than poetical: see Forc.

Pliny 24. 4 says of the mistletoe “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The colour is of course a prominent feature in the comparison. ‘MASK’ the trunks, as in MASK : see Forc. Some MSS. mentioned by Pierius have ‘MASK MASK’
comp. v. 144 above. ‘MASK’ v. 136. The dark shade of course gives the contrast.

the particular kind of tree has not hitherto been specified by Virg., a proof that he attaches no importance to the specification. ‘MASK MASK’ 3. 70. ‘MASK’ is not strictly speaking a point in the comparison. Virg. only means ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is thin foil, thinner than ‘MASK MASK’ a metallic plate. It is classed with cobweb for its thinness by MASK . The leaf is called ‘MASK’ here, as the ‘MASK’ is called ‘MASK’ in Latin, in Greek MASK , and in English foil or leaf. Lachm. on Lucr. l. c. prefers the spelling ‘MASK MASK’ which is found here in Med. and Rom. and supported by Pal. ‘MASK’ As usual, I have followed Wagn. Some MSS. (including Gud. originally) have ‘MASK’ which Heins. adopted, strangely regarding ‘MASK’ as a noun of multitude, whereas the fact would seem to be, as Heyne remarks, that ‘MASK’ was mistaken for a neuter plural.
“‘ MASK : ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Donatus. The old reading before Heins. was “MASK MASK MASK” Rom. has ‘MASK MASK’

is not to be pressed, as we know from vv. 147 foll. that it cannot really have offered any resistance, so that it must be taken as a correlative to ‘MASK MASK’ Aeneas' eagerness being too great even for the willingness of the branch. Even thus however the choice of the word seems a little unfortunate. Heyne comp. “MASK MASK” above v. 137. For the application of the word to things inanimate comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ seems to be the temple.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

“MASK MASK MASK” 1. 633 &c., a common form of transition MASK Virg. Hom. generally draws the contrast between two contemporaneous actions by repeating the first MASK a summary form before proceeding to the second— MASK MASK MASK . . . MASK : and so does Virg. sometimes, as MASK 1. 656 foll. The meaning here is that while Aeneas is plucking the bough and carrying it to the temple, the Trojans, having finished hewing wood, are constructing the pile, &c.

of funeral lamentation MASK . “‘ Ingrato : ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ ingrato ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. Heyne, after Taubm., rightly prefers the latter. So in the Copa (attributed to Virg.) v. 35, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Heyne comp. MASK MASK of the body of Hector, Il. 24. 54. The dead body is called ‘MASK’ by anticipation, as Donatus remarks. Forc. quotes no instance of ‘MASK’ for obsequies earlier than Virg., after whose time it is frequent. “MASK MASK” 11. 25, “MASK MASK” ib. 61. ‘MASK’ of offerings 3. 19 &c.

With the description of the pile comp. that of the pile of Patroclus Il. 23. 163 foll. On the whole I agree with Wakef. and Henry in connecting ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ see on 4. 505, where ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ are also explained.

comp. v. 178 above. The greater the pile, the greater the honour. Patroclus' pile measured a hundred feet both ways, Il. l. c.; there however many bodies of men and horses were burnt. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ leafy boughs from funeral trees like the yew.

“MASK MASK MASK MASK” 2. 16. Cerda distinguishes ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ from ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ making the latter refer to the custom of planting cypresses at Rome before the doors of the dead (Pliny 16. 33). This however does not prove that cypresses were planted before funeral piles, while we know on other authority that they were used in making or dressing the piles. Serv. tells us from Varro that piles were surrounded with cypresses that the smell of the burning wood might overpower that of the burning body, and Stat. 9. 460., 5. 54, in passages apparently imitated from the present, makes the cypress used in the composition of the pile. (Sil. 10. 535 has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” which may possibly support Cerda's view, as the cypresses are distinguished from other trees which would form a part of the pile: but the passage is too brief to build upon.) ‘MASK MASK’ will then refer to the laying down or perhaps setting upright of cypress trees or branches before the process indicated by ‘MASK’ takes place. Or Heyne may be right in taking ‘MASK’ locally, the pile being faced with trunks of cypresses. These he supposes to be used for trophies, like the oak in 11. 4, in which sense of course he understands the next clause ‘MASK’ &c.; but Forb. seems right in arguing from 11. 193 foll. that the arms (whether of Misenus himself, Il. 6. 418, Od. 12. 13, or of enemies despoiled by him) are thrown on the pile. See on 4. 496.

The washing and anointing of Patroclus' body are described more minutely Il. 18. 343 foll. ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ as it is the process of boiling that is going on. Comp. Virg.'s own simile 7. 462 foll.

1. 178. The meaning is simply that they get the pots boiled or get ready boiling water. The remainder of the line is from Enn. A. 3. fr. 8, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” as Serv. remarks. ‘MASK MASK’ is more poetical than ‘MASK MASK’ or than ‘MASK MASK MASK’

Forb. comp. Ter. And. 1. 1. 101, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” 1. 725, “MASK MASK” 2. 209. ‘MASK’ like “MASK” v. 481, “MASK” having the additional force of weeping one's fill, as in 11. 59. ‘MASK’ = “MASK MASK” the bier being laid on the pile and burnt with it. Comp. 4. 507, 659, where it is used of the “MASK MASK” which Dido has spread on the top of the pile.

Purple robes were used for wrapping the dead at great Roman funerals. See among a number of testimonies in Cerda's note Livy 34. 7, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” There is also some Homeric analogy for the custom. In Od. 24. 59 the ocean nymphs put immortal garments round the dead Achilles, who is apparently burned in them: in Il. 24. 795 foll., when Hector has been burned, his relations collect his bones and put them in a basket, MASK MASK MASK MASK . Virg. makes Aeneas wrap Pallas in the same manner 11. 72 foll. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as Heyne remarks, can hardly be understood except of the garments Misenus had worn when alive. The other alternative would be to refer ‘MASK’ to the customariness of thus covering the dead. There is the same sort of doubt about “MASK MASK” 11. 195.

in the sense of supporting generally takes an acc., sometimes, though rarely, the dat. or abl. It is not easy to distinguish these two last cases: in sense they would appear to differ, the one being equivalent to the acc. (move towards a thing, place one's self under), the other denoting motion when placed under. In the few instances where the construction occurs the reading is not always certain, the acc. being generally found as a variety. Forc. quotes among others Cic. Div. Verr. 14, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” the reading of Asconius, who comments on it, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ magno ponderi MASK . ’” But the MSS. of Cic. give ‘MASK MASK’ To carry the bier was esteemed an honour to the deceased among the Romans, as to bear the pall with us: Taubm. comp. Tac. A. 1. 8, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

is not, as Heyne thought, an interjection, but a cognate acc., or acc. in apposition to the action of the verb. The construction is infinitely rarer in Latin than in Greek (see on MASK ): Forb. however comp. 9. 53., 10. 311., 11. 383, to which add 8. 487. But the words may conceivably be a nom.; comp. 1. 168., 8. 422. ‘MASK’ &c. = ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ of setting fire to a thing 2. 37., 11. 186. Cerda comp. MASK , “MASK MASK” of burning the dead during the plague of Athens. It would seem from 11. 185, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” that ‘MASK MASK’ here refers to the whole action, probably indeed to the whole process of the funeral. If it has any special reference, it would probably be to ‘MASK MASK’ as Lersch understands it Antiqq. 9. § 86. Serv. however says “‘More parentum:’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” an explanation which may either mean that Virg. implies that the nearest male relatives officiated, or that Misenus' comrades took the part which would naturally have devolved on his parents. This latter view is taken by Erythraeus, who comp. Lucan 6. 530 foll. (of the witch Erichtho): “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

But the sense of ‘MASK MASK’ is fixed by “MASK MASK” 11, l. c. Virg. perhaps means that the same who carried the bier afterwards applied the torch: but his words need not be pressed. Comp. G. 4, 167 note. Pal. and Gud. seem to have had another reading, ‘MASK MASK MASK’

Lersch, § 86, comp. Arnob. 7. 51, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Tac. A. 3. 2, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The first passage explains ‘MASK MASK’ which doubtless refers to the victims, not, as some have thought, to the spices and oil. So perhaps 3. 301, where see note. In 5. 92 the reference is doubtful. For the application of ‘MASK’ to sacrifices see Forc. Victims are also mentioned 11. 197 foll., after Il. 23. 166, Od. 24. 65, none of which passages however speak of spices or oil. Libations of oil were made in the subsequent offerings to the grave ( MASK note: see other passages quoted by Lersch, § 68, “MASK MASK”), which seem to have had much in common with the actual funeral solemnities. See also Od. 24. 73, referred to on v. 227 below. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is doubtless the abl. of description, cups of poured out oil. Really of course it is not the cup that is burnt, but its contents, so that ‘MASK’ is used somewhat like “MASK” MASK .

The line, as Heyne remarks, is modelled on Il. 9. 212, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , compared with Il. 23. 228, MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ is from Il. 23. 251, MASK MASK MASK MASK .

In Il. 23. 250., 24. 791 the flame is quenched with wine and then the bones are collected: but in Od. 24. 72, the bones are collected after the body is consumed and are placed in (a vessel containing?) wine and oil. In Il. 23. 253 a double layer of fat is spread over the bones.) Virg. seems to follow the Od., probably understanding MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK of something which took place before the bones were placed in the vessel. In the three passages of Hom. the fire is allowed to burn all night and is quenched or quenches itself the next morning: and Virg.'s account in Book 11 (vv. 201, 210) is somewhat similar.

collected from the pile, MASK or MASK in Hom. ll. cc. The process was called MASK : Aesch. wrote a play named MASK . ‘MASK’ is doubtless an urn, as MASK is used for a balloting urn. In Hom. the vessels differ: Patroclus' bones are placed in a golden MASK , Hector's in a golden MASK , Achilles' in a golden MASK , the work of Hephaestus and gift of Dionysus. Brazen urns are common among Italian remains. Corynaeus is specified, as Heyne remarks, merely for specification's sake. The name occurs again 9. 571., 12. 298. This man may be identified with either, as both are probably Trojans. The name is variously spelt in the MSS.; but Heyne remarks that it must be MASK from MASK .

Corynaeus also performs the lustration, that the crews might be purified from the pollution contracted by the dead body, v. 150 above. It does not appear whether lustration formed a regular part of a Roman funeral, as of course we cannot argue from this passage that it did: but there was a lustration in the month of February, the month of special solemnities in honour of the Di Manes . Macrob. Sat. 1. 13 says “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ comp. MASK , 75 notes. Serv. says “‘ MASK : ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ Pro larvato te circumferam , ’MASK MASK MASK” This passage is not in the extant works of Plautus: but there is a similar one in MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” It is to be explained on the analogy of the double structure of ‘MASK’ &c. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ being a variety for ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ See on MASK . If not originally Virg.'s own expression, it is at any rate precisely such a one as we should expect him to affect, so that we need not be tempted by varieties like ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the reading of one MS., ‘MASK MASK’ found in another, or ‘MASK’ which is found in the margin of a MS. of Macrob. Sat. 3. 1. Sophocles, whose inversions of language are very like Virg.'s, has a similar expression El. 709, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , which has been similarly altered by reading MASK .

The manner of the lustration is described, sprinkling with a wetted branch. Bay was used as well as olive, Juv. 2. 158. Serv. quotes Donatus as saying that Virg. substituted the olive for the bay out of compliment to Augustus, whose birthday was marked by the springing up of a bay on the Palatine, and that it was not thought well that the triumphal associations of the tree should be mixed up with funeral reminiscences. Lersch shows that the olive was connected with funerals from Pliny 35. 12, 46, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Cerda shows the same connexion from Demosth. and Artemidorus. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is a good instance of MASK MASK MASK : see on MASK . “MASK MASK MASK” 7. 751, distinguished from the oleaster.

For ‘MASK’ Rom., Pal. a m. p., and others give ‘MASK MASK’ apparently introduced by some one who thought of the lustration of houses at Rome . Pierius thought it might be explained of the camp. Another MS. has ‘MASK MASK’ which Heins. preferred, but Heyne rightly rejects. “MASK MASK MASK” 4. 650. The reference seems to be to the ‘MASK’ with which they took leave of the dead, not to the ‘MASK MASK’ with which the assembly was dismissed. Serv. objects to the former view that the ‘MASK’ was not said till after the burial: but 11. 97 seems to show that it might come even before the burning. In v. 506 below, 3. 68 we may remember that the erection of the tomb stood in place of a proper burial.

The mention of MASK may be intended to intimate that it was MASK this point that he returned (see v. 212 above); but such things cannot be pressed in Virg. The setting up of a tomb in Hom. follows similarly MASK once upon the burning and the collecting of the bones, Il. 23. 255 foll., 24. 797 foll., Od. 12. 14., 24. 80 foll. The first and last of these passages will illustrate ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the size of the barrow, of earth and stones, being greater according to the honour intended. So Aesch. Cho. 351, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK .

seems to refer to ‘MASK MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” 1. 177 &c., as his arms in the strict sense appear to have been burnt with him, v. 217. Serv., who felt the difficulty, took the meaning to be that the arms were sculptured on the tomb. ‘MASK’ explains ‘MASK MASK’ which would naturally refer to Aeneas himself. The oar Misenus has in common with Elpenor, Od. 11. 77., 12. 15, who has his fixed MASK MASK : the trumpet is his own.

This grotto is not the same as that mentioned v. 11 above. Heyne identifies it with one now called Baian, as looking towards Baiae. With the latter part of the line comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ inmane ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The description seems partially taken from that of the MASK MASK (in the [Asiatic] Acherusian promontory) in MASK foll., though the vapour there is not mephitic, but icy.

‘MASK’ is found in Enn. Androm. fr. 8, and Pacuvius Nipt. fr. 6 speaks of “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ participle, sheltered, as in 1. 571 &c. The meaning seems to be that the darkness appears to afford it a protection.

MASK foll.: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” See also ib. 818 foll. ‘MASK’ used substantively, as in v. 728 below, Lucr. 2. 1083. So ‘MASK’ MASK .
“MASK MASK MASK” 7. 7.
Comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK” v. 750 below. Ribbeck reads ‘MASK’ from Pal. and Med. a m. p., and Rom.; but the cause of the mistake is obvious.

This line is wanting in fragm. Vat. and others, and is added in Med. by a later hand. Rom. however has it. Serv. does not explain it, nor does Non. quote it s. v. ‘MASK MASK’ as he might have been expected to do. There is a similar line in the Periegesis of Dionysius, v. 1151, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , rendered by Priscian, Perieg. 1056, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Heyne thinks it a gloss, and Wagn. and Ribbeck remove it from the text. There is nothing un-Virgilian about it: Virg. is fond of talking of the names of places, as Henry remarks (comp. e. MASK ): he refers to a Greek name G .3. 148 (a common habit with his master Lucr.): and the expression ‘MASK MASK MASK’ to which Wagn. objects, is found v. 441 below, as is observed by Forb. On the other hand the external evidence is such as to leave the question doubtful, so I have placed the line in brackets. There is a further question whether ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK’ ought to be read. The MSS. which retain the line would seem generally in favour of this latter, which I have adopted: but it would seem more likely that Virg. would use the Greek word than the Latin transformation of it, which hides the etymology. Is it certain that Lucr. in talking of the etymology of ‘MASK’ did not mean to derive it from “MASK”? Possibly however Virg. may have so far complied with the Latin form as to give ‘MASK’ the reading of Gud. and others, adopted by Heins.

Comp. MASK foll., where four bulls and four heifers are sacrificed to the Manes of Orpheus and Eurydice. “MASK MASK MASK” 5. 97. Black was the colour of the victims sacrificed to the shades, v. 153 above, Od. 10. 523—527.

5. 237. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ comp. 4. 61 note. Fl. 2. 611 of pouring sacrificial wine into the sea

The plucking of hairs from the head of the victim and the throwing of them into the fire as MASK is a Homeric custom, Od. 3. 445, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , from which we see also that prayers were made during the process, as in v. 247. ‘MASK’ of the hair of oxen 7. 790.

MASK , as ‘MASK’ is used of pouring out or taking away the first part of any thing. Gell. in his preface says, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Stat. Theb. 6. 224 has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” of offerings on a funeral pile, each one giving as it were a taste or specimen of his weapons. ‘MASK’ is frequently used of offerings 1. 49., 4. 453.

See on v. 245. The line is imitated from MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”. ‘MASK MASK’ 4. 680 note. For Hecate's attributes see on 4. 510. ‘MASK MASK’ less strong than ‘MASK MASK’, implying not sovereignty over a place, but power in it. ‘MASK MASK’ 7. 140.

Cerda, followed by Heyne and Forb., explains ‘MASK MASK’ of the custom of sacrificing victims to the gods below with their heads downwards, those devoted to the gods above being sacrificed with their heads upturned, the MASK MASK of Hom. For this he quotes Myrsilus De Rebus Lesbiacis 2 (? the passage does not occur in the remains of Myrsilus in Müller's Fragmenta Historicorum Graecorum ), MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK : MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK : MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . The same words however have already met us in MASK , where we cannot suppose that a sacrifice to the infernal gods is specially meant. All that is said is that the throat is cut from beneath, and this might be done equally well whether the victims' heads were turned up or down—more easily indeed in the former case. It is more probable that the special reference, if any, is to another (Roman?) sacrificial custom mentioned by Cerda in the same note, that of first striking the victims down with an axe or club, afterwards cutting their throats, a process which seems to have required two persons, according to a passage from Dionys. Hal. 7. 72, quoted by Cerda, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK : MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . Serv. says that ‘MASK’ was a sacrificial word, being of neutral signification and consequently avoiding a bad omen: and the three last words in the passage of Dionys. confirm the statement, as they would hardly have been translated from an expression found only in the poets. ‘MASK MASK’ 8. 106.

The form ‘MASK’ is supported by Pal. and fragm. Vat., Gud. a m. s. &c., and expressly recognized by Serv., who says “MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ MASK ’MASK MASK” it has accordingly been restored by Wagn. in later edd., here and 1. 175. It was evidently read by Pomponius Sabinus , whose note “MASK MASK MASK” is wrongly explained by Heyne as if the meaning were that the more ordinary word would be ‘MASK MASK’ The object of catching the blood is said by Donatus to be “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The Greek feeling would seem to have been just the reverse, as what was poured on the earth was supposed to reach the powers below. So Od. 11. 35 Ulysses cuts the throats of the sheep into a trench, that the shades may flock round it. Virg. however seems to mean that the blood is caught in bowls that it may be afterwards poured out, apparently on the ground (3. 67., 5. 78). Perhaps we may say then that this mode of offering was adopted as giving more solemnity to the act, and involving as it were a separate consecration of the blood apart from that of the victims. ‘MASK MASK’ Aeneas also acts as sacrificer, in the Homeric fashion. Stat. Theb. 4. 445 has “MASK MASK MASK MASK”

The mother of the Eumenides was Night (7. 331., 12. 846, Aesch. Eum. 416 &c.), her great sister Earth, both being daughters of Chaos. Comp. Hes. Theog. 116 foll., where however the birth of Gaea from Chaos is not expressly stated.

So Od. 11. 30 Ulysses vows that on his return to Ithaca he will sacrifice to the shades, MASK MASK MASK MASK . Lersch quotes from Arnob. 7. 21, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ may possibly be referred to striking down the victim, according to the distinction taken on v. 248. Serv. has a notion that the sword was used rather than any other weapon because, having been consecrated by the act, it became available for keeping the shades at a distance. ‘MASK MASK’ 12. 458.

of Pluto, like “MASK MASK” 4. 638. ‘MASK MASK’ sacrifices to the infernal gods were performed by night, which is now going on, as we see from v. 255. Cerda refers to Turnebus V. L. 28. 44. ‘MASK’ is said by Serv. to be a sacrificial word: but the only instance the commentators adduce is “MASK MASK” Cic. (?) De Domo 51. 132. Comp. however ‘MASK’ 4. 63 note.

= “MASK MASK” as in 2. 639: see Forc., where this sense is abundantly illustrated. Holocausts were offered to the infernal gods, MASK . For ‘MASK’ see on MASK ., 4. 302. It is on this line that Serv. gives the explanation there cited. ‘MASK’ above v. 246.

Modelled on Il. 11. 775, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . All Ribbeck's MSS. give ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is found in a few copies mentioned by Heyne, and in the Canon. and Balliol MSS. The ‘MASK’ seems to have been added as a support to the verse, as apparently in 1. 668, where it is similarly found in the best MSS. Between ‘MASK’ (Med.) and ‘MASK’ (fragm. Vat., Pal., Rom., Gud., &c.) there is little or nothing to choose, except on external grounds. Both ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ are found in composition, though the latter appears to have no higher authority than Celsus. Comp. however ‘MASK’ ‘MASK’ are the entrails proper as distinguished from ‘MASK MASK’ Comp. Aesch. Ag. 1221. MASK MASK MASK MASK . Oil was one of the offerings to the dead (see on v. 225), but it may have been intended merely to feed the fire. Emmen refers to Schedius de Dis German. c. 29 for the statement that oil was used for wine in sacrifices to Pluto.

MASK MASK MASK . ‘MASK’ = ‘MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ = ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK” 8. 69, MASK . Comp. also 7. 130, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Med. and some others have ‘MASK MASK’ an impossible reading here, as Burm. remarks, though it might stand in a passage where place, not time, was spoken of. The description here, like parts of that which has preceded, is modelled on Jason's invocation of Hecate MASK , where the time and circumstances of the approach of the goddess are the same as here.

Comp. 4. 490, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” See also on MASK . “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK . ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the ridges are regarded as belonging to the woods which grow on them rather than vice versa . So “MASK MASK” 11. 545, “MASK MASK” MASK , comp. by Forb. Seneca, Nat . Q. 6. 13, quotes the words with “MASK MASK MASK” which might stand, ‘MASK’ being understood from the next line.

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK , which shows that the dogs here are infernal hounds accompanying Hecate. Many MSS. have ‘MASK MASK’ but the fem. is more usual in a context like this: comp. MASK . ‘MASK’ of dogs, as of wolves 7. 18, MASK . Comp. MASK . So possibly 4. 609 (note), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

is perhaps a translation of MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”. The uninitiated were warned off at the commencement of the mysteries: comp. Hor. 3 Od. 1. 1, and see Lobeck's Aglaophamus, vol. 1, pp. 450 foll. If the words have any distinct reference here, it must be, as Wagn. points out, to the companions of Aeneas, who were not to undertake the journey with him. With ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as used rather than ‘MASK MASK MASK’ comp. the use of ‘MASK MASK’ MASK .

“‘ Invadere MASK , ’MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ evadere MASK ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Henry. Why Aeneas is told to draw his sword does not appear. Ulysses does so. Od. 11. 48 foll., as commanded by Circe, and, thereby prevents the ghosts from drinking the blood before he chooses that they should do so: but when Aeneas uses his sword vv. 290 foll. below, he is warned by the Sibyl that he can do them no harm. “MASK MASK MASK” 4. 579.
the arrival of Hecate and the greatness of the undertaking having brought back the afflatus.
of keeping pace with 3. 671.

The interposition of a special invocation is modelled on Hom.'s practice, e. g. before the catalogue of the ships. As the commentators have remarked, it greatly enhances the solemnity of the present passage. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 5. 235. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ are vocatives co-ordinate with ‘MASK MASK’ not, as they might possibly be, nominatives coordinate with ‘MASK’ though ‘MASK’ is perhaps rather awkward of things addressed as persons. ‘MASK’ are the ghosts, who are called “MASK” below v. 432 without a substantive.

‘MASK’ is classed with Erebus 4. 510, as here with ‘MASK’ (vv. 550 foll.), singled out from the infernal rivers as the most terrible of all. Mythologically Night and Erebus were children of MASK, which represents the formless void out of which things came and into which they were resolved. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as the infernal regions are called “MASK MASK MASK” below v. 462, “MASK MASK” v. 534. ‘MASK’ was restored by Heins. from Med., Rom., and fragm. Vat. for the common reading ‘MASK MASK’ which is found in the margin of Med.

Virg. professes to have obtained his information from tradition, like Hom. Il. 2. 486, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK . The second ‘MASK’ is for ‘MASK MASK’ as in E. 10. 46, though it would be possible to understand ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ as in 1. 133., 2. 777 &c., seems to have its etymological sense of ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK’ though it might also mean ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK’

A few MSS. (including Gud. a m. p.) give ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which, as Heyne remarks, would be the more ordinary distribution of the epithets. ‘MASK’ of persons concealed 2. 135, MASK . For ‘MASK’ applied to things where persons are really thought of, comp. MASK ; though in each case there is of course a certain propriety in the epithet as applied to the thing. Heins. restored ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK’ (Gud. a m. s. &c.).

and ‘MASK’ both give the notion of empty space, indicating that the mansions of the dead are capable of receiving all comers, and that their present inmates are unsubstantial, so that earthly travellers there would feel a sense of desolation, the same which has been already expressed by ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Hom. makes the unburied Patroclus say MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , Il. 23. 74. With ‘MASK MASK’ Taubm. well comp. “MASK MASK MASK” Hor. 1 Od. 4. 17. “MASK MASK” is applied to Avernus by MASK in a different sense, the inability of the birds to exist there being accounted for by the supposition that there is no atmosphere.

answers to ‘MASK MASK MASK’ v. 268, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ to ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The moonlight is looked upon as a medium through which they pass. Comp. 2. 255, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ib. 340 “MASK MASK MASK MASK” though in both cases the expression is somewhat less harsh: see also MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Henry is rather hypercritical in objecting to the ordinary view of ‘MASK MASK’ as “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” like “MASK MASK” 3. 203, though the epithet doubtless includes the sense which he maintains, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ a general attribute of moonlight as compared with sunlight. Serv. mentions a reading ‘MASK MASK’ still found in some MSS., and apparently supported by Donatus, who explains “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though Serv. thinks the two words mean the same thing, as it must be the new moon that is spoken of. ‘MASK’ churlish or niggardly, as in MASK .

as the god of the sky, MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ the early commentators discuss this doctrine of the removal of colour by night. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 2. 469, where see note on the meaning of ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ is distinguished from ‘MASK’ by Gell. 16. 5, who reports Sulpicius Apollinaris as explaining it as “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but it would seem more simple to understand the two expressions as poetically equivalent. As Macrob., Sat. 5. 7, points out from Il. 14. 231, MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK (comp. Il. 16. 682, where Sleep and Death carry off the dead Sarpedon to Lycia). A critic of this work in the “MASK” finds a difficulty in the introduction of Sleep among these forms of human ill, and suggests that ‘MASK’ really means lethargy. But though Sleep regarded from one point of view is the restorer of nature, it is quite intelligible that it should be considered as itself a sign of the weakness which it remedies, at the same time that the suspension of consciousness, in which it resembles death, may naturally impress the imagination as an actual evil. That it is not fanciful to attribute such considerations to an ancient poet may be seen by comparing the Sophoclean MASK MASK MASK (Ant. 606), where the feeling is precisely the same, Sleep being regarded as an actual agent in human decay, though it has been lost on several of the later critics, who wish to alter the text. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ i. q. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Sen. Ep. 59 thinks the epithet an improper one, as joy is always a good thing, since none but the wise can feel it. Virg. doubtless means to include evil pleasures of all kinds, as real evils, the end of which is death.

“MASK MASK MASK” below v. 636. Here it is merely poetical surplusage, saying, what has been said before, that these figures are at the gate fronting those who wished to enter, unless we choose to say with Serv. that war, being the chief cause of death, is placed at the threshold when the others are at the vestibule, or, what would be the same thing, that the thought is repeated MASK order to call special attention to the case of war. For the personification of War comp. 1. 294., 7. 607, and see Aristoph. Peace 205 &c.

The Furies are mentioned below, vv. 570 foll., as carrying on their work within: so that it has been questioned why they are represented here among the guardians of the gate. It has been replied that the Furies may be distinguished from the Eumenides; that the meaning may be that they sleep here, but work elsewhere, a view somewhat favoured by the form of expression, which speaks of their chambers, not of themselves, though it would naturally stand for the Furies and their chambers; that Virg. has been inconsistent, perhaps following different legends. Either of the two latter views seems probable. Virg. however has doubtless an object in placing the Furies on the threshold, which seems to have been their seat (see on v. 563 below), and there is something of the same inconsistency in his language about the Hydra, vv. 287, 576. The ‘MASK’ are chambers, compared by Heyne to the cells of the porters in some Roman houses (Dict. A. ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’). Vulcan's ‘MASK’ is of gold, 8. 372, where the synizesis “MASK” illustrates ‘MASK’ here. Another question was raised by Serv. about the propriety of the word as applied to the Furies, ‘MASK’ generally meaning a bridal chamber: but Cerda shows from Ov. M. 2. 738 &c. that it is attributed to maidens also. ‘MASK’ had been already personified by Ennius (?) whose words are quoted by Hor. 1 S. 4. 60. So the Homeric MASK .
Virg. represents Discord as a Fury, with snakes for hair. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” Catull. 62 (64.) 193. ‘MASK’ occurs again 7. 351, 753.

“MASK MASK MASK” 3. 619. The notion of dreams perched like birds on a tree Heyne traces to Il. 14. 286 foll., where Sleep, taking the form of a bird, perches on one of the trees of Ida, before coming down upon Zeus. Virg. may mean that the dreams are actually in the form of birds, as Henry thinks, comp. Sil. 13. 595 foll., who, imitating this passage, represents a yew on the banks of Cocytus as peopled by noisome birds. ‘MASK’ may go either with ‘MASK’ or with ‘MASK MASK’ but the latter seems more forcible. Wagn. comp. 3. 643, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” In Od. 24. 12 the MASK MASK is reached before the shades.

may be beside the dream-laded elm, which we must then suppose to be in the middle of the vestibule, or besides the shapes mentioned vv. 274 foll. ‘MASK MASK’ = “MASK MASK” as “MASK MASK” 8. 698 = “MASK MASK” The figures here are not personifications, but mythological monsters. Hom. knows nothing of them, though he makes Ulysses afraid lest Persephone should send the Gorgon's head from Hades against him Od. 11. 634: but Aristoph. neuter, MASK . The word is appropriate to the Centaurs. ‘MASK’ may be meant to include the two Scyllas, as the daughter of Nisus was turned into a monster according to one legend (see on MASK ), or the plural may be rhetorical, like Milton's “MASK MASK MASK MASK” It would almost seem as if Virg. wished them to be conceived of as a monstrous race, like the Centaurs. Lucr., whom Virg. doubtless had in view, speaking philosophically, treats them as a class, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 4. 732, and again “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 5. 891 foll.

‘MASK’ = “MASK” as “MASK” 4. 510 = “MASK MASK” “MASK” v. 801 below = “MASK” The latter part of the compound has no very precise force, as is frequently the case in compounds in Greek, though the notion probably is that as “MASK” indicates repetition, “MASK” &c. may indicate a thing repeated three &c. times. “MASK” is applied by MASK to Gorgon, who had three bodies. MASK had not a hundred bodies, but a hundred hands (Il. 1. 402 foll.), so that the expression is far from exact. Possibly however as Virg. (following Apollodorus) gives him fifty heads 10. 565 foll., he may have given him a hundred here. In Hom. there seems no reason for supposing him to have had more than one. The word is said to occur only in Val. F. 6. 118, where it is applied to the hundred-gated Thebes. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the Hydra, called “MASK MASK” 8. 300, “MASK MASK” MASK .

of the Hydra, as elsewhere of serpents. The Chimaera is called ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as the Parthian arrow is called “MASK MASK MASK” 12. 857. Wakef., thinking the expression commonplace, ingeniously proposed ‘MASK MASK’ which would produce a translation, though not perhaps a very Virgilian one, of Hom.'s MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , Il. 6. 182. The Chimaera is one of Turnus' cognizances, 7. 785 foll.

The ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is Geryon, mentioned again 7. 662., 8. 202. Aesch. Ag. 870 calls him MASK , and MASK talks of “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Sil. uses the word ‘MASK’ twice, each time of Geryon. The words ‘MASK MASK’ (for ‘MASK’ see on 3. 591) sufficiently indicate the spectral and unsubstantial nature of the appearances, pointed out by the Sibyl in the following lines. Some of these monsters had been actually killed, so that it was natural that they should appear spectrally in Hades; others, like the Harpies, were products of the infernal world (comp. 3. 214), and though when appearing on earth they may have had bodies, they may be supposed to be divested of them in the shades, where spirit acts upon spirit. The train of thought may be the same as that in Hom. (Od. 11. 602), where though Hercules himself is among the gods, his MASK is in the shades (comp. Shelley's ‘MASK MASK MASK’ in the Prometheus Unbound): or Virg. may have been influenced more or less by a philosophical motive, intending to hint at the unreality of these terrible shapes. The words of Serv. may be worth quoting, “‘ MASK : ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. also tells us that after these lines four others were inserted by some, who believed them to have been left by Virg., but omitted by those who revised his work. It will be seen that they are of the same quality as those quoted on 3. 204: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

In Hom. Ulysses' sword operates as a real terror to the ghosts (see on v. 260 above). The legend was that Hercules drew his sword on the Gorgon when he went down to the shades, and was reassured by Hermes as Aeneas here is by the Sibyl (Apollodorus 2. 5. 12: Schol. on Il. 8. 368). ‘MASK’ 5. 503 note.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

seems to mean that it is only after passing the gate of Orcus that they see the way to Acheron. Acheron is called ‘MASK’ from its dismal associations, though it is not, like Phlegethon v. 551, a river specially surrounding Tartarus, but apparently encompasses the whole of the lower world. But Virg.'s conception of the four infernal rivers, as given by Hom., is very confused. Hom. says briefly, Od. 10. 513 foll.: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

but he does not mention them at all when he comes to the actual journey of his hero. Virg. conducts Aeneas over the water circumstantially, but from his description we should infer that there is only one river, which, after being called Acheron or Cocytus here, turns out eventually to be Styx, v. 385. Heyne remarks with justice (Excursus 9) that the poet would have found it awkward to have to describe the passage of all three, especially as Styx alone is said to surround the lower world nine times, v. 439. Generally we may say that Virg. found the notion of a single river of death most convenient for poetical purposes, but that he wished as usual to introduce the various points of the legends he followed, and so he employed the names Acheron, Cocytus, and Styx, whenever the river was to be spoken of, with a dim conception of Acheron as emptying itself into Cocytus, and perhaps of Styx as the most inward of the three, and a clear one of Phlegethon as specially surrounding Tartarus. Plato gives a much more definite description in his Phaedo, pp. 112, 113, speaking of four rivers, Ocean, Acheron, Pyriphlegethon, and Styx, the last of which disappears under the earth and reappears as Cocytus, an attempt apparently to realize the picture in Hom.: and later Roman poets, as Heyne observes, Exc. 9, have introduced varieties of their own.

Acheron has here the Plationie characteristics of a marshy slough, combined with those of a rapid river. ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ are doubtless the same, as Heyne thinks. Comp. the description of the muddy pool in Catull. 17. 10, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ib. 25, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is applied to the infernal rivers in the only other passages where it occurs in Virg., 7. 569., 9. 105., 10. 114. ‘MASK’ may be either adv. or pron., perhaps better the former.
‘MASK MASK MASK’ into which Virg. evidently supposed Acheron to empty itself. Hom., as we have seen, makes Cocytus an MASK or arm of Styx.

properly a person who collects the portoria, duties on exports and imports, or tolls (Dict. A. ‘MASK’); hence a person who receives toll for carrying passengers or goods, and so, as here, a ferryman, a sense which it bears Sen. De Benef. 6. 18, and in various passages of the poets, where, as here, it is applied to Charon. In later Latin it came to be used for a porter: see Forc. We have had the word used of Charon MASK .

is not to be taken with ‘MASK MASK’ but forms in fact a second epithet. Charon is later than Hom., who employs only the agency of Hermes for transporting the dead to the shades (Od. 24), while the living cross the Ocean river in ships: he appears however in Aristoph. Frogs 180 &c., and was represented by Polygnotus in his paintings in the Lesche of the Cnidians at Delphi.

without assistance, old as he was. ‘MASK’ MASK , apparently expressing the motion of the pole or oar, pushing up from beneath. ‘MASK’ 5. 208. “MASK MASK” 10. 218. It has been a question since the time of Serv. whether ‘MASK’ is dat. or abl. “MASK” is used intransitively with a dat. of the person or thing served, and it also takes an abl. of the instrument of the service; two constructions which are exemplified in “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Tac. H. 1. 48. ‘MASK MASK’ then might either be ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ rati ’MASK‘ ratem ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Either construction would suit the present passage: 10. 218 is in favour of the dat., as there is nothing to suggest ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ unless we consider ‘MASK MASK’ to have become an elliptical phrase. On the other hand Tac. Germ. 44 has “MASK MASK MASK MASK” which makes strongly for the abl., and Val. F. 3. 38 has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” evidently imitating either this passage or that in A. 10. Stat. Theb. 7. 752, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (of Apollo sitting in the car with Amphiaraus, like Pallas with Diomed in Il. 5), also an evident imitation of Virg., is rather in favour of the dat., as it could not so well be said that Apollo was ministering either to the car or to Amphiaraus. The result of our examination of these passages, which the commentators have collected, seems to be that the question must still be left open.

“MASK MASK” 5. 179. ‘MASK’ with Virg., as Forb. remarks, is not the same as “MASK MASK” In its technical sense among the Romans it was applied to those who were between forty-five and sixty, Gell. 10. 28, referred to by Forb. ‘MASK MASK’ is a translation of MASK MASK , which occurs Od. 15. 357, Hes. Works 705, though apparently in a different sense of untimely (or perhaps cruel) old age. There is however a compound MASK applied to Ulysses Il. 23. 791, and this is doubtless what Virg. meant to represent here, ‘MASK’ meaning fresh, with the blood still in the veins, opposed to dried up and withered: i. q. ‘MASK’ in short. ‘MASK’ is elsewhere applied to youth, as in 5. 295, so that its connexion with ‘MASK’ is a kind of oxymoron. Some have supposed a contrast between ‘MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ but vv. 125, 126 above are rather against this. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK” MASK , where ‘MASK’ appears to be used generally, as we should say ‘MASK MASK MASK’ This interpretation has been questioned in both passages by Mr. Munro (Journal of Classical and Sacred Philology, vol. 4, pp. 290 foll.), who prefers explaining the words as equivalent to “MASK MASK” or “MASK” (as in MASK , where “MASK MASK” must = “MASK”), the genitive indicating the quality of the issue, not its parentage. In the present passage the sense strongly favours, if it does not absolutely require the ordinary interpretation, as the point seems to be that Aeneas is one of the class of “MASK MASK” vv. 131, 394 (comp. v. 123), rather than that his own quality is godlike. Ascanius is called “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 9. 642: Aeneas is called “MASK MASK MASK” 8. 36, where “MASK MASK” apparently must = “MASK MASK” Aeneas was in fact sprung from more gods than one, from Venus, and hence from Jupiter, not to mention Saturn and Caelus. So Soph. Ant. 986 has MASK MASK of Cleopatra the daughter of Boreas. “MASK MASK” 4. 12, “MASK MASK” 10. 228, both said of Aeneas, are in the same category with the present line, and must be ruled by the interpretation given to it. ‘MASK MASK’ because there were pretenders to the honour, as even mythology itself admitted, doubts about parentage forming the staple of some of the mythological stories, such as that of Phaethon. So Aristaeus in the passage referred to above, MASK , affects to doubt his own descent when in trouble. Thus Hercules 8. 301 is called “MASK MASK MASK MASK” having justified himself by his actions.

The belief that only those who had been buried could be received among the shades is as old as Hom., Il. 23. 71 foll.: comp. the story of Elpenor, Od. 11, who however does not appear to have been prevented, like Patroclus, from crossing the river, though he is the first to meet Ulysses. Patroclus is kept off, not by Charon, who, as has been remarked above, was unknown to Hom., but by the other ghosts. Heyne remarks on the humane character of the superstition, which was likely to have its effect on savage tribes. Serv. has a strange notion that ‘MASK’ means unburied, “MASK” being taken mythologically for the earth-goddess. “MASK MASK MASK” 11. 372.

Leucaspis is not mentioned elsewhere in Virg. The name is a Greek one, as are many of those assigned by Virg., and even by Hom., to the inferior Trojans. In Hom. it is an epithet of Deiphobus Il. 22. 294. The death of Orontes and his Lycians has been mentioned 1. 113. ‘MASK’ Pal., ‘MASK’ Med., Rom., Gud., &c.: Heyne restored the former, which some copies have in 1. 113: and Wagn. supports it there by the remark that in 1. 220 the best MSS. have ‘MASK’ the Latin form of the Greek gen. of proper names in ‘MASK MASK’ not ‘MASK’ In A. 1 we hear only of one ship: but the words here do not imply that the whole of the Lycian part of the fleet perished with its general.

may either be taken with ‘MASK MASK’ meaning that Leucaspis and Orontes died together, or with ‘MASK MASK’ meaning that they were fellow-voyagers of Aeneas. Wagn. thinks the latter sense weak; but surely it has peculiar force, showing what passed through Aeneas' mind and drew his tears, the thought that these men had been with him throughout his seven years' wanderings. With the other sense it would be possible to take ‘MASK’ as = “MASK” as Wagn. wishes (see on MASK , where “MASK MASK MASK MASK” has occurred already), so as to refer the words to the circumstances of the storm in which they met their death: but in that case we should rather have had ‘MASK MASK’ than ‘MASK MASK’ I think then it is best to understand ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ of all the sufferings during the seven years' voyage (comp. 1. 524, “MASK MASK MASK MASK”), referring ‘MASK’ to Aeneas, and I have removed the commas accordingly. Pal. a m. p. has ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which Ribbeck adopts.

As in v. 126, there is a question between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ See on 3. 475. ‘MASK’ generally, any god, an answer to Aeneas' question v. 341. Palinurus did not know the agency of the god of sleep in throwing him overboard, as Ilioneus did not know the agency of Aeolus in producing the storm 1. 535. Palinurus denies two things, that a god had any thing to do with throwing him into the sea, and that he was drowned at all, Aeneas' question having assumed both. Elpenor says the contrary, Od. 11. 61, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .
