is doubtless the abl.: it might however be the dat., as in v. 196, as a person or thing may be said to fail the antagonist he opposes unsuccessfully as well as the friend he does not help, just as “MASK MASK MASK” 9. 810 is said of the shield resisting the blows. We hear nothing of a storm in the narrative at the end of Book 5: see Introduction to that Book. Those who would defend Virg. from the charge of inconsistency say that Palinurus would naturally overrate the danger arising from his loss, and point out that 5. 866 gives some colour to what he says.

Peerlkamp observes with reason that we should hardly have gathered from the narrative that so long a time had elapsed between the loss of Palinurus and Aeneas' visit to the shades. See Introduction to Book 5. Ulysses floats for two days, Od. 5. 388 foll., and sees land on the third. Palinurus is doubtless meant to float on the spars which he dragged down with him. ‘MASK MASK’ winter nights, and consequently long.

“MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK note, when the Furies have been mentioned immediately before. The Eumenides here probably stand merely for the infernal gods, as Heyne thinks, without having any special relation to the river. But for the parallel in G. 3, and the mention of the river before and after, we might be tempted to read ‘MASK MASK’ Cerda however refers to Stat. Theb. 1. 89, where Tisiphone is sitting by Cocytus, and to Claud. Ruf. 1. 119 foll., where Megaera dips a torch in Phlegethon. Plato, Phaedo, p. 114, speaks of criminals as thrown into one or other of the infernal rivers: and Virg. may have some such meaning in his mind, though this is not the use to which the rivers are put in his story.

It was doubted in Serv.'s time whether ‘MASK’ went with ‘MASK’ or with ‘MASK MASK’ There seems, however, no authority for the use of ‘MASK’ with a gen. in ordinary writing for ‘MASK MASK’ nor perhaps for that of the Greek MASK , which Serv. adduces, though a wife is often so called in relation to the inferior members of the household, and even by her husband in the language of compliment. Even the English ‘MASK’ would hardly be used of a wife in plain speaking or writing, though common enough in the conventional language of society. ‘MASK’ then is to be taken separately, and explained either in relation to ‘MASK MASK’ or as said by Charon of his mistress and the queen of the shades, as it is frequently used of goddesses; see on 3. 113. The use of MASK as a special title of Proserpine (see Lidd. and Scott) contributes further to make it appropriate here. ‘MASK’ with inf. MASK .

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 12. 649. It is the emphatic part of the line; it is to see his father that he undertakes the descent, not to perform any act of violence. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ forms as it were one verbal notion, which is in fact the excuse for the somewhat loose form of expression, ‘MASK’ being intended not to be taken strictly, as if Aeneas were really penetrating the lowest depths of the infernal world, but simply to discriminate the shades from the world above, and thus mark the difficulty of the undertaking. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ 4. 26.

probably in an imperative sense. ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ illustrate each other, the metaphor being from water in a storm. Comp. MASK , 480. ‘MASK MASK’ expresses the change from the previous state, like “MASK MASK” MASK . “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 8. 40.

‘MASK’ is dat., not abl., the construction being to be completed by a verb supplied from the context. That verb was rightly supposed by Jahn in MASK first ed. (in MASK second he changed MASK mind) to be ‘MASK’ or some word of similar meaning, though we need not follow him in altering the punctuation into ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Charon is mollified, and does not reply. No pronoun has been used in the preceding clause ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ and none accordingly is used here, where the expression is elliptical: in the next clause Virg. expresses himself fully, and consequently uses ‘MASK MASK’ The old interpretation made ‘MASK MASK MASK’ part of the Sibyl's speech, on which Heyne remarks rightly that we should then have expected ‘MASK MASK’ Serv. explains “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” which is Jahn's second view, and virtually that of Heyne, Wagn., and Forb., who supply “MASK MASK MASK” If this view be adopted, it would seem better to make ‘MASK’ the abl., supplying “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ to Proserpine vv. 632 foll.

Cerberus has snakes for hair (comp. Hor. 3 Od. 11. 17), so that when he is angry his snakes bristle.

The MASK was a funeral offering, and there seems reason for thinking that it was supposed to be given to Cerberus. Suidas s. v. MASK says, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK . Another belief was that it was given to the dogs that accompanied Hecate (v. 257): see Dissen on Tibull. 1. 2. 54. Those who went into Trophonius' cave took it with them as a sop to the serpents, Aristoph. Clouds 507. There may be also a reference, as Heyne thinks, to the drugging of the dragon of Colchis by Jason: indeed a reference to MASK foll. will show that Virg. has had the whole passage in his mind, though Medea there does not give a cake, but sprinkles drugs over the dragon's eyes. ‘MASK MASK’ see on 5. 855. Turn. 28. 45 wished to read ‘MASK’ from one or two MSS. of Virg. and of Priscian, who quotes the passage (p. 705 P), honey not being a soporific: but ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ are to be taken together, and ‘MASK’ is a word of no authority. The cake is made of honey and wheat (‘MASK’), with soporific drugs, such as poppy-seed. See on 4. 486, MASK . The cake is called ‘MASK MASK’ a fragment, as ‘MASK’ are frequently said to be thrown to dogs. Cerda comp. MASK , where it is used of the broken meat given to parasites.

alluding to the Roman custom of burying new-born infants “MASK MASK” under the eaves of the house, as has been pointed out by a writer MASK the Saturday Review, Sept. 25, 1858, art. on Gladstone's Homeric Studies. Repeated 11. 28. Muretus V. L. 13. 2 explains this line by a reference to a custom of burying those who had died prematurely before daybreak, the calamity being thought too great for the sun to look upon—an explanation which, when taken in connexion with the illustration discovered in v. 427, is perhaps not hastily to be rejected, though of course it cannot be applied to 11. 28. If we take ‘MASK MASK’ in its ordinary sense, it may be modelled on the various uses of MASK in Hom. ‘MASK’ of plunging in doom vv. 512, 615. ‘MASK’ is specially used of untimely death, as in Cic. (?) De Domo Sua c. 16, quoted by Forc., “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” like “MASK MASK”

The meaning seems clear, that a separate place is assigned to those who have met their death by unjust condemnation. It has been asked why they should be made to suffer: but there is no suffering in this part of the shades; there is merely the absence of the enjoyment of life, the Homeric condition of the dead which Achilles declares to be worse than the lowest function on earth. That they should endure this is not unjust: the iniquity which dismissed them from life does not make their lives good or bad; that is decided by Minos, as we shall see immediately. We should expect however that they would not occupy this place permanently, but that on the rehearing of their case some would be despatched to Tartarus, others to Elysium. But Virg. does not say this, and if we compare the case of these persons with those of the infants and the suicides, we may doubt whether he intended it. Infants remain in their limbo apparently because they have had no opportunity of showing whether they were worthy of Elysium or of Tartarus; those who have cut short their own lives are not to be credited with the good or evil of their lives, but are consigned at once and for ever to a twilight condition like that imagined by Hom.: and so perhaps the victims of unjust sentences may be dealt with as those who having accidentally come into the state of death are exempted alike from reward and punishment. But we must not probe Virg.'s meaning too deeply: he has deserted the simplicity of Hom. for something far more complicated, and it is not surprising that in borrowing details from other sources he should have been led occasionally to combine inconsistencies. Warburton thought the reference here was to a story in Plato's Gorgias, pp. 523 foll., where the establishment of infernal judges is said to have been owing to the inequality of the sentences originally passed by living judges who had to decide the condition after death of those who were still in the body. Virg. may have thought of this: but his words are hardly reconcilable with it, as Warburton admits by his proposal to alter ‘MASK’ into ‘MASK MASK’ Virg. coincides with Plato in putting the place of judgment before the spot where the roads to Tartarus and Elysium diverge (vv. 540 foll.), and also in particularizing Minos, who according to Plato is a supreme judge of appeal, Asiatics being judged in the first instance by Rhadamanthus, Europeans by Aeacus. Virg. may also have thought of another passage in Plato, of which Cerda reminds us—that in the Apology, p. 41 B, where Socrates dwells on the pleasure of meeting in the shades those who, like himself, have died in consequence of an unjust sentence, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , such as Palamedes and the greater Ajax, though it is clear that if Plato had been asked where he intended to place these, he would have replied, in Elysium. There still remains a difficulty about the construction, as ‘MASK’ may be connected either with ‘MASK’ or with ‘MASK MASK’ Perhaps in the absence of any instance of ‘MASK MASK’=“MASK MASK” (comp. “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK”), it will be safer to adopt the former, ‘MASK’ with the gen. of the punishment being sufficiently common (see Forc. s. v.).

seems to be used generally of the lower world, so that this and the two following lines will be virtually parenthetical. At the same time it would be too much to suppose that Virg. meant to commit himself to stating that the jurisdiction of Minos extended to all those who came down into the shades; we should rather infer, as was hinted in the last note, that some at least of those who died prematurely were left without any judgment at all, and consigned neither to Tartarus nor to Elysium. What the effect of this new judgment is on those on whom it is undoubtedly meant to operate, the falsely condemned, he has not told us, and perhaps he did not clearly realize himself. Meantime in this line, as in those that follow, he has introduced the phraseology of the Roman law, ‘MASK MASK’ apparently referring to the “MASK MASK MASK” the choice by lot of “MASK” for a particular case out of the whole judicial body. (The notion of Serv. and some early critics that the reference is to the drawing of lots to decide the order in which the causes should come on is far less likely.) In any case Minos is represented as ‘MASK MASK’ the name given to the presiding magistrate on a Roman criminal trial, who was assisted by the ‘MASK’ just mentioned. To say any thing definite about those who in the world below would answer to these ‘MASK’ would have been embarrassing to Virg., as, if Rhadamanthus and Aeacus were meant, they would hold their places without “MASK MASK” while it would not be easy to conceive of a judicial body among the shades themselves: so the poet as usual leaves the matter in obscurity. The pseudoAsconius however, commenting on Cic. Verr. Act. 1. 10, refers to this passage in the following words: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ quaesitorem ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ urnam ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ consiliumque vocat : ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ vitasque et crimina discit . ’” But though ‘MASK’ is the technical term for the ‘MASK’ in relation to the presiding magistrate, and the word is found in Pal. and Gud. a m. p., the context is against it, as we should expect the ‘MASK’ to be the same as those whose ‘MASK MASK MASK’ are the subject of cognizance, though the position of ‘MASK’ does not necessarily prove this (see on G. 2. 119). Mr. Long suggests that the ‘MASK’ may consist of those who have been tried and pronounced innocent. On the whole it seems better to retain ‘MASK’ and refer it to the assemblage of those who are to be tried. Sen. H. F. 735 has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” an evident imitation of Virg., but not showing what he understood by “MASK MASK” though he goes on to mention Minos, Rhadamanthus , and Aeacus as judges in separate courts. ‘MASK MASK’ assigned to their occupants: the word however seems to have been chosen as associated with ‘MASK’ in the expression “MASK MASK MASK” which occurs 1. 139.

For ‘MASK’ Rom. and Med. have ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ spreading far and wide. ‘MASK’ is common MASK Virg. of persons lying on the ground, of flowing hair, &c., and hence he uses it here of extension generally. The only parallel quoted by Forc. is Lucan 4. 670, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” perhaps an imitation of Virg. The reason why this district is represented as extensive is to indicate not so much the number of its inhabitants as the scope given for solitude, as Heyne remarks. ‘MASK’ seems to be used generally, not necessarily implying that the place is pointed out by the Sibyl to Aeneas, but merely that the spectator who does not know them has an opportunity of seeing them. So 7. 568, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Comp. the use of “MASK” v. 107 note. Possibly it may be no more than a middle, i. q. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ meet the view.

The fields are said to mourn, as being the abode of mourners. It does not appear that Virg. borrowed the name from any other source. The nearest approach to it is perhaps a passage in the Axiochus, attributed to Plato, § 19, where the judgment of the dead is said to take place in the Plain of Truth. ‘MASK MASK’ v. 242 above.

is restored by Wagn. from all the MSS. for ‘MASK MASK’ a conjecture of Heins. supported by a correction in the Dresd. Serv. The feminine appellative would introduce a somewhat more regular construction, though, as Wagn. points out, MASK transformed back to a woman would naturally be expressed “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but Virg. has chosen to express the confusion of the sexes by a certain confusion in the position, not perhaps in the construction, of the words. The construction seems to be, as Wagn. has seen, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The licence assumed by Latin writers in making a verb or adj. agree not with the proper subject of the sentence, but with something placed in apposition to it, is well known. Wagn. comp. Sil. 11. 25, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” See also Madv. § 217.

Aeneas' knowledge is here perhaps too definite, though he might conjecture that the sword had been the means of her death. Imitated from Catull. 64 (66). 39, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” which is said by the hair of Berenice to its mistress. Aeneas here admits more than he admitted when speaking to Dido in life (4. 333 foll.), where all that he said was that he was going to Italy because the gods ordered him, his real will being to settle at Troy : it accords however with what we are told of his feelings 4. 281, 332, 395, 448.

From vv. 468, 469 we should have inferred that Dido remained motionless while Aeneas was speaking: we must suppose however that she was already moving away, as she does v. 472, and so that the speech more or less represents all that he said to her, even the tears with which he pursued her as she fled, v. 476. This is confirmed by ‘MASK’ v. 470. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” v. 698 below.

is strange in Latin poetry, though it would not be thought too bold in Greek: there is no reason however to suppose a corruption in the text (Jortin conj. ‘MASK MASK’ Peerlkamp ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Heyne suspects ‘MASK MASK MASK’ to be interpolated), or to resort to forced constructions, such as Heyne's, who proposes to separate ‘MASK’ from ‘MASK’ ( = MASK MASK ). ‘MASK’ is sometimes used in apposition with a person, as in 5. 751, and the mind may naturally be said to look out through the eyes—considerations which would encourage the poet to risk an expression like this. a poetical substitute for the verb subst. as perhaps in Hor. 1 Od. 9. 1, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though there the addition of “MASK MASK” makes a difference. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Comp. the use of ‘MASK’ of a statue MASK note. Marpessa was a mountain of Paros, so that Virg. compares Dido to marble. The epithet is one of the class adverted to vol. i. pp. 7, 8. The whole picture may be taken, as Valckenaer thinks, from Eur. There seems no special point in this description of Adrastus, which would apply to any spectre. The distinguishing feature in his history was that he was the only survivor of the Seven against Thebes.

In Hom. Deiphobus is Hector 's favourite brother (Il. 22. 233 foll.), ranking apparently next to him. As such, he naturally receives Helen after the death of Paris. To his house accordingly Ulysses and Menelaus go on emerging from the horse (Od. 8. 517 foll.); but nothing is said of their doings there. Later legends gave particulars of his death, Dictys 5. 12, agreeing with Virg., Quinctus Smyrnaeus 13. 354 foll., simply mentioning the death, with a speech of Menelaus thereupon, Tryphiodorus, vv. 626 foll., going rather more into detail, but not to the extent of Virg. The house of Deiphobus was mentioned as blazing conspicuously 2. 310. “MASK MASK” v. 860 below.

The editors are divided between ‘MASK’ (Heyne, Ribbeck) and ‘MASK MASK’ (Wagn., following Heins.). The MSS. may be said at once to favour neither and both, ‘MASK’ without ‘MASK’ being the reading of fragm. Vat., Pal., Rom., Gud., &c., while Med. has ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ being subsequently struck out. ‘MASK’ alone is however found in one of Ribbeck's cursives and another a m. s., so that it seems safest to adopt it, though the insertion of ‘MASK’ after ‘MASK’ would be a sufficiently easy conjecture, even without the quasisanction of Med. The description of Deiphobus' mutilation seems to show that Virg. was thinking of the vengeance sometimes inflicted by murderers on their victim, as by Clytaemnestra on Agamemnon (Aesch. Cho. 439, Soph. El. 445), either as a barbarous insult, or to prevent him from avenging himself in the lower world. The notion that the dead bear the disfigurements they received in life is further illustrated by Plato, Gorgias , p. 524 c. Similar mutilations are described Od. 18. 86., 22. 475.

The last word of the preceding line repeated, as in 10. 821, 822, MASK , 21. The hands or arms are cut off, and perhaps fastened under the armpits (see Stephanus' Lex. He seems to have avoided saying ‘MASK MASK’ partly for the sake of variety, partly that he might not separate ‘MASK MASK’ pointedly from ‘MASK’ (comp. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK ). ‘MASK’ is a strong expression, the word being generally applied to ravaging a country.

On the whole I have restored the latter with Ribbeck, though I am not satisfied that Lachmann is right on MASK in condemning the former as a faulty elision. It certainly seems arbitrary to allow that Virg. elides a final long vowel or diphthong preceded by a diphthong (which, as Lachm. admits, takes place in nine instances), and yet to insist that he cannot have elided a long vowel or diphthong preceded by a long vowel, as in the present instance and 10. 179, where Lachm. omits ‘MASK’ with no authority whatever. ‘MASK’ here used strictly of the Rhoeteian promontory, not, as in 3. 108, generally for Trojan. “MASK MASK” 3. 304 note.

We may reconcile this story with the narrative in 2. 254 foll. by supposing that Helen gave a signal for the fleet to start, and that Agamemnon when well on his way gave a second signal to Sinon, who then opened the horse: but it is simpler to suppose that the present account is an independent one, Virg. having forgotten that he had already given another, as we must certainly presume that when he wrote the lines about Helen introducing Menelaus, lower down, he did not remember the account of Helen hiding from Greeks and Trojans alike, 2. 567 foll., if the latter is genuine.

Helen is represented as thinking of her public character as well as her interest in Menelaus ' affections, supposing that by a signal act of vengeance on Troy and of service to Greece she will recover her good name as a true wife and as a lover of her country. ‘MASK MASK’ 4. 323. The feeling is not unlike that of the Homeric Helen, Il. 6. 358.

From this and the following lines we may infer that Aeneas answers Deiphobus' question, and that the conversation proceeds. The lines are imitated, though with additional elaboration, from Od. 11. 81, 465 foll.: Virg. also thought of MASK foll. ‘MASK MASK’ translates MASK MASK . “MASK MASK” occurs Ov. 4 Trist. 4. 79, “MASK MASK” Id. 2 Ex Pont. 10. 35, cited by Forc. The abl. here is one of circumstance. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ comp. 7. 26, where the Dawn goddess appears “MASK MASK MASK MASK” a number agreeing with the Homeric accunt Od. 23. 246. It matters little whether we suppose the car or the horses to be designated by the epithet ‘MASK’ nor yet whether the abl. be taken as instrumental with ‘MASK’ or as descriptive with ‘MASK MASK’ Considerable difficulty has been made about the time intended by the poet: but Wagn. rightly follows Cerda, who supposes that Aeneas spends a night, a day, and perhaps a second night in or about the infernal regions, the first night being devoted to the preliminary sacrifices, the whole of the succeeding time to the journey through the shades. They started at daybreak, vv. 255 foll.: they have been exploring till past noon, and now the Sibyl warns Aeneas, in language sufficiently natural, that night is hastening on, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ The amplification is perhaps a little unseasonable, as we searcely need to be reminded pointedly of what is going on in the upper world, though of course all notation of time must be made by a reference to daylight.

Perhaps from Od. 16. 220 (repeated 21. 226), MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . This mode of saying that something would have happened if it had not been prevented by something else, is common in Hom. to a degree which would appear grotesque in a less simple writer. ‘MASK MASK’ by the gods or by the Sibyl: see on v. 477. What the time assigned was we can only infer: but we may reasonably suppose that a visit to the shades would have its limits. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Virg. has chosen to say ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ instead of ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ So “MASK MASK MASK MASK” v. 539. The road is said to punish the bad and send them to Tartarus, a kind of hendiadys, expressing what would be expressed in less artificial language by saying that it conducts them to Tartarus where they are punished. The meaning is that neither men nor gods can make the gates of Tartarus open when once closed. ‘MASK’ is the reading of Rom., fragm. Vat., and Pal., ‘MASK’ of Med. With Ladewig I prefer the former, which is more picturesque, and avoids the awkwardness of ‘MASK’ following. may either be used generally, the punishments being supposed to have the sanction of the whole body of gods (comp. “MASK MASK” v. 376 &c.), or specially, indicating that the punishments were frequently inflicted at the instance of one or other of the gods, e. g. on Tityos, v. 595, who offered violence to Latona. A few MSS. have ‘MASK MASK MASK’ and Heins. ingeniously conjectured ‘MASK MASK’ i. e. ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is to be understood literally, as Forb. remarks, referring to vv. 582, 585.

MASK, the brother of Minos (Il. 14. 321), in Hom. is placed in the Elysian fields, apparently as a kind of president (Od. 4. 564). In Plato, as we have seen on v. 430, he is the judge of the Asiatic dead. Heyne remarks that his office here answers rather to that of the ‘MASK MASK’ at Rome , or to that of the Eleven at Athens, than to that of a judge, as the spirits are presumed guilty before being committed to him, and he tortures them into confession and inflicts or superintends their punishment. It is difficult to say whether or no Wagn. is right in placing a comma after ‘MASK MASK’ but on the whole the apposition, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ seems more in the manner of Virg. (comp. 3. 106, 272., 11. 252), and it has perhaps some additional force as a separate clause . ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ then, as Wagn. says, will be used generally, like MASK in Greek. In any case ‘MASK MASK’ will refer at least as much to the character of MASK' rule as to that of the regions subjected to it. So far as the reference is local, it extends to the whole of Tartarus, the ‘MASK’ of v. 549.

a MASK MASK , perhaps intended to express the summary character of Rhadamanthus' justice, punishment following at once on examination. ‘MASK’ seems to be put generally for crime, which is conceived of as skulking from justice and pleading not guilty. A more special instance of the same thing follows in the next clause. Forb. notes the general use of ‘MASK’ for injury.
The concealment is called ‘MASK MASK’ as a fraud on justice. So in Greek MASK is used of doing a thing secretly. Comp. v. 24., 4. 337. It is ‘MASK MASK’ because vengeance is not really cheated.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ not a strictly accurate expression, as Virg. means not a death-bed confession, but a suppression of guilt till it is revealed MASK the other world. ‘MASK’ of a crime is as old as Ennius and Plautus, see Forc. Its use here may be meant to suggest that the confession has been delayed till earthly expiation is too late, at the same time that it suits ‘MASK MASK’ as what is really put off is not the crime but the confession and atonement. Expiation must now be made MASK the lower world.

Tisiphone, as we saw on v. 556, is the ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ the meaning here accordingly seems to be that Rhadamanthus consigus the guilty to her, and she opens the door through which they pass to their doom. ‘MASK’ seems merely to mean armed, as we cannot suppose that Tisiphone carried a scourge at her girdle. See on v. 184. So “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 9. 74. Serv. explains it grotesquely of the long lash coiling round her as she wields it. There is a similar passage in 2. 612 foll., “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but it does not seem to help us to explain that before us. We might explain ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK” 1. 210, “MASK MASK MASK” 2. 235, but the parallel 9. 74 is against this.

is not constructed with ‘MASK MASK’ but there can be little doubt that ‘MASK MASK’ is meant to indicate the kind of ‘MASK’ meant. Heyne seems right in supposing that Virg. was thinking of shaking the scourge, which is the common expression; he intended however also to give the image of the victim driven as it were from side to side by the force of the blows (“MASK MASK” 5. 460), and writhing and shrinking under them. Comp. 12. 337, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where perhaps the notion of scourging is meant to be combined with that of rapid motion (“MASK MASK” MASK ), especially as ‘MASK’ follows in the next line, showing that Virg. there, as elsewhere, is imitating himself. Cerda comp. Val. F. 7. 149, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” an obvious imitation of Virg. For ‘MASK’ some of Pierius' MSS. gave ‘MASK MASK’ a very plausible reading, supported by an intermediate correction in Pal. Tisiphone apparently has a scourge in one hand and serpents in the other, as in the imitation in Val. Fl. Heyne refers to a similar picture of Tisiphone, Stat . Theb. 1. 112, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” If we suppose the serpents themselves to be the scourge, we may say that in her right hand she grasps the culprits. This would agree with “MASK” in the line just quoted. and with the reading ‘MASK MASK’ with which Ribbeck comp. “MASK MASK” 7. 378, MASK .

It would seem as if the other Furies were called to carry away the culprit; but it may be to assist in the torture. The former view however is supported by the author of the Axiochus, who says of the guilty, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ see note on 4. 469, 470.

The description is continued: when the culprit is handed over to the Furies, then, and not till then, is the adamantine door of the prison opened. Serv. says, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Another interpretation, also mentioned by Serv. and accepted by the earlier commentators, and now by Ribbeck, supposed these words to be the poet's, as if, just as the Sibyl was speaking, the gates flew open, and afforded a glimpse of the scene within; but this would be inconsistent with what follows, where the Sibyl calls attention to the sentry at the gate, whom Aeneas can see, and then proceeds to speak of the horrors within, which he cannot see. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 1. 449. Book 2. 879 foll.) will bear quoting again: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
not, set apart, and thence accursed (note on 3. 57), but belonging to the infernal gods. “MASK MASK MASK” 7. 608.

i.q. “MASK MASK” as in 9. 166, for “MASK MASK” So we say ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ The “MASK” is Tisiphone, not, as Süpfl thinks, a Hydra who is compared to another and fiercer one within.

and ‘MASK’ are important, being contrasted with ‘MASK MASK’ Henry remarks that the three degrees of horror are Tisiphone on the threshold, the Hydra within, and the terrific depth of Tartarus, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ v. 402., 2. 567. ‘MASK’ of a monster 8. 194.

a common epithet of serpents MASK . Here it seems to refer not so much to the skin or to the poisonous powers of the Hydra, as to the black gulf of its throats. “MASK MASK” above v. 237. The Hydra need not be the same as that mentioned v. 287. Virg. however may have some object in placing a Hydra near the gate of Tartarus as well as at the gate of Orcus, as in the case of the Furies. The number of heads assigned to the Hydra varied in different legends. Serv. cites Simonides for fifty.

fiercer than Tisiphone. ‘MASK MASK’ i. q. “MASK MASK” In what follows Virg. has copied Hom., doubling his measurement, MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK Il. 8. 16; a mode of ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which he has more than once resorted to. Milton, we may remember, has similarly attempted to improve on Virg. and Hom. both, placing the rebel angels in a region “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (P. L. Book 1. 73 foll.).

Comp. the description of the tree 4. 445 foll. Virg., as Cerda points out, has been indebted for some of his language to MASK foll., where the deceptive appearance of reflections MASK water is spoken of, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Here, as MASK some other places (see note on MASK ), we are admitted to see something of what passed MASK Virg.'s mind MASK the process of composition. The occurrence of ‘MASK’ MASK v. 576 cannot be unconnected with the presence of “MASK” MASK Lucr. l. c., so that we may imagine either that having talked of ‘MASK’ Virg. was reminded of “MASK” MASK Lucr. and so of the whole passage, or that having imitated the passage he was led to recast v. 576 so as to introduce ‘MASK MASK’ There is of course much scope for fancy MASK this kind of criticism; but a subtle imitator like Virg. may be said specially to invite it, and those who are themselves accustomed to composition will be interested MASK pursuing it, even though indisposed to build much on its apparent results.

occurs again 9. 530, where we hear of a tower “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ evidently means the looking up to heaven, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ being added to develope the thought. The meaning then will be that the gulf of Tartarus extends twice as far below the ground of the infernal regions which Aeneas and the Sibyl are traversing, as the heaven extends above the earth. To this explanation we are helped by the words of Hom. quoted on v. 577. We should have expected some mention of the earth, but Virg., writing with Hom. and Lucr. in his mind, was perhaps less likely to cultivate perfect clearness of expression, and he doubtless intended ‘MASK’ to be pressed, the earth being the only place from which a person could look up to heaven. This seems more likely than the view apparently held by Donatus and glanced at by Heyne, which would make the meaning to be that the depth of Tartarus below the infernal plains is as great as the height of heaven viewed, if it could be viewed, from the infernal plains; though there would be nothing harsh in thus slurring over ‘MASK MASK’ if we did not suppose Virg. to have the parallel of Hom. in his mind. Comp. MASK (note), where ‘MASK’ is used as loosely as ‘MASK’ would be according to this interpretation. A third view is mentioned by Forb. as Henry's, who however does not give it in his own note on this passage, viz. that ‘MASK MASK’ means the looking up from the floor of the sky to the highest point of Olympus, which he supposes to be meant by “MASK MASK” 1. 225. This view also would have much to recommend it, introducing as it does a striking comparison between the heights of heaven and the depths of the shades, but for the parallel in Hom. Petit ingeniously proposed to substitute ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK’ here, introducing ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK’ in the next verse. Ladewig, following some of the older commentators, connects ‘MASK MASK MASK’ supposing it to be so called to distinguish it from the mountain in Thessaly.

comp. MASK . The best comment on ‘MASK’ is furnished by the passages about the elder gods in the Prometheus of Aeschylus. For ‘MASK’ Rom. and some others give ‘MASK MASK’ which is more likely to have been introduced by a copyist.

is perhaps from Hom., who speaks of MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK Il. 14 279. With ‘MASK’ after ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ Forb. comp. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” v. 660 below. “MASK MASK” of lightning MASK : “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Ov. M. 3. 303.

The sons of Aloeus, Otus and Ephialtes, are mentioned Il. 5. 385 foll., as having put Ares in chains, and in Od. 11. 307 foll. the story of their attempt on heaven and their punishment is told at length, on the occasion of Ulysses seeing their mother Iphimedeia, who is there said to have borne them, not to her husband Aloeus, but to Poseidon. Nothing is said there of their having been thrust down to Tartarus; their mother is in the shades, but we hear of them merely as slain by Apollo. With the apposition of ‘MASK’ comp. 10. 430, and see note on 2. 18.
See note on MASK .

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK , of Typhoeus. In the account in Od. 11 the attempt is made somewhat less definite than here; it is added however that it would have succeeded had the giant twins been allowed to grow to manhood. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 9. 496.

Salmoneus again is mentioned in Od. 11 (v. 236), but only as the father of Tyro, being himself designated as MASK . Heyne attempts to trace the gradual growth of the myths about his impiety in an Excursus specially devoted to him. He is called MASK in a fragment of Hesiod quoted by Schol. on Pind. p. 4. 252 (fragm. 32 Göttling). Joseph Warton thought that Virg. meant here to censure the Roman custom of deification, a supposition most unlikely in itself, and directly refuted by the whole tenor of the Aeneid, as well as by the Fourth and Fifth Eclogues and the end of the First Georgic. “MASK MASK” above v. 501.

has been variously explained, but there can be little doubt that Forb. is right in preferring Jacob's view, cited by Hand, Turs. vol. 2, p. 310, that Salmoneus is described as struck with vengeance in the very midst of his impious triumph. We may say if we please that the sight of his punishment recalls the thought of his impiety, and so that the Sibyl may be said to have witnessed the latter as still continuing. The construction generally resembles that in the well-known lines “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Cic. Tusc. 1. 42. Gossrau's view that he is condemned to imitate Jupiter for ever in Tartarus is ingenious, but to the last degree unlikely, not being confirmed by any other instance of punishment, though others, not punished, are represented as following in the shades the employments they loved on earth, a distinction expressly made by Ov. M. 4. 445 foll. Pal., Gud. a m. p., and the Mentelian MS. have ‘MASK MASK’ Some MSS. give ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK MASK’ as might be exsected. There can be no doubt that Virg. deliberately preferred the less conventional word, as in 2. 113, where Wakef. wished to read ‘MASK’

brandishing his torches before hurling them, so as to give force to the blow and make the blaze brighter, Comp. 5. 642. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 9. 521, which will also illustrate ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ of a torch 9. 535.

is limited of course by ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ most naturally means the city of Elis, which was not built till long after, but may well have been mentioned by Virg., by a voluntary or involuntary anachronism. Serv. well remarks, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Apollod. 1. 9. 7 speaks of a city built by Salmoneus, and afterwards destroyed by lightning. If Virg. alludes to this, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ will probably be a variety for “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
Many MSS. give ‘MASK MASK’

the Homeric MASK MASK (Od. 1. 8). ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is meant to include thunder and lightning; the next verse however mentions only the mock-thunder, the mock-lightning having been already mentioned v. 587, a curious exemplification of Virg.'s indirect and fragmentary way of telling a story.

is most simply taken as the brazen car, though Apollod. l. c. speaks of brazen vessels dragged along the ground by Salmoneus, and Manilius 5. 91 foll. of a brazen bridge. See Heyne, Excursus 12. If we were to suppose a brazen bridge we should perhaps make the line neater, as there would then be a hendiadys, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ i. q. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ Pal., first readings of Med., fragm. Vat., and Gud., ‘MASK’ Rom., second readings of Med., fragm. Vat., and Gud. ‘MASK’ is obviously preferable, as much the more forcible word. Comp. 12. 533, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is the reading of Med., Rom., Pal., Gud., &c., and the first reading of fragm. Vat., ‘MASK’ being the other, found also in many other copies. The subj. is certainly preferable, as the narrative has already been given, so that a narrative mood is not required. We have already had a similar variety 2. 346. Wagn. remarks hat Virg. says ‘MASK MASK’ not “MASK” because this impious mockery was Salmoneus' habit. So ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’

Virg. doubtless thought of MASK foll. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK’ may be meant merely to give the picture, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK , or it may mean that Jupiter raised a storm and then hurled the lightning. The words have already occurred MASK .

2. 52 note. ‘MASK’ is semipleonastic, as in 1. 3., 5. 457 notes (comp. Hor. 4 Od. 9. 51, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”): here however, as perhaps in the passage just quoted from Hor., it has the force of contrast, distinguishing Jove from Salmoneus. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ a variety for ‘MASK MASK MASK’ In 7. 456 we have “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The smokiness of pinewood torches is doubtless mentioned contemptuously, as contrasted with the lightning, which, though it causes smoke when it falls, and so may be called MASK MASK , is itself clear. Comp. Aesch. Ag. 496, where Clytaemnestra contrasts the human messenger with the beacon in similar words, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . “MASK MASK MASK” MASK .

the wind of the thunderbolt, 1. 45 note. ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK” which is expressed 4. 25. It may be worth while to quote the lines of Manilius referred to on v. 591, as they are expressed with considerable ingenuity. He is speaking of the constellation Auriga. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Tityos actually appears in the shades in Od. 11. 576 foll., a passage of part of which this is an expanded translation. Virg. is also indebted to the celebrated lines of MASK foll., where the sufferings of Tityos are described and pronounced to be a symbolic representation of the effects of passion. Hom. (who mentions two vultures) says nothing about the growing again of the liver, and Lucr. makes it an objection to the literal truth of the story that the liver must come to an end, in spite of its gigantic size as inferred from the size of the body. Virg. may be said to have met this objection by introducing the circumstance of the imperishability of the liver, apparently from the story of Prometheus, as we shall see on v. 598: he has not however been quite consistent with himself, as v. 599 will show. ‘MASK’ ‘MASK’ is the reading a m. p. of Med. and fragm. Vat., quoted too by Arusianus and Nonius. ‘MASK’ is found in one MS. ‘MASK’ would not be a natural epithet of the earth, “MASK MASK” 10. 1, as Wagn. remarks, not being in point; and the error is one into which a transcriber would most naturally fall. ‘MASK’ on the other hand is found twice in Lucr. as an epithet of the earth (2. 706., 5. 259), and is a translation, as Heyne remarks, of MASK . Hom. affords no help, as his words are MASK MASK MASK , unless it should be contended that ‘MASK’ is a translation, an awkward one at best, of MASK . Still though ‘MASK’ appears to be Virg.'s word, it may be doubted whether he would not have done more wisely in following Hom. more closely, as it detracts from the grandeur of Tityos' descent as one of the earthborn to intimate in the same breath that the earth is the mother of all. ‘MASK’ expresses the relation of a child to the nurse rather than to the mother; but the two lie so near together that they are often identified. Comp. vv. 876 foll. below, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” So MASK MASK Aesch. Cho. 45, MASK MASK ib. 66. There is however a legend, which Virg. may have followed, that Tityos was the son of Elara, but was afterwards reared in the womb of the earth, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK . But the epithet ‘MASK’ would still be open to exception, striking as it does a chord which is philosophical rather than mythological.

MASK MASK . The construction is less elastic in Latin than in Greek, as in Greek the thing seen may be made the nom. to the verb substantive, while in Latin it must be the object of the infinitive. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK Hom. l. c. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Lucr. l. c.

as if the extension were a continuing act. ‘MASK MASK’ 11. 755. Rom., fragm. Vat., and others, have ‘MASK’ seemingly a vox nihili , and Pal., Gud., &c. ‘MASK MASK’ which was the reading of the old editions.

‘MASK MASK’ is a translation of “MASK MASK” (of Prometheus) MASK , from which Virg. may have borrowed the circumstance as well as the word. ‘MASK’ is the reading of Med. and others, and is supported by Hom., who has MASK : ‘MASK’ which was preferred by some of the early editors, has the authority of Pierius' Medicean and one of Ribbeck's cursives, and is perhaps supported by an erasure in fragm. Vat.; but though it might be used of pecking, it would be far too weak for a context like this. ‘MASK MASK’ might be i. q. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ (so Serv.); but it is better to make ‘MASK’ abl. (comp. “MASK MASK MASK” MASK ), the punishment being conceived of as growing along with the materials of punishment. Cerda reminds us appropriately that the liver was regarded by the ancients as the seat of passion, so that Tityos, the ravisher, is suitably punished: Lucr. however has not taken advantage of this in moralizing the legend, not mentioning the liver even in his description of Tityos' sufferings.

The vulture digs for its food in the inwards of the giant, as the birds in MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The image is from Hom. l. c. MASK MASK MASK , which is again rendered by ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ the word ‘MASK’ being doubtless suggested by Lucr. l. c. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” We may observe however that Hom. indirectly and Lucr. directly deny the inexhaustibility of the liver, so that it is natural for them to represent the vultures as digging deep for their food, like miners in a well-worked mine; not so in Virg., whose bird might be always eating in the same place. ‘MASK’ dat., ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ was at one time the reading of the inferior editions, seemingly without authority. Nonius v. ‘MASK’ quotes “MASK MASK MASK” a fact which may abate his authority in such passages as v. 595 above.

see on MASK . They are not suffered to rest, being always eaten as fasta s they grow. Comp. 1. 723, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” We might argue from MASK , if that passage has been rightly interpreted, that the meaning is ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ but this is less likely. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” is in MASK .

The enumeration of the culprits and their respective punishments is abandoned, and the rest of the guilty are dealt with in a mass; a change which has partly the advantage of variety, partly that of increasing the horror. It is as if the reader were allowed a glimpse of that fearful abyss, and, after distinguishing a few figures, were to find himself unable to disentangle his impressions of the sufferers and their torments, and so obliged to retire with a confused sense of terrors inextricably blended. Ixion and Pirithous stand for the whole class of hitherto unnamed criminals: the tortures which follow are chosen not as those which the persons specified individually suffered, but as belonging to some of the number. In this again there is a dramatic and poetical propriety, at the same time that the confusion is justified by the fact that the legends on which Virg. had to build were not always accordant in their accounts,—Hom. e. g. representing Tantalus as tormented with perpetual hunger and thirst (Od. 11. 582 foll.), while Pindar (Olymp. 1. 55 foll.) and Lucr. (3. 980) make him the victim of the everthreatening stone mentioned in the next line. Thus ‘MASK’ is regularly constructed after ‘MASK MASK MASK’ as its antecedent. “MASK MASK” v. 123 above. Comp. MASK foll. Ixion and Pirithous were Lapithae.

Rom., which Ribbeck adopts, supposing the passage to be incomplete, Virg. having intended to prefix something about Tantalus. MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK Pind. l. c. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Lucr. l. c. ‘MASK MASK’ the colour increases the horror. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 12. 754. The hypermeter has a rhetorical effect, the overlapping syllable expressing the just falling stone. Some MSS., including Rom., omit ‘MASK MASK’

&c. Wagn. and Forb. connect this punishment with the preceding, Ixion and Pirithous, whom they suppose to be placed under the overhanging rock, and also tormented by the presence of a banquet which they cannot enjoy. This may perhaps be supported by Stat. Theb. 1. 712, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

but though the mention of Megaera and the word ‘MASK’ show that Stat. had this passage of Virg. in his mind, the banquet he is thinking of is the banquet which Tantalus served up of his child's flesh, supposed to be repeated in the lower world, so that we cannot argue from the imitation to the right interpretation of the passage imitated. On the other hand, the two punishments are not easily combined in thought, the point of the terror of the overhanging rock being that it distracts the victim's mind from any thing else, while the banquet is represented as rendered impossible, not by the alarm of the rock, but by the interference of the Fury. If the view taken on v. 601 is the correct one, there is of course a further reason for supposing more than one punishment to be spoken of. On the whole then I think that two punishments are named, and those only as specimens of an infinite number. The hint of the banquet is evidently given by the Homeric description of Tantalus, but the circumstances are varied with considerable judgment, the board spread with artificial dainties being substituted for the simpler features of lake-water and orchard-trees. In Val. Fl. 2. 192 foll. Theseus and Phlegyas are represented as doomed to sit at a similar banquet, the poet having either followed another legend, or availed himself of Virg.'s example to introduce changes of his own. ‘MASK MASK’ are entirely different from the ‘MASK MASK’ or bridal bed, though both receive their name from the genius, the deification of the happier and more impulsive part of man (see on MASK ). ‘MASK MASK’ is a feast-day, and so ‘MASK MASK’ is a banqueting couch, whether the expression is Virg.'s own or borrowed from common language. ‘MASK MASK’ so “MASK MASK MASK” 2. 2. The second epithet is rather awkward, but it is doubtless to be explained with Wagn. on 5. 24 by saying that ‘MASK MASK’ forms one notion, and that ‘MASK’ is added as a piece of ornamental description.

the pillar or support of the couch. ‘MASK’ may be either a dat. or an attributive abl., the couch being made, for poetical variety, the appendage to its pillar; or again the abl. may be local, ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK’ On any view, the case must be regarded as substituted for the gen., the natural one in prose. ‘MASK’ of getting ready a banquet 1. 638. Rom. has ‘MASK MASK’ a reading which in an author of less pure taste might conceivably be strained into an allusion to the feast of Tantalus.

‘MASK’ is said to occur only in an imitation of this passage and of that just referred to from A. 1 in Val. Fl. 2. 652 foll.; but Enn. Andromacha fr. 9 Vahlen has “MASK MASK MASK MASK” so that the adj. was probably one of the many compound epithets invented by the old poets, who, like their Greek predecessors, frequently cared only for one part of the compound, ‘MASK’ being regarded as = ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ as ‘MASK’ was found to be virtually convertible with ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK” 1. 637. ‘MASK MASK’ is explained as a personification of Hunger by Serv., who refers to 3. 252, where the same words occur; but though Celaeno with her Prophecy of Famine illustrates and is illustrated by the office of the fiend here, there is no reason to suppose that the expression has any other but its ordinary sense, one of the Furies, conceived of as the eldest of the sisterhood, being charged with the execution of this mode of punishment. MASK MASK occurs Eur. Iph. T. 963. If we suppose Virg. to have thought of three Furies, we may suppose this to be either Allecto or Megaera, Tisiphone, as we have seen v. 555, being otherwise employed. Elsewhere however, 12. 845 foll., Virg. makes the three produced at a birth. ‘MASK MASK’ is perhaps suggested by the Erinnys and Orestes sitting opposite to each other in Eur. 1. c.
with ‘MASK MASK’ as in 2. 167. Comp. the Homeric MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK Il. 9. 221.

as if they were persisting in their attempt to eat, in spite of her prohibition. “MASK MASK” 4. 510. A few MSS., including Pal. and perhaps Gud. a m. p., have ‘MASK MASK’ a variety which occurs again 8. 527, though there the balance of MS. authority is reversed.

Virg. has apparently imitated Aristoph. Frogs 147, where Heracles enumerates those who lie in the infernal quagmires, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. well remarks that ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is general, though Virg. may have thought of special instances like Atreus and Thyestes, Eteocles and Polynices. “MASK MASK MASK” v. 661, merely meaning ‘MASK MASK’

In mentioning the striking of a parent rather than the further crime of parricide, Virg., like Aristoph. l. c., has followed the true moral feeling of antiquity, which counted even the less heinous crime among the blackest offences. So MASK is strictly the striker of a father, and so perhaps ‘MASK MASK’ Comp. the story of Solon providing no punishment for parricide. Sen. Contr. 9. 4, quoted by Taubm., has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The fragment of the so-called law of Servius Tullius makes the crime capital, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” For ‘MASK’ one or two MSS. with Non. ‘MASK’ have ‘MASK MASK’ but ‘MASK’ is virtually disjunctive. ‘MASK’ metaphorical, as in 4. 51, here of the web of trickery and wrong in which the patron is supposed to entangle his client. Urbanus, an old grammarian cited by Serv., thinks the meaning of the passage cannot be the true one, as clients are more likely to cheat their patrons than vice versa , a curious piece of aristocratic feeling, as Heyne remarks: he therefore supposes the criminals intended to be “MASK MASK” The laws of the Twelve Tables took a different view, specifying the crime here mentioned and making it capital, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” there however the man hides his money in the earth, here he has found a treasure. Heyne gives ‘MASK’ the sense of ‘MASK MASK’ which would suit the general language in the next line better, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ but the other sense is more natural and more picturesque, and Virg. may mean the treasure-finder as a type of all who are greedy of gain. Comp. for the picturesque image expressed in ‘MASK’ Hor. 1 S. 1. 66 foll.

= ‘MASK MASK’ as MASK frequently = MASK . Comp. the use of ‘MASK’ of setting a thing before a person at table: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Juv. 5. 135. ‘MASK MASK’ their kinsfolk and friends, which would be the extent of charity ordinarily practised.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ are particularized among other adulterers, either as having been surprised in the fact, or to show that punishment in life does not confer immunity from punishment after death. ‘MASK MASK’ 3. 54, 156., 11. 161, as we should say, to follow a standard. The followers are chosen instead of the leader for the sake of poetical variety. Doubtless Virg. had in his mind the civil wars of Rome , ‘MASK’ having that special reference, as in MASK , though in MASK it seems general. Augustus would of course not be likely to regard himself as glanced at, as some of the commentators have feared that he might, since he doubtless considered his own mission to be that of putting an end to such impious conflicts. Wagn. ingeniously supposes the servile wars to be meant, connecting ‘MASK MASK MASK’ closely with the preceding clause; but the two images do not seem as if they were meant to harmonize, and there is a point gained in supposing two classes of violators of relative duties to be intended rather than one. We have then (1) those who have violated duty to their brothers, (2) to their parents, (3) to their clients, (4) to their kindred generally, (5) to their married fellow-citizens, (6) to their country, (7) to their masters. Ruhkopf remarks that slaves partook largely of the general social disorganization of the time, and refers to Appian B. Civ. 1. 72., 4. 22, 29, 39, 51. ‘MASK MASK’ i. q. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Virg. seems to have expressed himself loosely, since a slave, as Mr. Long remarks, could not strictly be said to give ‘MASK’ to his master, like an equal.

presents a difficulty, as though Virg. might for the sake of variety take the culprits at the time when they are not actually suffering punishment, but in the agony of looking forward to it, we should have inferred from the preceding narrative that they would not have to wait after having been once hurled into Tartarus, ‘MASK MASK’ It would seem that we must suppose either that Virg. has been inconsistent with himself, expressing himself now as if Tartarus were a dungeon as well as a place of torture, or that he conceives of the guilty as not punished immediately upon reaching the prison-house, and chooses to regard them in the interval, a brief one, between incarceration and execution. There is a similar picture of the agony of expectation MASK foll. Schrader wished to read ‘MASK MASK’ and Med. a m. pr. has ‘MASK’ but the word seems a mere error, out of which nothing can be made. “MASK MASK” v. 868 below, 8. 532. For ‘MASK’ with inf. see Forc.

sc. ‘MASK MASK’ or, if the construction is the same as in the next clause, ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ shows that ‘MASK’ must be relative, not interrogative, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ though the awkwardness of such a construction may dispose us to see some plausibility in ‘MASK’ the reading of two MSS. ‘MASK’ however is simpler than ‘MASK MASK’ and is supported by v. 429, 512 above. ‘MASK’ too is very strange, though it receives some illustration from v. 626, where it evidently means “MASK MASK” a sense illustrated by Forc. from Cicero's Topics. Here the meaning seems not to be ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but ‘MASK MASK MASK’ so that ‘MASK MASK’ form a kind of hendiadys. Virg. probably chose the word on account of the dramatic character of the various mythological punishments, which consist in some striking, significant, and pictorial act. The form itself is said ‘MASK’ as it receives them when they are engulphed in the abyss.

the traditional punishment of Sisyphus, as the wheel is that of Ixion. Virg., as was remarked on v. 601, is purposely general. Heyne reads ‘MASK’ but ‘MASK’ is supported by all the MSS., and is virtually disjunctive. ‘MASK’ of the spokes of a wheel MASK

As usual, many MSS., including Med., Rom., Pal. a m. s., Gud., and fragm. Vat., give ‘MASK MASK’ The meaning of course is that the legs and arms of the sufferers are stretched out, and that in this state they are bound on a wheel which whirls them round and round. The word is often used nearly in the sense of ‘MASK MASK’ see Forc. The ordinary legend of Theseus was that, having been fixed in a chair in the shades for his attempt to carry off Persephone, he was released by Heracles, leaving some of his flesh behind him: Virg. however has varied the story, or followed another.

was taken by some interpreters whom Serv. mentions as acc. pl., Theseus being supposed to admonish the Phlegyae, a nation which was destroyed for its impiety by Poseidon, according to Euphorion: but it is evidently nom., being the name of the father of Ixion, who appears in the imitations of Statius and Val. Fl. mentioned on v. 603. The nature of his punishment is not specified by Virg., who leaves us to infer the horror of it from his melancholy warning.

is used of solemn affirmations, which are supposed to be equivalent to calling witnesses to the truth of the statement made; here it is extended to a warning which contains no formal affirmation, though we may say if we please that Phlegyas makes himself and those who witness his torture evidences of the truth of the propositions involved in his precept.

Virg. has evidently imitated Pind. Pyth. 2. 39 foll., where Ixion gives a similar warning from his wheel: MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK : MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . Henry makes ‘MASK MASK MASK’ a repetition of the preceding clause ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ but this would be rather flat, and the story of Phlegyas as told by Serv. says that his crime was burning the temple of Apollo at Delphi, so that it would be truer to say that the last part of the line interprets the first, ‘MASK’ meaning the rendering of their dues to all, gods as well as men. Taubm. has a curious note, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Macrob. Sat. 4. 1 says that these lines are closely copied from two of Varius', “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Virg. has been generally supposed to refer to Curio, who was bribed by Caesar's paying his debts to quit the party of Pompey; but though Lucan 4. 819 foll. speaks of him in similar language, it is not credible that Virg. should refer in this way to a transaction which reflected on the buyer no less than on the seller. Virg. might safely speak of the impiety of civil contests to Augustus, as we have seen on vv. 612, 613, but he cannot be supposed to have glanced at any of those who brought about either the dictatorship of the first Caesar or the imperial power of the second. ‘MASK’ &c. seems to refer to the same person as ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ so that the same reason would operate against our supposing a distinct reference to Antony, though we cannot say that his proceedings may not have been in Virg.'s mind. ‘MASK MASK’ 1. 484. “MASK MASK” 3. 438. Here the words are significant, as opposed to the liberty which has been taken away. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Hor. 1 Ep. 10. 40. ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ the laws being engraven on brazen tablets and fastened in some public place whence they were removed when abrogated. The laws of the Twelve Tables were engraved on brass and fixed in the Forum: the Senatusconsultum de Bacchanalibus, now preserved at Vienna, is on brass. See Lewis, Credibility of Rom. Hist., vol. 1. p. 138.
like MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK Aesch. Cho. 71. Virg. may have thought of the Homeric MASK MASK .
a somewhat bold expression for succeeding in a design, borrowed by Ov. M. 11. 242, cited by Forb. Comp. “MASK MASK” Hor. 1 Ep. 13. 11.
Repeated from MASK . See Introduction to Aeneid, p. 26.
see on v. 615, and comp. “MASK MASK” v. 560.
Some MSS. give ‘MASK MASK’ which was the old reading before Heins., but is certainly less grammatical. We have had the same variety MASK . See on v. 754.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

Med. has ‘MASK MASK MASK’ doubtless for ‘MASK’ though Heins. conj. “MASK MASK MASK” In ‘MASK MASK’ the meaning seems to hover between the duty undertaken of carrying the offering to Proserpine and the offering itself, ‘MASK’ belonging to the former sense. Having used the expression, Virg. considers himself free in v. 637 to talk of ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ employing ‘MASK’ in the sense of gift. In the first line of the poem, written, or supposed to be written by Virg., on the prospect of his Aeneid (‘MASK MASK’ Catalecta 6), ‘MASK MASK’ is used in the ordinary sense of a duty undertaken.

intransitive 5. 675. Some MSS. give ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ reared by the forges of the Cyclops, i. e. by Vulcan and his Cyclops. The Cyclops were supposed to be the authors of those unhewn polygon structures still seen in Greece, like the walls of Mycenae and Tiryns, and called Cyclopian architecture; the mass of the commentators too may be right in supposing that Virg. means the palaces of Pluto to be built of iron, which would be the natural material used by Vulcan and his workmen. ‘MASK’ is found in various MSS., including Rom., fragm. Vat., Pal., and Gud. a m. p.; but though ‘MASK MASK’ is a technical expression (1. 423 note), it would not go well with ‘MASK MASK’ even if ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ could be used indifferently. ‘MASK’ of rearing a fabric 2. 186, 461., 12. 676.
the arched gateway fronting us. ‘MASK MASK’ was the reading before Pier. and Heins.

not of course the precepts of the Sibyl, but the rules of the gods. It would be possible however to take ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” Culex 289 (comp. “MASK MASK” MASK , “MASK MASK” ib. 549), making ‘MASK MASK’ = ‘MASK MASK’
“MASK MASK” 2. 332, “MASK MASK” ib. 725, which is actually found here in Gud. as a various reading.
see note on G. S. 104. The meaning here is, as we should say in English, they annihilate the intervening distance. “MASK MASK” 5. 316.

“MASK MASK MASK” v. 424 note. We must suppose that there were means of lustration, vessels of water and lustral branches, at the entrance of Pluto's palace, like the MASK at the entrance of Greek temples. ‘MASK MASK’ is emphatic, like “MASK MASK” 2. 719, “MASK MASK” 4. 635. ‘MASK’ of fresh water MASK .
“MASK MASK MASK” v. 279 above.

‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’
“MASK MASK” v. 236 above. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ see on v. 629.

“MASK MASK” 1. 365. Homer's Elysium is not part of the infernal regions, but a separate region (Od. 4. 563 foll.), which later legends (Hesiod, Works 170 foll., Pind. Ol. 2. 61 foll., fr. 95, Bergk, ed. 1) developed into the ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Virg. has not copied Hom., whose description speaks of a place where there are no storms but always cooling zephyrs: from the second of Pindar's elaborate pictures he has taken the pursuits of the heroes. Perhaps the nearest parallel to his language is Aristoph. Frogs 154 foll., where Heracles says to Dionysus that after passing the place of punishment he will come to a region described as follows: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Comp. ib. 324—352.] In the spelling ‘MASK’ I have as usual followed Wagn. Heyne says it is the usual spelling of the MSS., and it appears to be found in all Ribbeck's. We may be reminded of Coleridge's “MASK MASK MASK MASK” enfolded by “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

is the Latin equivalent of MASK MASK . Plaut. however gives it “MASK MASK MASK” see Forc. ‘MASK MASK’ With the transference of the epithet we may comp. “MASK MASK” above v. 441. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK , a passage which Virg. may have been thinking of, as the next verse seems to show.

Virg. copies Hom.'s description of Olympus, Od. 6. 44, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK MASK MASK , the preceding lines of which resemble those on Elysium referred to on v. 638, and so would naturally be associated with them by a reader of the Odyssey. It is this passage which Lucr. imitates 3. 18 foll.; and Virg. would seem here again to be somewhat indebted to his language, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ is from another passage in MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” of the sun, and perhaps from Cic. Arat. 60, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ is meant to express MASK MASK , the transparency of the ether being conceived of as a superabundant fluid which permeates every part of the region. ‘MASK MASK’ as plainly is meant to render MASK MASK , ‘MASK’ having its Roman sense of dazzling. See on MASK , MASK . Wordsworth, imitating this passage, talks in his Laodamia of “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” as Gray, imitating “MASK MASK MASK” 1. 591, talks of “MASK MASK MASK MASK” The expression in each case would convey a false notion to a reader unacquainted with Latin, being only defensible if understood not as a translation of Virg.'s epithet, but as a quotation of it. ‘MASK’ is a predicate, and so is coupled with ‘MASK MASK MASK’ both qualifying ‘MASK MASK’ see on 5. 498. For ‘MASK’ fragm. Vat. a m. p., Rom., and Gud. a m. s. have ‘MASK MASK’ Pal. a m. p. ‘MASK MASK’

They have a sun and stars of their own, distinct from those in the upper world. Pind. fr. l. c. apparently says that the sun visits them when it leaves us: elsewhere however he gives them a sun which shines night and day alike (Ol. l. c.). Wakef. ingeniously but erroneously makes ‘MASK’ nom., ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ being used reciprocally; ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ = ‘MASK MASK MASK’ like ‘MASK’ MASK , though there perhaps rather more is intended: see note.

Orpheus was one of the mythical fathers of song, and his name was associated with revelations about the lower world, supposed to be preserved by secret societies (Dict. M. Orpheus), so that he is naturally made the harper who plays while the blessed spirits dance and sing. He is called ‘MASK MASK’ as in Hor. A. P. 391 he is called “MASK MASK MASK MASK” The long robe was characteristic of musicians, as Cerda shows, comp. Prop. 3. 23. 16, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” (of the statue of Apollo in the Palatine temple), and also Hor. A. P. 215, Ov. F. 6. 654, 688, where the long robes of the ‘MASK’ are mentioned and accounted for. ‘MASK MASK’ above v. 359. Elsewhere we have ‘MASK MASK’ as 12. 169, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

This line is unusually difficult, as owing to Virg.'s love of artificial expressions we cannot be sure whether he has used particular words in their natural or in their accommodated sense. ‘MASK’ is evidently intended i. q. MASK , though its usual sense is not so much that of answering as of interruption or contradiction: see Forc. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is evidently intended to express the seven notes produced by the seven strings of the lyre, known as the Heptachord of Orpheus. But whether in this line Orpheus is intended to produce the notes with his voice in singing, or with the lyre as he plays, is not clear. ‘MASK’ seems as if it may be intended to translate MASK , in the sense of ‘MASK’ as though the verb in Greek does not appear to be technically applied to music, MASK is used in Aristot. Probl. § 19 &c. of notes one of which is the octave of the other. Virg. is not likely to have intended this restricted sense, but he may have taken the general notion of accompanying from the special one of accompanying in a higher or lower octave. There is a further difficulty about ‘MASK MASK’ which may be either abl. or dat, meaning in the former case ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ the notes either of the voice or of the lyre, according as we understand ‘MASK MASK’ in the latter case ‘MASK MASK MASK’ either the notes of the harp, the notes of his own singing, or the beat of the dancers. In my first edition I had understood the present line of singing, and the next of playing, making ‘MASK’ the dat. and explaining it of the dancers. Now I return to the more ordinary opinion, taking ‘MASK’ dat. of the dancing, but supposing that Orpheus only plays, and so regarding the next line as epexegetical.

Imitated, as Cerda remarks, from Catull. 62 (64). 22, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Forb. thinks ‘MASK MASK’ refers specially to the days of Troy's prosperity, but the general reference to a happier divine foretime is more probable.
Comp. MASK , 36. Here MASK seems to be mentioned as a descendant of Teucer: but it is not easy to say which of the legends about them Virg. followed. See on 3. 107, 108, 168.

coupled with ‘MASK’ as in v. 485, 1. 16, 17. ‘MASK’ seems to go with both, as “MASK MASK” are combined 1. 119., 9. 777: but it might be constructed with ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” Pers. 2. 61. ‘MASK’ however seems to mean ghostly, as it is a constant epithet of the dead: see Forc. ‘MASK’ is found in fragm. Vat., Med., &c., and is perhaps right, as there is not much force in Pierius' objection that the Sibyl was not likely to wonder at what she had seen before. Pierius however says that he found ‘MASK’ in all his oldest MSS. but one: it is the reading of Pal. and Rom.; and the sing. may have been altered by some one who supposed ‘MASK’ to be the nom., a very common source of error: see Wagn. Q. V. 8. 2. a. It is not clear whether the cars are represented as empty or as filled by their ghostly riders. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ is in favour of the former view, meaning apparently, like its prototype, Il. 3. 135, quoted on the next line, that the warriors are enjoying relaxation: on the other hand ‘MASK MASK MASK’ &c. seems to show that martial exercises are still going on. Perhaps we may say that the present line refers to one class who are exercising, the next to another, who have done their exercise and are now feeding or grooming their horses, the same distinction which seems to be drawn in the words ‘MASK MASK MASK’ &c. and ‘MASK MASK MASK’ &c. But the difficulty may be best removed by regarding the sentence ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as a conclusion drawn from the picture actually presented: the warriors have their spears and horses near them, to use when they please.

MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK Il. 3. 135, of the armies resting before the combat of Paris and Menelaus. For ‘MASK’ fragm. Vat. and two of Ribbeck's cursives have ‘MASK MASK’ as in MASK : but it is not likely that Virg. should have preferred the jingle, while the clerical error is natural enough.

is restored by Wagn. from Med., Pal., fragm. Vat. &c. for ‘MASK’ (Rom.). The MSS. vary between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ inclining however to the contracted form, which is also supported by Priscian 7798 P, and by Serv. Priscian says that ‘MASK’ might be scanned as a hypermeter. Wagn. prefers accounting for it by crasis: but it is difficult to see why that should be resorted to when the next verse begins with a vowel, though it is of course admissible in such cases as v. 33 above. feasting on the grass, like the Trojans 1. 214., 3. 221 foll., 7. 109. The object is to give a picture of natural golden-age simplicity, with which we may contrast the elaboration of art in the infernal banquet above, v. 603. Compare Milton's language about Mammon, Par. Lost, Book 1.

without a case, as in Livy 37. 20, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” comp. by Forb. The word has been objected to as homely, but ‘MASK’ is used of a sacrificial feast 8. 182. The Paean at banquets is as old as Hom. Il. 1. 473, the words of which seem copied here, MASK MASK MASK . ‘MASK’ in a band or chorally. If the singers are the same as the banqueters, they can hardly be dancing.

The scent of the bay has been mentioned MASK foll. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ not unlike “MASK MASK” MASK . ‘MASK’ is rightly understood by Henry and Ladewig to mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The river is supposed to take its rise in the Elysian fields, just as in MASK foll, we are told that Aristaeus saw the subterranean sources of all the rivers in the world, Eridanus included. The Eridanus was the subject of various myths, being placed in different parts of the globe, and turned into a constellation. The notion of its underground source doubtless comes from the fact, noticed by Heyne, that the Po, with which the Romans identified it, not far from its source, flows underground for two miles. ‘MASK’ &c., will then refer to its course through the upper world, not through the shades.
with ‘MASK MASK’ a patriotic tribute to the size and force of the river, like those in MASK ., 4. 371 foll.

= “MASK MASK” A comment on the epithet as applied to poets is furnished by the well-known passage Hor. 2 Ep. 1. 126 foll. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is generally explained of their power of song, but it may also refer to their purity. Serv. thinks prophets are meant, and explains ‘MASK’ &c. of their truthfulness; but the presence of Musaeus shows that poets formed part of the fraternity, and Virg. would hardly have so little feeling for his order as to pass them over in silence.

Musaeus is the mythical father of poets, as Orpheus of singers. The tallness of his stature is described, rather unreasonably, in words copied from Hom.'s description of Ajax Il. 3. 227. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ a poetical variety for “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Some of the early critics accused Virg. of jealousy in not rather naming Homer than Musaeus, as if a sense of obligation ought to have made him ready to encounter an anachronism. Silius has been able to repair the omission, introducing Homer into his Elysian fields, which by-the-bye he speaks of incongruously as “MASK MASK MASK” in lines (13. 778 foll.) which have been excellently, though not quite accurately, translated by Chapman in the introductory verses to his Iliad.

with ‘MASK’ as well as with ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ is a fuller expression for the ordinary use of ‘MASK’ i. q. ‘MASK MASK’ Anchises here appears to be speaking of ordinary human expectation, not of prevision. Rom. reads “MASK” For ‘MASK’ Pal., Rom., the first reading of Med. and others have ‘MASK MASK’ Gud. has both. ‘MASK MASK’ which is found in fragm. In more ordinary Latin we should have had ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ but Virg., for variety's sake, makes the brakes rustle with the woods, of which they form a part. The rustling is caused by the wind, though we need not quote Od. 4. 567 foll. to prove that there are gales even in Elysium.

‘MASK’ may be compared with “MASK” which has the force of “MASK” as in Hor. 4 Od. 3. 10, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” “MASK” had been previously used of water by Ennius and Lucr., the former of whom is quoted by Serv. as talking of “MASK MASK” (A. fr. inc. 119), while the latter has “MASK MASK” more than once, 5. 488., 6. 267, 1142, an expression borrowed, probably in the same sense, by Virg. himself MASK : see note there. Lethe is unknown to Hom. Plato, Rep. p. 621 A, makes the spirits pass through a sultry plain called MASK MASK , after which they drink of the river of Indifference, MASK MASK : lower down however he speaks of MASK MASK MASK MASK .
