The doctrine of the ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which Anchises proceeds to expound, has been already mentioned by Virg. MASK (note), though there he does not commit himself to it. ‘MASK’ introducing an exposition 3. 381. It is common in Lucr., e. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” which Virg. may have imitated. There is some resemblance also, as Heyne remarks, between the present passage and Cic. de Div. 1. 11, where a long extract is given from Cicero's poem on his consulship beginning “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” For ‘MASK’ Pal., Rom., Gud., and the first reading of fragm. Vat. have ‘MASK MASK’ Wagn. Q. V. 9. 6 remarks that in expressions like this, where the earth is spoken of in its entirety, yet without any thought of personification, Virg. prefers the plural. ‘MASK MASK’ of the sea, like “MASK MASK” MASK note.

is the first reading of Med., possibly pointing to a variant ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK” Lucr. 5. 69. ‘MASK MASK’ seems best referred to the sun alone, already 4. 119 called ‘MASK MASK’ as one of the Titanic brotherhood, being the son of the Titan Hyperion. The stars had no connexion with the Titans: nor would it be natural either that they should be mentioned to the exclusion of the sun or that the sun should be merged among them, they having been already distinguished from the moon. The pl. for the sing. is supported by Ov. M. 14. 172, “MASK MASK” (where however another reading is “MASK”), and Val. F. 2. 364, “MASK MASK MASK” which is said of Capricorn alone. If it is any thing more than an arbitrary stretch of poetical licence, it is probably to be explained of the rising and setting sun regarded as two, as Ov. M. 1. 338 talks of “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and Petronius of “MASK MASK MASK” So Weber ( Corpus Poetarum ） on Ov. M. 14. 172. Dryden conj. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” a plausible suggestion from an amateur critic.

like ‘MASK’ of the entire mundane frame. Henry attempts to restrict it to the earth, comparing MASK ; but the expression there, as here, is simply an obvious metaphor, not a new sense stamped on a word and adhering to it independently of the context: and his other parallel from Pervigilium Veneris v. 55 is only an imitation of the passage in the Georgics. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK” 12. 838, the more ordinary construction being with the dat. or with the abl. with ‘MASK MASK’ Possibly it is to be explained grammatically as the abl. of the agent, as in such expressions as “MASK MASK MASK” 12. 445, the element of mixture being regarded as the cause which has brought the mixture about. Comp. 8. 510, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” where there seems a confusion between the mother as causing the son's blood to be mixed, not pure, and as mixing her own blood with the father's. At the same time, we must not forget the connexion between the dat. and abl., nor the probability that a case which is used in a particular sense with a preposition may be found bearing that sense without it. “MASK MASK MASK” occurs Lucr. 3. 233.

Rom. has ‘MASK’ but ‘MASK’ is written over an erasure. With the line generally comp. MASK foll. The expression resembles that of several passages in Lucr., e. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The meaning here seems to be that this union of mind with matter is the cause of individual life in animals, which consist of soul and body. Heyne refers to the Stoic expressions of the ‘MASK MASK’ doctrine, such as that of Posidonius, who made individual souls the sparks, MASK or MASK , of the MASK MASK MASK MASK .

the MASK MASK of Il. 14. 273. The application of ‘MASK’ to the sea in Latin is as old as Ennius. The Latins seem to have thought of smoothness where Hom. thought of glancing light, MASK being connected with MASK , and thus only one of many objects which might be said to glisten or reflect light, whereas in Latin the ‘MASK’ or polished stone gives the keynote, and things are called ‘MASK’ because they resemble marble. Comp. the different applications of MASK and ‘MASK MASK’ mentioned on MASK , where, though the case seems reversed, the Greek conception of colour being perhaps more definite there than the Roman, it is of no less importance to remark that the Romans apply the words to things partaking of the nature of the object purple, the Greeks to things partaking of the nature of that from which purple took its name. ‘MASK’ of strange shapes, there being more room for the marvellous among the creatures of the deep than among the better known inhabitants of the land.

is virtually parallel to ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the pure aether with which the divine soul is identified being regarded as flame. Comp. v. 746 below and MASK note. ‘MASK’ might conceivably be separated in grammar from ‘MASK MASK’ but they are doubtless meant to be constructed together. See on 3. 162.

It seems difficult to say whether ‘MASK’ is used with reference to the sparks of flame, “MASK MASK” v. 6 above (see on v. 728 ad finem ), or simply of the soul regarded as the seminal principle of life. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ &c. does not strictly cohere with what precedes, as the influence of the body would not affect the principle of the soul, but only the extent of its operation, which is evidently Virg.'s real meaning. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 5. 395. Ribbeck adopts from Pal. and Gud. (where however the order is corrected), and others mentioned by Burm., ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but the order in the text is found in Med., fragm. Vat., Rom., &c.
is stronger than ‘MASK MASK’ implying that the body is ready to die, and would die but for the resistance of the principle of life.

from this influence of the body. ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK’ form the fourfold division of ‘MASK’ in Cic. Tusc. 3. 11, the two first expressing the impression made by a great good, present or future, the two last that made by a great evil, present or future. The same division occurs Hor. 1 Ep. 6. 12, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where, as here, it is used as a philosophical commonplace. Cerda traces it in the Greek philosophers, including Plato. ‘MASK’ = ‘MASK MASK’ as Henry observes, though he is hypercritical in condemning Heyne'sexplanation ‘MASK MASK’ which was doubtless meant, not as a lexicographical explanation, but merely as a substantial equivalent in the present context.

In the small text of Virg. I had recalled ‘MASK’ with Henry, supposing it to be the reading of Pal.; but it is found only in two of Ribbeck's cursives and there from a correction, in inferior copies mentioned by Wagn., in the MSS. of Donatus, and in some copies of Serv. Thus the weight of authority is decidedly in favour of ‘MASK MASK’ which is actually found in Gud. a m. p. and some later copies, and is really supported by all those (Med., fragm. Vat., Rom., Pal., &c.) which read ‘MASK MASK’ See on 1. 211, MASK , 354 &c. ‘MASK’ is specially used of looking through darkness or seeing after blindness, as in MASK (which Virg. may have had in his mind), Cic. Fin. 4. 23, Suet. Ner. 19. In all of these places the MSS. seem to give ‘MASK MASK’ but modern critics will hardly agree with Wakef. on Lucr. l. c. in retaining ‘MASK’ on that account, and attempting to give it a sense which from analogy it appears incapable of bearing. Where the mistake is at once so easy and so commonly made, it is clearly one which may be corrected without the help of MSS., from a simple consideration of the requirements of the case. Henry denies the applicability of the sense here, but the language of the rest of the line seems to me distinctly to recommend it. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Cerda illustrates the comparison of the body to a dungeon, the origin of which is referred by Plato, Cratylus p. 400 c, to the Orphic school: MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK (sc. MASK ), MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK : MASK MASK MASK MASK , MASK MASK , MASK MASK . See Stallbaum l. c. and on Phaedo, p. 62 B.

MASK . ‘MASK MASK’ &c.: Heyne remarks that the natural sequence would have been “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Virg. has chosen not only to couple a negative sentence to an affirmative by an ordinary copulative (for which Forb. comp. inter alia Ov. M. 13. 521 foll. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”), but to use the present ‘MASK’ where we should have expected the past ‘MASK’ in other words to express himself as if he were speaking of the soul when still in life, not of the soul after death.

with ‘MASK MASK’ giving in fact the reason why these plagues become part of the being, viz. that they have grown together with it so long. “MASK MASK” below v. 746. ‘MASK MASK’ 1. 354 note. ‘MASK’ MASK . Fea's conj. ‘MASK’ is ingenious, but, as Henry remarks, quite unnecessary.
MASK . See on v. 543 above. “MASK MASK” v. 527, where as here it is used of crime.

11. 258, where there is a similar use of ‘MASK’ with a gen. of the offence. ‘MASK’ is explained of crucifixion by Cerda, whom Henry follows, perhaps rightly. He shows that MASK and ‘MASK’ were specially used in that sense (comp. St. Paul's application of MASK MASK MASK Gal. 3. 13 to crucifixion, the primary reference of the words being different, as is remarked by Ellicott in loco), and argues that ‘MASK’ points the same way. But it signifies little what was the precise image Virg. had before his mind, the real point being that the spirit is hung up in such a way as to secure its purification by air. Serv. refers to the ‘MASK’ in the festival of Bacchus ( MASK note, where the parallel is mentioned by anticipation): but Gossrau remarks that no one but Serv. seems to have connected these with purification, and that other traditional notices of them explain them differently. “MASK MASK” 10. 82. Henry ingeniously makes ‘MASK’ here the nom., supposing the meaning to be that the winds blow through the unsubstantial forms of the spirits: there would however be something awkward in the predicative epithet here, when we have already to connect ‘MASK’ closely with ‘MASK MASK’ and it is possible that the same meaning may be intended by the application of the epithet to the winds, which being thin and unsubstantial, are conceived of as the more penetrating. Notices of this threefold purification are cited by Cerda from Martianus Capella and St. Augustin: but it is not clear that they, any more than Serv., had any further authority for the custom than the present passage of Virg.
“MASK MASK” 1. 118. The epithet shows the thoroughness of the purification. Gossrau comp. the words of Glaucus, Ov. M. 13. 952 foll.

may either be an adj. or a participle. Gossrau understands it in the former sense, making ‘MASK MASK’ = ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ But this is hardly Virgilian, and is not sufficiently supported by 12. 242, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” On the other hand it is certainly harsh to understand ‘MASK MASK’ as ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ but it seems not unlike Virg., and is perhaps justified by such inversions as 4. 477 note. For passive participles in Greek which may be explained on the principle of the cognate acc. see my note on Aesch. Choeph. 806. The force of ‘MASK’ is well illustrated by Forb. from Sen. Ep. 59, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” No other instance is quoted of ‘MASK’ in the sense of being removed by burning (for in MASK and Cic. de Div. 3. 3 the sense or reading seems more than doubtful): but such a use of the compound is abundantly defended from analogy, e. g. ‘MASK’ which just preceded, and “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Cic. Planc. 4.

These lines are among the hardest in Virg. The first sentence ‘MASK MASK MASK’ has puzzled the commentators perhaps more than it would have done had they sufficiently remembered Virg.'s fondness for artificial phrases. The general meaning evidently is ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ This Virg. has apparently chosen to express by saying ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ the Manes, which appear to have been a sort of twofold genius belonging to each person (see on 4. 610), being regarded as separable from the person himself, and as subjecting him to inflictions: at the same time that Virg. probably intended to avail himself of other possible constructions, the cognate accusative, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ and the accusative of definition, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The suggestion that the Genius is meant is made by Serv., but it seems better not to regard it as exhausting the meaning of the passage, as the Manes or Genius elsewhere appear to stand for the deified individual, and their visitations, as in 4. 610, take effect not on the individual himself but on his enemies. We are also helped by the consideration that elsewhere in Virg. the infernal powers are spoken of loosely as ‘MASK’ (10. 39., 12. 646, MASK , 505), though it would be too much to infer from this with Cerda and others that ‘MASK’ here simply = ‘MASK’ if it were only that the words so interpreted would be open to the objection made in the last sentence, the Furies of a person generally meaning not the Furies that punish a person, but those which, being his embodied curses, punish his enemies (see on 4. 384). It is true that there is a distinct instance where ‘MASK’ appears to be used for spiritual punishment, Stat. Theb. 8. 84, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but this proves no more than that Stat. there as elsewhere ventured on an experiment in language in imitation, as he thought, of Virg. Professor Munro, Journal of Philology, vol. 2, pp. 145, 146 says, “‘ Quisque suos patimur Manis ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘we put on, bear the burden, each one of us good or bad, of his own manes or garb of death,’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK‘ Donator atrae lucis , Alcide , tuum Diti remitte munus , ereptos mihi Restitue manis : inpius frustra invoco Mortem relictam . ’” The difficulty of what follows is greater. The words are easy, but it is not easy to see the appropriateness of the sentence to the context. As they stand, they appear to speak of a second purgation as going on in Elysium, which is in itself not a very likely thing, while the change of person from ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ to ‘MASK’ v. 750 has still to be accounted for. Jahn, whose explanation is approved by Forb., supposes that all the shades are sent into Elysium after their purgation, but that while the greater part only pass through on their way to Lethe, a few, of whom Anchises is one, are allowed to remain there and complete a still higher purification, as a prelude to a new and glorious life on earth. This is probably as plausible an explanation as is likely to be suggested of the passage as it stands, but the inconsistencies of it lie on the surface. Elysium, as has been said above, is not a natural place for purgation; it is evidently the everlasting reward of a good life, not a place of temporary sojourn previous to a return to earth: there is nothing in vv. 741, 742, as compared with vv. 745—747, to show that the degree of purification contemplated in the latter is intended to be higher than that in the former: the ‘MASK MASK’ of v. 748 are plainly parallel to the ‘MASK MASK’ of v. 745; and it can hardly be meant that the more highly purified spirits return to earth without a draught of Lethe. A general view of the context seems to require, as Heyne and some of the early editors, and more lately Henry, have seen, that the souls which are purified and sent back to earth should be distinguished from the select few who are purified and established in Elysium, and this the change of person decidedly favours. The words ‘MASK MASK MASK’ then, if not the previous clause, will refer to the latter, the whole of the following lines to the former, who, as being far the larger number, are spoken of as if they were the whole body. But this sense, though required by the context and favoured by the language, does not suit the order of the passage. Heyne and his contemporaries wished to get rid of the difficulty by transposing the two lines before us, which is Ribbeck's remedy; Henry thinks they are no more than an ordinary Virgilian parenthesis. The first suggestion appears to me as much too violent as the second is too lenient. The supposition of a confusion of the order introduced by the transcribers is at all times hazardous (see on MASK —205), and is exposed to unusual suspicion here, as the lines would still look awkward if placed, where alone they could be placed, after v. 747, so that Heyne inclines to treat them as altogether spurious; while on the other hand, if Virg. intended no more than an ordinary parenthesis, it must be admitted that his sentence is exceedingly ill constructed. I think then that every thing points to the supposition, which at one time occurred to Heyne himself, that we have here one of the passages in the Aeneid (the case of the Georgics is different: see on MASK —205) which Virg. left unfinished. His whole conception of a metempsychosis seems, as I have said in the prefatory remarks to this book, to be really inconsistent with the general picture which he gives of the world of spirits, and so he naturally found a difficulty in harmonizing the two in Anchises' narrative. Had the Aeneid been a finished poem, the obstacle would doubtless have been surmounted so far as the mechanical structure of the present passage is concerned, but we should have felt it nevertheless in reading the Sixth Book. A doubt still remains whether ‘MASK’ refers to the whole body of the departed, as ‘MASK’ evidently does, or to the few spoken of in the next clause. In the one case the meaning will be that the whole multitude is sent through Elysium, the greater part to drink the Lethe water and then return to life, the few to remain in Elysium: in the other, that the few are distributed among the spacious plains, a use of ‘MASK’ for which see on 1. 680. On the whole the former view seems to agree best with the language of these two lines, while any objection which may be raised to it from the language of vv. 748 foll., where Lethe seems to be introduced for the first time, is obviated by the consideration mentioned above, that the present passage as left by Virg. is not meant to cohere with the context. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK” 1. 538.
“MASK MASK” 5. 783. The expression seems to be Virg.'s own, but MASK has “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK’ is explained by v. 748.
Rom. has ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK” says Heyne: but ‘MASK’ is clearly better. ‘MASK’ (fragm, Vat., Med.) is restored by Wagn. after Jahn for ‘MASK’ (Pal., Rom., Gud.).

the “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” of MASK . ‘MASK’ is here the sentient power. It is a very favourite word with Lucr., but almost the only passage in him which illustrates the present is 5. 144, where he denies that natural objects are “MASK MASK MASK MASK” An English reader may remember the disembodied Arvalan in Southey's Curse of Kehama, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ comp. vv. 204, 733 above and v. 762 below, and see on 1. 546, MASK . Med., Rom., and Pal. have ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is found however in one of Ribbeck's cursives and (from a correction) in Gud. and another, possibly also in fragm. Vat. as corrected, and is acknowledged by Serv. on 7. 464 as one of the four instances in which Virg. has used this form of the genitive, the others being 7 l. c., 3. 354, and 9. 26, in the first and third of which there is also variety in the MSS. ‘MASK’ is doubtless meant to go with both ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ but ‘MASK’ is thrown in that we may not feel the want of it in the latter clause.

seems merely to express the completion of a period, as Serv. explains it, remarking, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Comp. the use of “MASK” MASK , and see on 1. 9. Whether the revolution is one of the whole period, or, as ‘MASK’ might seem to show, of each successive year, it would perhaps be a refinement to inquire. The mention of a thousand years is probably suggested by the myth in Plato Rep. 10 p. 615 A, where those who have done wrong in life are punished through ten periods of a hundred years each, a hundred years being the estimated length of a life-time on earth, so that each criminal receives tenfold punishment, after which they are allowed to choose new lives, and each is made to drink of the river of Indifference (see on v. 715), as a preliminary to his new existence. Comp. also Plato Phaedr. p. 249, where the period is similarly given. In Pind. fr. 98 (Bergk ed. 1), quoted by Plato Meno p. 81, the return to earth takes place in the ninth year.

parenthetical, like MASK . ‘MASK MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv., who apparently means that it was given to young men on their first military success,—a sense sufficiently appropriate here. From Prop. 5. 3. 68, Suet. Claud. 28, it seems to have been bestowed on the occasion of the celebration of a triumph. Others explain it as ‘MASK’ and Donatus makes it the emblem of peace.

Comp. v. 434 above. ‘MASK’ of virtual rather than actual possession, ‘MASK MASK’ being a place in the upper world. Heins. wished to read ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ the custom of drawing lots for places (comp. 5. 132) is transferred to the shades as in such passages as Hor. 2 Od. 3. 25 foll.

see on 1. 546. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Italian blood mingling in his veins with our own. So Evander speaks of Pallus as “MASK MASK MASK” 8. 510, his own race being regarded as the normal element. Some of Pierius' MSS. have “MASK MASK MASK MASK”

seems to indicate that the name afterwards became a common one at Alba, as Livy 1. 3, quoted by Forb., says “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ means no more than latest: it came however to be applied to children born after the father's death ( MASK , Varro L. L. 9. 38),—or born after the father's last will (Gaius Inst. 1. 147, Ulpian Dig. 26. 2, 5, referred to by Freund s. v.: see Dict. A. “MASK MASK” Roman). Here it evidently has its original meaning, as Caesellius Vindex ap. Gell. 2. 16 long ago remarked, though Serv. and in later times even Henry and Sir G. Lewis give it the sense of ‘MASK’ contrary to the plain meaning of the next line. Virg. seems to have intended to translate the Homeric MASK , as the commentators remark. The word appears to be restricted to children, till we come to writers like Apuleius and Tertullian, who use it as convertible with ‘MASK MASK’ In the legendary accounts Silvius seems actually to have been called Silvius Postumus : see Lewis, Credibility, vol. 1, pp. 357 foll.

The story, as told by Serv. here and on 1. 270 and others (Lewis, p. 356), is that MASK was left pregnant at Aeneas' death, when, fearing Ascanius, she took refuge in the woods, and there brought forth Silvius; after which an arrangement, variously related, was made, by which Lavinium was left to MASK, and Ascanius founded Alba. In the latter kingdom Silvius eventually succeeded Ascanius, either in default of heirs, or because the actual heir, named Iulus, was too young. Some made Silvius the son of Ascanius, and so Livy 1. 4, who speaks of him as “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Virg. apparently adopts the tradition generally, without thinking it necessary to specify the circumstances of Silvius' birth in the woods, while he indirectly contradicts the story of MASK's fear of Ascanius, which would have jarred on all readers of the Aeneid, by representing Silvius as born in his father's lifetime. The legends of the sequel of Aeneas' life after his settlement in Latium are not altogether reconcilable with the treatment adopted by Virg. in the Aeneid. Virg. doubtless could have harmonized them with his purpose, had he pleased, as skilfully as he has harmonized discordant materials in the story of the Aeneid itself: but he has chosen instead to regard them from a distance, without distinctly committing himself to any one version of them. Even thus however he has not been able to escape some inconsistencies, as the present passage shows, compared with that in the First Book. There (1. 265 foll.) we are told by implication that Aeneas' death and deification takes place three years after his landing in Latium: here he is spoken of as living to old age, a time which must have been conceived of by Virg. as long subsequent to that in which he captivated Dido: there the name of Ascanius is associated with Alba, here that of Silvius. These statements, it is true, may be brought into agreement by supposing that Aeneas reigns at Lavinium after the expiration of three years in camp, Ascanius removing to Alba after his death, and that Silvius is mentioned here simply as the successor of Ascanius at Alba ; but it seems hardly likely that Virg. should have formed a definite and, in one respect at least, independent conception of events which he alludes to so cursorily. With ‘MASK’ Germ. comp. Evander's words to Pallas, 8. 581, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” This is the first mention of the name of Aeneas' destined wife, who has been already alluded to 2. 783., 6. 93. Serv. curiously reconciles ‘MASK’ with the posthumous birth of Silvius by understanding it of the immortal life of the deified Aeneas, as the Greeks call the gods MASK . Henry supposes ‘MASK MASK’ merely to mean that the child was conceived in Aeneas' old age.

here and v. 779 seems = ‘MASK MASK’ not, as Forb. and others give it, ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ are doubtless the same words, like ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK’ often has the sense of ‘MASK MASK’ as in 7. 763., 8. 413., 9. 584: but it is also used of bringing forth, as in MASK , Pliny 10. 54. 75, &c., quoted by Freund: and the dat. here naturally points to that meaning, which is indeed one peculiarly consonant to the etymology of the word. Perhaps on a comparison of 7. 763 we may say that Virg. meant to glance at both meanings (comp. also the association of MASK and MASK in Greek tragedy), though in v. 779 it can hardly be meant that Ilia reared as well as bore Romulus. With ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ comp. 9. 642, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Virg. doubtless intended a contrast between the place of Silvius' birth and his high destiny, whatever his view of the story may have been.
from Silvius, as ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Comp. 1. 6., 5. 123. ‘MASK’ with an abl. as 1. 285., 3. 97. ‘MASK MASK’ 1. 271 note.

‘MASK’ seems to be used loosely, as Serv. remarks that MASK was the twelfth king of Alba. Other accounts put him fourteenth in a list of sixteen: see Lewis, pp. 360 foll., where it appears further that some omitted him altogether. What MASK did to entitle him to the name of ‘MASK MASK MASK’ does not seem to appear from any extant legend. Ov. M. 14. 622 places the story of Vertumnus and Pomona under his reign.

MASK comes before Procas in other lists: according to Serv. he is sixth, according to others eighth or ninth. Anchises naturally mentions him as bearing the name of his own father. MASK follows Procas immediately in other lists. For his story see Lewis l. c. and Dict. M. Virg. is the first author cited for this use of ‘MASK’ like ‘MASK’ (comp. 4. 329., 12. 348), which is common in post-Augustan poetry and prose: see Freund. Rom. has ‘MASK MASK’ which might be supported from 1. 20., 287, in which passages, as in Enn. Alex. fr. 11 Vahlen, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” the subj. has perhaps something of its future sense.

MASK MASK , whom Ov. l. c. and F. 4. 31 foll. omits in his list of the Alban kings, appears in other lists next or next but one to the first MASK. The words ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ might seem merely to refer to the general contingency to which all these potential personages are subject: comp. v. 828, and see on v. 780: Serv. however explains it by saying that MASK MASK was kept out of his kingdom for fifty-three years by an usurping guardian. Sir G. Lewis rightly remarks that Serv.'s story is inconsistent with Dionysius and others, who assign to this king a reign of thirtyone years: but it is not clear why he should assume that Virg.'s expression cannot be reconciled with the supposition of a long reign, as the uncertainty affects his coming to the throne at all, and apparently ceases after his accession, and the words ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ in effect imply that his reign was a glorious one. ‘MASK’ is generally found with ‘MASK MASK’ here it is naturally enough used with ‘MASK MASK’ which, as Madv. § 436 remarks, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”—‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK” above v. 403. ‘MASK’ 3. 14.

It matters little whether a note of exclamation be put after ‘MASK’ or not, as long as it is understood that ‘MASK’ is not a relative but an exclamatory interrogative. ‘MASK MASK’ seems merely to refer to the martial bearing of the young heroes, not, as might be supposed from the next line, to any marks of distinction in war which they wear.

Heyne, following many of the old editions and one MS., read ‘MASK MASK’ connecting the line with what follows and supposing a difference to be made between those who are famed in war and those who are famed in peace. But this interpretation ignores the nature of the ‘MASK MASK’ which was given for preserving the life of a citizen in war and slaying an enemy, so that this line contains no contrast to the preceding, but only a specification and a climax (see Dict. A. ‘MASK’). ‘MASK MASK’ see on 1. 567. The expression was doubtless originally a piece of mere simplicity, a person being supposed to carry his limbs or at least the upper parts of his body as he might carry any thing separate from him: but in using it here Virg. may have thought of carrying the umbrageous wreath on the forehead, as conceivably MASK may have intended to indicate the feeling of weight and oppression in the head and eyes. ‘MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK MASK” 8. 276. The civic wreath was originally given only to those who distinguished themselves in hand to hand combat: like other ancient honours however it was voted by the senate to Augustus, who had oaken wreaths hung before his doors as being the perpetual preserver of the citizens. Gossrau, from whom this is taken, refers to Ov. F. 1. 614., 4. 953. This doubtless suggested the image to Virg., who is glad to show that Augustus is only the heir to the honours of his ancestors.
For the various lists of the Latin colonies, which were called the towns of the Prisci Latini , see Lewis, p. 362 foll. For the names here see Dict. Geogr.

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK of the cities of Italy. “MASK MASK MASK” Hor. 2 Ep. 1. 252, of the fortifications of Augustus. After this line many editions, even in modern times, give another, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” but it has no MS. authority whatever, and is said to be the work of an Italian lawyer, Fabricio Lampugnani.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’—i. e. places bearing names. For ‘MASK’ the first reading of Med. is ‘MASK MASK’ which Heins. prefers.

seems to mean merely, shall appear on earth to join his grandfather, Romulus being naturally associated with Numitor, whom according to the story he restored to his rights. Heyne prefers ‘MASK’ in this sense, after one MS.; but though the change would be easy enough (Med. has ‘MASK’ v. 762, ‘MASK’ v. 765), it is not necessary, as Anchises may speak of his descendants indifferently as they will hereafter appear on earth and as he now sees them in the shades. Other interpretations —‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ (Serv.)—‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ (Wagn., who has however since changed his opinion)—‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ (Thiel) are far less likely. ‘MASK’ 1. 276.

Comp. 1. 274. ‘MASK MASK’ an attributive gen. There seems no reason for taking ‘MASK’ as an adj. with Wagn. and Forb., though the form might perhaps be justified by the analogy, not of “MASK MASK” Hor. A. P. 292, which they compare, but of ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ See on 4. 552.
v. 765 note. Some inferior MSS. give ‘MASK’ see on MASK .

The right meaning of this verse, I have little doubt, has been substantially given by Peerlkamp and Henry, after Serv. Romulus is already marked as a child of upper air (comp. “MASK MASK” v. 568 above) by his father's token, the twocrested helmet. The reference apparently is to the contingency which more or less overshadows all who are in this state of potential existence (note on v. 769), and which Romulus by favour of his future father Mars has in fact already overcome. Henry's objection, that ‘MASK MASK’ in Virg. is restricted to Jupiter, is met by observing that ‘MASK’ here belongs not so much to ‘MASK’ as to ‘MASK MASK’ That the two-crested helmet was distinctive of Mars is, as Henry says, made probable by Val. Max. 1. 8, § 6, taken in conjunction with this passage, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Heyne remarks that Romulus is constantly represented with a helmet. ‘MASK’ can only refer to ‘MASK MASK’ as ‘MASK’ shows. The only difficulty is in the use of ‘MASK’ in the singular in the sense which, as we have seen, it bears in the plural; but this is not invincible (comp. its application to things vv. 128, 680), and certainly need not lead us to construct ‘MASK’ as gen. pl. with either ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ to the detriment of the general sense, though it may make us see some plausibility in Peerlkamp's conj. ‘MASK MASK’ which in an author less well supported by MSS. authority might itself be confused with ‘MASK MASK’ especially with ‘MASK’ preceding. There is however great propriety in the sense of ‘MASK MASK’ as explained above, while ‘MASK’ would add nothing which is not already contained in the line.

is used not vaguely, as in 4. 103, 341, but strictly, referring to the augury of the twelve vultures and the greatness promised thereby. Romulus takes the auspices, which are the cause of the future glories of his city. Thus we do not need Burmann's ‘MASK MASK’ The apostrophe to Aeneas agrees with ‘MASK MASK’ and is in keeping with the feeling of the passage, the grandeur of Rome being represented as the culmination of all a Trojan's hopes. Isidorus Orig. 18. 1 speaks of the verse as Ennius': but this is supposed to be a mistake, the name of Ennius having arisen from ‘MASK MASK MASK’

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 1. 287. ‘MASK MASK’ her greatness of soul. Comp. with Forb. “MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK , where the sense is parallel, though the construction is not the same. The expression may perhaps be regarded as an expansion of the common Virgilian phrase “MASK MASK” MASK &c.

See on MASK , where it should have been remarked that ‘MASK’ is abl., ‘MASK’ an ethical dat., as against Peerlkamp, who constructs ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ understanding ‘MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

doubtless refers to the great Roman families, such as those mentioned MASK foll., a passage to some extent parallel. Rome is not only the parent of men, but of heroes, as Cybele is the mother of gods. Henry's attempt to understand the passage of Rome as the mother of great nations, with which he aptly compares Byron's parallel of Rome , ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ to Niobe (Childe Harold, 4. 78, 79), is ingenious, but seems alien to Virg.'s thought, as in that case we should have had “MASK MASK MASK MASK” or something similar. “MASK MASK MASK” 9. 82.

This description of the progress of Cybele's statue is from MASK foll.: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

Virg. can hardly mean that the figures of the other gods appear along with Cybele in her car, though that is what his words would seem to suggest: we must suppose then that she is represented with the mien of a proud and happy mother.
With ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Germ. comp. MASK MASK MASK . “MASK MASK” 7. 562. Ribbeck adopts ‘MASK MASK’ from Rom., Pal., and Med. a m. p., which have ‘MASK’ but the corruption is obvious.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

in an ordinary passage would be thought either archaic or grandiloquent: but it suits the solemn prophetic enthusiasm of Anchises, as in the well-known passage in the Tempest “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” suits the quaint seriousness of Prospero. ‘MASK MASK’ the gens Iulia .
seems to be emphatic— Romans of your own stock. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 1. 288.
merely i. q. ‘MASK MASK’ the light of the upper world.

“MASK MASK” was once the reading, but it is found only in inferior MSS. ‘MASK’ refers to C. Julius MASK. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ comp. MASK . “MASK MASK” occurs MASK , in the sense of living through ages, seeing them to their end, as in MASK . Here it can only mean to establish, like “MASK MASK MASK” &c., though the analogy is not very close.

Saturn was the god of the golden age, 7. 324., MASK , Ov. M. 1. 113, as also the first ruler of Latium 7. 349. Virg. makes the two periods synchronize, which does not agree with Ov. l. c. “MASK MASK” 3. 14. Rom. reads ‘MASK MASK MASK’ which would make a kind of sense, ‘MASK’ being taken with ‘MASK MASK’ but it is evidently no more than a slip.

seems best taken in its ordinary sense of ‘MASK’ though Wagn. wishes here, and in Lucan 4. 333., 8. 164, to give it the meaning of reaching to a distant spot, as if it were “MASK MASK MASK MASK”—a view which harmonizes with his interpretation of “MASK MASK MASK” 1. 680 note, and is certainly plausible: Peerlkamp however, cited by Forb., justly remarks that the glory of Augustus is enhanced by representing him as having conquered nations beyond the farthest known. “MASK MASK” MASK . The Garamantes were conquered by L. Cornelius Balbus , who triumphed A.U.C. 735: they sent an embassy to Augustus and made a treaty, which in the language of Roman vanity is described as making submission. This passage then, as Heyne remarks, would be written in the last years of Virg.'s life. ‘MASK’ MASK note. The reference may be, as Heyne remarks, to the restoration of the Roman standards by the Parthians and the Indian embassy to Augustus while in Syria A.U.C. 734. It seems best to change the comma after ‘MASK’ into a longer stop, with the earlier editors, so as to make ‘MASK MASK MASK’ mean ‘MASK’ The sentence then will be independent, like that which follows in the next line, of which Heyne says “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

The meaning of course is ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ but Anchises seems to point to the land as if he saw it in vision. The land seems to be that spoken of less hyperbolically 4. 480 foll., where v. 797 has already occurred, that of Ethiopia, though here Virg. seems to be speaking of the whole country, there only of the western extremity of it. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ like ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ refers to the Zodiac, called by Arat. Phaen. 321, MASK MASK . Serv. comp. Lucan 3. 253, where the image is characteristically amplified: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” The reference is probably to the overrunning of Ethiopia by C. Petronius A.U.C. 732, Heyne.

“MASK MASK” 4. 481, a better epithet, as ‘MASK’ anticipates the next line. Perhaps it may suggest a doubt whether that line is not an interpolation from Book 4: it seems however to be contained in all MSS., and is noticed by Serv.

The MSS. vary between ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK’ the former however is read by all the first class MSS., though MASK Pal. and Gud. the last letter is erased. ‘MASK MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ a peculiar construction, the meaning being ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which would not have been expressed by ‘MASK’ with acc. Comp. ‘MASK MASK’
instr. abl., the predictions of Augustus' coming being the cause of their dread. ‘MASK MASK’ the reading of the first class MSS., was restored by Heins. after Pierius for ‘MASK’
intransitively, as MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” comp. by Germ. Other instances are given by Freund. “MASK MASK” Catull. 11. 7. For the compound see on v. 287.

Comp v. 392. “MASK MASK” Hor. 3 Od. 3. 9. Heyne and Schrader remark that Virg. has shown want of judgment in mentioning those only of Hercules' labours which were connected with Arcadia, as of course they could afford no measure of the hero's travels. Wagn. thinks the mention of the brazen-footed stag admissible, as it appears from Pind. Ol. 3. 26 foll. that Hercules' chase after it led him into the Hyperborean country: the remainder he has no doubt Virg. would have corrected if he had lived. The truth seems to be that Virg. conceives of Hercules generally as a hero who put down the various monsters in various parts of the world (comp. Soph. Trach. 1011, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK ), and so compares him to Augustus, who in his progress received the submission of the various barbaric nations, the reference being to that expedition through the provinces, which occupied the emperor during the last four years of Virg.'s life, and from which he was returning when the dying poet met him. Comp. generally the depreciation of Hercules' exploits as contrasted with those of Epicurus, MASK foll., where one of the points dwelt on is the distance of the monsters destroyed from the abode of civilized man.

The MSS. vary much in these tenses, Rom. having ‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ Rom. and Med. ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK’ while Pal., Rom., and the first reading of Med. and Gud. have ‘MASK’ There is of course no real question about the true readings: but the varieties are worth mentioning as showing how little even first class MS. evidence may be worth in such matters. A similar warning against absolute confidence in the authority, considerable as it is, of the ancient grammarians is afforded by the epithet ‘MASK’ which Serv., Charisius, p. 249 P, Diomedes, p. 437 P, and others all explain as a contracted form of ‘MASK’ MASK , an impossibility not only in metre but in language, as “MASK” is not the wind. Brazen feet are attributed to horses by Hom., Il. 8. 41, and other poets, the notion being that of strength and endurance, and, as a consequence, swiftness. ‘MASK MASK’ the common story was that Hercules had to bring the Cerynitian stag alive to Eurystheus, so Serv. thinks ‘MASK’ = “MASK MASK” Eur. H. F. 378 however represents him as killing it. “MASK MASK” MASK . For ‘MASK’ Markland wished to read ‘MASK MASK’ or else ‘MASK’ for ‘MASK’ in the next line; but Virg., as elsewhere (see v. 609), prefers variety. The force of ‘MASK’ is, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ &c. In ‘MASK’ the reference is to the boar which Hercules slew.

Some MSS. read ‘MASK’ (‘MASK’ Med.) a common confusion. Gossrau comp. Ov. M. 7. 405, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” of Theseus slaying the robbers. Not unlike is Hor. 1 Ep. 2. 45, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where the notion is that of wildness disappearing before cultivation. Contrast MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ Virg. implies that the Hydra was shot to death, contrary to the common account, which represents the heads as crushed by Hercules' club.

Alluding to Bacchus' famous Indian expedition. Comp. Hor. 3 Od. 3. 13 foll., where Bacchus is mentioned in the next stanza to Hercules. Bacchus was represented as driving a car of tigers or lynxes with reins of vine or ivy branches, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” Pers. 1. 101. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK”

From Catull. 62 (64). 390, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Nysa, the legendary mountain on which Bacchus was brought up, was identified with various places in Europe, Asia , and Africa (Dict. M. ‘MASK’ Dict. G. ‘MASK’).

Comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” where Virg. has pointed out what nature offers, and asks whether man will not do his part. So here Anchises, after showing the glorious culmination of the Trojan fortunes in Augustus, asks whether Aeneas hesitates to take his place as a link in that vast chain of destiny. The reading of the concluding words is doubtful. Med. has ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which is supported by Serv., and is parallel to the expression afterwards used 10. 468, “MASK MASK MASK MASK” except that while there the main thought is that of spreading and perpetuating fame by gallant deeds, here it is rather that of putting out inborn valour and making it felt in the world. But Rom., Pal., and two other of Ribbeck's MSS. have “MASK MASK MASK MASK” which is confirmed by Diomedes p. 411, whose MSS. have “MASK MASK MASK MASK” an ungrammatical reading, found nevertheless in Gud. a m. p. The sense would be nearly the same, to extend our power by our bravery, to commence the career of conquest: but it is not altogether easy to see how the variation can have arisen. If Med. stood alone as the chief authority for ‘MASK MASK’ there would be no difficulty, as elsewhere it repeats words from other passages, as in 5. 843, MASK (see also on 1. 364., 4. 564, where the case is not so clear): but Serv. of course has an independent weight. On the whole, however, I have with Ribbeck preferred the reading of Rom. and Pal., as I see no plausible hypothesis on which its introduction can be accounted for, an argument which has similarly determined my judgment in the two passages just referred to.
1. 541., 10. 75, to be distinguished from “MASK MASK” with which it is sometimes confounded in MSS., the one referring to entrance or invasion, the other to subsequent settlement.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

Ribbeck here inserts vv. 826—835 without authority, and with no sufficient reason. The order has been already disturbed in honour of Augustus, and the mention of Caesar after his successor does not restore it, while the tone in which the civil wars are spoken of is very different from that which celebrates the return of the golden age. With the latter Anchises identifies himself cordially: of the former he speaks with regret, and so naturally mentions it merely as one of the events of Roman history. Wagn. thought the question ‘MASK’ &c. was put by Aeneas, but it is evidently no more than a rhetorical variety in the narrative. Anchises sees Numa in the distance (‘MASK’), and begins to recognize him (‘MASK’). Gossrau well remarks that no worse compliment could have been paid to Augustus than to make Aeneas interrupt the praises of his great descendant by a question about a figure in the distance.

Numa, as the great author of the Roman worship, is naturally represented as a sacrificing priest. ‘MASK MASK’ MASK . This picture of Numa with hoary hair and beard is seen on late coins. Serv. has a story that Numa's hair was hoary from his youth. Rom. gives ‘MASK’

is the reading of the great majority of MSS.: ‘MASK’ however, though very inferior in authority (it is found in one MS. of the 15th century, and in a quotation by Serv. on 1. 1), took possession of the early editions, and was recalled by Burm. and Heyne. ‘MASK’ is much more in Virg.'s manner: comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK MASK’ seems virtually to designate Numa as the second founder of the city, as having been its first great lawgiver. ‘MASK’ then is emphatic, as showing in what sense the city was founded by Numa. Henry well comp. Justin, 2. 7, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

“MASK MASK MASK MASK” 11. 47. With ‘MASK MASK MASK’ comp. MASK , “MASK MASK MASK MASK” For ‘MASK’ Ribbeck restores ‘MASK MASK’ the reading according to Pier. of some old copies, supported by ‘MASK’ the first reading of Med. and ‘MASK’ Rom. (‘MASK’ from ‘MASK’): Pal. however has ‘MASK MASK’ and the archaism is not one which Virg. can be proved to have affected, though there are a few passages, where, as here, it is found MASK some MSS.

like “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ joined with ‘MASK’ as in 1. 722., 7. 693, where the expression resembles this, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” We might have expected “MASK” or “MASK” here: but the poet seems to have chosen a word which would especially suit ‘MASK MASK’ at the same time that it might remind a reader of the expression “MASK MASK MASK” and so prepare him for “MASK MASK”

Henry remarks the effective manner MASK which ‘MASK’ is brought late into the sentence, immediately before ‘MASK MASK’ For ‘MASK MASK MASK’ Rom. has ‘MASK MASK MASK’ a strange aberration, not accounted for by Ribbeck's supposition that the transcriber thought of “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Elegy to Messala, v. 3.

The character here given to MASK does not agree with the accounts of the historians, such as Livy and Dionysius: Pomponius Sabinus however has preserved a notice which says that MASK valued himself on his birth as Numa's grandson, and courted the favour of the people in the hopes of destroying Tullus.

even in this lower world, the ruling passion being strong even before birth. Various attempts have been made to alter this line so as to understand it of Servius Tullius , “MASK MASK MASK” but Pomponius is doubtless right in supposing him to be included in “MASK MASK MASK” One inferior and interpolated MS. gives ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ is found in Cic., Livy, and Hor. (see Freund): Cicero also has “MASK MASK” Cluent. 47. The voice of the people is naturally spoken of as breath, as readers of Shakspere's Julius Caesar will remember, and this makes the metaphor of a favouring gale at sea more obvious.

Anchises asks if he shall point out to Aeneas the later kings and Brutus. Virg. has not chosen to call Tarquin ‘MASK MASK’ but has transferred the epithet to Brutus, the majestic and inflexible founder of Roman liberty, doubtless intentionally, so that there is no ground to suspect the text with Peerlkamp and Ribbeck.
seems to be used like “MASK MASK MASK MASK” So at the beginning of Livy, Book 2, Brutus is made to say “MASK MASK MASK MASK”
“MASK MASK” MASK , MASK .
may either mean sudden and unexpected (comp. 2. 228., 8. 637), or renewed, because the object of the sons of Brutus was to bring back the Tarquins.
like “MASK MASK MASK” 8. 495.

Macrob. Sat. 4. 6 and Augustine De Civitate Dei 3. 16 connect ‘MASK’ &c. with ‘MASK MASK’ the latter paraphrasing the line “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Heyne's interpretation however is evidently the right one, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” He remarks that probably Brutus' action was condemned by some in Virg.'s time, a very possible supposition, as the exploit of the younger Brutus would naturally provoke animadversion on the character of his supposed ancestor. For the use of ‘MASK’ where praise is not intended, comp. 7. 78, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ the reading of some MSS., was the common one before Heins. (see on 4. 596), and ‘MASK MASK’ the reading of one MS., is supported by Macrob. Voss, with some ingenuity but little probability, understood ‘MASK’ of the younger generation in Brutus' own day.

At first sight there may seem some incongruity between Brutus' indifference to the opinion of posterity and his unmeasured thirst of fame: but the meaning apparently is that he will risk being called cruel by posterity, so long as he forces them to acknowledge that he is great. “MASK MASK MASK” 5. 138.

The Drusi are doubtless introduced out of compliment to Livia, as Heyne remarks, though Livius the conqueror of Hasdrubal was sufficiently remarkable on his own account. ‘MASK MASK’ refers of course to Torquatus beheading his son. Torquatus is doubtless represented with the axe, as Camillus with the recovered standards.
captured by the Gauls at the battle of the Allia, and recovered by Camillus when he conquered the enemy, according to the Roman account, on their leaving Rome .

“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 5. 562. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ they are represented as armed MASK the same manner, partly to show their natural concord, as mentioned MASK the next line, partly to point out that the war which they are hereafter to wage is a civil war (Cerda comp. MASK , “MASK MASK”). There may also be a notion of their equality as great generals. ‘MASK MASK’ the antique third conjugation, found MASK MASK &c. So “MASK” 8. 677.

Med., Gud., Pal. a m. s., ‘MASK’ Rom., Pal. a m. p. Either might stand, the sense being virtually the same, as ‘MASK’ would mean ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ See also on 4. 336. On the whole I have preferred ‘MASK’ with Wagn. and subsequent editors, as Virg. is likely to have used his tenses so as to bring out the distinction between the present and the immediate future on the one hand, and the ultimate future (‘MASK’) on the other. With ‘MASK MASK’ Gossrau comp. Hor. 1 Od. 4. 16, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Here ‘MASK’ = ‘MASK MASK’ restrain from emerging into the upper world. Serv. refers the words to the time before Caesar and Pompey were famous, reading ‘MASK’ ‘MASK’ is used loosely, as Wagn. remarks, as we have been told v. 641 that the Elysian fields have a sun of their own.
“MASK MASK” 1. 541. ‘MASK MASK’ 7. 771, and several times in Lucr. Here it is contrasted with ‘MASK MASK’ Some inferior MSS. give ‘MASK MASK’ which Wakef. adopts.

“‘ MASK MASK : ’MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. ‘MASK’ is of course Caesar, whose daughter Julia Pompey married. ‘MASK MASK’ the port of Hercules Monoecus , the modern Monaco, where was a promontory and a temple, whence ‘MASK MASK’ as in 3. 531. There is a difficulty in this specification of the place, as this is not otherwise known to have been the way by which Caesar entered Italy. The most natural supposition seems to be that Virg. wrote as a poet, not as an historian.
‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ referring to the composition of Pompey's forces.

Probably from Il. 7. 279, MASK , MASK MASK , MASK , MASK MASK , where Idaeus is addressing Ajax and Hector. ‘MASK’ with reference to the difference in age between them and Anchises. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ a variety for “MASK MASK MASK” (“MASK MASK” 9. 201). Perhaps we may say that the inversion calls more attention to the gentleness of their natures as a positive quality from which war is made to recoil: but we must not refine needlessly.

The conquerors of Greece are now introduced, that being naturally one of the chief achievements of Rome in the eye of a Trojan. Comp. 1. 283 foll. The victor of Corinth is of course L. Mummius (Dict. Biog.), who had the surname of Achaicus. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” MASK . The use of the past participle is not strictly consistent with the order of time, the expression being in fact a mixture of ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ and ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ The triumph of Mummius was peculiarly famous for the splendour of the booty carried in procession. Horace uses it as a synonym for a stage pageant, 2 Ep. 1. 193, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
With the expression ‘MASK MASK MASK’ comp. MASK .

This second ‘MASK’ has been variously identified. Hyginus, quoted by Gell. 10. 16, assumed that Mummius was still intended, and accused Virg. of confounding two distinct events, Mummius' campaign and the war with Pyrrhus, whom he supposes to be intended by ‘MASK MASK’ his conclusion being that Virg. would doubtless have altered the passage had he lived, and that if v. 839 were excluded, all would be right. Gossrau still pleads for Mummius, contending with considerable ingenuity that Anchises in the preceding couplet has expressed himself in Roman imagery, and now repeats his meaning in words more intelligible to Aeneas, who knew nothing of Corinth or the Capitol, and would only conceive of the conquest of Greece as a victory over the descendants of Achilles or the destruction of the empire of Agamemnon. But Anchises is not elsewhere so considerate to his son's ignorance, referring as he does throughout to Roman exploits in Roman language: nor is it credible that ‘MASK MASK’ should have been used not for an individual but for the descendants of Achilles generally. The argument that if ‘MASK’ &c. v. 840 be referred to any one but Mummius, Virg. virtually denies that Mummius did execute this revenge, needs no refutation. So far as the language is concerned, it would certainly seem that the second ‘MASK’ denotes a different person from the first. The most probable candidate for this honour appears to be L. Aemilius Paullus , the conqueror of Macedon, v. 839 being understood of his victory over Perseus, who is said by Prop. 5. 11. 39, Sil. 15. 291 (speaking of his father Philip) to have been a descendant of Achilles; though there still remains a difficulty, as Paullus was not the destroyer of MASK and Mycenae. We must suppose then that Virg. has written loosely, perhaps conceiving that the indefinite ‘MASK MASK MASK’ exempted him from the need of strict accuracy. Heyne suggests that ‘MASK MASK’ may refer to Paullus' cruel destruction of the Epirots, supposed to be represented by their ancestor Pyrrhus (agreeably to the well-known line of Ennius, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Ann. 6. fr. 7): but this is far less likely. Others have suggested that the person meant by ‘MASK’ may be Q. Caecilius Metellus, surnamed Macedonicus , who conquered the pseudo-Philip, and began the war with the Achaeans which Mummius finished.
is transferred in a modified sense to ‘MASK MASK’

refers to the sacrilege of Ajax (1. 41. &c.), and probably to the seizure of the Palladium also. Comp. Eur. Tro. 69, 85, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK . . . . MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK .

the censor. ‘MASK MASK’ A. Cornelius Cossus , the winner of the ‘MASK MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ is used in its strict participial sense, ‘MASK MASK MASK’ So Cic. Ep. 3. 8, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

probably refers not only to the two brothers, but to their ancestor who distinguished himself in the second Punic war. ‘MASK MASK’ is explained by Serv. of the two Scipios who fell in Spain, an interpretation supported, as Cerda remarks, by Cic. pro Balbo 15, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though there ‘MASK’ would seem a more probable reading (comp. 11. 349, “MASK MASK MASK MASK”). Cerda himself however and the later commentators have rightly seen that the reference must be to the elder and younger Africanus, who alone could be called ‘MASK MASK MASK’ The elder Africanus is evidently referred to by MASK , whom Virg. imitated,— “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

We may wonder that Virg. did not rather think of Cincinnatus, who seems to have been the more famous of these heroes of the plough. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK” 12. 520,—words immediately following the use of ‘MASK’ cited in the last note, and noticeable as showing how Virg. in reproducing himself or others is apt to take words from the same context, even when they have no special connexion. See on 1. 375, &c. For the rhyme comp. 4. 189, 190, 256, 257.

Alluding to the numbers and exploits of the MASK (Dict. B. ‘MASK’), which tire the narrator who tries to count them. Comp. Johnson's celebrated line, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Rom. has “MASK MASK MASK” which, as Pierius remarked, might be understood as an address to the MASK, supposed to be seen by Anchises in the act of undertaking their ill-omened expedition to the Cremera. ‘MASK MASK’ Virg. follows the story which made Q. Fabius surnamed Cunctator , the dictator in the second Punic war, the first to bear the name MASK. Others said that it was originally given to his great-grandfather, the general in the Samnite war. See Dict. B. ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

Taken almost verbally from the well-known lines of Ennius A. 9. fr. 8, preserved by Cic. Off. 1. 24, and others: “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Rom. and one or two others have ‘MASK MASK’ which has been recommended on the ground that Anchises is using throughout the predictive future. But the present is much more forcible, making it an attribute of Fabius that he saved the state by delay, and being in fact a translation of his name ‘MASK MASK’

“MASK MASK MASK MASK” remarks Serv. of this celebrated passage. The concessive fut., as Forb. calls it, is used elsewhere, as in Hor. 1 Od. 7. 1, 3 Od. 23. 13, instead of the more usual subj. Here it is more appropriate, as being the language of prophecy. ‘MASK’ of bronze statues Hor. 2 Ep. 1. 240. “MASK MASK” MASK . The reference throughout is to the Greeks, the natural rivals of Rome . ‘MASK’ expresses grace and delicacy, with some reference perhaps, as Forb. thinks, to giving the soft appearance of flesh.

4. 12. Here it has almost the force of ‘MASK MASK’ which was conjectured by Markland, and is the first reading of Pal. ‘MASK MASK’ occurs 2. 704., 12. 818, but not quite in this sense. ‘MASK MASK’ is not ironical, as Burm. thinks, but means ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ i. e., I am quite ready to admit it. So Hor. 2 Ep. 1. 66 foll., “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” unless there we are to read ‘MASK’ with Bentley from the Queen's Coll. MS. ‘MASK’ is properly used of producing forms by extension, as in metal (7. 634), wax (Pers. 5. 40., Juv. 7. 237), or clay (“MASK MASK MASK MASK” Vitruv. 2. 3). Hence it is transferred to marble, probably with the accessory notion of the form growing and spreading over the material under the sculptor's hand. ‘MASK MASK’ is a material abl., as in 4. 457, MASK , but it also stands in connexion with ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” in 7. 634 just cited.

has perplexed commentators and critics, from Cerda to De Quincey (Works, vol. 14, p. 67, first Eng. ed.), who cannot understand why Virg. should have conceded to Greece superiority in oratory, and in some cases even insinuate that he must have been jealous of the fame of Cicero. But Virg.'s concession is made in a liberal and magnificent spirit, in order that the real fame of his countrymen as warriors and statesmen may appear greater: and it is not likely that he thought of the number of individual reputations that the position thus assumed compelled him to sacrifice. In the general proposition, that the real greatness of Rome lay in acts of war and policy, all moderns will agree with him: and whether he has specified oratory among the pursuits in which other nations are allowed to excel or has left it to be inferred is a matter of little consequence. He would doubtless have specified poetry with equal or greater readiness, if he had not felt that the very mention of it would have implied a latent egotism. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK” MASK , though there the addition of “MASK MASK” softens the expression. Henry understands the words specifically of the heavenly circles.
“MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK . ‘MASK MASK MASK’ seems to mean, will fix, or predict, the risings of the stars.

‘MASK MASK’ is a Lucretian expression, as Forb. remarks. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” MASK . We have had “MASK MASK” above, 1. 230. ‘MASK MASK’ an address to the nation, as in Hor. 3 Od. 6. 2. ‘MASK’ is a mode of conveying an injunction of which Horace is fond, 2 Od. 3. 1, 3 Od. 29. 32, Epod. 10. 4, 1 Ep. 8. 16. ‘MASK MASK’ subject nations. Comp. generally 1. 263, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

or ‘MASK’ is a common expression for pursuits or appliances of any kind: here however there is probably a reference to its stricter sense. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’—these shall stand to you in the place of sculpture, eloquence, and astronomy. Pal. a m. pr. and three inferior MSS. have ‘MASK MASK’ and so Ribbeck: but though it is not unlikely that copyists should have been puzzled by the older form of the nom. fem. plural, as they doubtless were in MASK , where I would now read “MASK MASK MASK MASK” the external authority for the change is hardly sufficient. ‘MASK’ &c. are in apposition with ‘MASK MASK’ not, as some have taken them, dependent on ‘MASK’ ‘MASK MASK MASK’ being regarded as parenthetical. For ‘MASK’ all the best MSS. (Pal. and Gud. as well as Med. and Rom., if Ribbeck's silence is to be trusted) appear to give ‘MASK MASK’ which Ribbeck adopts. Admitting the difficulty of the question, I have on the whole preferred to abide by the more usual reading, which is found in Serv., “MASK MASK MASK” and supported by Livy 9. 14, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” quoted by Wagn. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ however means more than “MASK MASK MASK MASK” being equivalent, as Wagn. interprets it, to “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Henry. Comp. 8. 316, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” and see on 1. 264, MASK . This might be the sense with ‘MASK MASK’ though I am not sure that it would be Virgilian to understand ‘MASK’ as i. q. “MASK MASK MASK” Perhaps we might say that peace is curbed by institutions which prevent it from degenerating into luxury and licence, or that it is restrained by being made lasting. No parallel however occurs to me in Virg. or any other author, which would clear up the expression. ‘MASK’ on the other hand is further confirmed by “MASK MASK MASK” 12. 112, which is parallel in expression (‘MASK’ and ‘MASK’ being similar) rather than in sense.

Carm. Saec. 51 (of Augustus), “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” though there ‘MASK’ is the more probable reading.

seems to mean that Aeneas and the Sibyl are already penetrated by the grandeur of the vision and the prophecy, and so indicates, as has been remarked to me, Virg.'s own sense of the greatness of the elevation attained in the preceding passage.
MASK is of course singled out for the sake of his namesake and descendant, soon to be mentioned. ‘MASK MASK MASK’ won from the general of the Insubrian Gauls Viridomarus.

occurs twice in Enn., Ann. fr. inc. 10, 41. “MASK MASK MASK” 9. 397. ‘MASK’ is here used in its technical sense of a Gallic war, for which see the celebrated passage Cic. 8 Phil. 1.

MASK , opposed to the shaking of the ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” is quoted from an edict of Augustus by Suet. Aug. 28. Comp. also the phrase “MASK MASK MASK MASK” common in Livy (3. 9, 16, 20 &c.). So the epithet ‘MASK MASK’ which was used not only of Jupiter as the stayer of flight (Livy 1. 12, comp. by Forb.), but of Jupiter and other gods as supporters of Rome. “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Vell. 2. 131. It is not altogether easy to say whether ‘MASK’ should go with ‘MASK’ or with ‘MASK MASK’ The combat in which Marcellus gained the ‘MASK MASK’ was a combat of cavalry (Dict. B. ‘MASK’): and though ‘MASK MASK’ as Wagn. remarks, goes more naturally with ‘MASK’ than ‘MASK MASK’ it does not seem certain that Marcellus' advantages against the Carthaginians had any special connexion with cavalry. Gossrau however refers to Sil. 12. 178 foll., who speaks as if the sally from Nola, memorable as the first success obtained against Hannibal, were chiefly one of cavalry: but this does not specially appear in the account in Livy 23. 16. If we take ‘MASK’ with ‘MASK MASK’ we shall do right to connect them closely, with Henry, ‘MASK MASK’ MASK . Rom. has ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK MASK’ the Insubrian Gauls had sued for peace, but their overtures were rejected: upon which they combined with another tribe, the Gaesatae, took the field in great force, and laid siege to Clastidium, where the battle happened.

There is a difficulty about ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ as the story was that Romulus, the author of the custom, dedicated the first ‘MASK MASK’ to Jupiter Feretrius. Serv. explains it by referring to a law of Numa's, which is said to have enjoined that on the first winning of ‘MASK MASK’ they should be offered to Jupiter Feretrius, as had been already done by Romulus; on the second to Mars, which was done by Cossus; on the third to Quirinus. Livy however, 3. 20, distinctly speaks of the ‘MASK MASK’ of Cossus as dedicated to Jupiter Feretrius: and Prop. 5. 10. 45 talks of “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Serv. proposes as an alternative to separate ‘MASK’ from ‘MASK MASK’ taking ‘MASK’ of Jupiter, and connecting ‘MASK MASK MASK’ formerly won by Romulus, which is sufficiently unlikely. For ‘MASK’ Rom. has ‘MASK MASK’
with Marcellus.

Heyne comp. Eur. Phoen. 148, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , where Antigone is asking the names of the invading generals, and commenting on them as she sees them, and the imitation of Virg. in Sil. 13. 782 (speaking of the shade of Homer) “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Henry has a note on ‘MASK’ in which he attempts to prove that the word never means any thing but ‘MASK’ He appears to be right in regarding it as to some extent parallel with ‘MASK MASK’ comparing Ammian. 15. 1, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” with Macrob. Somn. Scip. 1. 16, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” just as Gell. 2. 6 virtually explains it by ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” But the same word may have many shades of meaning, as might be shown in the case of ‘MASK’ itself, though all of course flow from a single notion. In the case of ‘MASK’ it seems probable from the appearance of the word that the original notion was something like ‘MASK’ This will explain all the instances where it is used with the gen. in the sense of resemblance (comp. “MASK MASK”). There seems no doubt that in some passages (e.g. Suet. Caes. 61, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”) it means a representation, but it does not appear that there is any trace of this earlier than Livy, so that we need not assume it to be the original notion of the word, at the same time that we can quite account for it as a meaning that may have been attached to it in subsequent usage. Here then it might possibly be taken with Serv. &c. in the sense of ‘MASK MASK’ It is to be observed however that Virg. elsewhere uses the word in connexion with size (2. 15., 3. 637., 7. 707), so that I would rather suppose the meaning to be, with Heyne, ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’ which is besides suggested by the context. ‘MASK’ is evidently meant to distinguish him from those about him, so that we should expect some attribute of distinction to be predicated of him, not simple similarity to his ancestor. Heyne edited ‘MASK MASK MASK’ the reading before Heins., but all the best MSS. omit the verb subst.

the shades of the heroes of Latium or Lavinium, who are supposed either to look forward to the future glory of one who is now a shade along with them, or to be conscious while he is on earth and they themselves in darkness. The future ‘MASK’ seems in favour of the latter. We may suppose them to inquire about him from new comers, as Agamemnon in Od. 11 inquires about Orestes. Virg. has adroitly varied his expression, so as to make us think in this sentence of the ancestors of the Romans, Trojan or Latin, in the next of Rome itself.

with ‘MASK MASK’ not, as Forb., following Ruhkopf, thinks, with ‘MASK MASK’ W. Ribbeck cites Auson. Cupido Crucifixus v. 1, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” It seems to be a general expression for the place of the dead, “MASK MASK MASK” ‘MASK’ probably including the notion of mist as well as of air. Elsewhere Elysium has aether and light, as the rest of the infernal regions have darkness: here a neutral word is chosen. Stat. Silv. 5. 3. 286 seems to have taken it exclusively of the Elysian fields, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
“MASK MASK MASK” v. 565 above.

Med. has ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ evidently from 4. 221, an error which takes away from its authority in such passages as v. 806 (see note there). ‘MASK MASK’ in the future. He was to be inspired with a passion for the long line of historic glories which depended on his valour in Italy. Comp. vv. 718, 806., 4. 232.

is introduced for the sake of the juxtaposition with ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ from this time, v. 756. Here and in the next two lines Virg. almost repeats 3. 458, 459, the difference being that there the Sibyl is to tell Aeneas what here he learns from Anchises. See note there.
of the single Laurentian nation, perhaps with reference to the many nations of Italy, 3. 458, &c. For the Laurentes see 7. 63. “MASK MASK” 12. 137.

“MASK MASK MASK MASK” 7. 607. The gates of Sleep are from Hom.'s gates of dreams, which are similarly described Od. 19. 562 foll. Much ingenuity has been expended in searching for a symbolical meaning in them. Heyne seems right in saying that Virg. wanted to dismiss Aeneas from the shades by some other way than that by which he had entered, and that Hom.'s gates fortunately occurred to him. See Introduction to this Book. Turnebus and others wanted to understand ‘MASK’ as ‘MASK MASK’ but ‘MASK’ would not be the same as ‘MASK MASK’ Here, as elsewhere (e. g. v. 702 above), Virg. evidently substitutes sleep for dreams, on account of the metrical unmanageableness of ‘MASK MASK’ ‘MASK’ might conceivably be understood as = ‘MASK’ or ‘MASK MASK MASK’ but it is simpler to understand it ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK’ Virg. speaking doubtfully of things that mortals have no direct means of knowing. ‘MASK MASK’ like “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” Hor. 2 Od. 19. 26.

real spirits which appear in sleep. How far the existence of such apparitions agrees with Virg.'s philosophy may be doubted: see on 4. 353., 5. 722. In Hom. the distinction is between truthful and lying dreams; and perhaps Virg. means to include this as well. See on v. 896.
seems = “MASK MASK MASK” like “MASK MASK MASK” “MASK MASK MASK” &c., though ‘MASK MASK’ would naturally go together, like “MASK MASK MASK” 5. 267. ‘MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK’

Beautiful as the ivory gate is, the apparitions that pass through it are false. For the power of the shades to send dreams comp. Clytaemnestra's dream, which was sent by Agamemnon, MASK “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”. Wagn. Comp. Tibull. 2. 6. 37, “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” which Virg. may have thought of, if it was published before his death. ‘MASK’ probably refers both to the quality of the apparition and to the message that it brings. Both may be illustrated from the dreams of Hom.: in Od. 4. 796 the apparition of Iphthime is made by Athene: in Il. 2. 6 foll. the Dream-god is sent to give false counsel. There is apparently a similar combination of the two notions in Hor. 3 Od. 27. 40 foll., “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”

It is difficult to choose between ‘MASK’ (fragm. Vat., Rom., Gud. a m. p., and probably Pal.) and ‘MASK’ (Med.). The former is the more simple, the latter the more artificial. On the whole I have followed Ribbeck in preferring ‘MASK MASK’ as ‘MASK MASK MASK’ loses force by being thrown into the protasis, and even Wagn. does not propose to treat it as forming the apodosis, though in 12. 81 he makes ‘MASK’ the apodosis to ‘MASK MASK’ “MASK MASK MASK” v. 752 above.
“MASK MASK” 9. 310. ‘MASK’ is explained by what precedes, vv. 890 foll. Anchises continues his instructions till they part at the gate.

“MASK MASK” 12. 368. So MASK MASK . “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK” 8. 546. The sense is from Od. 11. 636, MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK , of Ulysses leaving the shades.

sailing straight along the shore, like “MASK MASK” 8. 57. He follows the line of coast, and it takes him to Caieta. Heyne read ‘MASK’ from three or four inferior MSS., to avoid the repetition of ‘MASK’ in the same part of the next verse: but though the repetition is certainly awkward, it seems better to suppose a slight carelessness on Virg.'s part than to question the reading of all the great MSS. Ribbeck cuts the knot by bracketing v. 901, which is repeated from 3. 277. Perhaps we may say that Virg. inserted it as a piece of his own epic common-place, whether as a stop-gap or not, and that this accounts for the repetition of ‘MASK MASK’ The mention of Caieta has been objected to, as inconsistent with the opening of the next Book, where it is said that the death of Caieta, Aeneas ' nurse, was the occasion of the name. But this is natural and Virgilian enough; and we can hardly wish that the poet had rivalled the accuracy of Ovid, who in his brief narrative of Aeneas' adventures (M. 14. 157) says “MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK MASK”
